<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<h1>AGREEMENT ON THE EUROPEAN<br>ECONOMIC AREA</h1>
<p>THE EUROPEAN ECONOMIC COMMUNITY,</p>
<p>THE EUROPEAN COAL AND STEEL COMMUNITY,</p>
<p>THE KINGDOM OF BELGIUM,</p>
<p>THE KINGDOM OF DENMARK,</p>
<p>THE FEDERAL REPUBLIC OF GERMANY,</p>
<p>THE HELLENIC REPUBLIC,</p>
<p>THE KINGDOM OF SPAIN,</p>
<p>THE FRENCH REPUBLIC,</p>
<p>IRELAND,</p>
<p>THE ITALIAN REPUBLIC,</p>
<p>THE GRAND DUCHY OF LUXEMBOURG,</p>
<p>THE KINGDOM OF THE NETHERLANDS,</p>
<p>THE PORTUGUESE REPUBLIC,</p>
<p>THE UNITED KINGDOM OF GREAT BRITAIN AND NORTHERN<br>IRELAND,</p>
<p>AND</p>
<p>THE REPUBLIC OF AUSTRIA,</p>
<p>THE REPUBLIC OF FINLAND,</p>
<p>THE REPUBLIC OF ICELAND,</p>
<p>THE PRINCIPALITY OF LIECHTENSTEIN,</p>
<p>THE KINGDOM OF NORWAY,</p>
<p>THE KINGDOM OF SWEDEN,</p>
<p>THE SWISS CONFEDERATION</p>
<p>hereinafter referred to as the CONTRACTING PARTIES;</p>
<p>CONVINCED of the contribution that a European Economic Area will<br>bring to the construction of a Europé based on peace, democracy and human<br>rights;</p>
<p>REAFFIRMING the high priority attached to the privileged relationship<br>between the European Community, its Member States and the EFTA States,<br>which is based on proximity, long-standing common values and European<br>identity;</p>
<p>DETERMINED to contribute, on the basis of market economy, to world-<br>wide trade liberalization and cooperation, in particular in accordance with<br>the provisions of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and the Con-<br>vention on the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development;</p>
<p>CONSIDERING the objective of establishing a dynamic and homogeneous<br>European Economic Area, based on common rules and equal conditions of<br>competition and providing for the adequate means of enforcement including<br>at the judicial level, and achieved on the basis of equality and reciprocity and<br>of an overall balance of benefits, rights and obligations for the Contracting<br>Parties;</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>DETERMINED to provide for the fullest possible realization of the free<br>movement of goods, persons, services and Capital within the whole Euro-<br>pean Economic Area, as well as for strengthened and broadened coopera-<br>tion in flanking and horizontal policies;</p>
<p>AIMING to promote a harmonious development of the European Economic<br>Area and convinced of the need to contribute through the application of this<br>Agreement to the reduction of economic and social regional disparities;</p>
<p>DESIROUS of contributing to the strengthening of the cooperation between<br>the members of the European Parliament and of the Parliaments of the<br>EFTA States, as well as between the social partners in the European Com-<br>munity and in the EFTA States;</p>
<p>CONVINCED of the important role that individuals will play in the Euro-<br>pean Economic Area through the exercise of the rights conferred on them<br>by this Agreement and through the judicial defence of these rights;</p>
<p>DETERMINED to preserve, protect and improve the quality of the envi-<br>ronment and to ensure a prudent and rational utilization of natural resources<br>on the basis, in particular, of the principle of sustainable development, as<br>well as the principle that precautionary and preventive action should be ta-<br>ken;</p>
<p>DETERMINED to take, in the further development of rules, a high level of<br>protection concerning health, safety and the environment as a basis;</p>
<p>NOTING the importance of the development of the social dimension, inclu-<br>ding equal treatment of men and women, in the European Economic Area<br>and wishing to ensure economic and social progress and to promote condi-<br>tions for full employment, an improved standard of living and improved wor-<br>king conditions within the European Economic Area;</p>
<p>DETERMINED to promote the interests of consumers and to strengthen<br>their position in the market place, aiming at a high level of consumer protec-<br>tion;</p>
<p>ATTACHED to the common objectives of strengthening the scientific and<br>technological basis of European industry and of encouraging it to become<br>more competitive at the international level;</p>
<p>CONSIDERING that the conclusion of this Agreement shall not prejudge<br>in any way the possibility of any EFTA State to accede to the European Com-<br>munities;</p>
<p>WHEREAS, in full deference to the independence of the courts, the objec-<br>tive of the Contracting Parties is to arrive at, and maintain, a uniform interp-<br>retation and application of this Agreement and those provisions of Commu-<br>nity legislation which are substantially reproduced in this Agreement and to<br>arrive at an equal treatment of individuals and economic operators as re-<br>gards the four freedoms and the conditions of competition;</p>
<p>WHEREAS this Agreement does not restrict the decision-making auto-<br></p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>nomy or the treaty-making power of the Contracting Parties, subject to the<br>provisions of this Agreement and the limitations set by public international<br>law;</p>
<p>HAVE DECIDED to conclude the following Agreement:</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<h1>PART I OBJECTIVES AND PRINCIPLES</h1>
<p>Article 1</p>
<p>1. The aim of this Agreement of association is to promote a continuous and<br>balanced strengthening of trade and economic relations between the Cont-<br>racting Parties with equal conditions of competition, and the respect of the<br>same rules, with a view to creating a homogeneous European Economic<br>Area, hereinafter referred to as the EEA.</p>
<p>2. In order to attain the objectives set out in paragraph 1, the association<br>shall entail, in accordance with the provisions of this Agreement:</p>
<p>(a) the free movement of goods;</p>
<p>(b) the free movement of persons;</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;the free movement of services;</p>
<p>(d) the free movement of Capital;</p>
<p>(e) &nbsp;the setting up of a system ensuring that competition is not distorted<br>and that the rules thereon are equally respected; as well as</p>
<p>(f) &nbsp;closer cooperation in other fields, such as research and develop-<br>ment, the environment, education and social policy.</p>
<p>Article 2</p>
<p>For the purposes of this Agreement:</p>
<p>(a) the term “Agreement” means the main Agreement, its Protocols<br>and Annexes as well as the acts referred to therein;</p>
<p>(b) the term “EFTA States” means the Contracting Parties, which are<br>members of the European Free Trade Association;</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;the term “Contracting Parties” means, concerning the Community<br>and the EC Member States, the Community and the EC Member<br>States, or the Community, or the EC Member States. The meaning<br>to be attributed to this expression in each case is to be deduced from<br>the relevant provisions of this Agreement and from the respective<br>competences of the Community and the EC Member States as they<br>follow from the Treaty establishing the European Economic Com-<br>munity and the Treaty establishing the European Coal and Steel<br>Community.</p>
<p>Article 3</p>
<p>The Contracting Parties shall take all appropriate measures, whether general<br>or particular, to ensure fulfilment of the obligations arising out of this Agree-<br>ment.</p>
<p>They shall abstain from any measure which could jeopardize the attain-<br>ment of the objectives of this Agreement.</p>
<p>Moreover, they shall facilitate cooperation within the framework of this<br>Agreement.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>Article 4</p>
<p>Within the scope of application of this Agreement, and without prejudice to<br>any special provisions contained therein, any discrimination on grounds of<br>nationality shall be prohibited.</p>
<p>Article 5</p>
<p>A Contracting Party may at any time raise a matter of concern at the level of<br>the EEA Joint Committee or the EEA Council according to the modalities<br>laid down in Artides 92 (2) and 89 (2), respectively.</p>
<p>Article 6</p>
<p>Without prejudice to future developments of case law, the provisions of this<br>Agreement, in so far as they are identical in substance to corresponding rules<br>of the Treaty establishing the European Economic Community and the<br>Treaty establishing the European Coal and Steel Community and to acts ad-<br>opted in application of these two Treaties, shall in their implementation and<br>application, be interpreted in conformity with the relevant rulings of the<br>Court of Justice of the European Communities given prior to the date of sig-<br>nature of this Agreement.</p>
<p>Article 7</p>
<p>Acts referred to or contained in the Annexes to this Agreement or in deci-<br>sions of the EEA Joint Committee shall be binding upon the Contracting<br>Parties and be, or be made, part of their internal legal order as follows:</p>
<p>(a) an act corresponding to an EEC regulation shall as such be made<br>part of the internal legal order of the Contracting Parties;</p>
<p>(b) an act corresponding to an EEC directive shall leave to the authori-<br>ties of the Contracting Parties the choice of form and method of im-<br>plementation.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<h1>PART II FREE MOVEMENT OF GOODS</h1>
<h2>CHAPTER 1 BASIC PRINCIPLES</h2>
<p>Article 8</p>
<p>1. Free movement of goods between the Contracting Parties shall be establis-<br>hed in conformity with the provisions of this Agreement.</p>
<p>2. Unless otherwise specified, Articles 10 to 15, 19, 20 and 25 to 27 shall<br>apply only to products originating in the Contracting Parties.</p>
<p>3. Unless otherwise specified, the provisions of this Agreement shall apply<br>only to:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;products falling within Chapters 25 to 97 of the Harmonized Com-<br>modity Description and Coding System, excluding the products lis-<br>ted in Protocol 2;</p>
<p>(b) products specified in Protocol 3, subject to the specific arrangements<br>set out in that Protocol.</p>
<p>Article 9</p>
<p>1. The rules of origin are set out in Protocol 4. They are without prejudice<br>to any international obligations which have been, or may be, subscribed to<br>by the Contracting Parties under the General Agreement on Tariffs and<br>Trade.</p>
<p>2. With a view to developing the results achieved in this Agreement, the<br>Contracting Parties will continue their efforts in order further to improve and<br>simplify all aspects of rules of origin and to increase cooperation in customs<br>matters.</p>
<p>3. A first review will take place before the end of 1993. Subsequent reviews<br>shall take place at two-yearly intervals. On the basis of these reviews, the<br>Contracting Parties undertake to decide on the appropriate measures to be<br>included in this Agreement.</p>
<p>Article 10</p>
<p>Customs duties on imports and exports, and any charges having equivalent<br>effect, shall be prohibited between the Contracting Parties. Without preju-<br>dice to the arrangements set out in Protocol 5, this shall also apply to customs<br>duties of a fiscal nature.</p>
<p>Article 11</p>
<p>Quantitative restrictions on imports and all measures having equivalent ef-<br>fect shall be prohibited between the Contracting Parties.</p>
<p>Article 12</p>
<p>Quantitative restrictions on exports and all measures having equivalent ef-<br>fect shall be prohibited between the Contracting Parties.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>Article 13</p>
<p>The provisions of Artides 11 and 12 shall not preclude prohibitions or re-<br>strictions on imports, exports or goods in transit justified on grounds of pu-<br>blic morality, public policy or public security; the protection of health and<br>life of humans, animals or plants; the protection of national treasures posses-<br>sing artistic, historic or archaeological value; or the protection of industrial<br>and commercial property. Such prohibitions or restrictions shall not, howe-<br>ver, constitute a means of arbitrary discrimination or a disguised restriction<br>on trade between the Contracting Parties.</p>
<p>Article 14</p>
<p>No Contracting Party shall impose, directly or indirectly, on the products of<br>other Contracting Parties any internal taxation of any kind in excess of that<br>imposed directly or indirectly on similar domestic products.</p>
<p>Furthermore, no Contracting Party shall impose on the products of other<br>Contracting Parties any internal taxation of such a nature as to afford indi-<br>rect protection to other products.</p>
<p>Article 15</p>
<p>Where products are exported to the territory of any Contracting Party, any<br>repayment of internal taxation shall not exceed the internal taxation impo-<br>sed on them whether directly or indirectly.</p>
<p>Article 16</p>
<p>1. The Contracting Parties shall ensure that any State monopoly of a com-<br>mercial character be adjusted so that no discrimination regarding the condi-<br>tions under which goods are procured and marketed will exist between natio-<br>nals of EC Member States and EFTA States.</p>
<p>2. The provisions of this Article shall apply to any body through which the<br>competent authorities of the Contracting Parties, in law or in fact, either di-<br>rectly or indirectly supervise, determine or appreciably influence imports or<br>exports between Contracting Parties. These provisions shall likewise apply<br>to monopolies delegated by the State to others.</p>
<h2>CHAPTER 2 AGRICULTURAL AND FISHERY<br>PRODUCTS</h2>
<p>Article 17</p>
<p>Annex I contains specific provisions and arrangements concerning veteri-<br>nary and phytosanitary matters.</p>
<p>Article 18</p>
<p>Without prejudice to the specific arrangements govermng trade in agricultu-<br>ral products, the Contracting Parties shall ensure that the arrangements pro-</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>vided for in Articles 17 and 23 (a) and (b), as they apply to products other<br>than those covered by Article 8(3), are not compromised by other technical<br>barriers to trade. Article 13 shall apply.</p>
<p>Article 19</p>
<p>1. The Contracting Parties shall examine any difficulties that might arise in<br>their trade in agricultural products and shall endeavour to seek appropriate<br>Solutions.</p>
<p>2. The Contracting Parties undertake to continue their efforts with a view to<br>achieving progressive liberalization of agricultural trade.</p>
<p>3. To this end, the Contracting Parties will carry out, before the end of 1993<br>and subsequently at two-yearly intervals, reviews of the conditions of trade<br>in agricultural products.</p>
<p>4. In the light of the results of these reviews, within the framework of their<br>respective agricultural policies and taking into account the results of the Uru-<br>guay Round, the Contracting Parties will decide, within the framework of<br>this Agreement, on a preferential, bilateral or multilateral, reciprocal and<br>mutually beneficial basis, on further reductions of any type of barriers to<br>trade in the agricultural sector, including those resulting from State monopo-<br>lies of a commercial character in the agricultural field.</p>
<p>Article 20</p>
<p>Provisions and arrangements that apply to fish and other marine products<br>are set out in Protocol 9.</p>
<h2>CHAPTER 3 COOPERATION IN CUSTOMS-<br>RELATED MATTERS AND TRADE FACILITATION</h2>
<p>Article 21</p>
<p>1. In order to facilitate trade between them, the Contracting Parties shall<br>simplify border Controls and formalities. Arrangements for this purpose are<br>set out in Protocol 10.</p>
<p>2. The Contracting Parties shall assist each other in customs matters in order<br>to ensure that customs legislation is correctly applied. Arrangements for this<br>purpose are set out in Protocol 11.</p>
<p>3. The Contracting Parties shall strengthen and broaden cooperation with<br>the aim of simplifying the procedures for trade in goods, in particular in the<br>context of Community programmes, projects and actions aimed at trade faci-<br>litation, in accordance with the rules set out in Part VI.</p>
<p>4. Notwithstanding Article 8(3), this Article shall apply to all products.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>11</p>
<p>Article 22</p>
<p>A Contracting Party which is considering the reduction of the effective level<br>of its duties or charges having equivalent effect applicable to third countries<br>benefiting from most-favoured-nation treatment, or which is considering the<br>suspension of their application, shall, as far as may be practicable, notify the<br>EEA Joint Committee not later than thirty days before such reduction or<br>suspension comes into effect. It shall take note of any representations by ot-<br>her Contracting Parties regarding any distortions which might result theref-<br>rom.</p>
<h2>CHAPTER 4 OTHER RULES RELATING TO THE<br>FREE MOVEMENT OF GOODS</h2>
<p>Article 23</p>
<p>Specific provisions and arrangements are laid down in:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;Protocol 12 and Annex II in relation to technical regulations, stan-<br>dards, testing and certification;</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;Protocol 47 in relation to the abolition of technical barriers to trade<br>in wine;</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;Annex III in relation to product liability.</p>
<p>They shall apply to all products unless otherwise specified.</p>
<p>Article 24</p>
<p>Annex IV contains specific provisions and arrangements concerning energy.</p>
<p>Article 25</p>
<p>Where compliance with the provisions of Artides 10 and 12 leads to:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;re-export towards a third country against which the exporting Cont-<br>racting Party maintains, for the product concerned, quantitative ex-<br>port restrictions, export duties or measures or charges having equi-<br>valent effect; or</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;a serious shortage, or threat thereof, of a product essential to the<br>exporting Contracting Party;</p>
<p>and where the situations referred to above give rise, or are likely to give rise,<br>to major difficulties for the exporting Contracting Party, that Contracting<br>Party may take appropriate measures in accordance with the procedures set<br>out in Article 113.</p>
<p>Article 26</p>
<p>Anti-dumping measures, countervailing duties and measures against illicit<br>commercial practices attributable to third countries shall not be applied in<br>relations between the Contracting Parties, unless otherwise specified in this<br>Agreement.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>12</p>
<h2>CHAPTER 5 CO AL AND STEEL PRODUCTS</h2>
<p>Article 27</p>
<p>Provisions and arrangements concerning coal and Steel products are set out<br>in Protocols 14 and 25.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>13</p>
<h1>PART III FREE MOVEMENT OF PERSONS,<br>SERVICES AND CAPITAL</h1>
<h2>CHAPTER 1 WORKERS AND SELF-EMPLOYED<br>PERSONS</h2>
<p>Article 28</p>
<p>1. Freedom of movement for workers shall be secured among EC Member<br>States and EFTA States.</p>
<p>2. Such freedom of movement shall entail the abolition of any discrimination<br>based on nationality between workers of EC Member States and EFTA Sta-<br>tes as regards employment, remuneration and other conditions of work and<br>employment.</p>
<p>3. It shall entail the right, subject to limitations justified on grounds of public<br>policy, public security or public health:</p>
<p>(a) to accept offers of employment actually made;</p>
<p>(b) to move freely within the territory of EC Member States and EFTA<br>States for this purpose;</p>
<p>(c) to stay in the territory of an EC Member State or an EFTA State<br>for the purpose of employment in accordance with the provisions<br>governing the employment of nationals of that State laid down by<br>law, regulation or administrative action;</p>
<p>(d) to remain in the territory of an EC Member State or an EFTA State<br>after having been employed there.</p>
<p>4. The provisions of this Article shall not apply to employment in the public<br>service.</p>
<p>5. Annex V contains specific provisions on the free movement of workers.</p>
<p>Article 29</p>
<p>In order to provide freedom of movement for workers and self-employed<br>persons, the Contracting Parties shall, in the field of social security, secure,<br>as provided for in Annex VI, for workers and self-employed persons and<br>their dependants, in particular:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;aggregation, for the purpose of acquiring and retaining the right to<br>benefit and of calculating the amount of benefit, of all periods taken<br>into account under the laws of the several countries;</p>
<p>(b) payment of benefits to persons resident in the territories of Contrac-<br>ting Parties.</p>
<p>Article 30</p>
<p>In order to make it easier for persons to take up and pursue activities as wor-<br>kers and self-employed persons, the Contracting Parties shall take the neces-<br>sary measures, as contained in Annex VII, concerning the mutual recogni-<br>tion of diplomas, certificates and other evidence of formal qualifications,<br></p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>14</p>
<p>and the coordination of the provisions laid down by law, regulation or admi-<br>nistrative action in the Contracting Parties concerning the taking up and pur-<br>suit of activities by workers and self-employed persons.</p>
<h2>CHAPTER 2 RIGHT OF ESTABLISHMENT</h2>
<p>Article 31</p>
<p>1. Within the framework of the provisions of this Agreement, there shall be<br>no restrictions on the freedom of establishment of nationals of an EC Mem-<br>ber State or an EFTA State in the territory of any other of these States. This<br>shall also apply to the setting up of agencies, branches or subsidiaries by na-<br>tionals of any EC Member State or EFTA State established in the territory<br>of any of these States.</p>
<p>Freedom of establishment shall include the right to take up and pursue<br>activities as self-employed persons and to set up and manage undertakings,<br>in particular companies or firms within the meaning of Article 34, second<br>paragraph, under the conditions laid down for its own nationals by the law<br>of the country where such establishment is effected, subject to the provisions<br>of Chapter 4.</p>
<p>2. Annexes VIII to XI contain specific provisions on the right of establish-<br>ment.</p>
<p>Article 32</p>
<p>The provisions of this Chapter shall not apply, so far as any given Contrac-<br>ting Party is concerned, to activities which in that Contracting Party are con-<br>nected, even occasionally, with the exercise of official authority.</p>
<p>Article 33</p>
<p>The provisions of this Chapter and measures taken in pursuance thereof shall<br>not prejudice the applicability of provisions laid down by law, regulation or<br>administrative action providing for special treatment for foreign nationals on<br>grounds of public policy, public security or public health.</p>
<p>Article 34</p>
<p>Companies or firms formed in accordance with the law of an EC Member<br>State or an EFTA State and having their registered Office, central admini-<br>stration or principal place of business within the territory of the Contracting<br>Parties shall, for the purposes of this Chapter, be treated in the same way as<br>natural persons who are nationals of EC Member States or EFTA States.</p>
<p>'Companies or firms’ means companies or firms constituted under civil or<br>commercial law, including cooperative societies, and other legal persons go-<br>verned by public or private law, save for those which are non-profit-making.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>15</p>
<p>Article 35</p>
<p>The provisions of Article 30 shall apply to the matters covered by this Chap-<br>ter.</p>
<h2>CHAPTER 3 SERVICES</h2>
<p>Article 36</p>
<p>1. Within the framework of the provisions of this Agreement, there shall be<br>no restrictions on freedom to provide services within the territory of the<br>Contracting Parties in respect of nationals of EC Member States and EFTA<br>States who are established in an EC Member State or an EFTA State other<br>than that of the person for whom the services are intended.</p>
<p>2. Annexes IX to XI contain specific provisions on the freedom to provide<br>services.</p>
<p>Article 37</p>
<p>Services shall be considered to be 'services’ within the meaning of this Agree-<br>ment where they are normally provided for remuneration, in so far as they<br>are not governed by the provisions relating to freedom of movement for<br>goods, Capital and persons.</p>
<p>'Services’ shall in particular include:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;activities of an industrial character;</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;activities of a commercial character;</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;activities of craftsmen;</p>
<p>(d) &nbsp;activities of the professions.</p>
<p>Without prejudice to the provisions of Chapter 2, the person providing a ser-<br>vice may, in order to do so, temporarily pursue his activity in the State where<br>the service is provided, under the same conditions as are imposed by that<br>State on its own nationals.</p>
<p>Article 38</p>
<p>Freedom to provide services in the field of transport shall be governed by<br>the provisions of Chapter 6.</p>
<p>Article 39</p>
<p>The provisions of Artides 30 and 32 to 34 shall apply to the matters covered<br>by this Chapter.</p>
<h2>CHAPTER 4 CAPITAL</h2>
<p>Article 40</p>
<p>Within the framework of the provisions of this Agreement, there shall be<br>no restrictions between the Contracting Parties on the movement of capitai</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>16</p>
<p>belonging to persons resident in EC Member States or EFTA States and no<br>discrimination based on the nationality or on the place of residence of the<br>parties or on the place where such Capital is invested. Annex XII contains<br>the provisions necessary to implement this Article.</p>
<p>Article 41</p>
<p>Current payments connected with the movement of goods, persons, services<br>or Capital between Contracting Parties within the framework of the provi-<br>sions of this Agreement shall be free of all restrictions.</p>
<p>Article 42</p>
<p>1. Where domestic rules governing the Capital market and the credit system<br>are applied to the movements of Capital liberalized in accordance with the<br>provisions of this Agreement, this shall be done in a non-discriminatory<br>manner.</p>
<p>2. Loans for the direct or indirect financing of an EC Member State or an<br>EFTA State or its regional or local authorities shall not be issued or placed<br>in other EC Member States or EFTA States unless the States concerned have<br>reached agreement thereon.</p>
<p>Article 43</p>
<p>1. Where differences between the exchange rules of EC Member States and<br>EFTA States could lead persons resident in one of these States to use the<br>freer transfer facilities within the territory of the Contracting Parties which<br>are provided for in Article 40 in order to evade the rules of one of these Sta-<br>tes concerning the movement of Capital to or from third countries, the Cont-<br>racting Party concerned may take appropriate measures to overcome these<br>difficulties.</p>
<p>2. If movements of Capital lead to disturbances in the functioning of the Capi-<br>tal market in any EC Member State or EFTA State, the Contracting Party<br>concerned may take protective measures in the field of Capital movements.</p>
<p>3. If the competent authorities of a Contracting Party make an aiteration in<br>the rate of exchange which seriously distorts conditions of competition, the<br>other Contracting Parties may take, for a strictly limited period, the neces-<br>sary measures in order to counter the consequences of such aiteration.</p>
<p>4. Where an EC Member State or an EFTA State is in difficulties, or is se-<br>riously threatened with difficulties, as regards its balance of payments either<br>as a result of an overall disequilibrium in its balance of payments, or as a<br>result of the type of currency at its disposal, and where such difficulties are<br>liable in particular to jeopardize the functioning of this Agreement, the<br>Contracting Party concerned may take protective measures.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>2 Riksdagen 1991/92. 1 saml. Nr 170. Bil. 15</p>
<p>Article 44</p>
<p>The Community, on the one hand, and the EFTA States, on the other, shall<br>apply their internal procedures, as provided for in Protocol 18, to implement<br>the provisions of Article 43.</p>
<p>Article 45</p>
<p>1. Decisions, opinions and recommendations related to the measures laid<br>down in Article 43 shall be notified to the EEA Joint Committee.</p>
<p>2. All measures shall be the subject of prior consultations and exchange of<br>information within the EEA Joint Committee.</p>
<p>3. In the situation referred to in Article 43(2), the Contracting Party concer-<br>ned may, however, on the grounds of secrecy and urgency take the measures,<br>where this proves necessary, without prior consultations and exchange of in-<br>formation.</p>
<p>4. In the situation referred to in Article 43(4), where a sudden crisis in the<br>balance of payments occurs and the procedures set out in paragraph 2 cannot<br>be followed, the Contracting Party concerned may, as a precaution, take the<br>necessary protective measures. Such measures must cause the least possible<br>disturbance in the functioning of this Agreement and must not be wider in<br>scope than is strictly necessary to remedy the sudden difficulties which have<br>arisen.</p>
<p>5. When measures are taken in accordance with paragraphs 3 and 4, notice<br>thereof shall be given at the latest by the date of their entry into force, and<br>the exchange of information and consultations as well as the notifications<br>referred to in paragraph 1 shall take place as soon as possible thereafter.</p>
<h2>CHAPTER 5 ECONOMIC AND MONETARY</h2>
<h2>POLICY COOPERATION</h2>
<p>Article 46</p>
<p>The Contracting Parties shall exchange views and information concerning<br>the implementation of this Agreement and the impact of the integration on<br>economic activities and on the conduct of economic and monetary policies.<br>Furthermore, they may discuss macro-economic situations, policies and pro-<br>spects. This exchange of views and information shall take place on a non-<br>binding basis.</p>
<h2>CHAPTER 6 TRANSPORT</h2>
<p>Article 47</p>
<p>1. Artides 48 to 52 shall apply to transport by rail, road and inland waterway.</p>
<p>2. Annex XIII contains specific provisions on all modes of transport.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>18</p>
<p>Article 48</p>
<p>1. The provisions of an EC Member State or an EFTA State, relative to<br>transport by rail, road and inland waterway and not covered by Annex XIII,<br>shall not be made less favourable in their direct or indirect effect on carriers<br>of other States as compared with carriers who are nationals of that State.</p>
<p>2. Any Contracting Party deviating from the principle laid down in para-<br>graph 1 shall notify the EEA Joint Committee thereof. The other Contrac-<br>ting Parties which do not accept the deviation may take corresponding coun-<br>termeasures.</p>
<p>Article 49</p>
<p>Aid shall be compatible with this Agreement if it meets the needs of coordi-<br>nation of transport or if it represents reimbursement for the discharge of cer-<br>tain obligations inherent in the concept of a public service.</p>
<p>Article 50</p>
<p>1. In the case of transport within the territory of the Contracting Parties,<br>there shall be no discrimination which takes the form of carriers charging<br>different rates and imposing different conditions for the carriage of the same<br>goods over the same transport links on grounds of the country of origin or of<br>destination of the goods in question.</p>
<p>2. The competent authority according to Part VII shall, acting on its own<br>initiative or on application by an EC Member State or an EFTA State, inves-<br>tigate any cases of discrimination falling within this Article and take the ne-<br>cessary decisions within the framework of its internal rules.</p>
<p>Article 51</p>
<p>1. The imposition, in respect of transport operations carried out within the<br>territory of the Contracting Parties, of rates and conditions involving any ele-<br>ment of support or protection in the interest of one or more particular under-<br>takings or industries, shall be prohibited unless authorized by the competent<br>authority referred to in Article 50(2).</p>
<p>2. The competent authority shall, acting on its own initiative or on applica-<br>tion by an EC Member State or an EFTA State , examine the rates and con-<br>ditions referred to in paragraph 1, taking account in particular of the require-<br>ments of an appropriate regional economic policy, the needs of underdevelo-<br>ped areas and the problems of areas seriously affected by political circums-<br>tances, on the one hand, and of the effects of such rates and conditions on<br>competition between the different modes of transport, on the other.</p>
<p>The competent authority shall take the necessary decisions within the fra-<br>mework of its internal rules.</p>
<p>3. The prohibition provided for in paragraph 1 shall not apply to tariffs fixed<br>to meet competition.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>Article 52</p>
<p>Charges or dues in respect of the Crossing of frontiers which are charged by<br>a carrier in addition to transport rates shall not exceed a reasonable level<br>after taking the costs actually incurred thereby into account. The Contrac-<br>ting Parties shall endeavour to reduce these costs progressively.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>20</p>
<h1>PART IV COMPETITION AND OTHER</h1>
<h1>COMMON RULES</h1>
<h2>CHAPTER 1 RULES APPLICABLE TO<br>UNDERTAKINGS</h2>
<p>Article 53</p>
<p>1. The following shall be prohibited as incompatible with the functioning of<br>this Agreement: all agreements between undertakings, decisions by associa-<br>tions of undertakings and concerted practices which may affect trade bet-<br>ween Contracting Parties and which have as their object or effect the preven-<br>tion, restriction or distortion of competition within the territory covered by<br>this Agreement, and in particular those which:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;directly or indirectly fix purchase or selling prices or any other tra-<br>ding conditions;</p>
<p>(b) limit or control production, markets, technical development, or in-<br>vestment;</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;share markets or sources of supply;</p>
<p>(d) &nbsp;apply dissimilar conditions to equivalent transactions with other tra-<br>ding parties, thereby placing them at a competitive disadvantage;</p>
<p>(e) &nbsp;make the conclusion of contracts subject to acceptance by the other<br>parties of supplementary obligations which, by their nature or accor-<br>ding to commercial usage, have no connection with the subject of<br>such contracts.</p>
<p>2. Any agreements or decisions prohibited pursuant to this Article shall be<br>automatically void.</p>
<p>3. The provisions of paragraph 1 may, however, be declared inapplicable in<br>the case of:</p>
<p>- any agreement or category of agreements between undertakings;</p>
<p>- &nbsp;any decision or category of decisions by associations of undertakings;</p>
<p>- &nbsp;any concerted practice or category of concerted practices;</p>
<p>which contributes to improving the production or distribution of goods or<br>to promoting technical or economic progress, while allowing consumers a<br>fair share of the resulting benefit, and which does not:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;impose on the undertakings concerned restrictions which are not in-<br>dispensable to the attainment of these objectives;</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;afford such undertakings the possibility of eliminating competition<br>in respect of a substantial part of the products in question.</p>
<p>Article 54</p>
<p>Any abuse by one or more undertakings of a dominant position within the<br>territory covered by this Agreement or in a substantial part of it shall be pro-<br>hibited as incompatible with the functioning of this Agreement in so far as it<br>may affect trade between Contracting Parties.</p>
<p>Such abuse may, in particular, consist in:</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>21</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;directly or indirectly imposing unfair purchase or selling prices or<br>other unfair trading conditions;</p>
<p>(b) limiting production, markets or technical development to the preju-<br>dice of consumers;</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;applying dissimilar conditions to equivalent transactions with other<br>trading parties, thereby placing them at a competitive disadvantage;</p>
<p>(d) making the conclusion of contracts subject to acceptance by the ot-<br>her parties of supplementary obligations which, by their nature or<br>according to commercial usage, have no connection with the subject<br>of such contracts.</p>
<p>Article 55</p>
<p>1. Without prejudice to the provisions giving effect to Artides 53 and 54 as<br>contained in Protocol 21 and Annex XIV of this Agreement, the EC Com-<br>mission and the EFTA Surveillance Authority provided for in Article 108(1)<br>shall ensure the application of the principles laid down in Artides 53 and 54.</p>
<p>The competent surveillance authority, as provided for in Article 56, shall<br>investigate cases of suspected infringement of these principles, on its own<br>initiative, or on application by a State within the respective territory or by<br>the other surveillance authority. The competent surveillance authority shall<br>carry out these investigations in cooperation with the competent national<br>authorities in the respective territory and in cooperation with the other sur-<br>veillance authority, which shall give it its assistance in accordance with its<br>internal rules.</p>
<p>If it finds that there has been an infringement, it shall propose appropriate<br>measures to bring it to an end.</p>
<p>2. If the infringement is not brought to an end, the competent surveillance<br>authority shall record such infringement of the principles in a reasoned deci-<br>sion.</p>
<p>The competent surveillance authority may publish its decision and autho-<br>rize States within the respective territory to take the measures, the condi-<br>tions and details of which it shall determine, needed to remedy the situation.<br>It may also request the other surveillance authority to authorize States within<br>the respective territory to take such measures.</p>
<p>Article 56</p>
<p>1. Individual cases falling under Article 53 shall be decided upon by the sur-<br>veillance authorities in accordance with the following provisions:</p>
<p>(a) individual cases where only trade between EFTA States is affected<br>shall be decided upon by the EFTA Surveillance Authority;</p>
<p>(b) without prejudice to subparagraph (c), the EFTA Surveillance Aut-<br>hority shall decide, as provided for in the provisions set out in Ar-<br>ticle 58, Protocol 21 and the rules adopted for its implementation,<br>Protocol 23 and Annex XIV, on cases where the turnover of the un-<br>dertakings concerned in the territory of the EFTA States equals 33<br></p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>22</p>
<p>per cent or more of their turnover in the territory covered by this<br>Agreement;</p>
<p>(c) the EC Commission shall decide on the other cases as well as on ca-<br>ses under (b) where trade between EC Member States is affected,<br>taking into account the provisions set out in Article 58, Protocol 21,<br>Protocol 23 and Annex XIV.</p>
<p>2. Individual cases falling under Article 54 shall be decided upon by the sur-<br>veillance authority in the territory of which a dominant position is found to<br>exist. The rules set out in paragraph 1 (b) and (c) shall apply only if domi-<br>nance exists within the territories of both surveillance authorities.</p>
<p>3. Individual cases falling under subparagraph (c) of paragraph 1, whose ef-<br>fects on trade between EC Member States or on competition within the<br>Community are not appreciable, shall be decided upon by the EFTA Surveil-<br>lance Authority.</p>
<p>4. The terms 'undertaking’ and 'turnover’ are, for the purposes of this Ar-<br>ticle, defined in Protocol 22.</p>
<p>Article 57</p>
<p>1. Concentrations the control of which is provided for in paragraph 2 and<br>which create or strengthen a dominant position as a result of which effective<br>competition would be significantly impeded within the territory covered by<br>this Agreement or a substantial part of it, shall be declared incompatible with<br>this Agreement.</p>
<p>2. The control of concentrations falling under paragraph 1 shall be carried<br>out by:</p>
<p>(a) the EC Commission in cases falling under Regulation (EEC) No<br>4064/89 in accordance with that Regulation and in accordance with<br>Protocols 21 and 24 and Annex XIV to this Agreement. The EC<br>Commission shall, subject to the review of the EC Court of Justice,<br>have sole competence to take decisions on these cases;</p>
<p>(b) the EFTA Surveillance Authority in cases not falling under subpara-<br>graph (a) where the relevant thresholds set out in Annex XIV are<br>fulfilled in the territory of the EFTA States in accordance with Pro-<br>tocols 21 and 24 and Annex XIV . This is without prejudice to the<br>competence of EC Member States.</p>
<p>Article 58</p>
<p>With a view to developing and maintaining a uniform surveillance throug-<br>hout the European Economic Area in the field of competition and to promo-<br>ting a homogeneous implementation, application and interpretation of the<br>provisions of this Agreement to this end, the competent authorities shall<br>cooperate in accordance with the provisions set out in Protocols 23 and 24.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>23</p>
<p>Article 59</p>
<p>1. In the case of public undertakings and undertakings to which EC Member<br>States or EFTA States grant special or exclusive rights, the Contracting Par-<br>ties shall ensure that there is neither enacted nor maintained in force any<br>measure contrary to the rules contained in this Agreement, in particular to<br>those rules provided for in Artides 4 and 53 to 63.</p>
<p>2. Undertakings entrusted with the operation of services of general econo-<br>mic interest or having the character of a revenue - producing monopoly shall<br>be subject to the rules contained in this Agreement, in particular to the rules<br>on competition, in so far as the application of such rules does not obstruct<br>the performance, in law or in fact, of the particular tasks assigned to them.<br>The development of trade must not be affected to such an extent as would<br>be contrary to the interests of the Contracting Parties.</p>
<p>3. The EC Commission as well as the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall en-<br>sure within their respective competence the application of the provisions of<br>this Article and shall, where necessary, address appropriate measures to the<br>States falling within their respective territory.</p>
<p>Article 60</p>
<p>Annex XIV contains specific provisions giving effect to the principles set out<br>in Artides 53, 54, 57 and 59.</p>
<h2>CHAPTER 2 STATE AID</h2>
<p>Article 61</p>
<p>1. Save as otherwise provided in this Agreement, any aid granted by EC<br>Member States, EFTA States or through State resources in any form what-<br>soever which distorts or threatens to distort competition by favouring certain<br>undertakings or the production of certain goods shall, in so far as it affects<br>trade between Contracting Parties, be incompatible with the functioning of<br>this Agreement.</p>
<p>2. The following shall be compatible with the functioning of this Agreement:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;aid having a social character, granted to individual consumers, pro-<br>vided that such aid is granted without discrimination related to the<br>origin of the products concerned;</p>
<p>(b) aid to make good the damage caused by natural disasters or excep-<br>tional occurrences;</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;aid granted to the economy of certain areas of the Federal Republic<br>of Germany affected by the division of Germany, in so far as such aid<br>is required in order to compensate for the economic disadvantages<br>caused by that division.</p>
<p>3. The following may be considered to be compatible with the functioning of<br>this Agreement:</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>(a) aid to promote the economic development of areas where the stan-<br>dard of living is abnormally low or where there is serious underem-<br>ployment;</p>
<p>(b) aid to promote the execution of an important project of common<br>European interest or to remedy a serious disturbance in the eco-<br>nomy of an EC Member State or an EFTA State;</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;aid to facilitate the development of certain economic activities or of<br>certain economic areas, where such aid does not adversely affect tra-<br>ding conditions to an extent contrary to the common interest;</p>
<p>(d) such other categories of aid as may be specified by the EEA Joint<br>Committee in accordance with Part VII.</p>
<p>Article 62</p>
<p>1. All existing systems of State aid in the territory of the Contracting Parties,<br>as well as any plans to grant or alter State aid,shall be subject to constant<br>review as to their compatibility with Article 61. This review shall be carried<br>out:</p>
<p>(a) as regards the EC Member States, by the EC Commission according<br>to the rules laid down in Article 93 of the Treaty establishing the<br>European Economic Community;</p>
<p>(b) as regards the EFTA States, by the EFTA Surveillance Authority<br>according to the rules set out in an agreement between the EFTA<br>States establishing the EFTA Surveillance Authority which is ent-<br>rusted with the powers and functions laid down in Protocol 26.</p>
<p>2. With a view to ensuring a uniform surveillance in the field of State aid<br>throughout the territory covered by this Agreement, the EC Commission<br>and the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall cooperate in accordance with the<br>provisions set out in Protocol 27.</p>
<p>Article 63</p>
<p>Annex XV contains specific provisions on State aid.</p>
<p>Article 64</p>
<p>1. If one of the surveillance authorities considers that the implementation by<br>the other surveillance authority of Artides 61 and 62 of this Agreement and<br>Article 5 of Protocol 14 is not in conformity with the maintenance of equal<br>conditions of competition within the territory covered by this Agreement,<br>exchange of views shall be held within two weeks according to the procedure<br>of Protocol 27, paragraph (f).</p>
<p>If a commonly agreed solution has not been found by the end of this two<br>week period, the competent authority of the affected Contracting Party may<br>immediately adopt appropriate interim measures in order to remedy the re-<br>sulting distorsion of competition.</p>
<p>Consultations shall then be held in the EEA Joint Committee with a view<br>to finding a commonly acceptable solution.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>If within three months the EEA Joint Committee has not been able to find<br>such a solution, and if the practice in question causes, or threatens to cause,<br>distortion of competition affecting trade between the Contracting Parties,<br>the interim measures may be replaced by definitive measures, strictly neces-<br>sary to offset the effect of such distortion. Priority shall be given to such mea-<br>sures that will least disturb the functioning of the EEA.</p>
<p>2. The provisions of this Article will also apply to State monopolies, which<br>are established after the date of signature of the Agreement.</p>
<h2>CHAPTER 3 OTHER COMMON RULES</h2>
<p>Article 65</p>
<p>1. Annex XVI contains specific provisions and arrangements concerning<br>procurement which, unless otherwise specified, shall apply to all products<br>and to services as specified.</p>
<p>2. Protocol 28 and Annex XVII contain specific provisions and arrangements<br>concerning intellectual, industrial and commercial property, which, unless<br>otherwise specified, shall apply to all products and services.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>26</p>
<h1>PART V HORIZONTAL PROVISIONS<br>RELEVANT TO THE FOUR FREEDOMS</h1>
<h2>CHAPTER 1 SOCIAL POLICY</h2>
<p>Article 66</p>
<p>The Contracting Parties agree upon the need to promote improved working<br>conditions and an improved standard of iiving for workers.</p>
<p>Article 67</p>
<p>1. The Contracting Parties shall pay particular attention to encouraging im-<br>provements, especially in the working environment, as regards the health<br>and safety of workers. In order to help achieve this objective, minimum re-<br>quirements shall be applied for gradual implementation, having regard to<br>the conditions and technical rules obtaining in each of the Contracting Par-<br>ties. Such minimum requirements shall not prevent any Contracting Party<br>from maintaining or introducing more stringent measures for the protection<br>of working conditions compatible with this Agreement.</p>
<p>2. Annex XVIII specifies the provisions to be implemented as the minimum<br>requirements referred to in paragraph 1.</p>
<p>Article 68</p>
<p>In the field of labour law the Contracting Parties shall introduce the measu-<br>res necessary to ensure the good functioning of this Agreement. These mea-<br>sures are specified in Annex XVIII.</p>
<p>Article 69</p>
<p>1. Each Contracting Party shall ensure and maintain the application of the<br>principle that men and women should receive equal pay for equal work.</p>
<p>For the purposes of this Article, ’pay’ means the ordinary basic or mini-<br>mum wage or salary and any other consideration, whether in cash or in kind,<br>which the worker receives, directly or indirectly, in respect of his employ-<br>ment from his employer.</p>
<p>Equal pay without discrimination based on sex means:</p>
<p>(a) that pay for the same work at piece rates shall be calculated on the<br>basis of the same unit of measurement;</p>
<p>(b) that pay for work at time rates shall be the same for the same job.</p>
<p>2. Annex XVIII contains specific provisions for the implementation of para-<br>graph 1.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>Article 70</p>
<p>The Contracting Parties shall promote the principle of equal treatment for<br>men and women by implementing the provisions specified in Annex XVIII.</p>
<p>27</p>
<p>Article 71</p>
<p>The Contracting Parties shall endeavour to promote the dialogue between<br>management and labour at European level.</p>
<h2>CHAPTER 2 CONSUMER PROTECTION</h2>
<p>Article 72</p>
<p>Annex XIX contains provisions on consumer protection.</p>
<h2>CHAPTER 3 ENVIRONMENT</h2>
<p>Article 73</p>
<p>1. Action by the Contracting Parties relating to the environment shall have<br>the following objectives:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;to preserve, protect and improve the quality of the environment;</p>
<p>(b) to contribute towards protecting human health;</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;to ensure a prudent and rational utilization of natural resources.</p>
<p>2. Action by the Contracting Parties relating to the environment shall be ba-<br>sed on the principles that preventive action should be taken, that environ-<br>mental damage should as a priority be rectified at source, and that the pollu-<br>ter should pay. Environmental protection requirements shall be a compo-<br>nent of the Contracting Parties’ other policies.</p>
<p>Article 74</p>
<p>Annex XX contains the specific provisions on protective measures which<br>shall apply pursuant to Article 73.</p>
<p>Article 75</p>
<p>The protective measures referred to in Article 74 shall not prevent any Cont-<br>racting Party from maintaining or introducing more stringent protective<br>measures compatible with this Agreement.</p>
<h2>CHAPTER 4 STATISTICS</h2>
<p>Article 76</p>
<p>1. The Contracting Parties shall ensure the production and dissemination of<br>coherent and comparable statistical information for describing and monito-<br>ring all relevant economic, social and environmental aspects of the EEA.</p>
<p>2. To this end the Contracting Parties shall develop and use harmonized met-<br>hods, definitions and classifications as well as common programmes and pro-<br>cedures organizing statistical work at appropriate administrative levels and<br>duly observing the need for statistical confidentiality.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>3. Annex XXI contains specific provisions on statistics.</p>
<p>28</p>
<p>4. Protocol 30 contains specific provisions on the organization of cooperation<br>in the field of statistics.</p>
<h2>CHAPTER 5 COMPANY LAW</h2>
<p>Article 77</p>
<p>Annex XXII contains specific provisions on company law.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>29</p>
<h1>PART VI COOPERATION OUTSIDE THE<br>FOUR FREEDOMS</h1>
<p>Article 78</p>
<p>The Contracting Parties shall strengthen and broaden cooperation in the fra-<br>mework of the Community’s activities in the fields of:</p>
<p>- research and technological development,</p>
<p>- information services,</p>
<p>- the environment,</p>
<p>- education, training and youth,</p>
<p>- &nbsp;social policy,</p>
<p>- consumer protection,</p>
<p>- small and medium-sized enterprises,</p>
<p>- &nbsp;tourism,</p>
<p>- the audiovisual sector, and</p>
<p>- &nbsp;civil protection,</p>
<p>in so far as these matters are not regulated under the provisions of other<br>Parts of this Agreement.</p>
<p>Article 79</p>
<p>1. The Contracting Parties shall strengthen the dialogue between them by all<br>appropriate means, in particular through the procedures provided for in Part<br>VII, with a view to identifying areas and activities where closer cooperation<br>could contribute to the attainment of their common objectives in the fields<br>referred to in Article 78.</p>
<p>2. They shall, in particular, exchange information and, at the request of a<br>Contracting Party, hold consultations within the EEA Joint Committee in<br>respect of plans or proposals for the establishment or amendment of frame-<br>work programmes, specific programmes, actions and projects in the fields<br>referred to in Article 78.</p>
<p>3. Part VII shall apply mutatis mutandis with regard to this Part whenever<br>the latter or Protocol 31 specifically provides therefor.</p>
<p>Article 80</p>
<p>The cooperation provided for in Article 78 shall normally take one of the<br>following forms:</p>
<p>- participation by EFTA States in EC framework programmes, specific<br>programmes, projects or other actions;</p>
<p>- &nbsp;establishment of joint activities in specific areas, which may include con-<br>certation or coordination of activities, fusion of existing activities and es-<br>tablishment of ad hoc joint activities;</p>
<p>- the formal and informal exchange or provision of information;</p>
<p>- common efforts to encourage certain activities throughout the territory<br>of the Contracting Parties;</p>
<p>- &nbsp;parallel legislation, where appropriate, of identical or similar content;</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>30</p>
<p>- coordination, where this is of mutual interest, of efforts and activities via,<br>or in the context of, international organizations, and of cooperation with<br>third countries.</p>
<p>Article 81</p>
<p>Where cooperation takes the form of participation by EFTA States in an EC<br>framework programme, specific programme, project or other action, the fol-<br>lowing principles shall apply:</p>
<p>(a) The EFTA States shall have access to all parts of a programme.</p>
<p>(b) The status of the EFTA States in the committees which assist the EC<br>Commission in the management or development of a Community<br>activity to which EFTA States may be contributing financially by vir-<br>tue of their participation shall take full account of that contribution.</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;Decisions by the Community, other than those relating to the gene-<br>ral budget of the Community, which affect directly or indirectly a<br>framework programme, specific programme, project or other ac-<br>tion, in which EFTA States participate by a decision under this Ag-<br>reement, shall be subject to the provisions of Article 79(3). The<br>terms and conditions of the continued participation in the activity in<br>question may be reviewed by the EEA Joint Committee in accor-<br>dance with Article 86.</p>
<p>(d) At the project level, institutions, undertakings, organizations and<br>nationals of EFTA States shall have the same rights and obligations<br>in the Community programme or other action in question as those<br>applicable to partner institutions, undertakings, organizations and<br>nationals of EC Member States. The same shall apply mutatis mu-<br>tandis to participants in exchanges between EC Member States and<br>EFTA States, under the activity in question.</p>
<p>(e) &nbsp;EFTA States, their institutions, undertakings, organizations and na-<br>tionals shall have the same rights and obligations with regard to dis-<br>semination, evaluation and exploitation of results as those appli-<br>cable to EC Member States, their institutions, undertakings, organi-<br>zations and nationals.</p>
<p>(f) &nbsp;The Contracting Parties undertake, in accordance with their respec-<br>tive rules and regulations, to facilitate the movement of participants<br>in the programme and other action to the extent necessary.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>Article 82</p>
<p>1. When the cooperation envisaged under the present Part involves a finan-<br>cial participation of the EFTA States, this participation shall take one of the<br>following forms:</p>
<p>(a) The contribution of the EFTA States, arising from their participa-<br>tion in Community activities, shall be calculated proportionally:</p>
<p>- to the commitment appropriations; and</p>
<p>- to the payment appropriations;</p>
<p>31</p>
<p>entered each year for the Community in the general budget of the Com-<br>munity for each budgetary line corresponding to the activities in question.</p>
<p>The ’proportionality factor’ determining the participation of the EFTA<br>States shall be the sum of the ratios between, on the one hand, the gross<br>domestic product at market prices of each of the EFTA States and, on the<br>other hand, the sum of the gross domestic products at market prices of the<br>EC Member States and of that EFTA State. This factor shall be calculated,<br>for each budgetary year, on the basis of the most recent statistical data.</p>
<p>The amount of the contribution of the EFTA States shall be additional,<br>both in commitment appropriations and in payment appropriations, to the<br>amounts entered for the Community in the general budget on each line cor-<br>responding to the activities concerned.</p>
<p>The contributions to be paid each year by the EFTA States shall be deter-<br>mined on the basis of the payment appropriations.</p>
<p>Commitments entered into by the Community prior to the entry into<br>force, on the basis of this Agreement, of the participation of the EFTA States<br>in the activities in question - as well as the payments which result from this -<br>shall give rise to no contribution on the part of the EFTA States.</p>
<p>(b) The financial contribution of EFTA States deriving from their parti-<br>cipation in certain projects or other activities shall be based on the<br>principle that each Contracting Party shall cover its own costs, with<br>an appropriate contribution which shall be fixed by the EEA Joint<br>Committee to the Community’s overhead costs.</p>
<p>(c) The EEA Joint Committee shall take the necessary decisions con-<br>cerning the contribution of the Contracting Parties to the costs of the<br>activity in question.</p>
<p>2. The detailed provisions for the implementation of this Article are set out<br>in Protocol 32.</p>
<p>Article 83</p>
<p>Where cooperation takes the form of an exchange of information between<br>public authorities, the EFTA States shall have the same rights to receive,<br>and obligations to provide, information as EC Member States, subject to the<br>requirements of confidentiality, which shall be fixed by the EEA Joint Com-<br>mittee.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>Article 84</p>
<p>Provisions governing cooperation in specific fields are set out in Protocol 31.</p>
<p>Article 85</p>
<p>Unless otherwise provided for in Protocol 31, cooperation already establis-<br>hed between the Community and individual EFTA States in the fields refer-<br>red to in Article 78 on the date of entry into force of this Agreement shall<br>thereafter be governed by the relevant provisions of this Part and of Protocol<br>31.</p>
<p>32</p>
<p>Article 86</p>
<p>The EEA Joint Committee shall, in accordance with Part VII, take all deci-<br>sions necessary for the implementation of Artides 78 to 85 and measures<br>derived therefrom, which may include, inter alia, supplementing and amen-<br>ding the provisions of Protocol 31, as well as adopting any transitional arran-<br>gements required by way of implementation of Article 85.</p>
<p>Article 87</p>
<p>The Contracting Parties shall take the necessary steps to develop, strengthen<br>or broaden cooperation in the framework of the Community’s activities in<br>fields not listed in Article 78, where such cooperation is considered likely to<br>contribute to the attainment of the objectives of this Agreement, or is other-<br>wise deemed by the Contracting Parties to be of mutual interest. Such steps<br>may include the amendment of Article 78 by the addition of new fields to<br>those listed therein.</p>
<p>Article 88</p>
<p>Without prejudice to provisions of other Parts of this Agreement, the provi-<br>sions of this Part shall not preclude the possibility for any Contracting Party<br>to prepare, adopt and implement measures independently.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>3 Riksdagen 1991192. 1 saml. Nr 170. Bil. 15</p>
<h1>PART VII INSTITUTIONAL PROVISIONS</h1>
<h2>CHAPTER 1 THE STRUCTURE OF THE<br>ASSOCIATION</h2>
<p>SECTION 1 THE EEA COUNCIL</p>
<p>Article 89</p>
<p>1. An EEA Council is hereby established. It shall, in particular, be respon-<br>sible for giving the political impetus in the implementation of this Agreement<br>and laying down the general guidelines for the EEA Joint Committee.</p>
<p>To this end, the EEA Council shall assess the overall functioning and the<br>development of the Agreement. It shall take the political decisions leading<br>to amendments of the Agreement.</p>
<p>2. The Contracting Parties, as to the Community and the EC Member States<br>in their respective fields of competence, may, after having discussed it in the<br>EEA Joint Committee, or directly in exceptionally urgent cases, raise in the<br>EEA Council any issue giving rise to a difficulty.</p>
<p>3. The EEA Council shall by decision adopt its rules of procedure.</p>
<p>Article 90</p>
<p>1. The EEA Council shall consist of the members of the Council of the Euro-<br>pean Communities and members of the EC Commission, and of one member<br>of the Government of each of the EFTA States.</p>
<p>Members of the EEA Council may be represented in accordance with the<br>conditions to be laid down in its rules of procedure.</p>
<p>2. Decisions by the EEA Council shall be taken by agreement between the<br>Community, on the one hand, and the EFTA States, on the other.</p>
<p>Article 91</p>
<p>1. The office of President of the EEA Council shall be held alternately, for<br>a period of six months, by a member of the Council of the European Com-<br>munities and a member of the Government of an EFTA State.</p>
<p>2. The EEA Council shall be convened twice a year by its President. The<br>EEA Council shall also meet whenever circumstances so require, in accor-<br>dance with its rules of procedure.</p>
<p>SECTION 2 THE EEA JOINT COMMITTEE</p>
<p>Article 92</p>
<p>1. An EEA Joint Committee is hereby established. It shall ensure the effec-<br>tive implementation and operation of this Agreement. To this end, it shall<br>carry out exchanges of views and information and take decisions in the cases<br>provided for in this Agreement.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>2. The Contracting Parties, as to the Community and the EC Member States</p>
<p>34</p>
<p>in their respective fields of competence, shall hold consultations in the EEA<br>Joint Committee on any point of relevance to the Agreement giving rise to<br>a difficulty and raised by one of them.</p>
<p>3. The EEA Joint Committee shall by decision adopt its rules of procedure.</p>
<p>Article 93</p>
<p>1. The EEA Joint Committee shall consist of representatives of the Contrac-<br>ting Parties.</p>
<p>2. The EEA Joint Committee shall take decisions by agreement between the<br>Community, on the one hand, and the EFTA States speaking with one voice,<br>on the other.</p>
<p>Article 94</p>
<p>1. The Office of President of the EEA Joint Committee shall be held alterna-<br>tely, for a period of six months, by the representative of the Community, i.e.<br>the EC Commission, and the representative of one of the EFTA States.</p>
<p>2. In order to fulfil its functions, the EEA Joint Committee shall meet, in<br>principle, at least once a month. It shall also meet on the initiative of its Pre-<br>sident or at the request of one of the Contracting Parties in accordance with<br>its rules of procedure.</p>
<p>3. The EEA Joint Committee may decide to establish any subcommittee or<br>working group to assist it in carrying out its tasks. The EEA Joint Committee<br>shall in its rules of procedure lay down the composition and mode of opera-<br>tion of such subcommittees and working groups. Their tasks shall be deter-<br>mined by the EEA Joint Committee in each individual case.</p>
<p>4. The EEA Joint Committee shall issue an annual report on the functioning<br>and the development of this Agreement.</p>
<p>SECTION 3 PARLIAMENTARY COOPERATION</p>
<p>Article 95</p>
<p>1. An EEA Joint Parliamentary Committee is hereby established. It shall be<br>composed of equal numbers of, on the one hand, members of the European<br>Parliament and, on the other, members of Parliaments of the EFTA States.<br>The total number of members of the Committee is laid down in the Statute<br>in Protocol 36.</p>
<p>2. The EEA Joint Parliamentary Committee shall alternately hold sessions<br>in the Community and in an EFTA State in accordance with the provisions<br>laid down in Protocol 36.</p>
<p>3. The EEA Joint Parliamentary Committee shall contribute, through dialo-<br>gue and debate, to a better understanding between the Community and the<br>EFTA States in the fields covered by this Agreement.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>4. The EEA Joint Parliamentary Committee may express its views in the<br>form of reports or resolutions, as appropriate. It shall, in particular, examine<br>the annual report of the EEA Joint Committee, issued in accordance with<br>Article 94 (4), on the functioning and the development of this Agreement.</p>
<p>5. The President of the EEA Council may appear before the EEA Joint Par-<br>liamentary Committee in order to be heard by it.</p>
<p>6. The EEA Joint Parliamentary Committee shall adopt its rules of proce-<br>dure.</p>
<p>SECTION 4 COOPERATION BETWEEN ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL<br>PARTNERS</p>
<p>Article 96</p>
<p>1. Members of the Economic and Social Committee and other bodies repre-<br>senting the social partners in the Community and the corresponding bodies<br>in the EFTA States shall work to strengthen contacts between them and to<br>cooperate in an organized and regular manner in order to enhance the awa-<br>reness of the economic and social aspects of the growing interdependence<br>of the economies of the Contracting Parties and of their interests within the<br>context of the EEA.</p>
<p>2. To this end, an EEA Consultative Committee is hereby established. It<br>shall be composed of equal numbers of, on the one hand, members of the<br>Economic and Social Committee of the Community and, on the other, mem-<br>bers of the EFTA Consultative Committee. The EEA Consultative Commit-<br>tee may express its views in the form of reports or resolutions, as appro-<br>priate.</p>
<p>3. The EEA Consultative Committee shall adopt its rules of procedure.</p>
<h2>CHAPTER 2 THE DECISION-MAKING<br>PROCEDURE</h2>
<p>Article 97</p>
<p>This Agreement does not prejudge the right for each Contracting Party to<br>amend, without prejudice to the principle of non-discrimination and after<br>having informed the other Contracting Parties, its internal legislation in the<br>areas covered by this Agreement:</p>
<p>- if the EEA Joint Committee concludes that the legislation as amended<br>does not affect the good functioning of this Agreement; or</p>
<p>- &nbsp;if the procedures referred to in Article 98 have been completed.</p>
<p>Article 98</p>
<p>The Annexes to this Agreement and Protocols 1 to 7, 9 to 11, 19 to 27, 30 to<br>32, 37, 39, 41 and 47, as appropriate, may be amended by a decision of the<br>EEA Joint Committee in accordance with Artides 93 (2), 99, 100, 102 and<br>103.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>36</p>
<p>Article 99</p>
<p>1. As soon as new legislation is being drawn up by the EC Commission in a<br>field which is governed by this Agreement, the EC Commission shall infor-<br>mally seek advice from experts of the EFTA States in the same way as it<br>seeks advice from experts of the EC Member States for the elaboration of<br>its proposals.</p>
<p>2. When transmitting its proposal to the Council of the European Communi-<br>ties, the EC Commission shall transmit copies thereof to the EFTA States.</p>
<p>At the request of one of the Contracting Parties, a preliminary exchange<br>of views takes place in the EEA Joint Committee.</p>
<p>3. During the phase preceding the decision of the Council of the European<br>Communities, in a continuous information and consultation process, the<br>Contracting Parties consult each other again in the EEA Joint Committee at<br>the significant moments at the request of one of them.</p>
<p>4. The Contracting Parties shall cooperate in good faith during the informa-<br>tion and consultation phase with a view to facilitating, at the end of the pro-<br>cess, the decision-taking in the EEA Joint Committee.</p>
<p>Article 100</p>
<p>The EC Commission shall ensure experts of the EFTA States as wide a parti-<br>cipation as possible according to the areas concerned, in the preparatory<br>stage of draft measures to be submitted subsequently to the committees<br>which assist the EC Commission in the exercise of its executive powers. In<br>this regard, when drawing up draft measures the EC Commission shall refer<br>to experts of the EFTA States on the same basis as it refers to experts of the<br>EC Member States.</p>
<p>In the cases where the Council of the European Communities is seized in<br>accordance with the procedure applicable to the type of committee involved,<br>the EC Commission shall transmit to the Council of the European Commu-<br>nities the views of the experts of the EFTA States.</p>
<p>Article 101</p>
<p>1. In respect of committees which are covered neither by Article 81 nor by<br>Article 100 experts from EFTA States shall be associated with the work when<br>this is called for by the good functioning of this Agreement.</p>
<p>These committees are listed in Protocol 37. The modalities of such an asso-<br>ciation are set out in the relevant sectoral Protocols and Annexes dealing<br>with the matter concerned.</p>
<p>2. If it appears to the Contracting Parties that such an association should be<br>extended to other committees which present similar characteristics, the EEA<br>Joint Committee may amend Protocol 37.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>Article 102</p>
<p>1. In order to guarantee the legal security and the homogeneity of the EEA,<br>the EEA Joint Committee shall take a decision concerning an amendment<br>of an Annex to this Agreement as closely as possible to the adoption by the<br>Community of the corresponding new Community legislation with a view to<br>permitting a simultaneous application of the latter as well as of the amend-<br>ments of the Annexes to the Agreement. To this end, the Community shall,<br>whenever adopting a legislative act on an issue which is governed by this Ag-<br>reement, as soon as possible inform the other Contracting Parties in the<br>EEA Joint Committee.</p>
<p>2. The part of an Annex to this Agreement which would be directly affected<br>by the new legislation is assessed in the EEA Joint Committee.</p>
<p>3. The Contracting Parties shall make all efforts to arrive at an agreement on<br>matters relevant to this Agreement.</p>
<p>The EEA Joint Committee shall, in particular, make every effort to find<br>a mutually acceptable solution where a serious problem arises in any area<br>which, in the EFTA States, falls within the competence of the legislator.</p>
<p>4. If, notwithstanding the application of the preceding paragraph, an agree-<br>ment on an amendment of an Annex to this Agreement cannot be reached,<br>the EEA Joint Committee shall examine all further possibilities to maintain<br>the good functioning of this Agreement and take any decision necessary to<br>this effect, including the possibility to take notice of the equivalence of legis-<br>lation. Such a decision shall be taken at the latest at the expiry of a period of<br>six months from the date of referral to the EEA Joint Committee or, if that<br>date is later, on the date of entry into force of the corresponding Community<br>legislation.</p>
<p>5. If, at the end of the time limit set out in paragraph 4, the EEA Joint Com-<br>mittee has not taken a decision on an amendment of an Annex to this Agree-<br>ment, the affected part thereof, as determined in accordance with paragraph<br>2, is regarded as provisionally suspended, subject to a decision to the cont-<br>rary by the EEA Joint Committee. Such a suspension shall take effect six<br>months after the end of the period referred to in paragraph 4, but in no event<br>earlier than the date on which the corresponding EC act is implemented in<br>the Community. The EEA Joint Committee shall pursue its efforts to agree<br>on a mutually acceptable solution in order for the suspension to be termina-<br>ted as soon as possible.</p>
<p>6. The practical consequences of the suspension referred to in paragraph 5<br>shall be discussed in the EEA Joint Committee. The rights and obligations<br>which individuals and economic operators have already acquired under this<br>Agreement shall remain. The Contracting Parties shall, as appropriate, de-<br>cide on the adjustments necessary due to the suspension.</p>
<p>Article 103</p>
<p>1. If a decision of the EEA Joint Committee can be binding on a Contracting<br>Party only after the fulfilment of constitutional requirements, the decision</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>shall, if a date is contained therein, enter into force on that date, provided<br>that the Contracting Party concerned has notified the other Contracting Par-<br>ties by that date that the constitutional requirements have been fulfilled.</p>
<p>In the absence of such a notification by that date, the decision shall enter<br>into force on the first day of the second month following the last notification.</p>
<p>2. If upon the expiry of a period of six months after the decision of the EEA<br>Joint Committee such a notification has not taken place, the decision of the<br>EEA Joint Committee shall be applied provisionally pending the fulfilment<br>of the constitutional requirements unless a Contracting Party notifies that<br>such a provisional application cannot take place. In the latter case, or if a<br>Contracting Party notifies the non-ratification of a decision of the EEA Joint<br>Committee, the suspension provided for in Article 102 (5) shall take effect<br>one month after such a notification but in no event earlier than the date on<br>which the corresponding EC act is implemented in the Community.</p>
<p>Artide 104</p>
<p>Decisions taken by the EEA Joint Committee in the cases provided for in<br>this Agreement shall, unless otherwise provided for therein, upon their entry<br>into force be binding on the Contracting Parties which shall take the neces-<br>sary steps to ensure their implementation and application.</p>
<h2>CHAPTER 3 HOMOGENEITY, SURVEILLANCE<br>PROCEDURE AND SETTLEMENT OF DISPUTES</h2>
<p>SECTION 1 HOMOGENEITY</p>
<p>Artide 105</p>
<p>1. In order to achieve the objective of the Contracting Parties to arrive at as<br>uniform an interpretation as possible of the provisions of the Agreement and<br>those provisions of Community legislation which are substantially reprodu-<br>ced in the Agreement, the EEA Joint Committee shall act in accordance<br>with this Article.</p>
<p>2. The EEA Joint Committee shall keep under constant review the develop-<br>ment of the case law of the Court of Justice of the European Communities<br>and the EFTA Court. To this end judgments of these Courts shall be trans-<br>mitted to the EEA Joint Committee which shall act so as to preserve the<br>homogeneous interpretation of the Agreement.</p>
<p>3. If the EEA Joint Committee within two months after a difference in the<br>case law of the two Courts has been brought before it, has not succeeded to<br>preserve the homogeneous interpretation of the Agreement, the procedures<br>laid down in Article 111 may be applied.</p>
<p>Artide 106</p>
<p>In order to ensure as uniform an interpretation as possible of this Agree-<br>ment, in full deference to the independence of courts, a system of exchange</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>of information concerning judgments by the EFTA Court, the Court of Jus-<br>tice of the European Communities and the Court of First Instance of the<br>European Communities and the Courts of last instance of the EFTA States<br>shall be set up by the EEA Joint Committee. This system shall comprise:</p>
