<p>(a) transmission to the Registrar of the Court of Justice of the European<br>Communities of judgments delivered by such courts on the interpre-<br>tation and application of, on the one hand, this Agreement or, on<br>the other hand, the Treaty establishing the European Economic<br>Community and the Treaty establishing the European Coal and<br>Steel Community, as amended or supplemented, as well as the acts<br>adopted in pursuance thereof in so far as they concern provisions<br>which are identical in substance to those of this Agreement;</p>
<p>(b) classification of these judgments by the Registrar of the Court of<br>Justice of the European Communities including, as far as necessary,<br>the drawing up and publication of translations and abstracts;</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;Communications by the Registrar of the Court of Justice of the Euro-<br>pean Communities of the relevant documents to the competent na-<br>tional authorities, to be designated by each Contracting Party.</p>
<p>Article 107</p>
<p>Provisions on the possibility for an EFTA State to allow a court or tribunal<br>to ask the Court of Justice of the European Communities to decide on the<br>interpretation of an EEA rule are laid down in Protocol 34.</p>
<p>SECTION 2 SURVEILLANCE PROCEDURE</p>
<p>Article 108</p>
<p>1. The EFTA States shall establish an independent surveillance authority<br>(EFTA Surveillance Authority) as well as procedures similar to those exis-<br>ting in the Community including procedures for ensuring the fulfilment of<br>obligations under this Agreement and for control of the legality of acts of the<br>EFTA Surveillance Authority regarding competition.</p>
<p>2. The EFTA States shall establish a court of justice (EFTA Court).</p>
<p>The EFTA Court shall, in accordance with a separate agreement between<br>the EFTA States, with regard to the application of this Agreement be com-<br>petent, in particular, for:</p>
<p>(a) actions concerning the surveillance procedure regarding the EFTA<br>States;</p>
<p>(b) appeals concerning decisions in the field of competition taken by the<br>EFTA Surveillance Authority;</p>
<p>(c) the settlement of disputes between two or more EFTA States.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>Article 109</p>
<p>1. The fulfilment of the obligations under this Agreement shall be monitored<br>by, on the one hand, the EFTA Surveillance Authority and, on the other,</p>
<p>40</p>
<p>the EC Commission acting in conformity with the Treaty establishing the<br>European Economic Community, the Treaty establishing the European Coal<br>and Steel Community and this Agreement.</p>
<p>2. In order to ensure a uniform surveillance throughout the EEA, the EFTA<br>Surveillance Authority and the EC Commission shall cooperate, exchange<br>information and consult each other on surveillance policy issues and indivi-<br>dual cases.</p>
<p>3. The EC Commission and the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall receive<br>any complaints concerning the application of this Agreement. They shall in-<br>form each other of complaints received.</p>
<p>4. Each of these bodies shall examine all complaints falling within its compe-<br>tence and shall pass to the other body any complaints which fall within the<br>competence of that body.</p>
<p>5. In case of disagreement between these two bodies with regard to the ac-<br>tion to be taken in relation to a complaint or with regard to the result of<br>the examination, either of the bodies may refer the matter to the EEA Joint<br>Committee which shall deal with it in accordance with Article 111.</p>
<p>Article 110</p>
<p>Decisions under this Agreement by the EFTA Surveillance Authority and<br>the EC Commission which impose a pecuniary obligation on persons other<br>than States, shall be enforceable. The same shall apply to such judgments<br>under this Agreement by the Court of Justice of the European Communities,<br>the Court of First Instance of the European Communities and the EFTA<br>Court.</p>
<p>Enforcement shall be governed by the rules of civil procedure in force in<br>the State in the territory of which it is carried out. The order for its enforce-<br>ment shall be appended to the decision, without other formality than verifi-<br>cation of the authenticity of the decision, by the authority which each Cont-<br>racting Party shall designate for this purpose and shall make known to the<br>other Contracting Parties, the EFTA Surveillance Authority, the EC Com-<br>mission, the Court of Justice of the European Communities, the Court of<br>First Instance of the European Communities and the EFTA Court.</p>
<p>When these formalities have been completed on application by the party<br>concerned, the latter may proceed to enforcement, in accordance with the<br>law of the State in the territory of which enforcement is to be carried out, by<br>bringing the matter directly before the competent authority.</p>
<p>Enforcement may be suspended only by a decision of the Court of Justice<br>of the European Communities, as far as decisions by the EC Commission,<br>the Court of First Instance of the European Communities or the Court of<br>Justice of the European Communities are concerned, or by a decision of the<br>EFTA Court as far as decisions by the EFTA Surveillance Authority or the<br>EFTA Court are concerned. However, the courts of the States concerned<br>shall have jurisdiction over complaints that enforcement is being carried out<br>in an irregular manner.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>41</p>
<p>SECTION 3 SETTLEMENT OF DISPUTES</p>
<p>Article 111</p>
<p>1. The Community or an EFTA State may bring a matter under dispute<br>which concerns the interpretation or application of this Agreement before<br>the EEA Joint Committee in accordance with the following provisions.</p>
<p>2. The EEA Joint Committee may settle the dispute. It shall be provided<br>with all information which might be of use in making possible an indepth<br>examination of the situation, with a view to finding an acceptable solution.<br>To this end, the EEA Joint Committee shall examine all possibilities to main-<br>tain the good functioning of the Agreement.</p>
<p>3. If a dispute concerns case law regarding provisions of this Agreement,<br>which are identical in substance to corresponding rules of the Treaty estab-<br>lishing the European Economic Community and the Treaty establishing the<br>European Coal and Steel Community and to acts adopted in application of<br>these two Treaties and if the dispute has not been settled within three months<br>after it has been brought before the EEA Joint Committee, the Contracting<br>Parties to the dispute may agree to request the Court of Justice of the Euro-<br>pean Communities to give a ruling on the interpretation of the relevant rules.</p>
<p>If the EEA Joint Committee in such a dispute has not reached an agree-<br>ment on a solution within six months from the date on which this procedure<br>was initiated or if, by then, the Contracting Parties to the dispute have not<br>decided to ask for a ruling by the Court of Justice of the European Communi-<br>ties, a Contracting Party may, in order to remedy possible imbalances,</p>
<p>- &nbsp;either take a safeguard measure in accordance with Article 112(2) and<br>following the procedure of Article 113;</p>
<p>- or apply Article 102 mutatis mutandis.</p>
<p>4. If a dispute concerns the scope or duration of safeguard measures taken<br>in accordance with Article 111(3) or Article 112, or the proportionality of<br>rebalancing measures taken in accordance with Article 114, and if the EEA<br>Joint Committee after three months from the date when the matter has been<br>brought before it has not succeeded to resolve the dispute, any Contracting<br>Party may refer the dispute to arbitration under the procedures laid down in<br>Protocol 33. No question of interpretation of the provisions of this Agree-<br>ment referred to in paragraph 3 may be dealt with in such procedures. The<br>arbitration award shall be binding on the parties to the dispute.</p>
<h2>CHAPTER 4 SAFEGUARD MEASURES</h2>
<p>Article 112</p>
<p>1. If serious economic, societal or environmental difficulties of a sectorial or<br>regional nature liable to persist are arising, a Contracting Party may unilate-<br>rally take appropriate measures under the conditions and procedures laid<br>down in Article 113.</p>
<p>2. Such safeguard measures shall be restricted with regard to their scope and<br>duration to what is strictly necessary in order to remedy the situation. Prio-<br></p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>rity shall be given to such measures as will least disturb the functioning of<br>this Agreement.</p>
<p>3. The safeguard measures shall apply with regard to all Contracting Parties.</p>
<p>Article 113</p>
<p>1. A Contracting Party which is considering taking safeguard measures under<br>Article 112 shall, without delay, notify the other Contracting Parties through<br>the EEA Joint Committee and shall provide all relevant information.</p>
<p>2. The Contracting Parties shall immediately enter into consultations in the<br>EEA Joint Committee with a view to finding a commonly acceptable solu-<br>tion.</p>
<p>3. The Contracting Party concerned may not take safeguard measures until<br>one month has elapsed after the date of notification under paragraph 1, un-<br>less the consultation procedure under paragraph 2 has been concluded be-<br>fore the expiration of the stated time limit. When exceptional circumstances<br>requiring immediate action exclude prior examination, the Contracting<br>Party concerned may apply forthwith the protective measures strictly neces-<br>sary to remedy the situation.</p>
<p>For the Community, the safeguard measures shall be taken by the EC<br>Commission.</p>
<p>4. The Contracting Party concerned shall, without delay, notify the measures<br>taken to the EEA Joint Committee and shall provide all relevant informa-<br>tion.</p>
<p>5. The safeguard measures taken shall be the subject of consultations in the<br>EEA Joint Committee every three months from the date of their adoption<br>with a view to their abolition before the date of expiry envisaged, or to the<br>limitation of their scope of application.</p>
<p>Each Contracting Party may at any time request the EEA Joint Commit-<br>tee to review such measures.</p>
<p>Article 114</p>
<p>1. If a safeguard measure taken by a Contracting Party creates an imbalance<br>between the rights and obligations under this Agreement, any other Cont-<br>racting Party may towards that Contracting Party take such proportionate<br>rebalancing measures as are strictly necessary to remedy the imbalance.<br>Priority shall be given to such measures as will least disturb the functioning<br>of the EEA.</p>
<p>2. The procedure under Article 113 shall apply.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>43</p>
<h1>PART VIII FINANCIAL MECHANISM</h1>
<p>Article 115</p>
<p>With a view to promoting a continuous and balanced strengthening of trade<br>and economic relations between the Contracting Parties, as provided for in<br>Article 1, the Contracting Parties agree on the need to reduce the economic<br>and social disparities between their regions. They note in this regard the rele-<br>vant provisions set out elsewhere in this Agreement and its related protocols,<br>including certain of the arrangements regarding agriculture and fisheries.</p>
<p>Article 116</p>
<p>A Financial Mechanism shall be established by the EFTA States to contri-<br>bute, in the context of the EEA and in addition to the efforts already dep-<br>loyed by the Community in this regard, to the objectives laid down in Article<br>115.</p>
<p>Article 117</p>
<p>Provisions goveming the Financial Mechanism are set out in Protocol 38.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>44</p>
<h1>PART IX GENERAL AND FINAL<br>PROVISIONS</h1>
<p>Article 118</p>
<p>1. Where a Contracting Party considers that it would be useful in the interests<br>of all the Contracting Parties to develop the relations established by this Ag-<br>reement by extending them to fields not covered thereby, it shall submit a<br>reasoned request to the other Contracting Parties within the EEA Council.<br>The latter may instruct the EEA Joint Committee to examine all the aspects<br>of this request and to issue a report.</p>
<p>The EEA Council may, where appropriate, take the political decisions<br>with a view to opening negotiations between the Contracting Parties.</p>
<p>2. The agreements resulting from the negotiations referred to in paragraph 1<br>will be subject to ratification or approval by the Contracting Parties in accor-<br>dance with their own procedures.</p>
<p>Article 119</p>
<p>The Annexes and the acts referred to therein as adapted for the purposes of<br>this Agreement as well as the Protocols shall form an integral part of this<br>Agreement.</p>
<p>Article 120</p>
<p>Unless otherwise provided in this Agreement and in particular in Protocols<br>41, 43 and 44, the application of the provisions of this Agreement shall pre-<br>vail over provisions in existing bilateral or multilateral agreements binding<br>the European Economic Community, on the one hand, and one or more<br>EFTA States, on the other, to the extent that the same subject matter is go-<br>verned by this Agreement.</p>
<p>Article 121</p>
<p>The provisions of this Agreement shall not preclude cooperation:</p>
<p>(a) within the framework of the Nordic cooperation to the extent that<br>such cooperation does not impair the good functioning of this Ag-<br>reement;</p>
<p>(b) within the framework of the regional union between Switzerland<br>and Liechtenstein to the extent that the objectives of this union are<br>not attained by the application of this Agreement and the good func-<br>tioning of this Agreement is not impaired;</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;within the framework of cooperation between Austria and Italy con-<br>cerning Tyrol, Vorarlberg and Trentino - South Tyrol/AJto Adige,<br>to the extent that such cooperation does not impair the good functio-<br>ning of this Agreement.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>45</p>
<p>Article 122</p>
<p>The representatives, delegates and experts of the Contracting Parties, as well<br>as officials and other servants acting under this Agreement shall be required,<br>even after their duties have ceased, not to disclose information of the kind<br>covered by the obligation of professional secrecy, in particular information<br>about undertakings, their business relations or their cost components.</p>
<p>Article 123</p>
<p>Nothing in this Agreement shall prevent a Contracting Party from taking any<br>measures:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;which it considers necessary to prevent the disclosure of information<br>contrary to its essential security interests;</p>
<p>(b) which reläte to the production of, or trade in, arms, munitions and<br>war materials or other products indispensable for defence purposes<br>or to research, development or production indispensable for de-<br>fence purposes, provided that such measures do not impair the con-<br>ditions of competition in respect of products not intended for specifi-<br>cally military purposes;</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;which it considers essential to its own security in the event of serious<br>internal disturbances affecting the maintenance of law and order, in<br>time of war or serious international tension constituting threat of<br>war or in order to carry out obligations it has accepted for the pur-<br>pose of maintaining peace and international security.</p>
<p>Article 124</p>
<p>The Contracting Parties shall accord nationals of EC Member States and<br>EFTA States the same treatment as their own nationals as regards participa-<br>tion in the Capital of companies or firms within the meaning of Article 34,<br>without prejudice to the application of the other provisions of this Agree-<br>ment.</p>
<p>Article 125</p>
<p>This Agreement shall in no way prejudice the rules of the Contracting Parties<br>governing the system of property ownership.</p>
<p>Article 126</p>
<p>1. The Agreement shall apply to the territories to which the Treaty establish-<br>ing the European Economic Community and the Treaty establishing the<br>European Coal and Steel Community is applied and under the conditions<br>laid down in those Treaties, and to the territories of the Republic of Austria,<br>the Republic of Finland, the Republic of Iceland, the Principality of<br>Liechtenstein, the Kingdom of Norway, the Kingdom of Sweden and the<br>Swiss Confederation.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>2. Notwithstanding paragraph 1, this Agreement shall not apply to the Åland<br>Islands. The Government of Finland may, however, give notice, by a decla-<br>ration deposited when ratifying this Agreement with the Depositary, which<br>shall transmit a certified copy thereof to the Contracting Parties, that the<br>Agreement shall apply to those Islands under the same conditions as it ap-<br>plies to other parts of Finland subject to the following provisions:</p>
<p>(a) The provisions of this Agreement shall not preclude the application<br>of the provisions in force at any given time on the Åland Islands on:</p>
<p>(i) restrictions on the right for natural persons who do not enjoy re-<br>gional citizenship in Åland, and for legal persons, to acquire and<br>hold real property on the Åland Islands without permission by<br>the competent authorities of the Islands;</p>
<p>(ii) restrictions on the right of establishment and the right to provide<br>services by natural persons who do not enjoy regional citizenship<br>in Åland, or by any legal person,without permission by the com-<br>petent authorities of the Åland Islands.</p>
<p>(b) The rights enjoyed by Ålanders in Finland shall not be affected by<br>this Agreement.</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;The authorities of the Åland Islands shall apply the same treatment<br>to all natural and legal persons of the Contracting Parties.</p>
<p>Article 127</p>
<p>Each Contracting Party may withdraw from this Agreement provided it gives<br>at least twelve months’ notice in writing to the other Contracting Parties.</p>
<p>Immediately after the notification of the intended withdrawal, the other<br>Contracting Parties shall convene a diplomatic conference in order to envi-<br>sage the necessary modifications to bring to the Agreement.</p>
<p>Article 128</p>
<p>1. Any European State becoming a member of the Community shall, or be-<br>coming a member of EFTA may, apply to become a Party to this Agreement.<br>It shall address its application to the EEA Council.</p>
<p>2. The terms and conditions for such participation shall be the subject of an<br>agreement between the Contracting Parties and the applicant State. That ag-<br>reement shall be submitted for ratification or approval by all Contracting<br>Parties in accordance with their own procedures.</p>
<p>Article 129</p>
<p>1. This Agreement is drawn up in a single original in the Danish, Dutch,<br>English, Finnish, French, German, Greek, Icelandic, Italian, Norwegian,<br>Portuguese, Spanish and Swedish languages, each of these texts being<br>equally authentic.</p>
<p>The texts of the acts referred to in the Annexes are equally authentic in<br>Danish, Dutch, English, French, German, Greek, Italian, Portuguese and<br></p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>47</p>
<p>Spanish as published in the Official Journal of the European Communities<br>and shall for the authentication thereof be drawn up in the Finnish, Icelan-<br>dic, Norwegian and Swedish languages.</p>
<p>2. This Agreement shall be ratified or approved by the Contracting Parties<br>in accordance with their respective constitutional requirements.</p>
<p>It shall be deposited with the General Secretariat of the Council of the<br>European Communities by which certified copies shall be transmitted to all<br>other Contracting Parties.</p>
<p>The instruments of ratification or approval shall be deposited with the Ge-<br>neral Secretariat of the Council of the European Communities which shall<br>notify all other Contracting Parties.</p>
<p>3. This Agreement shall enter into force on 1 January 1993, provided that all<br>Contracting Parties have deposited their instruments of ratification or appro-<br>val before that date. After that date this Agreement shall enter into force on<br>the first day of the second month following the last notification. The final<br>date for such a notification shall be 30 June 1993. After that date the Cont-<br>racting Parties shall convene a diplomatic conference to appreciate the situa-<br>tion.</p>
<p>In witness whereof, the undersigned Plenipotentiaries, have signed this<br>Agreement.</p>
<p>Done at Oporto this second day of May in the year one thousand nine<br>hundred and ninety two.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Main agreement</p>
<p>48</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL1</h1>
<h1>ON HORIZONTAL ADAPTATIONS</h1>
<p>The provisions of the acts referred to in the Annexes to the Agreement shall<br>be applicable in accordance with the Agreement and this Protocol, unless<br>otherwise provided in the respective Annex. The specific adaptations neces-<br>sary for individual acts are set out in the Annex where the act concerned is<br>listed.</p>
<p>1. Introductory parts of the acts</p>
<p>The preambles of the acts referred to are not adapted for the purposes of the<br>Agreement. They are relevant to the extent necessary for the proper interp-<br>retation and application, within the framework of the Agreement, of the<br>provisions contained in such acts.</p>
<p>2. Provisions on EC committees</p>
<p>Procedures, institutional arrangements or other provisions concerning EC<br>committees contained in the acts referred to are dealt with in Artides 81,100<br>and 101 of the Agreement and in Protocol 31.</p>
<p>3. Provisions setting up procedures for adaptinglamending Community<br>acts</p>
<p>Where an act referred to provides for EC procedures on its adaptation, ex-<br>tension or amendment or for the development of new Community policies,<br>initiatives or acts, the relevant decision-making procedures provided for in<br>the Agreement shall apply.</p>
<p>4. Exchange ofinformation and notification procedures</p>
<p>(a) Where an EC Member State is to submit information to the EC Commis-<br>sion, an EFTA State shall submit such information to the EFTA Surveillance<br>Authority and to a Standing Committee of the EFTA States. The same shall<br>apply when the transmission of information is to be carried out by the com-<br>petent authorities. The EC Commission and the EFTA Surveillance Autho-<br>rity shall exchange information they have received from the EC Member Sta-<br>tes or from the EFTA States or from the competent authorities.</p>
<p>(b) Where an EC Member State is to submit information to one or more<br>other EC Member States, it shall also submit that information to the EC<br>Commission which shall pass it on to the Standing Committee for distribu-<br>tion to the EFTA States.</p>
<p>An EFTA State shall submit corresponding information to one or more<br>other EFTA States and to the Standing Committee which shall pass it on to<br>the EC Commission for distribution to the EC Member States. The same<br>shall apply when the information is to be submitted by the competent autho-<br>rities.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol1</p>
<p>4 Riksdagen 1991192. 1 saml. Nr 170. Bil. 15</p>
<p>(c) In areas where, for reasons of urgency, rapid transfer of information is<br>called for, appropriate sectoral Solutions providing for direct exchange of in-<br>formation shall apply.</p>
<p>(d) Functions of the EC Commission in the context of procedures for verifi-<br>cation or approval, information, notification or consultation and similar mat-<br>ters shall for the EFTA States be carried out according to procedures estab-<br>lished among them. This is without prejudice to paragraphs 2, 3 and 7.<br>The EC Commission and the EFTA Surveillance Authority or the Standing<br>Committee, as the case may be, shall exchange all information regarding<br>these matters. Any issue arising in this context may be referred to the EEA<br>Joint Committee.</p>
<p>5. Review and reporting procedures</p>
<p>Where, according to an act referred to, the EC Commission or another EC<br>body is to prepare a report or an assessment or the like, the EFTA Surveil-<br>lance Authority or the Standing Committee, as the case may be, shall, unless<br>otherwise agreed, concurrently prepare, as appropriate, a corresponding re-<br>port or assessment or the like, with regard to the EFTA States. The EC Com-<br>mission and the EFTA Surveillance Authority or the Standing Committee,<br>as the case may be, shall consult each other and exchange information during<br>the preparation of their respective reports, copies of which shall be sent to<br>the EEA Joint Committee.</p>
<p>6. Publication ofinformation</p>
<p>(a) Where, according to an act referred to, an EC Member State is to pub-<br>lish certain information on facts, procedures and the like, also the EFTA Sta-<br>tes shall, under the Agreement, publish the relevant information in a corre-<br>sponding manner.</p>
<p>(b) Where, according to an act referred to, facts, procedures, reports and<br>the like are to be published in the Official Journal of the European Commu-<br>nities, the corresponding information regarding the EFTA States shall be<br>published in a separate EEA section<sup>1</sup> thereof.</p>
<p>7. Rights and obligations</p>
<p>Rights conferred and obligations imposed upon the EC Member States or<br>their public entities, undertakings or individuals in relation to each other,<br>shall be understood to be conferred or imposed upon Contracting Parties,<br>the latter also being understood, as the case may be, as their competent aut-<br>horities, public entities, undertakings or individuals.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 1</p>
<p><sup>1</sup> The table of contents of the EEA section would also contain references to where the<br>information in question concerning the EC and its Member States could be found.</p>
<p>50</p>
<p>8. References to territories</p>
<p>Whenever the acts referred to contain references to the territory of the<br>“Community” or of the “common market” the references shall for the purpo-<br>ses of the Agreement be understood to be references to the territories of the<br>Contracting Parties as defined in Article 126 of the Agreement.</p>
<p>9. References to nationals of EC Member States</p>
<p>Whenever the acts referred to contain references to nationals of EC Member<br>States, the references shall for the purposes of the Agreement be understood<br>to be references also to nationals of EFTA States.</p>
<p>10. References to languages</p>
<p>Where an act referred to confers upon the EC Member States or their public<br>entities, undertakings or individuals rights or imposes obligations regarding<br>the use of any of the official languages of the European Communities, the<br>corresponding rights and obligations regarding the use of any of the official<br>languages of all Contracting Parties shall be understood to be conferred or<br>imposed upon Contracting Parties, their competent authorities, public enti-<br>ties, undertakings or individuals.</p>
<p>11. Entry into force and implementation of acts</p>
<p>Provisions on the entry into force or implementation of the acts referred to<br>in the Annexes to the Agreement are not relevant for the purposes of the<br>Agreement. The time limits and dates for the EFTA States for bringing into<br>force and implementing acts referred to follow from Article 129(3) of the<br>Agreement, as well as from provisions on transitional arrangements.</p>
<p>12. Addressees of the Community acts</p>
<p>Provisions indicating that a Community act is addressed to the Member Sta-<br>tes of the Community are not relevant for the purposes of the Agreement.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 1</p>
<p>51</p>

<p>52</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 3</h1>
<h1>CONCERNING PRODUCTS REFERRED TO<br>IN ARTICLE 8(3)(b) OF THE AGREEMENT<br>CHAPTERI</h1>
<p>GENERAL PROVISION</p>
<p>Article 1</p>
<p>Application of the EEA provisions</p>
<p>Subject to the provisions of this Protocol and unless otherwise specified in<br>the Agreement, the provisions of the Agreement shall apply to products lis-<br>ted in Tables I and II.</p>
<h2>CHAPTER II</h2>
<p>PRICE COMPENSATION ARRANGEMENTS</p>
<p>Article 2</p>
<p>General principle of price compensation</p>
<p>1. In order to take account of differences in the cost of the agricultural raw<br>materials used in the manufacture of the products specified in Table I, the<br>Agreement does not preclude the application of price compensation measu-<br>res to these products; that is the levying of variable components upon import<br>and the granting of refunds upon export.</p>
<p>2. If a Contracting Party applies internal measures which reduce the price<br>of raw materials to processing industries, these measures shall be taken into<br>account in the calculation of price compensation amounts.</p>
<p>Article 3</p>
<p>New calculation system</p>
<p>1. Subject to the conditions and specific provisions set out in Artides 4 to 9,<br>the price compensation shall be calculated on the basis of the amounts of raw<br>materials actually used in the manufacture of the product and on the basis of<br>jointly confirmed reference prices.</p>
<p>2. Unless otherwise provided in Article 1 of Appendix 1, the Contracting<br>Parties shall not levy customs duties or other fixed amounts on imported<br>goods which are subject to the system referred to in paragraph 1.</p>
<p>3. The list of raw materials for which each Contracting Party may apply price<br>compensation is established in Appendix 2. The procedure for the amend-<br>ment of the list is established in Appendix 3.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol3</p>
<p>Article 4</p>
<p>Declaration of raw materials</p>
<p>1. Whenever, in connection with the importation, a declaration of raw mate-<br>rials used in the production process is submitted to the authorities of the im-<br>porting State, these authorities shall, unless they have reasonable doubt as<br>to the accuracy of the information in the declaration, calculate the variable<br>component in proportion to the net weight of the product presented for clea-<br>rance and the amounts of raw materials indicated in the declaration.</p>
<p>2. Rules concerning the declarations to be used and procedures for their<br>submission are established in Appendix 4.</p>
<p>Article 5</p>
<p>Verification of declarations</p>
<p>1. The Contracting Parties shall assist each other in verifying the accuracy<br>of the declarations.</p>
<p>2. The details of the verification procedure of the declarations are establis-<br>hed in Appendix 5.</p>
<p>Article 6</p>
<p>Reference prices</p>
<p>1. Contracting Parties shall notify to the EEA Joint Committee the prices<br>of raw materials for which price compensation measures are applied. The<br>prices which are notified shall reflect the actual price situation in the territory<br>of the Contracting Party. They shall be the prices normally paid at the Whole-<br>sale or the manufacturing stage by processing industries. If an agricultural<br>raw material is available to the processing industry, or to a part of it, at a<br>price lower than the one otherwise ruling on the domestic market, the notifi-<br>cation shall be adjusted accordingly.</p>
<p>2. The EEA Joint Committee shall on the basis of the notifications periodi-<br>cally confirm the reference prices to be used in the calculation of price com-<br>pensation amounts.</p>
<p>3. Details of the reference prices to be used, the notification system and the<br>procedures for the confirmation of the reference prices are established in<br>Appendix 6.</p>
<p>Article 7</p>
<p>Coefficients</p>
<p>1. When converting amounts of raw materials concerned into quantities of<br>raw materials for which there is a reference price confirmed, the Contracting<br>Parties shall use agreed coefficients.</p>
<p>2. A list of the coefficients to be applied is provided for in Appendix 7.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol3</p>
<p>54</p>
<p>Article 8</p>
<p>Difference between the reference prices</p>
<p>For each of the raw materials concerned, the price compensation amount<br>shall not exceed the difference between the domestic reference price and the<br>lowest of the reference prices in any of the Contracting Parties.</p>
<p>Article 9</p>
<p>Limit to price compensation amounts</p>
<p>A Contracting Party shall not levy on a product coming from another Cont-<br>racting Party variable price compensation components higher than the cus-<br>toms duty or fixed amount which it applied on 1 January 1992 to the product<br>concerned when coming from the Contracting Party in question. This limit<br>also applies when the customs duty or fixed amount was administered<br>through a tariff quota, but not in cases where, in addition to the customs duty<br>or fixed amount, the product concerned was subject to a price compensation<br>measure on 1 January 1992.</p>
<h2>CHAPTER III</h2>
<p>OTHER PROVISIONS</p>
<p>Article 10</p>
<p>Non-application of Chapter II to Table II products</p>
<p>1. The provisions of Chapter II shall not apply to products listed in Table II.<br>In particular, with respect to these products, the Contracting Parties may not<br>levy customs duties on imports or charges having equivalent effect, including<br>variable components, or grant refunds upon export.</p>
<p>2. As regards the products referred to in paragraph 1, special arrangements<br>concerning customs duties on imports and other fixed amounts are set out in<br>Article 2 of Appendix 1.</p>
<p>Article 11</p>
<p>Application of Protocol No.2</p>
<p>In so far as trade between an EFTA State and the Community in a product<br>covered by the respective Table of Protocol No.2 of the Free Trade Agree-<br>ment is concerned and without prejudice to the provision of Article 6 of Ap-<br>pendix 1 to this Protocol, the provisions of the Protocol No.2 and Protocol<br>No.3 of the respective Free Trade Agreement as well as all other relevant<br>provisions of the Free Trade Agreement shall apply:</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;if the product is listed in Table I but the conditions for the applica-<br>tion of the system set out in Artides 3 to 9 are not fulfilled, or</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;if the product falls within HS Chapters 1 to 24 but is not listed in<br>Table I or II, or</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;if the product is listed in Protocol 2 of this Agreement.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 3</p>
<p>55</p>
<p>Article 12</p>
<p>Transparency</p>
<p>1. The Contracting Parties shall make available to the EEA Joint Commit-<br>tee as soon as possible and at the latest two weeks after their entry into force,<br>full details of any price compensation measures applied on the basis of the<br>system set out in Artides 3 to 9. Any Contracting Party may request an ex-<br>amination of such measures in the light of the foregoing provisions within<br>the EEA Joint Committee.</p>
<p>2. In case a Contracting Party applies, autonomously or on contractual ba-<br>sis, to products not listed in Table I or to products listed in that Table but<br>coming from third countries, a system similar to that set out in Artides 3 to<br>9, it shall inform the EEA Joint Committee.</p>
<p>3. The Contracting Parties shall also inform the EEA Joint Committee of<br>internal measures which reduce the price of raw materials to processing indu-<br>stries.</p>
<p>4. Any Contracting Party may request a discussion in the EEA Joint Com-<br>mittee on the systems and measures referred to in paragraphs 2 and 3.</p>
<p>Article 13</p>
<p>Country-specific arrangements</p>
<p>Artides 4 to 6 of Appendix 1 contain specific arrangements concerning Aust-<br>ria, Finland, Iceland and Norway.</p>
<p>Article 14</p>
<p>Reviews</p>
<p>The Contracting Parties shall review at two-yearly intervals the development<br>of their trade in processed agricultural products. A first review shall be held<br>before the end of 1993. In the light of these reviews the Contracting Parties<br>will decide on a possible extension of the product coverage of the Protocol<br>as well as on a possible abolition of the remaining customs duties and other<br>charges referred to in Artides 1 and 2 of Appendix 1.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol3</p>
<p>56</p>

<p>Article 3</p>
<p>1. The basic duties to which the successive reductions provided for in Artic-<br>les 1 and 2 are to be applied shall, for each product, be the duties actually<br>applied by a Contracting Party on 1 January 1992 to products coming from<br>the other Contracting Parties. If, after 1 January 1992, any tariff reductions<br>resulting from the multilateral trade negotiations of the Uruguay Round be-<br>come applicable, such reduced duties shall be used as the basic duties.</p>
<p>2. The reduced duties shall be applied by rounding down to the first decimal<br>place by deleting the second decimal.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol3</p>
<p>Article 4</p>
<p>1. With regard to Finland, the provisions of Article 9 of the Protocol shall<br>not apply to the products falling within HS Headings 15.17 and 20.07.</p>
<p>2. With regard to Norway, the provisions of Article 9 of the Protocol shall<br>not apply to the products falling within HS Headings 20.07, 20.08 and 21.04.</p>
<p>Article 5</p>
<p>1. With regard to Iceland, the provisions of the Protocol shall not apply to<br>the following products:</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol3</p>

<p>more than 15% by weight of butter or other milkfat</p>

<p>2. With regard to Iceland the limitation, foreseen in Article 9 of the Proto-<br>col, of price compensation amounts levied on imports shall not apply to Ice-<br>land for products falling within HS Headings 04.03, 15.17, 18.06, 19.01,<br>19.02, 19.05, 20.07, 21.03 and 21.04.</p>
<p>However, the amounts of import charges levied at the border shall not in<br>any case exceed the level applied by Iceland in 1991 to imports coming from<br>any Contracting Party.</p>
<p>Article 6</p>
<p>1. With regard to Austria, Article 16 of the Agreement shall be applicable<br>to products falling within HS Heading 22.08 at the latest from 1 January<br>1996. The licensing system applied by Austria to these products shall, howe-<br>ver, be liberalized and licenses granted automatically from 1 January 1993.</p>
<p>Austria shall progressively eliminate during the period 1 January 1993 to 1<br>January 1996, in accordance with the following timetable, the customs duties<br>levied at the border on spirituous beverages and undenatured ethyl alcohol<br>of an alcoholic strength by volume of less than 80% vol., falling within HS<br>Heading 22.08:</p>
<p>(a) on 1 January 1993 the customs duty actually applied on 1 January<br>1991 shall be reduced by 15%,</p>
<p>(b) a further reduction of 15 % shall be made on 1 January 1994,</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;a further reduction of 30% shall be made on 1 January 1995, and</p>
<p>(d) a final reduction of 40% shall be made on 1 January 1996.</p>
<p>The reduced duties shall be applied by rounding down to the first decimal<br>place by deleting the second decimal.</p>
<p>Notwithstanding the above, Austria will, taking into account the tariff<br>concessions granted to the European Community in the trade arrangement</p>
<p>59</p>
