<p>71</p>
<h1>TITLE I</h1>
<h2>GENERAL PROVISIONS</h2>
<p>Article 1</p>
<p>Definitions</p>
<p>For the purposes of this Protocol:</p>
<p>(a) “manufacture” means any kind of working or processing including as-<br>sembly or specific operations;</p>
<p>(b) “material” means any ingredient, raw material, component or part, etc.,<br>used in the manufacture of the product;</p>
<p>(c) “product” means the product being manufactured, even if it is intended<br>for later use in another manufacturing operation;</p>
<p>(d) “goods” means both materials and products;</p>
<p>(e) “customs value” means the value as determined in accordance with the<br>Agreement on implementation of Article VII of the General Agreement on<br>Tariffs and Trade, done at Geneva on 12 April 1979;</p>
<p>(f) “ex-works price” means the price paid for the product ex works to the<br>manufacturer in the EEA in whose undertaking the last working or proces-<br>sing is carried out or to the person in the EEA who arranged for the last<br>working or processing to be carried out outside the EEA, provided the price<br>includes the value of all the materials used, minus any internal taxes which<br>are, or may be, repaid when the product obtained is exported;</p>
<p>(g) “value of materials” means the customs value at the time of importation<br>of the non-originating materials used, or, if this is not known and cannot be<br>ascertained, the first ascertainable price paid for the materials in the EEA;</p>
<p>(h) “value of originating materials” means the value of such materials as defi-<br>ned in subparagraph (g) applied mutatis mutandis;</p>
<p>(i) “chapters” and “headings” means the chapters and the headings (four-<br>digit codes) used in the nomenclature which makes up the Harmonized Com-<br>modity Description and Coding System, referred to in this Protocol as “the<br>Harmonized System” or “HS”;</p>
<p>(j) “classified” refers to the classification of a product or material under a<br>particular heading;</p>
<p>(k) “consignment” means products which are either sent simultaneously<br>from one exporter to one consignee or covered by a single transport docu-<br>ment covering their shipment from the exporter to the consignee or, in the<br>absence of such a document, by a single invoice.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>72</p>
<h1>TITLE II</h1>
<h2>DEFINITION OF THE CONCEPT OF “ORIGINATING<br>PRODUCTS”</h2>
<p>Article 2</p>
<p>Origin criteria</p>
<p>1. A product shall be considered to be originating in the EEA within the<br>meaning of this Agreement if it has been either wholly obtained or suffi-<br>ciently worked or processed in the EEA. For this purpose, the territories of<br>the Contracting Parties, including the territorial waters, to which this Agree-<br>ment applies, shall be considered as a single territory.</p>
<p>2. Notwithstanding paragraph 1, the territory of the Republic of Austria<br>shall, until 1 January 1997, be excluded from that of the EEA for the purpose<br>of determining the origin of the products referred to in Appendix VIII and<br>such products shall only be considered to be originating in the EEA if they<br>have been either wholly obtained or sufficiently worked or processed in the<br>territories of the other Contracting Parties.</p>
<p>3. The products referred to in Appendix VII shall be temporarily excluded<br>from the scope of application of this Protocol. Nevertheless, the provisions<br>in Titles IV to VI shall apply mutatis mutandis to these products.</p>
<p>Article 3</p>
<p>Wholly obtained products</p>
<p>1. The following shall be considered as wholly obtained in the EEA:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;mineral products extracted from its soil or from its seabed;</p>
<p>(b) vegetable products harvested therein;</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;live animals born and raised therein;</p>
<p>(d) &nbsp;products from live animals raised therein;</p>
<p>(e) &nbsp;products obtained by hunting or fishing conducted therein;</p>
<p>(f) &nbsp;products of sea fishing and other products taken from the sea outside<br>the territorial waters of the Contracting Parties by their vessels;</p>
<p>(g) &nbsp;products made aboard factory ships of the Contracting Parties exclu-<br>sively from products referred to in subparagraph (f);</p>
<p>(h) &nbsp;used artides collected there fit only for the recovery of raw mate-<br>rials, including used tyres fit only for retreading or for use as waste;</p>
<p>(i) &nbsp;waste and scrap resulting from manufacturing operations conducted<br>therein;</p>
<p>Q) goods produced there exclusively from the products specified in sub-<br>paragraphs (a) to (i).</p>
<p>2. The terms “their vessels” and “factory ships of the Contracting Parties” in<br>paragraphs l(f) and (g) shall apply only to vessels and factory ships:</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>(a) which are registered or recorded in an EC Member State or an<br>EFTA State;</p>
<p>73</p>
<p>(b) which sail under the flag of an EC Member State or an EFTA State;</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;which are owned to an extent of at least 50 per cent by nationals of</p>
<p>EC Member States or EFTA States, or by a company with its head<br>Office in one of these States, of which the manager or managers,<br>Chairman of the Board of Directors or the Supervisory Board, and<br>the majority of the members of such boards are nationals of EC<br>Member States or EFTA States and of which, in addition, in the case<br>of partnerships or limited companies, at least half the Capital belongs<br>to those States or to public bodies or nationals of the said States;</p>
<p>(d) of which the master and officers are nationals of EC Member States<br>or EFTA States; and</p>
<p>(e) of which at least 75 per cent of the crew are nationals of EC Member<br>States or EFTA States.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>Article 4</p>
<p>Sufficiently worked or processed products</p>
<p>1. For the purposes of Article 2, products which are not wholly obtained in<br>the EEA are considered to be sufficiently worked or processed there when<br>the conditions set out in the list in Appendix II are fulfilled.</p>
<p>These conditions indicate, for all products covered by the Agreement, the<br>working or processing which must be carried out on the non-originating ma-<br>terials used in the manufacture of these products, and apply only in relation<br>to such materials. Accordingly, it follows that if a product, which has acqui-<br>red originating status by fulfilling the conditions set out in the list for that<br>product, is used in the manufacture of another product, the conditions appli-<br>cable to the product in which it is incorporated do not apply to it, and no<br>account shall be taken of the non-originating materials which may have been<br>used in its manufacture.</p>
<p>2. Notwithstanding paragraph 1 and except as provided in Article 11(4), non-<br>originating materials which, according to the conditions set out in the list for<br>a given product, should not be used in the manufacture of this product may<br>nevertheless be used, provided that:</p>
<p>(a) their total value does not exceed 10 per cent of the ex-works price<br>of the product;</p>
<p>(b) where, in the list, one or several percentages are given for the maxi-<br>mum value of non-originating materials, such percentages are not<br>exceeded through the application of this paragraph.</p>
<p>This paragraph shall not apply to products falling within Chapters 50 to 63<br>of the Harmonized System.</p>
<p>3. Paragraphs 1 and 2 shall apply except as provided in Article 5.</p>
<p>74</p>
<p>Article 5</p>
<p>Insufficient working or processing operations</p>
<p>1. The following operations shall be considered as insufficient working or<br>processing to confer the status of originating products, whether or not the<br>requirements of Article 4 are satisfied:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;operations to ensure the preservation of products in good condition<br>during transport and storage (ventilation, spreading out, drying,<br>chilling, placing in salt, sulphur dioxide or other aqueous Solutions,<br>removal of damaged parts, and like operations);</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;simple operations consisting of removal of dust, sifting or screening,<br>sorting, classifying, matching (including the making-up of sets of ar-<br>tides), washing, painting, cutting up;</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;(i) changes of packaging and breaking up and assembly of pack-</p>
<p>ages;</p>
<p>(ii) simple placing in bottles, fläsks, bags, cases, boxes, fixing on<br>cards or boards etc., and all other simple packaging operations;</p>
<p>(d) &nbsp;affixing marks, labels and other like distinguishing signs on products<br>or their packaging;</p>
<p>(e) &nbsp;simple mixing of products, whether or not of different kinds, where<br>one or more components of the mixtures do not meet the conditions<br>laid down in this Protocol to enable them to be considered as origi-<br>nating in the EEA;</p>
<p>(f) &nbsp;simple assembly of parts to constitute a complete product;</p>
<p>(g) &nbsp;a combination of two or more operations specified in subparagraphs</p>
<p>(a) to(f);</p>
<p>(h) slaughter of animals.</p>
<p>2. All the operations carried out in the EEA on a given product shall be con-<br>sidered together when determining whether the working or processing un-<br>dergone by that product is to be regarded as insufficient within the meaning<br>of paragraph 1.</p>
<p>Article 6</p>
<p>Unit of qualification</p>
<p>1. The unit of qualification for the application of the provisions of this Protocol<br>shall be the particular product which is considered as the basic unit when de-<br>termining classification using the nomenclature of the Harmonized System.</p>
<p>Accordingly, it follows that:</p>
<p>(a) when a product composed of a group or assembly of articles is classi-<br>fied under the terms of the Harmonized System in a single heading,<br>the whole constitutes the unit of qualification;</p>
<p>(b) when a consignment consists of a number of identical products clas-<br>sified under the same heading of the Harmonized System, each pro-<br>duct must be taken individually when applying the provisions of this<br>Protocol.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>75</p>
<p>2. Where, under general rule 5 of the Harmonized System, packaging is in-<br>cluded with the product for classification purposes, it shall be included for<br>the purposes of determining origin.</p>
<p>Article 7</p>
<p>Accessories, spare parts and tools</p>
<p>Accessories, spare parts and tools dispatched with a piece of equipment,<br>machine, apparatus or vehicle, which are part of the normal equipment and<br>included in the price thereof or which are not separately invoiced, shall be<br>regarded as one with the piece of equipment, machine, apparatus or vehicle<br>in question.</p>
<p>Article 8</p>
<p>Sets</p>
<p>Sets, as defined in general rule 3 of the Harmonized System, shall be regar-<br>ded as originating when all component products are originating. Neverthe-<br>less, when a set is composed of originating and non-originating products, the<br>set as a whole shall be regarded as originating, provided that the value of the<br>non-originating products does not exceed 15 per cent of the ex-works price<br>of the set.</p>
<p>Article 9</p>
<p>Neutral elements</p>
<p>In order to determine whether a product originates in the EEA, it shall not<br>be necessary to establish whether the energy, plant and equipment as well as<br>machines and tools used to obtain such product, or whether any goods, used<br>in the course of production which do not enter and which were not intended<br>to enter into the final composition of the product, are originating or not.</p>
<h1>TITLE III</h1>
<h2>TERRITORIAL REQUIREMENTS</h2>
<p>Article 10</p>
<p>Principle of territoriality</p>
<p>The conditions set out in Title II relative to the acquisition of originating<br>status must be fulfilled without interruption in the EEA. For this purpose,<br>the acquisition of originating status shall be considered as interrupted when<br>goods which have undergone working or processing in the EEA have left the<br>EEA whether or not operations have been carried out outside this territory,<br>except as provided in Artides 11 and 12.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>76</p>
<p>Article 11</p>
<p>Working or processing carried out outside the EEA</p>
<p>1. The acquisition of originating status under the conditions set out in Title<br>II shall not be affected by working or processing carried out outside the EEA<br>on materials exported from the EEA and subsequently reimported there,<br>provided that:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;the said materials are wholly obtained in the EEA or have under-<br>gone there working or processing going beyond the insufficient ope-<br>rations listed in Article 5 prior to their exportation outside the EEA;<br>and</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;it can be demonstrated to the satisfaction of the customs authorities<br>that:</p>
<p>(i) the reimported goods result from the working or processing of<br>the exported materials; and</p>
<p>(ii) the total added value acquired outside the EEA through the ap-<br>plication of this Article does not exceed 10 per cent of the ex-<br>works price of the final product for which originating status is<br>claimed.</p>
<p>2. For the purposes of paragraph 1, the conditions set out in Title II relative<br>to the acquisition of originating status shall not apply in respect of working<br>or processing carried out outside the EEA. Nevertheless, where, in the list<br>in Appendix II, a rule giving the maximum value of all the non-originating<br>materials used is applied in determining the originating status of the final<br>product concerned, the total value of the non-originating materials used in<br>the EEA and the total added value acquired outside the EEA through the<br>application of this Article taken together shall not exceed the percentage gi-<br>ven.</p>
<p>3. For the purposes of paragraphs 1 and 2, “total added value” shall mean all<br>costs accumulated outside the EEA, including all the value of the materials<br>added there.</p>
<p>4. Paragraphs 1 and 2 shall not apply to products which do not fulfil the con-<br>ditions set out in the list in Appendix II and which can only be considered as<br>sufficiently worked or processed as a result of the application of the general<br>tolerance in Article 4 (2).</p>
<p>5. Paragraphs 1 and 2 shall not apply to products falling within Chapters 50<br>to 63 of the Harmonized System.</p>
<p>Article 12</p>
<p>Reimportation of goods</p>
<p>Goods exported from one of the Contracting Parties to a third country and<br>subsequently returned, shall be considered as never having left the EEA if<br>it can be demonstrated to the satisfaction of the customs authorities that:</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 4</p>
<p>(a) the goods returned are the same goods as those exported; and</p>
<p>77</p>
<p>(b) they have not undergone any operation beyond that necessary to<br>preserve them in good condition while in that country or while being<br>exported.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>Article 13</p>
<p>Direct transport</p>
<p>1. The preferential treatment provided for under the Agreement applies<br>only to products, satisfying the requirements of this Protocol, which are tran-<br>sported within the EEA. However, products constituting one single consign-<br>ment may be transported through territories other than that of the EEA,<br>with, should the occasion arise, trans-shipment or temporary warehousing in<br>such territories, provided that the products have remained under the surveil-<br>lance of the customs authorities in the country of transit or of warehousing<br>and that they have not undergone operations other than unloading, reloa-<br>ding or any operation designed to preserve them in good condition.</p>
<p>2. Evidence that the conditions set out in paragraph 1 have been fulfilled<br>shall be supplied to the customs authorities of the importing country by the<br>production of:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;a through bill of lading issued in the exporting country covering the<br>passage through the country of transit; or</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;a certificate issued by the customs authorities of the country of tran-<br>sit:</p>
<p>(i) &nbsp;giving an exact description of the products;</p>
<p>(ii) stating the dates of unloading and reloading of the products<br>and, where applicable, the names of the ships used; and</p>
<p>(iii) certifying the conditions under which the products remained in<br>the transit country; or</p>
<p>(c) failing these, any substantiating documents.</p>
<p>Article 14</p>
<p>Exhibitions</p>
<p>1. Products sent from one of the Contracting Parties for exhibition in a third<br>country and sold after the exhibition for importation in another Contracting<br>Party shall benefit on importation from the provisions of the Agreement on<br>condition that the products meet the requirements of this Protocol entitling<br>them to be recognized as originating in the EEA and provided that it is<br>shown to the satisfaction of the customs authorities that:</p>
<p>(a) an exporter has consigned these products from one of the Contrac-<br>ting Parties to the country in which the exhibition is held and has<br>exhibited them there;</p>
<p>(b) the products have been sold or otherwise disposed of by that expor-<br>ter to a person in another Contracting Party;</p>
<p>78</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;the products have been consigned during the exhibition or immedia-<br>tely thereafter to the latter Contracting Party in the State in which<br>they were sent for exhibition; and</p>
<p>(d) the products have not, since they were consigned for exhibition,<br>been used for any purpose other than demonstration at the exhibi-<br>tion.</p>
<p>2. A proof of origin must be issued or made out in accordance with the provi-<br>sions of Title V and submitted to the customs authorities of the importing<br>country in the normal manner. The name and address of the exhibition must<br>be indicated thereon. Where necessary, additional documentary evidence of<br>the nature of the products and the conditions under which they have been<br>exhibited may be required.</p>
<p>3. Paragraph 1 shall apply to any trade, industrial, agricultural or crafts exhi-<br>bition, fair or similar public show or display which is not organized for pri-<br>vate purposes in shops or business premises with a view to the sale of foreign<br>products, and during which the products remain under customs control.</p>
<h1>TITLE IV</h1>
<h2>DRAWBACK OR EXEMPTION</h2>
<p>Article 15</p>
<p>Prohibition of drawback of, or exemption from, customs duties</p>
<p>1. Non-originating materials used in the manufacture of products originating<br>in the EEA within the meaning of this Protocol for which a proof of origin<br>is issued or made out in accordance with the provisions of Title V shall not<br>be subject in any of the Contracting Parties to drawback of, or exemption<br>from, customs duties of whatever kind.</p>
<p>2. The prohibition in paragraph 1 shall apply to any arrangement for refund,<br>remission or non-payment, partial or complete, of customs duties or charges<br>having an equivalent effect, applicable in any of the Contracting Parties to<br>materials used in the manufacture, where such refund, remission or non-pay-<br>ment applies, expressly or in effect, when products obtained from the said<br>materials are exported and not when they are retained for home use in this<br>Contracting Party.</p>
<p>3. The exporter of products covered by a proof of origin shall be prepared to<br>submit at any time, upon request from the customs authorities, all appro-<br>priate documents proving that no drawback has been obtained in respect of<br>the non-originating materials used in the manufacture of the products con-<br>cerned and that all customs duties or charges having equivalent effect appli-<br>cable to such materials have actually been paid.</p>
<p>4. The provisions of paragraphs 1 to 3 shall also apply in respect of packaging<br>within the meaning of Article 6(2), accessories, spare parts and tools within<br>the meaning of Article 7 and products in a set within the meaning of Article<br>8 when such items are non-originating.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 4</p>
<p>5. The provisions of paragraphs 1 to 4 shall apply only in respect of materials<br>which are of the kind to which the Agreement applies. Furthermore, they<br>shall not preclude the application by the Contracting Parties of price com-<br>pensation measures for agricultural products applicable upon export in ac-<br>cordance with the provisions of the Agreement.</p>
<h1>TITLE V</h1>
<h2>PROOF OF ORIGIN</h2>
<p>Article 16</p>
<p>General requirements</p>
<p>1. Originating products within the meaning of this Protocol shall, on impor-<br>tation into one of the Contracting Parties, benefit from the Agreement upon<br>submission of either:</p>
<p>(a) a movement certificate EUR.l, a specimen of which appears in<br>Appendix III; or</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;in the cases specified in Article 21(1), a declaration, the text of which<br>appears in Appendix IV, given by the exporter on an invoice, a deli-<br>very note or any other commercial document which describes<br>the products concerned in sufficient detail to enable them to be iden-<br>tified (hereinafter referred to as the “invoice declaration”).</p>
<p>2. Notwithstanding paragraph 1, originating products within the meaning of<br>this Protocol shall, in the cases specified in Article 26, benefit from the Ag-<br>reement without it being necessary to submit any of the documents referred<br>to above.</p>
<p>Article 17</p>
<p>Procedure for the issue of a movement certificate EUR.l</p>
<p>1. A movement certificate EUR.l shall be issued by the customs authorities<br>of the exporting country on application having been made in writing by the<br>exporter or, under the exporter’s responsibility, by his authorized represen-<br>tative.</p>
<p>2. For this purpose, the exporter or his authorized representative shall fill<br>out both the movement certificate EUR.l and the application form, speci-<br>mens of which appear in Appendix III.</p>
<p>These forms shall be completed in one of the languages in which the Ag-<br>reement is drawn up, in accordance with the provisions of the domestic law<br>of the exporting country. If they are handwritten, they shall be completed in<br>ink in printed characters. The description of the products must be given in<br>the box reserved for this purpose without leaving any blank lines. Where the<br>box is not completely filled a horizontal line must be drawn below the last<br>line of the description, the empty space being crossed through.</p>
<p>3. The exporter applying for the issue of a movement certificate EUR.l shall</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 4</p>
<p>80</p>
<p>be prepared to submit at any time, at the request of the customs authorities<br>of the exporting country where the movement certificate EUR.l is issued,<br>all appropriate documents proving the originating status of the products con-<br>cerned as well as the fulfilment of the other requirements of this Protocol.</p>
<p>4. A movement certificate EUR.l shall be issued by the customs authorities<br>of an EC Member State or an EFTA State if the products concerned can be<br>considered as products originating in the EEA and fulfil the other require-<br>ments of this Protocol.</p>
<p>5. The issuing customs authorities shall take any steps necessary to verify the<br>originating status of the products and the fulfilment of the other require-<br>ments of this Protocol. For this purpose, they shall have the right to call for<br>any evidence and to carry out any inspection of the exporter’s accounts or<br>any other check which they consider appropriate.</p>
<p>The issuing customs authorities shall also ensure that the forms referred<br>to in paragraph 2 are duly completed. In particular, they shall check whether<br>the space reserved for the description of the products has been completed in<br>such a manner as to exclude all possibility of fraudulent additions.</p>
<p>6. The date of issue of the movement certificate EUR.l shall be indicated in<br>the part of the certificate reserved for the customs authorities.</p>
<p>7. A movement certificate EUR.l shall be issued by the customs authorities<br>of the exporting country when the products to which it relätes are exported.<br>It shall be made available to the exporter as soon as actual exportation has<br>been effected or ensured.</p>
<p>Article 18</p>
<p>Movement certificates EUR.l issued retrospectively</p>
<p>1. Notwithstanding Article 17(7), amovement certificate EUR.l may excep-<br>tionally be issued after exportation of the products to which it relätes if:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;it was not issued at the time of exportation because of errors or invo-<br>luntary omissions or special circumstances; or</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;it is demonstrated to the satisfaction of the customs authorities that<br>a movement certificate EUR.l was issued but was not accepted at<br>importation for technical reasons.</p>
<p>2. For the implementation of paragraph 1, the exporter must indicate in his<br>application the place and date of exportation of the products to which the<br>movement certificate EUR.l relätes, and State the reasons for his request.</p>
<p>3. The customs authorities may issue a movement certificate EUR.l retro-<br>spectively only after verifying that the information supplied in the exporter’s<br>application agrees with that in the corresponding file.</p>
<p>4. Movement certificates EUR.l issued retrospectively must be endorsed<br>with one of the following phrases:</p>
<p>“EXPEDIDO A POSTERIORI”, “UDSTEDT EFTERF0L-</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>6 Riksdagen 1991192. 1 saml. Nr 170. Bil. 15</p>
<p>GENDE”, “NACHTRÄGLICH AUSGESTELLT”, “EKAOAEN EK<br>TON YNTEMIIN, “ISSUED RETROSPECTIVELY”, “DELIVRE<br>A POSTERIORI”, “RILASCIATO A POSTERIORI”, “AFGEGE-<br>VEN A POSTERIORI”, “EMITIDO A POSTERIORI”, “UTGEFID<br>EFTIR Ä’, “UTSTEDT SENERE”, “ANNETTU JÄLKIKÄTEEN”,<br>“UTFÄRDAT I EFTERHAND”.</p>
<p>5. The endorsement referred to in paragraph 4 shall be inserted in the “Re-<br>marks” box of the movement certificate EUR.l.</p>
<p>Article 19</p>
<p>Issue of a duplicate movement certificate EUR.l</p>
<p>1. In the event of theft, loss or destruction of a movement certificate EUR.l,<br>the exporter may apply to the customs authorities which issued it for a dupli-<br>cate made out on the basis of the export documents in their possession.</p>
<p>2. The duplicate issued in this way must be endorsed with one of the follo-<br>wing words:</p>
<p>“DUPLICADO”, “DUPLIKAT”, “DUPLIKAT”, “ANTITMA&lt;I&gt;O”,<br>“DUPLICATE”, “DUPLICATA”, “DUPLICATO”, “DUPLICAAT”,<br>“SEGUNDA VIA”, “EFTIRRIT”, “DUPLIKAT”, “KAKSOISKAP-<br>PALE”, “DUPLIKAT”.</p>
<p>3. The endorsement referred to in paragraph 2 shall be inserted in the “Re-<br>marks” box of the duplicate movement certificate EUR.l.</p>
<p>4. The duplicate, which must bear the date of issue of the original movement<br>certificate EUR.l, shall take effect as from that date.</p>
<p>Article 20</p>
<p>Issue of movement certificates EUR.l on the basis of<br>proof of origin issued or made out previously</p>
<p>When products constituting a single consignment covered by a movement<br>certificate EUR.l or an invoice declaration are placed under the control of<br>a customs office in an EC Member State or an EFTA State, it shall be pos-<br>sible to replace the original proof of origin by one or more movement certifi-<br>cates EUR.l issued by this customs office for the purpose of sending all or<br>some of these products to other customs offices whether or not located in the<br>same EC Member State or EFTA State.</p>
<p>Article 21</p>
<p>Conditions for making out an invoice declaration</p>
<p>1. An invoice declaration as referred to in Article 16(l)(b) may be made out:</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>(a) by an approved exporter within the meaning of Article 22;</p>
<p>(b) by any exporter for any consignment consisting of one or more pack-</p>
<p>82</p>
<p>ages containing originating products whose total value does not ex-<br>ceed ECU 6 000.</p>
<p>2. An invoice declaration may be made out if the products concerned can be<br>considered as products originating in the EEA and fulfil the other require-<br>ments of this Protocol.</p>
<p>3. The exporter making out an invoice declaration shall be prepared to sub-<br>mit at any time, at the request of the customs authorities of the exporter’s<br>country, all appropriate documents proving the originating status of the pro-<br>ducts concerned as well as the fulfilment of the other requirements of this<br>Protocol.</p>
<p>4. An invoice declaration shall be made out by the exporter by typing, stam-<br>ping or printing on the invoice, the delivery note or another commercial do-<br>cument, the declaration, the text of which appears in Appendix IV, using<br>one of the linguistic versions set out in that Appendix in accordance with the<br>provisions of the domestic law of the exporting country. The declaration may<br>also be handwritten; in such a case, it shall be written in ink in printed charac-<br>ters.</p>
<p>5. Invoice declarations shall bear the original signature of the exporter in<br>manuscript.</p>
<p>However, an approved exporter within the meaning of Article 22 shall not<br>be required to sign such declarations provided that he gives the customs aut-<br>horities of the exporting country a written undertaking that he accepts full<br>responsibility for any invoice declaration which identifies him as if it had<br>been signed in manuscript by him.</p>
<p>6. An invoice declaration may be made out by the exporter when the pro-<br>ducts to which it relätes are exported or subsequently. If the invoice declara-<br>tion is made out after the products to which it relätes have been declared to<br>the customs authorities in the importing country, this invoice declaration<br>must bear a reference to the documents already submitted to these authori-<br>ties.</p>
<p>Article 22</p>
<p>Approved exporter</p>
<p>1. The customs authorities of the exporting country may authorize any ex-<br>porter, hereinafter referred to as “approved exporter”, who makes frequent<br>shipments of products under the Agreement, and who offers to the satisfac-<br>tion of the customs authorities all guarantees necessary to verify the origina-<br>ting status of those products as well as the fulfilment of the other require-<br>ments of this Protocol, to make out invoice declarations irrespective of the<br>value of the products concerned.</p>
<p>2. The customs authorities may grant the status of approved exporter subject<br>to any conditions which they consider appropriate.</p>
<p>3. The customs authorities shall grant to the approved exporter a customs<br>authorization number which shall appear on the invoice declaration.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 4</p>
<p>4. The customs authorities shall monitor the use of the authorization by the<br>approved exporter.</p>
<p>5. The customs authorities may withdraw the authorization at any time. They<br>shall do so where the approved exporter no longer offers the guarantees re-<br>ferred to in paragraph 1, does not fulfil the conditions referred to in para-<br>graph 2 or otherwise makes an incorrect use of the authorization.</p>
<p>Article 23</p>
<p>Validity of proof of origin</p>
<p>1. A movement certificate EUR.l shall be valid for four months from the<br>date of issue in the exporting country, and must be submitted within the said<br>period to the customs authorities of the importing country.</p>
<p>An invoice declaration shall be valid for four months from the date it was<br>made out by the exporter and must be submitted within the said period to<br>the customs authorities of the importing country.</p>
<p>2. Movement certificates EUR.l and invoice declarations which are submit-<br>ted to the customs authorities of the importing country after the final date<br>for presentation specified in paragraph 1 may be accepted for the purpose of<br>applying preferential treatment, where the failure to submit these docu-<br>ments by the final date set is due to reasons of force majeure or exceptional<br>circumstances.</p>
<p>3. In other cases of belated presentation, the customs authorities of the im-<br>porting country may accept the movement certificates EUR. 1 or invoice dec-<br>larations where the products have been submitted to them before the said<br>final date.</p>
<p>Article 24</p>
<p>Submission of proof of origin</p>
<p>Movement certificates EUR.l and invoice declarations shall be submitted<br>to the customs authorities of the importing country in accordance with the<br>procedures applicable in that country. The said authorities may require a<br>translation of a movement certificate EUR.l or an invoice declaration. They<br>may also require the import declaration to be accompanied by a statement<br>from the importer to the effect that the products meet the conditions requi-<br>red for the implementation of the Agreement.</p>
<p>Article 25</p>
<p>Importation by instalments</p>
<p>Where, at the request of the importer and on the conditions laid down by the<br>customs authorities of the importing country, dismantled or non-assembled<br>products within the meaning of general rule 2 (a) of the Harmonized System<br>falling within Sections XVI and XVII or headings Nos 73.08 and 94.06 of the<br>Harmonized System are imported by instalments, a single proof of origin for</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>84</p>
<p>such products shall be submitted to the customs authorities upon importa-<br>tion of the first instalment.</p>
<p>Article 26</p>
<p>Exemptions from formal proof of origin</p>
<p>1. Products sent as small packages from private persons to private persons or<br>forming part of travellers’ personal luggage shall be admitted as originating<br>products without requiring the submission of a formal proof of origin, provi-<br>ded that such products are not imported by way of trade and have been dec-<br>lared as meeting the requirements of this Protocol and where there is no<br>doubt as to the veracity of such declaration. In the case of products sent by<br>post, this declaration can be made on the customs declaration C2/CP3 or on<br>a sheet of paper annexed to that document.</p>
<p>2. Imports which are occasional and consist solely of products for the perso-<br>nal use of the recipients or travellers or their families shall not be considered<br>as imports by way of trade if it is evident from the nature and quantity of the<br>products that no commercial purpose is in view.</p>
<p>3. Furthermore, the total value of these products must not exceed »CU 500<br>in the case of small packages or ECU 1200 in the case of products forming<br>part of travellers’ personal luggage.</p>
<p>Article 27</p>
<p>Supplier’s declaration</p>
<p>1. When a movement certificate EUR.l is issued, or an invoice declaration<br>is made out, in one of the Contracting Parties for originating products, in the<br>manufacture of which goods coming from other Contracting Parties which<br>have undergone working or processing in the EEA without having obtained<br>preferential originating status have been used, account shall be taken of sup-<br>plier’s declarations given for these goods in accordance with this Article.</p>
<p>2. The supplier’s declaration referred to in paragraph 1 shall serve as the evi-<br>dence of the working or processing undergone in the EEA by the goods con-<br>cerned for the purpose of determining whether the products in the manufac-<br>ture of which these goods are used, can be considered as products originating<br>in the EEA and fulfil the other requirements of this Protocol.</p>
<p>3. A separate supplier’s declaration shall, except in cases provided for in pa-<br>ragraph 4, be made out by the supplier for each consignment of goods in the<br>form prescribed in Appendix V on a sheet of paper annexed to the invoice,<br>the delivery note or any other commercial document describing the goods<br>concerned in sufficient detail to enable them to be identified.</p>
<p>4. Where a supplier regularly supplies a particular customer with goods for<br>which the working or processing undergone in the EEA is expected to re-<br>main constant for considerable periods of time, he may provide a single sup-<br>plier’s declaration to cover subsequent consignments of those goods, herei-<br>nafter referred to as a “long-term supplier’s declaration”.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>85</p>
<p>A long-term supplier’s declaration may normally be valid for a period of<br>up to one year from the date of making out the declaration. The customs<br>authorities of the country where the declaration is made out lay down the<br>conditions under which longer periods may .be used.</p>
<p>The long-term supplier’s declaration shall be made out by the supplier in<br>the form prescribed in Appendix VI, and shall describe the goods concerned<br>in sufficient detail to enable them to be identified. It shall be provided to the<br>customer concerned before supplying him with the first consignment of<br>goods covered by this declaration or together with his first consignment.</p>
<p>The supplier shall inform his customer immediately if the long-term sup-<br>plier’s declaration is no longer applicable to the goods supplied.</p>
<p>5. The supplier’s declaration referred to in paragraphs 3 and 4 shall be typed<br>or printed using one of the languages in which the Agreement is drawn up,<br>in accordance with the provisions of the domestic law of the country where<br>it is made out, and shall bear the original signature of the supplier in manusc-<br>ript. The declaration may also be handwritten; in such a case, it shall be writ-<br>ten in ink in printed characters.</p>
<p>6. The supplier making out a declaration must be prepared to submit at any<br>time, at the request of the customs authorities of the country where the dec-<br>laration is made out, all appropriate documents proving that the information<br>given on this declaration is correct.</p>
<p>Article 28</p>
<p>Supporting documents</p>
<p>The documents referred to in Artides 17(3), 21(3) and 27(6) used for the<br>purpose of proving that products covered by a movement certificate EUR.l<br>or an invoice declaration can be considered as products originating in the<br>EEA and fulfil the other requirements of this Protocol and that the informa-<br>tion given in a supplier’s declaration is correct may consist inter alia of the<br>following:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;direct evidence of the processes carried out by the exporter or sup-<br>plier to obtain the goods concerned, contained for example in his<br>accounts or internal bookkeeping;</p>
<p>(b) documents proving the originating status of materials used in the<br>manufacture of the goods concerned issued or made out in the Cont-<br>racting Party where these documents are used in accordance with the<br>domestic law of that Contracting Party;</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;documents proving the working or processing undergone in the<br>EEA by materials used in the manufacture of the goods concerned<br>issued or made out in the Contracting Party where these documents<br>are used in accordance with the domestic law of that Contracting<br>Party;</p>
<p>(d) movement certificates EUR.l or invoice declarations proving the<br>originating status of materials used in the manufacture of the goods<br>concerned issued or made out in other Contracting Parties in accor-</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>86</p>
<p>dance with this Protocol;</p>
<p>(e) supplier’s declarations proving the working or processing undergone<br>in the EEA by materials used in the manufacture of the goods con-<br>cerned made out in other Contracting Parties in accordance with this<br>Protocol;</p>
<p>(f) &nbsp;appropriate evidence concerning working or processing undergone<br>outside the EEA by application of Article 11, proving that the requi-<br>rements of this Article have been satisfied.</p>
<p>Article 29</p>
<p>Preservation of proof of origin, supplier’s declarations and supporting<br>documents</p>
<p>1. The exporter applyingfor the issue of a movement certificate EUR.l shall<br>keep for at least two years the documents referred to in Article 17(3).</p>
<p>2. The exporter making out an invoice declaration shall keep for at least two<br>years a copy of this invoice declaration as well as the documents referred to<br>in Article 21(3).</p>
<p>3. The supplier making out a supplier’s declaration shall keep for at least<br>two years copies of the declaration and of the invoice, delivery note or other<br>commercial document to which this declaration is annexed as well as the do-<br>cuments referred to in Article 27(6).</p>
<p>The supplier making out a long-term supplier’s declaration shall keep for<br>at least two years copies of the declaration and of all the invoices, delivery<br>notes or other commercial documents concerning goods covered by that dec-<br>laration sent to the customer concerned, as well as the documents referred<br>to in Article 27(6). This period shall begin from the date of expiry of validity<br>of the long-term supplier’s declaration.</p>
<p>4. The customs authorities of the exporting country issuing a movement cer-<br>tificate EUR.l shall keep for at least two years the application form referred<br>to in Article 17(2).</p>
<p>5. The customs authorities of the importing country shall keep for at least<br>two years the movement certificates EUR.l and the invoice declarations<br>submitted to them.</p>
<p>Article 30</p>
<p>Discrepancies and formal errors</p>
<p>1. The discovery of slight discrepancies between the statements made in a<br>movement certificate EUR.l, or in an invoice declaration and those made<br>in the documents submitted to the customs office for the purpose of carrying<br>out the formalities for importing the products shall not ipso facto render the<br>movement certificate EUR.l, or the invoice declaration null and void if it is<br>duly established that this document does correspond to the products submit-<br>ted.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>87</p>
<p>2. Obvious formal errors such as typing errors on a movement certificate<br>EUR.l, an invoice declaration or a supplier’s declaration should not cause<br>this document to be rejected if these errors are not such as to create doubts<br>concerning the correctness of the statements made in this document.</p>
<p>Article 31</p>
<p>Amounts expressed in ECU</p>
<p>1. Amounts in the national currency of the exporting country equivalent to<br>the amounts expressed in ECU shall be fixed by the exporting country and<br>communicated to the other Contracting Parties.</p>
<p>When the amounts exceed the corresponding amounts fixed by the impor-<br>ting country, the latter shall accept them if the products are invoiced in the<br>currency of the exporting country. When the products are invoiced in the<br>currency of another EC Member State or EFTA State, the importing country<br>shall recognize the amount notified by the country concerned.</p>
<p>2. Up to and including 30 April 1998, the amounts to be used in any given<br>national currency shall be the equivalent in that national currency of the<br>amounts expressed in ECU as at 1 October 1992.</p>
<p>For each successive period of five years, the amounts expressed in ECU<br>and their equivalents in the national currencies of the EC Member States<br>and the EFTA States shall be reviewed by the EEA Joint Committee on the<br>basis of the exchange rates of the ECU as at the first working day in October<br>in the year immediately preceding that five years’ period.</p>
<p>When carrying out this review, the EEA Joint Committee shall ensure that<br>there will be no decrease in the amounts to be used in any national currency<br>and shall furthermore consider the desirability of preserving the effects of<br>the limits concerned in real terms. For this purpose, it may decide to modify<br>the amounts expressed in ECU.</p>
<h1>TITLE VI</h1>
<h2>ARRANGEMENTS FOR ADMINISTRATIVE<br>COOPERATION</h2>
<p>Article 32</p>
<p>Mutual assistance</p>
<p>In order to ensure the proper application of this Protocol, the Contracting<br>Parties shall assist each other, through the competent customs administra-<br>tions, in checking the authenticity of the movement certificates EUR.l, the<br>invoice declarations and the supplier’s declarations and the correctness of<br>the information given in these documents.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 4</p>
<p>88</p>
<p>Article 33</p>
<p>Verification of proof of origin</p>
<p>1. Subsequent verifications of movement certificates EUR.l and of invoice<br>declarations shall be carried out at random or whenever the customs authori-<br>ties of the importing country have reasonable doubts as to the authenticity<br>of such documents, the originating status of the products concerned or the<br>fulfilment of the other requirements of this Protocol.</p>
<p>2. For the purposes of implementing the provisions of paragraph 1, the cus-<br>toms authorities of the importing country shall return the movement certifi-<br>cate EUR.l and the invoice, if it has been submitted, or the invoice declara-<br>tion, or a copy of these documents, to the customs authorities of the export-<br>ing country giving, where appropriate, the reasons of substance or form for<br>an inquiry.</p>
<p>They shall forward, in support of the request for subsequent verification, any<br>documents and information that have been obtained suggesting that the in-<br>formation given on the movement certificate EUR.l or the invoice declara-<br>tion is incorrect.</p>
<p>3. The verification shall be carried out by the customs authorities of the ex-<br>porting country. For this purpose, they shall have the right to call for any<br>evidence and to carry out any inspection of the exporter’s accounts or any<br>other check which they consider appropriate.</p>
<p>4. If the customs authorities of the importing country decide to suspend the<br>granting of preferential treatment to the products concerned while awaiting<br>the results of the verification, they shall offer to release the products to the<br>importer subject to any precautionary measures judged necessary.</p>
<p>5. The customs authorities requesting the verification shall be informed of<br>the results of this verification as soon as possible. These results must indicate<br>clearly whether the documents are authentic and whether the products con-<br>cerned can be considered as products originating in the EEA and fulfil the<br>other requirements of this Protocol.</p>
<p>Article 34</p>
<p>Verification of supplier’s declarations</p>
<p>1. Subsequent verifications of supplier’s declarations or long term supplier’s<br>declarations may be carried out at random or whenever the customs authori-<br>ties of the country where such declarations have been taken into account to<br>issue a movement certificate EUR.l or to make out an invoice declaration<br>have reasonable doubts as to the authenticity of the document or the correct-<br>ness of the information given in this document.</p>
<p>2. For the purposes of implementing the provisions of paragraph 1, the cus-<br>toms authorities of the above-mentioned country shall return the supplier’s<br>declaration and the invoice(s), delivery note(s) or other commercial docu-<br>ment(s) concerning goods covered by this declaration, to the customs autho-</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>89</p>
<p>rities of the country where the declaration was made out, giving, where ap-<br>propriate, the reasons of substance or form for an inquiry.</p>
<p>They shall forward, in support of the request for subsequent verification,<br>any documents and information that have been obtained suggesting that the<br>information given in the supplier’s declaration is incorrect.</p>
<p>3. The verification shall be carried out by the customs authorities of the<br>country where the supplier’s declaration was made out. For this purpose,<br>they shall have the right to call for any evidence and to carry out any inspec-<br>tion of the supplier’s accounts or any other check which they consider appro-<br>priate.</p>
<p>4. The customs authorities requesting the verification shall be informed of<br>the results of this verification as soon as possible. These results must indicate<br>clearly whether the information given in the supplier’s declaration is correct<br>and make it possible for them to determine whether and to what extent this<br>supplier’s declaration could be taken into account for issuing a movement<br>certificate EUR.l or for making out an invoice declaration.</p>
<p>Article 35</p>
<p>Dispute settlement</p>
<p>Where disputes arise in relation to the verification procedures of Artides 33<br>and 34 which cannot be settled between the customs authorities requesting<br>a verification and the customs authorities responsible for carrying out this<br>verification or where they raise a question as to the interpretation of this Pro-<br>tocol, they shall be submitted to the EEA Joint Committee.</p>
<p>Article 36</p>
<p>Penalties</p>
<p>Penalties shall be imposed on any person who draws up, or causes to be<br>drawn up, a document which contains incorrect information for the purpose<br>of obtaining a preferential treatment for products.</p>
<h1>TITLE VII</h1>
<h2>CEUTA AND MELILLA</h2>
<p>Article 37</p>
<p>Provisions applicable to Ceuta and Melilla</p>
<p>1. The term “EEA” used in this Protocol does not cover Ceuta and Melilla.<br>The term “products originating in the EEA” does not cover products origina-<br>ting in Ceuta and Melilla.</p>
<p>2. For the purpose of the application of Protocol 49 to the Agreement con-<br>cerning products originating in Ceuta and Melilla, this Protocol shall apply<br>mutatis mutandis subject to the special conditions set out in Article 38.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>Article 38</p>
<p>Special conditions</p>
<p>1. The following shall be considered as:</p>
<p>(a) products originating in Ceuta and Melilla:</p>
<p>(i) products wholly obtained in Ceuta and Melilla;</p>
<p>(ii) products obtained in Ceuta and Melilla in the manufacture of<br>which materials which are not wholly obtained there have been<br>used provided that these products have undergone sufficient<br>working or processing in Ceuta and Melilla. This condition shall<br>not apply, however, in respect of materials originating in the<br>EEA within the meaning of this Protocol.</p>
<p>(b) products originating in the EEA:</p>
<p>(i) products wholly obtained in the EEA;</p>
<p>(ii) products obtained in the EEA in the manufacture of which ma-<br>terials which are not wholly obtained there have been used pro-<br>vided that these products have undergone sufficient working or<br>processing in the EEA. This condition shall not apply, however,<br>in respect of materials originating in Ceuta and Melilla within<br>the meaning of this Protocol.</p>
<p>2. Ceuta and Melilla shall be considered as a single territory.</p>
<p>3. When a proof of origin, issued or made out in accordance with this Proto-<br>col relätes to products originating in Ceuta and Melilla, the exporter must<br>clearly indicate them by means of the symbol “CM”.</p>
<p>In the case of a movement certificate EUR.l, this shall be indicated in box<br>4 of the certificate.</p>
<p>In the case of an invoice declaration, this shall be indicated on the docu-<br>ment in which the declaration is made.</p>
<p>4. The Spanish customs authorities shall be responsible for the application<br>of this Protocol in Ceuta and Melilla.</p>
<p>5. Article 15 shall not apply to trade between Ceuta and Melilla, on the one<br>hand, and the EFTA States on the other.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 4</p>
<p>91</p>
<h1>APPENDIX I</h1>
<h2>INTRODUCTORY NOTES TO THE LIST IN<br>APPENDIX II</h2>
<p>Note 1:</p>
<p>The list sets out for all products covered by the Agreement the condi-<br>tions required for these products to be considered as sufficiently worked<br>or processed within the meaning of Article 4(1) of the Protocol.</p>
<p>Note 2:</p>
<p>2.1 The first two columns in the list describe the product obtained. The first<br>column gives the heading number or chapter number used in the Har-<br>monized System and the second column gives the description of goods<br>used in that system for that heading or chapter. For each entry in the<br>first two columns a rule is specified in columns 3 or 4. Where, in some<br>cases, the entry in the first column is preceded by an “ex”, this signifies<br>that the rules in columns 3 or 4 apply only to the part of that heading or<br>chapter as described in column 2.</p>
<p>2.2 Where several heading numbers are grouped together in column 1 or a<br>chapter number is given and the description of products in column 2 is<br>therefore given in general terms, the adj acent rules in columns 3 or 4<br>apply to all products which, under the Harmonized System, are classi-<br>fied in headings of the chapter or in any of the headings grouped toget-<br>her in column 1.</p>
<p>2.3 Where there are different rules in the list applying to different products<br>within a heading, each indent contains the description of that part of<br>the heading covered by the adjacent rules in columns 3 or 4.</p>
<p>2.4 Where, for an entry in the first two columns, a rule is specified in both<br>columns 3 and 4, the exporter may opt, as an alternative, to apply either<br>the rule set out in column 3 or that set out in column 4. If no origin rule<br>is given in column 4, the rule set out in column 3 has to be applied.</p>
<p>Note 3:</p>
<p>3.1 The provisions of Article 4(1) of the Protocol concerning products ha-<br>ving acquired originating status which are used in the manufacture of<br>other products apply regardless of whether this status has been acquired<br>inside the factory where these products are used, in another factory in<br>the same country or in another EEA country.</p>
<p>Example:</p>
<p>An engine of heading No. 84.07, for which the rule States that the<br>value of the non-originating materials which may be incorporated<br>may not exceed 40% of the ex-works price, is made from other alloy<br>Steel roughly shaped by forging of heading No. ex 72.24.</p>
<p>If this forging has been forged in the EEA froma non-originating<br>ingot, it has already acquired originating status by virtue of the rule<br>for heading No. ex 72.24 in the list. The forging can then count as<br>originating in the value calculation for the engine regardless of whet-<br>her it was produced in the same factory, in another factory in the</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>92</p>
<p>same country or in another EEA country. The value of the non-origi-<br>nating ingot is thus not taken into account when adding up the value<br>of the non-originating materials used.</p>
<p>3.2 The rule in the list represents the minimum amount of working or pro-<br>cessing required and the carrying out of more working or processing<br>also confers originating status; conversely, the carrying out of less wor-<br>king or processing cannot confer originating status. Thus if a rule provi-<br>des that non-originating material at a certain level of manufacture may<br>be used, the use of such material at an earlier stage of manufacture is<br>allowed and the use of such material at a later stage is not.</p>
<p>3.3 When a rule in the list specifies that a product may be manufactured<br>from more than one material, this means that any one or more materials<br>may be used. It does not require that all be used.</p>
<p>Example:</p>
<p>The rule for fabrics of ex Chapter 50 to Chapter 55 provides that natu-<br>ral fibres may be used and that Chemical materials, among other ma-<br>terials, may also be used. This does not mean that both have to be<br>used; it is possible to use one or the other or both.</p>
<p>3.4 Where a rule in the list specifies that a product must be manufactured<br>from a particular material, the condition obviously does not prevent the<br>use of other materials which, because of their inherent nature, cannot<br>satisfy the rule. (See also Note 6.2 below in relation to textiles).</p>
<p>Example:</p>
<p>The rule for prepared foods of heading No. 19.04 which specifically<br>excludes the use of cereals and their derivatives does not prevent the<br>use of mineral salts, Chemicals and other additives which are not pro-<br>duced from cereals.</p>
<p>However, this does not apply to products which, although they can-<br>not be manufactured from the particular material specified in the list,<br>can be produced from a material of the same nature at an earlier stage<br>of manufacture.</p>
<p>Example:</p>
<p>In the case of an article of apparel of ex Chapter 62 made from non-<br>woven materials, if the use of only non-originating yarn is allowed for<br>this class of article, it is not possible to start from non-woven cloth -<br>even if non-woven cloths cannot normally be made from yarn. In such<br>cases, the starting material would normally be at the stage before<br>yarn - that is the fibre stage.</p>
<p>3.5 Where, in a rule in the list, two percentages are given for the maximum<br>value of non-originating materials that can be used, then these percen-<br>tages may not be added together. In other words, the maximum value<br>of all the non-originating materials used may never exceed the highest<br>of the percentages given. Furthermore, the individual percentages must<br>not be exceeded in relation to the particular materials they apply to.</p>
<p>Note 4:</p>
<p>4.1 The term “natural fibres” is used in the list to refer to fibres other than</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 4</p>
<p>artificial or synthetic fibres. It is restricted to the stages before spinning<br>takes place, including waste, and, unless otherwise specified, includes<br>fibres that have been carded, combed or otherwise processed but not<br>spun.</p>
<p>4.2 The term “natural fibres” includes horsehair of heading No. 05.03, silk<br>of heading Nos. 50.02 and 50.03 as well as the wool fibres, fine or coarse<br>animal hair of heading Nos. 51.01 to 51.05, the cotton fibres of heading<br>Nos. 52.01 to 52.03 and the other vegetable fibres of heading Nos. 53.01<br>to 53.05.</p>
<p>4.3 The terms “textile pulp”, “Chemical materials” and “paper-making ma-<br>terials” are used in the list to describe the materials not classified in<br>Chapters 50 to 63, which can be used to manufacture artificial, synthetic<br>or paper fibres or yarns.</p>
<p>4.4 The term “man-made staple fibres” is used in the list to refer to synthe-<br>tic or artificial filament tow, staple fibres or waste, of heading Nos.<br>55.01 to 55.07.</p>
<p>Note 5:</p>
<p>5.1 Where for a given product in the List a reference is made to this Note,<br>the conditions set out in column 3 shall not be applied to any basic tex-<br>tile materials, used in the manufacture of this product, which, taken to-<br>gether, represent 10% or less of the total weight of all the basic textile<br>materials used. (See also Notes 5.3 and 5.4 below).</p>
<p>5.2 However, this tolerance may only be applied to mixed products which<br>have been made from two or more basic textile materials.</p>
<p>The following are the basic textile materials:</p>
<p>- silk,</p>
<p>- wool,</p>
<p>- coarse animal hair,</p>
<p>- fine animal hair,</p>
<p>- horsehair,</p>
<p>- cotton,</p>
<p>- paper-making materials and paper,</p>
<p>- flax,</p>
<p>- true hemp,</p>
<p>- jute and other textile bast fibres,</p>
<p>- sisal and other textile fibres of the genus Agave,</p>
<p>- coconut, abaca, ramie and other vegetable textile fibres,</p>
<p>- synthetic man-made filaments</p>
<p>- artificial man-made filaments</p>
<p>- synthetic man-made staple fibres,</p>
<p>- artificial man-made staple fibres.</p>
<p>Example:</p>
<p>A yarn of heading No. 52.05 made from cotton fibres of heading No.<br>52.03 and synthetic staple fibres of heading No. 55.06 is a mixed yarn.<br>Therefore, non-originating synthetic staple fibres that do not satisfy<br>the origin rules (which require manufacture from Chemical materials<br>or textile pulp) may be used up to a weight of 10% of the yarn.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 4</p>
<p>94</p>
<p>Example:</p>
<p>A woollen fabric of heading No. 51.12 made from woollen yarn of<br>heading No. 51.07 and synthetic yarn of staple fibres of heading No.<br>55.09 is a mixed fabric. Therefore synthetic yarn which does not sa-<br>tisfy the origin rules (which require manufacture from Chemical mate-<br>rials or textile pulp) or woollen yarn that does not satisfy the origin<br>rules (which require manufacture from natural fibres, not carded or<br>combed or otherwise prepared for spinning) or a combination of the<br>two may be used provided their total weight does not exceed 10 % of<br>the weight of the fabric.</p>
<p>Example:</p>
<p>Tufted textile fabric of heading No. 58.02 made from cotton yarn of<br>heading No. 52.05 and cotton fabric of heading No. 52.10 is only a<br>mixed product if the cotton fabric is itself a mixed fabric being made<br>from yarns classified in two separate headings or if the cotton yarns<br>used are themselves mixtures.</p>
<p>Example:</p>
<p>If the tufted textile fabric concerned had been made from cotton yarn<br>of heading No. 52.05 and synthetic fabric of heading No. 54.07, then,<br>obviously, the yarns used are two separate basic textile materials and<br>the tufted textile fabric is accordingly a mixed product.</p>
<p>Example:</p>
<p>A carpet with tufts made from both artificial yarns and cotton yarns<br>and with a jute backing is a mixed product because three basic textile<br>materials are used. Thus, any non-originating materials that are at a<br>later stage of manufacture than the rule allows may be used, provided<br>their total weight does not exceed 10% of the weight of the textiles<br>materials of the carpet. Thus, both the jute backing and/or the artififi-<br>cal yarns could be imported at that stage of manufacture, provided<br>the weight conditions are met.</p>
<p>5.3 In the case of products incorporating “yarn made of polyurethane seg-<br>mented with flexible segments of polyether whether or not gimped” this<br>tolerance is 20% in respect of this yarn.</p>
<p>5.4 &nbsp;In the case of products incorporating strip consisting of a core of alumi-<br>nium foil or of a core of plastic film whether or not coated with alumi-<br>nium powder, of a width not exceeding 5 mm, sandwiched by means of<br>an adhesive between two films of plastic film, this tolerance is 30% in<br>respect of this strip.</p>
<p>Note 6:</p>
<p>6.1 In the case of those textile products which are marked in the list by a<br>footnote referring to this note, textile materials, with the exception of<br>linings and interlinings, which do not satisfy the rule set out in the list<br>in column 3 for the made up product concerned may be used provided<br>that they are classified in a heading other than that of the product and<br>that their value does not exceed 8% of the ex- works price of the pro-<br>duct.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>95</p>
<p>6.2 Materials which are not classified within Chapters 50 to 63 may be used<br>freely, whether or not they contain textiles.</p>
<p>Example:</p>
<p>If a rule in the list provides that for a particular textile item, such as<br>trousers, yarn must be used, this does not prevent the use of metal<br>items, such as buttons, because buttons are not classified within<br>Chapters 50 to 63. For the same reason, it does not prevent the use of<br>slide-fasteners even though slide-fasteners normally contain textiles.</p>
<p>6.3 Where a percentage rule applies, the value of materials which are not<br>classified within chapter 50 to 63 must be taken into account when cal-<br>culating the value of the non-originating materials incorporated.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>96</p>

<p>30.03<br>and 30.04</p>
<p>Medicaments (excluding<br>goods of heading No.<br>30.02, 30.05 or 30.06)</p>
<p>Manufacture in<br>which:</p>

Howe-<br>ver, materials of<br>heading No. 30.03<br>or 30.04 may be<br>used provided their<br>value, taken toget-<br>her, does not ex-<br>ceed 20% of the ex-<br>works price of the<br>product, and</p>
<p>- the value of all the<br>materials used does<br>not exceed 50% of<br>the ex-works price<br>of the product</p>

<p>Manufacture:</p>
<p>- in which the value<br>of all the materials<br>used does not ex-<br>ceed 40% of the ex-<br>works price of the<br>product, and</p>
<p>- where the value of<br>all the non-origina-<br>ting materials used<br>does not exceed the<br>value of the origi-<br>nating materials<br>used</p>
<p>Manufacture in<br>which the value of<br>all the materials<br>used does not ex-<br>ceed 30% of the<br>ex-works price of<br>the product</p>

<h1>APPENDIX III</h1>
<h2>MOVEMENT CERTIFICATE EUR.l</h2>
<h2>AND APPLICATION FOR A MOVEMENT<br>CERTIFICATE EUR.l</h2>
<p>Printing instructions:</p>
<p>1. Each form shall measure 210 x 297 mm; a tolerance of up to minus 5 mm<br>or plus 8 mm in the length may be allowed. The paper used must be white,<br>sized for writing, not containing mechanical pulp and weighing not less than<br>25 g/m<sup>2</sup>. It shall have a printed green guilloche pattern background making<br>any falsification by mechanical or Chemical means apparent to the eye.</p>
<p>2. The public authorities of the EEA countries may reserve the right to print<br>the forms themselves or may have them printed by approved printers. In the<br>latter case, each form must include a reference to such approval. Each form<br>must bear the name and address of the printer or a mark by which the printer<br>can be identified. It shall also bear a serial number, either printed or not, by<br>which it can be identified.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 4</p>
<p>179</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>

<h1>APPENDIX IV</h1>
<h2>INVOICE DECLARATION</h2>
<p>The invoice declaration, the text of which is given overleaf, must be made<br>out in accordance with the footnotes. However, the footnotes do not have to<br>be reproduced.</p>
<p>The exporter of the products covered by this document (customs authori-<br>zation No....’) declares that, except where otherwise clearly indicated, these<br>products are of EEA preferential origin <sup>2</sup></p>
<p>Spanish version</p>
<p>El exportador de los productos incluidos en el presente documento (autori-<br>zacion aduanera n ... ') declara que, salvo indicacion en sentido contrario,<br>estos productos gozan de un origen preferencial EEE <sup>2</sup></p>
<p>Danish version</p>
<p>Eksportpren af varer, der er omfattet af naervterende dokument, (toldmyn-<br>dighedernes tilladelse nr. ... ’), erklaerer, at varerne, medmindre andet tyde-<br>ligt er angivet, har prasferenceoprindelse i E0S <sup>2</sup></p>
<p>German version</p>
<p>Der Ausfiihrer (Ermächtigter Ausfiihrer; Bewilligungs-Nr. ..') der Waren,<br>auf die sich dieses Handelspapier bezieht erklärt, dass diese Waren, soweit<br>nicht anders angegeben, präferenzbegiinstigte EWR-Ursprungswaren sind <sup>2</sup></p>
<p>Greek version</p>
<p>O E^aycoyE twv jtqoi ovrarv jrov xakv jtrorvrai arco to jtapov Eyyatpo<br>(aÖEia teacovel ov vit agio. ...') öqlwvei ort, EXTOg Eav öqXcovETat oatptog<br>aXkcog, ra Ttpoi ovra avra ei vai rtpoTipTjoiaxT] ;g xaTaycoyqg EOX <sup>2</sup></p>
<p><sup>1</sup> When the invoice declaration is made out by an approved exporter within the mea-<br>ning of Article 22 of the Protocol, the authorization number of the approved exporter<br>must be entered in this space. When the invoice declaration is not made out by an<br>approved exporter, the words in brackets shall be omitted or the space left blank.</p>
<p><sup>2</sup> When the invoice declaration relätes, in whole or in part, to products originating in<br>Ceuta and Melilla within the meaning of Article 38 of the Protocol, the exporter must<br>clearly indicate them in the document on which the declaration is made out by means<br>of the symbol “CM”.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>184</p>
<p>French version</p>
<p>L’exportateur des produits couverts par le présent document (autorisation<br>douaniére no ... ') déclare que, sauf indication claire du contraire, ces pro-<br>duits ont 1’origine préférentielle EEE <sup>2</sup></p>
<p>Italian version</p>
<p>L’esportatore delle merci contemplate nel presente documento (autorizza-<br>zione doganale n. ... ') dichiara che, salvo indicazione contraria, le merci<br>sono di origine preferenziale SEE <sup>2</sup></p>
<p>Dutch version</p>
<p>De exporteur van de goederen waarop dit document van toepassing is (doua-<br>nevergunning nr. ... '), verklaart dat, behoudens uitdrukkelijke anderslui-<br>dende vermelding, deze goederen van preferentiéle EER-oorsprong zijn <sup>2</sup></p>
<p>Portuguese version</p>
<p>O abaixo assinado, exportador dos produtos cobertos pelo presente docu-<br>mento (autorizagäo aduaneira n ... *), declara que, salvo expressamente in-<br>dicado em conträrio, estes produtos säo de origem preferencial EEE <sup>2</sup></p>
<p>Icelandic version</p>
<p>Utflytjandi framleisluvara sem skjal ötetta tekur til (leyfi tollyfirvalda nr.<br>...*), lysir pvi yfir, a vörurnar séu, ef annars er ekki greinilega geti, af EES-<br>friindauppruna</p>
<p>Norwegian version</p>
<p>Eksportpren av produktene omfattet av dette dokument (tollmyndighetenes<br>autorisasjonsnr. ...<sup>1</sup> erklasrer at disse produktene, unntatt hvor annet er ty-<br>delig angitt, har E0S preferanseopprinnelse <sup>2</sup></p>
<p>Finnish version</p>
<p>Tässä asiakirjassa mainittujen tuotteiden viejä (tullin lupanumero...<sup>1</sup>) il-<br>moittaa, että nämä tuotteet ovat, ellei toisin ole selvästi merkitty, etuuskoh-<br>teluun oikeuttavaa ETA-alkuperää <sup>2</sup>.</p>
<p><sup>1</sup> When the invoice declaration is made out by an approved exporter within the mea-<br>ning of Article 22 of the Protocol, the authorization number of the approved exporter<br>must be entered in this space. When the invoice declaration is not made out by an<br>approved exporter, the words in brackets shall be omitted or the space left blank.</p>
<p><sup>2</sup> When the invoice declaration relätes, in whole or in part, to products originating in<br>Ceuta and Melilla within the meaning of Article 38 of the Protocol, the exporter must<br>clearly indicate them in the document on which the declaration is made out by means<br>of the symbol “CM”.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>185</p>
<p>Swedish version</p>
<p>Exportören av de varor som omfattas av detta dokument (tullmyndighetens<br>tillstånd nr...<sup>1</sup>) försäkrar att dessa varor, om inte annat tydligt markerats, har<br>förmånsberättigande EES-ursprung <sup>2</sup>.</p>
<p>(Place and date)</p>
<p>(Signature of the exporter;</p>
<p>in addition the name of the person sig-<br>ning the declaration has to be indicated<br>in clear script)</p>
<p><sup>1</sup> When the invoice declaration is made out by an approved exporter within the mea-<br>ning of Article 22 of the Protocol, the authorization number of the approved exporter<br>must be entered in this space. When the invoice declaration is not made out by an<br>approved exporter, the words in brackets shall be omitted or the space left blank.</p>
<p><sup>2</sup> When the invoice declaration relätes, in whole or in part, to products originating in<br>Ceuta and Melilla within the meaning of Article 38 of the Protocol, the exporter must<br>clearly indicate them in the document on which the declaration is made out by means<br>of the symbol “CM”.</p>
<p><sup>3</sup> These indications may be omitted if the information is contained on the document<br>itself.</p>
<p><sup>4</sup> See Article 21(5) of the Protocol. In cases where the exporter is not required to sign,<br>the exemption of signature also implies the exemption of the name of the signatory.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>

<h1>APPENDIX V</h1>
<h2>SUPPLIER’S DECLARATION</h2>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 4</p>
<p>The supplier’s declaration, the text of which is given overleaf, must be made<br>out in accordance with the footnotes. However, the footnotes do not have to<br>be reproduced.</p>
<p>187</p>
<h1>SUPPLIER’S DECLARATION</h1>
<p>for goods which have undergone working or processing in the EEA without<br>having obtained preferential originating status</p>
<p>I, the undersigned, supplier of the goods covered by the annexed document,<br>declare that:</p>
<p>1. The following materials which do not originate in the EEA have been<br>used in the EEA to produce these goods.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<table border="1">
<tr><td>
<p>Description of the</p></td><td>
<p>Description of</p></td><td>
<p>HS heading of</p></td><td>
<p>Value of</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>goods supplied<sup>1</sup></p></td><td>
<p>non-originating<br>materials used</p></td><td>
<p>non-originating<br>materials used*</p></td><td>
<p>non-originating</p>
<p>materials used*’<sup>3</sup></p></td></tr>
</table>
<p>Total value:</p>
<p>Total value: &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;........</p>
<p><sup>1</sup> When the invoice, delivery note or other commercial document to which the declara-<br>tion is annexed relätes to different kinds of goods, or to goods which do not incorpo-<br>rate non-originating materials to the same extent, the supplier must clearly differen-<br>tiate them.</p>
<p>Example:</p>
<p>The document relätes to different models of electrical motors of heading No. 85.01<br>to be used in the manufacture of washing machines of heading No. 84.50. The types<br>and value of the non-originating materials used in the manufacture of these motors<br>differ from one model to another. The models must therefore be differentiated in the<br>first column and the indications in the other columns must be provided separately for<br>each of the models to make it possible for the manufacturer of washing machines to<br>make a correct assessment of the originating status of his products depending on which<br>model of electrical motor he uses.</p>
<p><sup>2</sup> The indications requested in these columns should only be given if they are necessary.</p>
<p>Examples:</p>
<p>The rule for garments of ex Chapter 62 says that non-originating yarn may be used.<br>If a manufacturer of such garments in France uses fabric imported from Switzerland<br>which has been obtained there by weaving non-originating yarn, it is sufficient for the<br>Swiss supplier to describe in his declaration the non-originating material used as yarn,<br>without it being necessary to indicate the HS heading and value of such yarn.</p>
<p>A producer of iron wire of HS heading No. 72.17 who has produced it from non-<br>originating iron bars should indicate in the second column “bars of iron”. Where this<br>wire is to be used in the production of a machine, for which the origin rule contains<br>a limitation for all non-originating materials used to a certain percentage value, it is<br>necessary to indicate in the third column the value of the non-originating bars.</p>
<p><sup>3</sup> “Value of materials” means the customs value at the time of importation of the non-<br>originating materials used, or, if this is not known and cannot be ascertained, the first<br>ascertainable price paid for the materials in the EEA.</p>
<p>The exact value of each non-originating material used must be given per unit of the<br>goods specified in the first column.</p>
<p>188</p>
<p>2. All the other materials used in the EEA to produce these goods originate<br>in the EEA;</p>
<p>3. The following goods have undergone working or processing outside the<br>EEA in accordance with Article 11 of Protocol 4 to the EEA Agreement and<br>have acquired the following total added value there:</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>Description of the<br>goods supplied<sup>1</sup></p>
<p>Total added value acquired outside the<br>EEA<sup>4</sup></p>
<p>(Place and date)</p>
<p>(Address and signatuare of the supplier;<br>in addition the name of the person sig-<br>ning the declaration has to be indicades<br>in clear script)</p>
<p><sup>1</sup> When the invoice, delivery note or other commercial document to which the declara-<br>tion is annexed relätes to different kinds of goods, or to goods which do not incorpo-<br>rate non-originating materials to the same extent, the supplier must clearly differen-<br>tiate them.</p>
<p>Example:</p>
<p>The document relätes to different models of electrical motors of heading No. 85.01<br>to be used in the manufacture of washing machines of heading No. 84.50. The types<br>and value of the non-originating materials used in the manufacture of these motors<br>differ from one model to another. The models must therefore be differentiated in the<br>first column and the indications in the other columns must be provided separately for<br>each of the models to make it possible for the manufacturer of washing machines to<br>make a correct assessment of the originating status of his products depending on which<br>model of electrical motor he uses.</p>
<p><sup>4</sup> “Total added value” shall mean all costs accumulated outside the EEA, including the<br>value of all the materials added there.</p>
<p>The exact total added value acquired outside the EEA must be given per unit of<br>goods specified in the first column.</p>
<p>189</p>

<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
