<p>Description of the Description of non-<br>goods supplied<sup>2</sup> originating mate-<br>rials used</p>
<p>HS heading of non- Value of non-ori-<br>originating mate- ginating mate-<br>rials used<sup>3</sup> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;rials used<sup>3,4</sup></p>
<p>Total value:</p>
<p><sup>1</sup> Name and address of customer.</p>
<p><sup>2</sup> When the declaration covers different goods, or goods which do not incorporate non-<br>originating materials to the same extent, the supplier must clearly differentiate them.</p>
<p>Example:</p>
<p>The document relätes to electrical motors of heading No. 85.01 to be used in the<br>manufacture of washing machines of heading No. 84.50. The types and value of the<br>non-originating materials used in the manufacture of these motors differ from one mo-<br>del to another. The models must therefore be differentiated in the first column and the<br>indications in the other columns must be provided separately for each of the models to<br>make it possible for the manufacturer of washing machines to make a correct assess-<br>ment of the originating status of his products depending on which model of electrical<br>motor he uses.</p>
<p><sup>3</sup> The indications requested in these columns should only be given if they are necessary.</p>
<p>Examples:</p>
<p>The rule for garments of ex Chapter 62 says that non-originating yam may be used.<br>If a manufacturer of such garments in France uses fabric imported from Switzerland<br>which has been obtained there by weaving non-originating yarn, it is sufficient for the<br>Swiss supplier to describe in his declaration the non-originating material used as yarn,<br>without it being necessary to indicate the HS heading and value of such yarn.</p>
<p>A producer of iron wire of HS heading No. 72.17 who has produced it from non-<br>originating iron bars should indicate in the second column “bars of iron”. Where this<br>wire is to be used in the production of a machine, for which the origin rule contains<br>a limitation for all non-originating materials used to a certain percentage value, it is<br>necessary to indicate in the third column the value of the non-originating bars.</p>
<p><sup>4</sup> “Value of materials” means the customs value at the time of importation of the non-<br>originating materials used, or, if this is not known and cannot be ascertained, the first<br>ascertainable price paid for these materials in the EEA.</p>
<p>The exact value of each non-originating materials used must be given per unit of the<br>goods specified in the first column.</p>

<p>194</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 5</h1>
<h2>ON CUSTOMS DUTIES OF A FISCAL NATURE</h2>
<p>(Liechtenstein, Switzerland)</p>
<p>1. Without prejudice to paragraph 2 of this Protocol, Liechtenstein and<br>Switzerland may retain temporarily customs duties of a fiscal nature for pro-<br>ducts falling under the tariff headings specified in the annexed table while<br>observing the conditions of Article 14 of the Agreement. Concerning tariff<br>headings 0901 and ex 2101, these customs duties shall be abolished at the<br>latest on 31.12.1996.</p>
<p>2. When production is started in Liechtenstein or Switzerland of a product<br>of like kind to one of those listed in the table, the customs duty of a fiscal<br>nature to which the latter product is subject must be abolished.</p>
<p>3. The EEA Joint Committee shall examine the situation before the end of<br>1996.</p>
<p>Table</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol5</p>
<p>Tariff Heading Description of goods</p>
<p>0901 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Coffee, whether or not roasted or decaffeinated; coffee husks</p>
<p>and skins; substitutes containing coffee in any proportion (for a<br>transitional period of 4 years)</p>
<p>ex 2101 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Extracts, essences and concentrates, of coffee, and prepara-</p>
<p>tions with a basis of these extracts, essences and concentrations<br>(for a transitional period of 4 years)</p>

<p>2709. 0010/0090</p>

<p>Tariff Heading</p>
<p>Description of goods</p>
<p>ex 8707</p>
<p>ex 8708</p>
<p>8702. 1010, 9010, 8703. 1000/9030, 8704. 2110/2120, 3110/3120,<br>9010/9020</p>

<p>with other transmission components</p>

<p>cluding wheel rims and parts thereof, not surface-trea-<br>ted, and wheel rims and parts thereof, unfinished or<br>roughed down</p>

<p>cers with side tubes of a length of not more than 15 cm<br>9390 &nbsp;- clutches and parts thereof</p>
<p>9490 &nbsp;- steering wheels, steering columns and steering boxes</p>
<p>9999 &nbsp;- other, not including steering-wheel covers</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 5</p>
<p>196</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 6</h1>
<h2>ON THE BUILDING UP OF COMPULSORY<br>RESERVES BY SWITZERLAND AND<br>LIECHTENSTEIN</h2>
<p>Switzerland and Liechtenstein may subject to a scheme of compulsory reser-<br>ves products which are indispensable for the survival of the population and,<br>in relation to Switzerland, for the army, in times of serious supply shortages,<br>and the production of which in Switzerland and Liechtenstein is insufficient<br>or nonexistent and the characteristics and nature of which enable reserves to<br>be built up.</p>
<p>Switzerland and Liechtenstein shall apply this scheme in a manner that<br>does not involve discrimination, direct or indirect, between the products im-<br>ported from the other Contracting Parties and like or substitute national pro-<br>ducts.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 6</p>
<p>197</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 7</h1>
<h2>ON QUANTITATIVE RESTRICTIONS WHICH<br>ICELAND MAY RETAIN</h2>
<p>Notwithstanding Article 11 of the Agreement, Iceland may retain quantita-<br>tive restrictions on the products listed below:</p>
<p>Icelandic heading NoDescription</p>
<p>96.03 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Brooms, brushes (including brushes constituting parts</p>
<p>of machines, appliances or vehicles), hand-operated<br>mechanical floor sweepers, not motorised, mops and<br>feather dusters; prepared knots and tufts for broom or<br>brush making; paint pads and rollers; squeegees (other<br>than roller squeegees):</p>
<p>- Tooth brushes, shaving brushes, hair brushes, nail<br>brushes, eyelash brushes and other toilet brushes<br>for use on the person, including such brushes consti-<br>tuting parts of appliances:</p>
<p>96.03 29 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;-- Other:</p>
<p>96.03 29 01 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;---With brush backs of plastic material</p>
<p>96.03 29 09 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;---Other</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 7</p>
<p>198</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 8</h1>
<h2>ON STATE MONOPOLIES</h2>
<p>1. Article 16 of the Agreement shall be applicable at the latest from 1 Ja-<br>nuary 1995 in the case of the following State monopolies of a commercial<br>character:</p>
<p>- Austrian monopoly on salt;</p>
<p>- &nbsp;Icelandic monopoly on fertilizers;</p>
<p>- Swiss and Liechtenstein monopolies on salt and gunpowder.</p>
<p>- Article 16 shall also apply to wine (HS Heading No 22.04).</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 8</p>
<p>199</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 9</h1>
<h2>ON TRADE IN FISH AND OTHER MARINE<br>PRODUCTS</h2>
<p>Article 1</p>
<p>1. Without prejudice to the provisions referred to in Appendix 1, the<br>EFTA States shall upon entry into force of the Agreement abolish customs<br>duties on imports and charges having equivalent effect on the products listed<br>in Table I of Appendix 2.</p>
<p>2. Without prejudice to the provisions referred to in Appendix 1, the<br>EFTA States shall apply no quantitative restrictions on imports or measures<br>having equivalent effect on the products listed in Table I of Appendix 2. In<br>this context the provisions of Article 13 of the Agreement shall apply.</p>
<p>Article 2</p>
<p>1. The Community shall, upon the entry into force of the Agreement, abo-<br>lish customs duties on imports and charges having equivalent effect on the<br>products listed in Table II of Appendix 2.</p>
<p>2. The Community shall reduce customs duties on the products listed in<br>Table III of Appendix 2 progressively in accordance with the following time-<br>table:</p>
<p>(a) on 1 January 1993 each duty shall be reduced to 86% of the basic<br>duty;</p>
<p>(b) four further reductions of 14% each of the basic duty shall be made<br>on 1 January 1994, 1 January 1995, 1 January 1996 and 1 January<br>1997.</p>
<p>3. The basic duties to which the successive reductions provided for in<br>paragraph 2 are to be applied shall, for each product, be the duties bound by<br>the Community under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or,<br>where the duty is not bound, the autonomous duty on 1 January 1992.<br>Should, after 1 January 1992, any tariff reductions resulting from the multila-<br>teral trade negotiations of the Uruguay Round become applicable, such re-<br>duced duties shall be used as the basic duties.</p>
<p>Whenever in the context of bilateral agreements between the Community<br>and individual EFTA States reduced duties exist for certain products, those<br>duties shall be considered as the basic duties for each of the EFTA States<br>concerned.</p>
<p>4. The rates of duty calculated in accordance with paragraphs 2 and 3 shall<br>be applied by rounding down to the first decimal place by deleting the second<br>decimal.</p>
<p>5. The Community shall apply no quantitative restrictions on imports or<br>measures having equivalent effect on the products listed in Appendix 2. In<br>this context the provisions of Article 13 of the Agreement shall apply.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol9</p>
<p>200</p>
<p>Article 3</p>
<p>The provisions of Articles 1 and 2 shall apply to products originating in the<br>Contracting Parties. The rules of origin are set out in Protocol 4 of the Agree-<br>ment.</p>
<p>Article 4</p>
<p>1. Aid granted through State resources to the fisheries sector which distorts<br>competition shall be abolished.</p>
<p>2. Legislation relating to the market organization in the fisheries sector shall<br>be adjusted so as not to distort competition.</p>
<p>3. The Contracting Parties shall endeavour to ensure conditions of competi-<br>tion which will enable the other Contracting Parties to refrain from the appli-<br>cation of anti-dumping measures and countervailing duties.</p>
<p>Article 5</p>
<p>The Contracting Parties shall take the necessary measures to ensure that all<br>fishing vessels flying the flag of other Contracting Parties enjoy access equal<br>to that of their own vessels to ports and first-stage marketing installations<br>together with all associated equipment and technical installations.</p>
<p>Notwithstanding the provisions of the preceding paragraph, a Contracting<br>Party may refuse landings of fish from a fish stock of common interest over<br>the management of which there is serious disagreement.</p>
<p>Article 6</p>
<p>Should the necessary legislative adaptations not have been effected to the<br>satisfaction of the Contracting Parties at the time of entry into force of the<br>Agreement, any points at issue may be put to the EEA Joint Committee. In<br>the event of failure to reach agreement, the provisions of Article 114 of the<br>Agreement shall apply mutatis mutandis.</p>
<p>Article 7</p>
<p>The provisions of the agreements listed in Appendix 3 shall prevail over pro-<br>visions of this Protocol to the extent they grant to the EFTA States concer-<br>ned more favourable trade regimes than this Protocol.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol9</p>
<p>201</p>

<h1>APPENDIX 3</h1>
<p>Agreements between the Community and individual EFTA States, as refer-<br>red to in Article 7:</p>
<p>Agreement between the European Economic Community and the King-<br>dom of Sweden, signed on 22 July 1972, and a subsequent Exchange of Let-<br>ters concerning agriculture and fisheries, signed on 14 July 1986.</p>
<p>Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss<br>Confederation, signed on 22 July 1972, and a subsequent Exchange of Let-<br>ters concerning agriculture and fisheries, signed on 14 July 1986.</p>
<p>Agreement between the European Economic Community and the King-<br>dom of Norway, signed on 14 May 1973, and a subsequent Exchange of Let-<br>ters concerning agriculture and fisheries, signed on 14 July 1986.</p>
<p>Article 1 of Protocol No 6 of the Agreement, between the European Eco-<br>nomic Community and the Republic of Iceland, signed on 22 July 1972.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol9</p>
<p>207</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 10</h1>
<h2>ON SIMPLIFICATION OF INSPECTIONS AND<br>FORMALITIES IN RESPECT OF CARRIAGE OF<br>GOODS</h2>
<p>CHAPTERI</p>
<p>GENERAL PROVISIONS</p>
<p>Article 1</p>
<p>Definitions</p>
<p>For the purposes of this Protocol:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;'inspections’ shall mean the carrying out by customs or any other su-<br>pervisory department of an operation which consists of the physical<br>examination, including visual inspection, of the means of transport<br>and/or the goods themselves with the aim of checking that their na-<br>ture, origin, State, quantity or value are in conformity with the parti-<br>culars given in the documents which have been presented;</p>
<p>(b) 'formalities’ shall mean any formality imposed on operators by the<br>administration consisting in the presentation or examination of do-<br>cuments and certificates accompanying goods or other particulars,<br>irrespective of form or medium, relating to the goods or means of<br>transport.</p>
<p>Article 2</p>
<p>Scope</p>
<p>1. Without prejudice to the specific provisions in force under agreements<br>concluded between the European Economic Community and EFTA States,<br>this Protocol shall apply to inspections and formalities concerning the car-<br>riage of goods which have to cross a frontier between an EFTA State and the<br>Community, as well as between the EFTA States.</p>
<p>2. This Protocol shall not apply to inspections or formalities:</p>
<p>- &nbsp;in respect of ships and aircraft as means of transport; however, it shall<br>apply to vehicles and goods carried by the said means of transport;</p>
<p>- &nbsp;required for the issue of health or plant health certificates in the country<br>of origin or of provenance of the goods.</p>
<p>CHAPTER II</p>
<p>PROCEDURES</p>
<p>Article 3</p>
<p>Random checks and formalities</p>
<p>1. Save as otherwise expressly provided in this Protocol, the Contracting<br>Parties shall take the necessary measures to ensure that:</p>
<p>- &nbsp;the different inspections and formalities provided for in Article 2(1) are</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 10</p>
<p>208</p>
<p>carried out with the minimum delay necessary and, in so far as possible,<br>at one place;</p>
<p>- inspections are carried out by means of random checks, except in duly<br>justified circumstances.</p>
<p>2. For the purposes of implementing the second indent of paragraph 1, the<br>basis for carrying out random checks shall be the total number of consign-<br>ments passing through a frontier post and presented to a customs office or<br>inspection authority during a given period, and not the total number of goods<br>making up each consignment.</p>
<p>3. The Contracting Parties shall facilitate, at the places of departure and des-<br>tination of goods, the use of simplified procedures and data processing and<br>data transmission techniques for the purposes of the export, transit and im-<br>port of goods.</p>
<p>4. The Contracting Parties shall endeavour to deploy customs offices, inclu-<br>ding those in the interiör of their territory, in such a way as best to take ac-<br>count of the requirements of commercial operators.</p>
<p>Article 4</p>
<p>Veterinary rules</p>
<p>In areas relating to the protection of human and animal health and the pro-<br>tection of animals, implementation of the principles set out in Articles 3, 7<br>and 13 and the rules governing the fees to be charged in respect of the forma-<br>lities and inspections carried out shall be decided upon by the EEA Joint<br>Committee in accordance with Article 93(2) of the Agreement.</p>
<p>Article 5</p>
<p>Plant health rules</p>
<p>1. Plant health inspections of imports shall take the form only of random<br>checks and sample testing except in duly justified circumstances. Such in-<br>spections shall be carried out at either the place of destination of the goods<br>or another place designated within the respective territories on condition<br>that the itinerary of the goods is affected to the least possible extent.</p>
<p>2. Rules governing the carrying out of identity checks on imports in relation<br>to goods covered by plant health legislation shall be adopted by the EEA<br>Joint Committee in accordance with Article 93(2) of the Agreement. The<br>measures pertaining to the fees to be charged in respect of plant health for-<br>malities and inspections shall be decided upon by the EEA Joint Committee<br>in accordance with Article 93(2) of the Agreement.</p>
<p>3. Paragraphs 1 and 2 shall not apply to goods other than those produced in<br>the Community or in an EFTA State except in cases where, by their nature,<br>they present no plant health risk or in cases where they have undergone a<br>plant health inspection on entering the territory of the respective Contrac-<br>ting Parties, and are found, at the time of such inspections, to meet the requi-<br>rements relating to plant health laid down in their legislation.</p>
<p>14 Riksdagen 1991/92. 1 saml. Nr 170. Bil. 15</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 10</p>
<p>209</p>
<p>4. Where a Contracting Party considers that there is imminent danger of the<br>introduction or sprcad of harmful organisms in its territory, it may take such<br>temporary measures as are necessary to protect itself against that danger.<br>The Contracting Parties shall notify one another forthwith of the measures<br>taken and of the reasons which made them necessary.</p>
<p>Article 6</p>
<p>Delegation of powers</p>
<p>The Contracting Parties shall see to it that, by express delegation by the com-<br>petent authorities and on their behalf, one of the other services represented,<br>and preferably the customs service, may carry out inspections for which<br>those authorities are responsible and, in so far as such inspections reläte to<br>the requirement to produce the necessary documents, checks on the validity<br>and authenticity thereof and on the identity of the goods declared in such<br>documents. In that event the authorities concerned shall ensure that the<br>means required for carrying out such checks are made available.</p>
<p>Article 7</p>
<p>Recognition of inspections and documents</p>
<p>For the purposes of implementing this Protocol and without prejudice to the<br>possibility of carrying out random checks, the Contracting Parties shall, in<br>the event of goods being imported or entering in transit, recognize the in-<br>spections carried out and the documents drawn up by the competent authori-<br>ties of the other Contracting Parties which certify that the goods comply with<br>the legal requirements of the country of import or equivalent requirements<br>in the country of export.</p>
<p>Article 8</p>
<p>Opening hours offrontier posts</p>
<p>1. Where the volume of traffic so warrants, the Contracting Parties shall see<br>to it that:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;frontier posts are open, except when traffic is prohibited, so that:<br>frontiers can be crosscd twenty-four hours a day with the correspon-<br>ding inspections and formalities in respect of goods placed under a<br>customs transit procedure, their means of transport and vehicles tra-<br>velling unladen, save where frontier inspection is necessary in order<br>to prevent the spread of disease or protect animals;</p>
<p>inspections and formalities relating to the movement of means of<br>transport and goods which are not moving under a customs transit<br>procedure may be performed from Monday to Friday during an<br>uninterrupted period of at least ten hours, and on Saturday during<br>an uninterrupted period of at least six hours, unless those days are<br>public holidays;</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;as regards vehicles and goods transported by air, the periods refer-</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 10</p>
<p>210</p>
<p>red to in the second indent of subparagraph (a) are adapted in such<br>a way as to meet actual needs and for that purpose are split or exten-<br>ded if necessary.</p>
<p>2. Where general compliance with the periods referred to in the second in-<br>dent of subparagraph l(a) and in subparagraph l(b) poses problems for vete-<br>rinary services, the Contracting Parties shall see to it that, subject to at least<br>twelve hours’ notice being given by the carrier, a veterinary expert is avai-<br>lable during those periods; in the case of the transport of live animals, howe-<br>ver, the period of such notice may be increased to eighteen hours.</p>
<p>3. Where several frontier posts are situated in the immediate vicinity of one<br>and the same frontier zone, the Contracting Parties concerned may jointly<br>agree for certain of such posts, to derogate from paragraph 1 provided that<br>the other posts in that zone are able to clear goods and vehicles in accordance<br>with that paragraph.</p>
<p>4. As regards the frontier posts and customs offices and services referred to<br>in paragraph 1, and under the conditions laid down by the Contracting Par-<br>ties, the competent authorities shall, if specifically requested during business<br>hours and for sound reasons, provide for inspections and formalities to be<br>carried out, as an exception, outside business hours, on condition that,<br>where relevant, payment is made for services so rendered.</p>
<p>Article 9</p>
<p>Express lanes</p>
<p>The Contracting Parties shall endeavour to establish at frontier posts, where<br>technically possible and justified by the volume of traffic, express lanes re-<br>served for goods placed under a customs transit procedure, their means of<br>transport, vehicles travelling unladen and all goods subject to such inspec-<br>tions and formalities as do not exceed those required in respect of goods pla-<br>ced under a transit procedure.</p>
<p>CHAPTER III</p>
<p>COOPERATION</p>
<p>Article 10</p>
<p>Cooperation between authorities</p>
<p>1. In order to facilitate the Crossing of frontiers, the Contracting Parties shall<br>take the measures necessary to extend cooperation at both national and re-<br>gional or local level between the authorities responsible for the organization<br>of inspections and between the various departments carrying out inspections<br>and formalities on either side of such frontiers.</p>
<p>2. Each Contracting Party shall, in so far as it is concerned, see to it that<br>persons engaged in trade covered by this Protocol can rapidly inform the<br>competent authorities of any problems encountered when Crossing frontiers.</p>
<p>3. The cooperation referred to in paragraph 1 shall cover in particular:</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 10</p>
<p>211</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;the arrangement of frontier posts in such a way as to meet traffic<br>requirements;</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;the conversion of frontier offices into juxtaposed inspection offices,<br>where possible;</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;the harmonization of the responsibilities of the frontier posts and<br>offices situated on either side of the frontier;</p>
<p>(d) the seeking of appropriate Solutions to any problems reported.</p>
<p>4. The Contracting Parties shall cooperate in order to harmonize the busi-<br>ness hours of the various departments carrying out inspections and formali-<br>ties on either side of the frontier.</p>
<p>Article 11</p>
<p>Notification of new inspections and formalities</p>
<p>Where a Contracting Party intends to introduce a new inspection or forma-<br>lity, it shall inform the other Contracting Parties thereof. The Contracting<br>Party concerned shall ensure that the measures taken to facilitate the Cros-<br>sing of frontiers are not rendered inoperative through the application of such<br>new inspections or formalities.</p>
<p>Article 12</p>
<p>Free flow of traffic</p>
<p>1. The Contracting Parties shall take the measures necessary to ensure that<br>waiting time caused by the various inspections and formalities does not ex-<br>ceed the time required for their proper completion. To that end, they shall<br>organize the business hours of the departments which are to carry out inspec-<br>tions and formalities, the staff available and the practical arrangements for<br>processing goods and documents associated with the carrying out of inspec-<br>tions and formalities in such a way as to reduce waiting time in the flow of<br>traffic to the fullest possible extent.</p>
<p>2. The competent authorities of the Contracting Parties in whose territory<br>serious disruption in regard to the carriage of goods occurs, which is likely<br>to jeopardize the objectives of simplifying and expediting the Crossing of<br>frontiers, shall immediately inform the competent authorities of the other<br>Contracting Parties affected by such disruption.</p>
<p>3. The competent authorities of each Contracting Party so affected shall im-<br>mediately take appropriate measures to ensure, as far as possible, the free<br>flow of traffic. The measures shall be notified to the EEA Joint Committee<br>which shall, where appropriate, meet in emergency session at the request of<br>a Contracting Party, to diseuss these measures.</p>
<p>Article 13</p>
<p>Administrative assistance</p>
<p>In order to ensure the smooth functioning of trade between the Contracting<br>Parties and to facilitate the detection of any irregularity or infringement, the<br></p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 10</p>
<p>212</p>
<p>competent authorities of the Contracting Parties shall cooperate with each<br>other mutatis mutandis in accordance with the provisions of Protocol 11.</p>
<p>Article 14</p>
<p>Consultation groups</p>
<p>1. The competent authorities of the Contracting Parties concerned may set<br>up any consultation group responsible for dealing with questions of a practi-<br>cal, technical or organizational nature at regional or local level.</p>
<p>2. Such consultation groups shall meet whenever necessary at the request of<br>the competent authorities of a Contracting Party. The EEA Joint Committee<br>shall be kept regularly informed of their deliberations by the Contracting<br>Parties responsible for them.</p>
<p>CHAPTER IV</p>
<p>FINAL PROVISIONS</p>
<p>Article 15</p>
<p>Payment facilities</p>
<p>The Contracting Parties shall see to it that any sums payable in respect of<br>the inspections and formalities applied to trade can also be paid by means of<br>guaranteed or certified international cheques, expressed in the currency of<br>the country in which such sums are payable.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 10</p>
<p>Article 16</p>
<p>Relationship to other agreements and national legislation</p>
<p>This Protocol shall not prevent the applicaton of greater facilities which two<br>or more Contracting Parties grant to each other, nor the right of the Contrac-<br>ting Parties to apply their own legislation to Controls and formalities at their<br>frontiers, on condition that this does not reduce in any way the facilities deri-<br>ving from this Protocol.</p>
<p>213</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 11</h1>
<h2>ON MUTUAL ASSISTANCE IN CUSTOMS MATTERS</h2>
<p>Article 1</p>
<p>Definitions</p>
<p>For the purposes of this Protocol:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;'customs legislation’ shall mean provisions applicable in the territo-<br>ries of the Contracting Parties governing the import, export, transit<br>of goods and their placing under any other customs procedure, in-<br>cluding measures of prohibition, restriction and control adopted by<br>the said Parties.</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;'customs duties’ shall mean all duties, taxes, fees or other charges<br>which are levied and collected in the territories of the Contracting<br>Parties, in application of customs legislation, but not including fees<br>and charges which are limited in amount to the approximate costs of<br>services rendered;</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;'applicant authority’ shall mean a competent administrative autho-<br>rity which has been appointed by a Contracting Party for this pur-<br>pose and which makes a request for assistance in customs matters;</p>
<p>(d) 'requested authority’ shall mean a competent administrative autho-<br>rity which has been appointed by a Contracting Party for this pur-<br>pose and which receives a request for assistance in customs matters;</p>
<p>(e) &nbsp;'contravention’ shall mean any violation of the customs legislation<br>as well as any attempted violation of such legislation.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 11</p>
<p>Article 2</p>
<p>Scope</p>
<p>1. The Contracting Parties shall assist each other, in the manner and under<br>the conditions laid down in this Protocol, in ensuring that customs legislation<br>is correctly applied, in particular by the prevention, detection and investiga-<br>tion of contraventions of this legislation.</p>
<p>2. Assistance in customs matters, as provided for in this Protocol, applies to<br>any administrative authority of the Contracting Parties which is competent<br>for the application of this Protocol. It shall not prejudice the rules governing<br>mutual assistance in criminal matters.</p>
<p>Article 3</p>
<p>Assistance on request</p>
<p>1. At the request of the applicant authority, the requested authority shall<br>furnish it with all relevant information to enable it to ensure that customs<br>legislation is correctly applied, including information regarding operations<br>noted or planned which contravene or would contravene such legislation.</p>
<p>2. At the request of the applicant authority, the requested authority shall</p>
<p>214</p>
<p>inform it whether goods exported from the territory of one of the Contrac-<br>ting Parties have been properly imported into the territory of the other Party,<br>specifying, where appropriate, the customs procedure applied to the goods.</p>
<p>3. At the request of the applicant authority, the requested authority shall<br>take the necessary steps to ensure that a surveillance is kept on:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;natural or legal persons of whom there are reasonable grounds for<br>believing that they are contravening or have contravened customs<br>legislation;</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;movement of goods notified as possibly giving rise to substantial<br>contraventions of customs legislation;</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;means of transport for which there are reasonable grounds for belie-<br>ving that they have been, are or may be used in the contravening of<br>customs legislation.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 11</p>
<p>Article 4</p>
<p>Spontaneous assistance</p>
<p>The Contracting Parties shall within their competences provide each other<br>with assistance if they consider that to be necessary for the correct applica-<br>tion of customs legislation, particularly when they obtain information pertai-<br>ning to:</p>
<p>- operations which have contravened, contravene or would contravene<br>such legislation and which may be of interest to other Contracting Parties;</p>
<p>- new means or methods employed in realizing such operations;</p>
<p>- goods known to be subject to substantial contravention of customs legis-<br>lation on import, export, transit or any other customs procedure.</p>
<p>Article 5</p>
<p>Delivery/Notification</p>
<p>At the request of the applicant authority, the requested authority shall in<br>accordance with its legislation take all necessary measures in order to:</p>
<p>- &nbsp;deliver all documents;</p>
<p>- &nbsp;notify all decisions;</p>
<p>- &nbsp;falling within the scope of this Protocol to an addressee, residing or estab-<br>lished in its territory.</p>
<p>Article 6</p>
<p>Form and substance of requests for assistance</p>
<p>1. Requests pursuant to the present Protocol shall be made in writing. Do-<br>cuments necessary for the execution of such requests shall accompany the<br>request. When required because of the urgency of the situation, oral re-<br>quests may be accepted, but must be confirmed in writing immediately.</p>
<p>2. Requests pursuant to paragraph 1 shall include the following information:</p>
<p>215</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;the applicant authority;</p>
<p>(b) the measure requested;</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;the object of and the reason for the request;</p>
<p>(d) &nbsp;laws, rules and other legal instruments involved;</p>
<p>(e) &nbsp;indications as exact and comprehensive as possible on the natural or<br>legal persons being the target of the investigations;</p>
<p>(f) &nbsp;a summary of the relevant facts, except in cases provided for in Ar-<br>ticle 5.</p>
<p>3. Requests shall be submitted in an official language of the requested aut-<br>hority or in a language acceptable to such authority.</p>
<p>4. If a request does not meet the formal requirements, its correction or com-<br>pletion may be demanded; the ordering of precautionary measures may, ho-<br>wever, take place.</p>
<p>Article 7</p>
<p>Execution of requests</p>
<p>1. In order to comply with a request for assistance, the requested authority<br>or, when the latter cannot act on its own, the administrative department to<br>which the request has been addressed by this authority, shall proceed, within<br>its competence and resources available, as though it were acting on its own<br>account or at the request of other authorities of that same Contracting Party,<br>by supplying information already possessed, by carrying out appropriate en-<br>quiries or by arranging for them to be carried out.</p>
<p>2. Requests for assistance will be executed in accordance with the laws, rules<br>and other legal instruments of the requested Contracting Party.</p>
<p>3. Duly authorized officials of a Contracting Party may, with the agreement<br>of the other Contracting Party involved and within the conditions laid down<br>by the latter, obtain from the offices of the requested authority or other aut-<br>hority for which the requested authority is responsible, information relating<br>to the contravention of customs legislation which the applicant authority<br>needs for the purposes of this Protocol.</p>
<p>4. Officials of a Contracting Party may, with the agreement of the other<br>Contracting Party, be present at enquiries carried out in the latter’s territory.</p>
<p>Article 8</p>
<p>Form in which information is to be communicated</p>
<p>1. The requested authority shall communicate results of enquiries to the ap-<br>plicant authority in the form of documents, certified copies of documents,<br>reports and the like.</p>
<p>2. The documents provided for in paragraph 1 may be replaced by compute-<br>rized information produced in any form for the same purpose.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 11</p>
<p>216</p>
<p>Article 9</p>
<p>Exceptions to the obligation to provide assistance</p>
<p>1. The Contracting Parties may refuse to give assistance as provided for in<br>this Protocol, where to do so would:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;be likely to prejudice sovereignty, public policy (1’ordre publique),<br>security or other essential interests; or</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;involve currency or tax regulations other than regulations concer-<br>ning customs duties; or</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;violate an industrial, commercial or professional secret.</p>
<p>2. Where the applicant authority asks for assistance which it would itself be<br>unable to provide if so asked, it shall draw attention to that fact in its request.<br>It shall then be left to the requested authority to decide how to respond to<br>such a request.</p>
<p>3. If assistance is withheld or denied, the decision and the reasons therefor<br>must be notified to the applicant authority without delay.</p>
<p>Article 10</p>
<p>Obligation to observe confidentiality</p>
<p>Any information communicated in whatever form pursuant to this Protocol<br>shall be of a confidential nature. It shall be covered by the obligation of offi-<br>cial secrecy and shall enjoy the protection extended to like information un-<br>der the relevant laws applicable in the Contracting Party which received it<br>and the corresponding provisions applying to the Community authorities.</p>
<p>Article 11</p>
<p>Use of information</p>
<p>1. Information obtained shall be used solely for the purposes of this Protocol<br>and may be used within each Contracting Party for other purposes only with<br>the prior written consent of the administrative authority which furnished the<br>information and shall be subject to any restrictions laid down by that autho-<br>rity. These provisions are not applicable to information concerning offences<br>relating to narcotic drugs and psychotropic substances. Such information<br>may be communicated to other authorities directly involved in the combat<br>of illicit drug traffic.</p>
<p>2. Paragraph 1 shall not impede the use of information in any judicial or<br>administrative proceedings subsequently instituted for failure to comply with<br>customs legislation.</p>
<p>3. The Contracting Parties may, in their records of evidence, reports and<br>testimonies and in proceedings and charges brought before the courts, use<br>as evidence information obtained and documents consulted in accordance<br>with the provisions of this Protocol.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 11</p>
<p>217</p>
<p>Article 12</p>
<p>Experts and witnesses</p>
<p>An official of a requested authority may be authorized to appear, within the<br>limitations of the authorization granted, as expert or witness in judicial or<br>administrative proceedings regarding the matters covered by this Protocol<br>in the jurisdiction of another Contracting Party, and produce such objects,<br>documents or authenticated copies thereof, as may be needed for the procee-<br>dings. The request for an appearance must indicate specifically on what mat-<br>ter and by virtue of what title or qualification the official will be questioned.</p>
<p>Article 13</p>
<p>Assistance expenses</p>
<p>The Contracting Parties shall waive all claims on each other for the reimbur-<br>sement of expenses incurred pursuant to this Protocol, except, as appro-<br>priate, for expenses to experts and witnesses and to interpreters and transla-<br>tors who are not dependent upon public services.</p>
<p>Article 14</p>
<p>Implementation</p>
<p>1. The management of this Protocol shall be entrusted to the central cus-<br>toms authorities of the EFTA States, on the one hand, and the competent<br>services of the EC Commission and, where appropriate, the customs autho-<br>rities of the EC Member States, on the other. They shall decide on all practi-<br>cal measures and arrangements necessary for its application, taking into con-<br>sideration rules in the field of data protection. They may recommend to the<br>competent bodies amendments which they consider should be made to this<br>Protocol.</p>
<p>2. The Contracting Parties shall transmit to each other lists of the competent<br>authorities appointed to act as correspondents for the purpose of the opera-<br>tional implementation of this Protocol.</p>
<p>As regards cases covered by Community competence, due account shall<br>be taken in this respect of specific situations which, because of the urgency<br>or the fact that only two countries are involved in a request or communica-<br>tion, may require direct contacts between the competent services of the<br>EFTA States and of the EC Member States for the handling of requests or<br>exchange of information. This information shall be supplemented by lists,<br>to be revised when necessary, of officials of those services responsible for<br>preventing, investigating and combatting contravention of customs legisla-<br>tion.</p>
<p>Moreover, in order to ensure the maximum efficiency of operation of this<br>Protocol, the Contracting Parties shall take appropriate measures to ensure<br>that the departments responsible for combatting customs fraud establish di-<br>rect personal contacts, including when applicable at the level of local cus-<br>toms authorities, in order to facilitate exchange of information and handling<br>of requests.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 11</p>
<p>218</p>
<p>3. The Contracting Parties shall consult each other and subsequently keep<br>each other informed of the detailed rules of implementation which are adop-<br>ted in accordance with the provisions of this Article.</p>
<p>Article 15</p>
<p>Complementarity</p>
<p>1. This Protocol shall complement and not impede application of any agree-<br>ments on mutual assistance which have been concluded or may be concluded<br>between EC Member States and EFTA States as well as between the EFTA<br>States. Nor shall it preclude more extensive mutual assistance granted under<br>such agreements.</p>
<p>2. Without prejudice to Article 11, these agreements do not prejudice Com-<br>munity provisions governing the communication between the competent ser-<br>vices of the EC Commission and the customs authorities of the Member Sta-<br>tes of any information obtained in customs matters which could be of Com-<br>munity interest.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 11</p>
<p>219</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 12</h1>
<h2>ON CONFORMITY ASSESSMENT AGREEMENTS<br>WITH THIRD COUNTRIES</h2>
<p>Mutual recognition agreements with third countries concerning conformity<br>assessment for products where the use of a mark is provided for in EC legisla-<br>tion will be negotiated on the initiative of the Community. The Community<br>will negotiate on the basis that the third countries concerned will conclude<br>with the EFTA States parallel mutual recognition agreements equivalent to<br>those to be concluded with the Community. The Contracting Parties shall<br>cooperate in accordance with the general information and consultation pro-<br>cedures set out in the EEA Agreement. Should a difference arise in relations<br>with third countries, it will be dealt with in accordance with the relevant pro-<br>visions of the EEA Agreement.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 12</p>
<p>220</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 13</h1>
<h2>ON THE NON-APPLICATION OF ANTI-DUMPING<br>AND COUNTERVAILING MEASURES</h2>
<p>The application of Article 26 of the Agreement is limited to the areas cove-<br>red by the provisions of the Agreement and in which the Community acquis<br>is fully integrated into the Agreement.</p>
<p>Moreover, unless other Solutions are agreed upon by the Contracting Par-<br>ties, its application is without prejudice to any measures which may be intro-<br>duced by the Contracting Parties to avoid circumvention of the following<br>measures aimed at third countries:</p>
<p>- anti-dumping measures;</p>
<p>- &nbsp;countervailing duties;</p>
<p>- &nbsp;measures against illicit commercial practices attributable to third count-<br>ries.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 13</p>
<p>221</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 14</h1>
<h2>ON TRADE IN CO AL AND STEEL PRODUCTS</h2>
<p>Article 1</p>
<p>This Protocol applies to products covered by the bilateral Free Trade Agree-<br>ments (hereinafter referred to as the 'Free Trade Agreements’) concluded<br>between, on the one hand, the European Coal and Steel Community and its<br>Member States and the individual EFTA States, on the other hand, or, as<br>the case may be, between the Member States of the European Coal and Steel<br>Community and the respective EFTA States.</p>
<p>Article 2</p>
<p>1. The Free Trade Agreements shall remain unaffected unless otherwise<br>provided in this Protocol. Where the Free Trade Agreements do not apply,<br>the provisions of this Agreement are applicable. Where the substantive pro-<br>visions of the Free Trade Agreements continue to be applied, the institutio-<br>nal provisions of those agreements will also be applicable.</p>
<p>2. Quantitative restrictions on exports, measures having equivalent effect<br>and customs duties and charges having equivalent effect, applicable to trade<br>within the European Economic Area, shall be abolished.</p>
<p>Article 3</p>
<p>The Contracting Parties shall not introduce any restrictions or administrative<br>and technical regulations which would form, in trade between the Contrac-<br>ting Parties, an impediment to the free movement of products covered by<br>this Protocol.</p>
<p>Article 4</p>
<p>The substantive competition rules applicable to undertakings concerning<br>products covered by this Protocol are included in Protocol 25. Secondary le-<br>gislation is set out in Protocol 21 and Annex XIV.</p>
<p>Article 5</p>
<p>The Contracting Parties shall comply with the rules for aid to the Steel indu-<br>stry. They recognize in particular the relevance of, and accept of the Com-<br>munity rules for aid to the Steel industry as laid down in Commission Deci-<br>sion 322/89/ECSC which expires on 31 December 1991. The Contracting Par-<br>ties declare their commitment to integrate into the EEA Agreement new<br>Community rules for aid to the Steel industry by the entry into force of this<br>Agreement, provided that they are substantially similar to those of the afore-<br>mentioned act.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 14</p>
<p>222</p>
<p>Article 6</p>
<p>1. The Contracting Parties shall exchange information on markets. The<br>EFTA States shall use their best endeavours in order to ensure that Steel pro-<br>ducers, consumers and merchants provide such information.</p>
<p>2. The EFTA States shall use their best endeavours in order to ensure that<br>the steel-producing undertakings established within their territories will par-<br>ticipate in annual surveys concerning investment referred to in Article 15 of<br>Commission Decision No 3302/81/ECSC of 18 November 1981. The Cont-<br>racting Parties will exchange, without prejudice to the requirements of busi-<br>ness confidentiality, information on significant investment or disinvestment<br>projects.</p>
<p>3. All matters relating to the exchange of information between the Contrac-<br>ting Parties shall be covered by the general institutional provisions of this<br>Agreement.</p>
<p>Article 7</p>
<p>The Contracting Parties note that the rules of origin laid down in Protocol 3<br>of the Free Trade Agreements concluded between the European Economic<br>Community and individual EFTA States are replaced by Protocol 4 to this<br>Agreement.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 14</p>
<p>223</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 15</h1>
<h2>ON TRANSITIONAL PERIODS ON THE FREE<br>MOVEMENT OF PERSONS (SWITZERLAND AND<br>LIECHTENSTEIN)</h2>
<p>Article 1</p>
<p>The provisions of the Agreement and its Annexes relating to free movement<br>of persons between the EC Member States and EFTA States shall apply sub-<br>ject to the transitional provisions laid down in this Protocol.</p>
<p>Article 2</p>
<p>1. Notwithstanding the provisions of Article 4, Switzerland, on the one<br>hand, and EC Member States and other EFTA States, on the other hand,<br>may maintain in force until 1 January 1998 with regard to nationals from EC<br>Member States and other EFTA States and to nationals of Switzerland, re-<br>spectively, national provisions submitting to prior authorization entry, resi-<br>dence and employment.</p>
<p>2. Switzerland may maintain in force until 1 January 1998 with regard to na-<br>tionals of EC Member States and other EFTA States quantitative limitations<br>for new residents and seasonal workers. These quantitative limitations will<br>be gradually reduced until the end of the transitional period.</p>
<p>Article 3</p>
<p>1. Notwithstanding the provisions of paragraph 3, Switzerland may main-<br>tain in force until 1 January 1998 national provisions limiting professional<br>and geographical mobility of seasonal workers, including the obligation for<br>such workers to leave the territory of Switzerland at the expiry of their seaso-<br>nal permit for at least three months. As from 1 January 1993, seasonal per-<br>mits will be automatically renewed for seasonal workers holding a seasonal<br>work contract on their return to the territory of Switzerland.</p>
<p>2. Articles 10, 11 and 12 of Regulation (EEC) No 1612/68 as listed in point<br>2 of Annex V to the Agreement shall apply in Switzerland with regard to<br>seasonal workers as from 1 January 1997.</p>
<p>3. As from 1 January 1993 and notwithstanding the provisions of Article 2<br>of this Protocol, the provisions of Article 28 of the Agreement and of Annex<br>V to the Agreement shall apply to seasonal workers in Switzerland provided<br>that such workers have completed 30 months of seasonal employment in the<br>territory of Switzerland within a preceding reference period of four consecu-<br>tive years.</p>
<p>Article 4</p>
<p>Switzerland may maintain in force until:</p>
<p>- 1 January 1996 national provisions requiring a worker who, while having</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 15</p>
<p>224</p>
<p>his residence in a territory other than that of Switzerland, is employed in<br>the territory of Switzerland (frontier worker) to return each day to the<br>territory of his residence;</p>
<p>- &nbsp;1 January 1998 national provisions requiring a worker who, while having<br>his residence in a territory other than that of Switzerland, is employed in<br>the territory of Switzerland (frontier worker) to return each week to the<br>territory of his residence;</p>
<p>- &nbsp;1 January 1997 national provisions concerning the limitation of employ-<br>ment of frontier workers within defined frontier zones;</p>
<p>- &nbsp;1 January 1995 national provisions submitting to prior authorization em-<br>ployment undertaken by frontier workers in Switzerland.</p>
<p>Article 5</p>
<p>1. Liechtenstein, on the one hand, and EC Member States and other EFTA<br>States, on the other hand, may maintain in force until 1 January 1998 with<br>regard to nationals from EC Member States and other EFTA States and to<br>nationals of Liechtenstein, respectively, national provisions submitting to<br>prior authorization entry, residence and employment.</p>
<p>2. Liechtenstein may maintain in force until 1 January 1998 with regard to<br>nationals of EC Member States and other EFTA States quantitative limita-<br>tions for new residents, seasonal workers and frontier workers. These quan-<br>titative limitations will be gradually reduced.</p>
<p>Article 6</p>
<p>1. Liechtenstein may maintain in force until 1 January 1998 national provi-<br>sions limiting professional mobility of seasonal workers, including the obli-<br>gation of such workers to leave the territory of Liechtenstein at the expiry of<br>their seasonal permit for at least three months. As from 1 January 1993, sea-<br>sonal permits will be automatically renewed for seasonal workers holding a<br>seasonal work contract on their return to the territory of Liechtenstein.</p>
<p>2. Articles 10, 11 and 12 of Regulation (EEC) No 1612/68 as listed in point<br>2 of Annex V to the Agreement shall apply in Liechtenstein with regard to<br>residents as from 1 January 1995 and with regard to seasonal workers as from<br>1 January 1997.</p>
<p>3. The arrangements provided for in paragraph 2 shall also apply to mem-<br>bers of the family of a self-employed person in the territory of Liechtenstein.</p>
<p>Article 7</p>
<p>Liechtenstein may maintain in force until:</p>
<p>- &nbsp;1 January 1998 national provisions requiring a worker who, while having<br>his residence in a territory other than that of Liechtenstein, is employed<br>in the territory of Liechtenstein (frontier worker) to return each day to<br>the territory of his residence;</p>
<p>- &nbsp;1 January 1998 national provisions on restrictions on professional mobi-<br>lity and access to professions for all categories of workers;</p>
<p>15 Riksdagen 1991/92. 1 saml. Nr 170. Bil. 15</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 15</p>
<p>225</p>
<p>- 1 January 1995 national provisions on restrictions on access to professio-<br>nal activities with regard to self-employed persons having their residence<br>in the territory of Liechtenstein. Such restrictions may be upheld until 1<br>January 1997 with regard to self-employed persons having their residence<br>in a territory other than that of Liechtenstein.</p>
<p>Article 8 ,</p>
<p>1. Other than the limitations set out in Articles 2 to 7, Switzerland and<br>Liechtenstein shall not introduce any new restrictive measures concerning<br>entry, employment and residence of workers and self-employed persons as<br>of the date of signature of the Agreement.</p>
<p>2. Switzerland and Liechtenstein shall take all necessary measures so that<br>during the transitional periods nationals of EC Member States and of other<br>EFTA States may take up available employment in the territory of Switzer-<br>land and Liechtenstein with the same priority as nationals of Switzerland and<br>Liechtenstein, respectively.</p>
<p>Article 9</p>
<p>1. As from 1 January 1996 the Contracting Parties shall examine the results<br>of the application of the transitional periods as set out in Articles 2 to 4. On<br>completion of this examination the Contracting Parties may, on the basis of<br>new data and with a view to a possible shortening of the transition period,<br>propose provisions intended to adjust the transitional periods.</p>
<p>2. At the end of the transitional period for Liechtenstein the transitional<br>measures shall be jointly revicwcd by the Contracting Parties, duly taking<br>into account the specific geographic situation of Liechtenstein.</p>
<p>Article 10</p>
<p>During transitional periods, existing bilateral arrangements will continue to<br>apply unless provisions which are more favourable in their effect to citizens<br>of the EC Member States and EFTA States result from the Agreement.</p>
<p>Article 11</p>
<p>For the purposes of this Protocol, the terms 'seasonal worker’ and 'frontier<br>worker’ contained therein shall have the meaning as defined by the national<br>legislation of Switzerland and Liechtenstein, respectively, at the time of sig-<br>nature of the Agreement.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 15</p>
<p>226</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 16</h1>
<p>ON MEASURES IN THE FIELD OF SOCIAL<br>SECURITY RELATED TO TRANSITIONAL PERIODS<br>ON THE FREE MOVEMENT OF PERSONS<br>(SWITZERLAND AND LIECHTENSTEIN)</p>
<p>Article 1</p>
<p>For the purposes of applying this Protocol and Regulation (EEC) No 1408/71<br>of 14 June 1971 on the application of social security schemes to employed<br>persons, to self-employed persons and to members of their families moving<br>within the Community (OJ No L 149, 5.7.1971, p.416), 'seasonal worker’<br>shall mean, as regards Switzerland and Liechtenstein, any worker who is a<br>national of an EC Member State or another EFTA State and who is the hol-<br>der of a seasonal permit in the sense of the national legislation of Switzerland<br>and Liechtenstein, respectively, for a maximum period of nine months.</p>
<p>Article 2</p>
<p>During the period of validity of the permit, the seasonal worker shall be en-<br>titled to unemployment benefits according to Swiss and Liechtenstein legis-<br>lation, respectively, under the same conditions as a national of Switzerland<br>and Liechtenstein, respectively, and according to the provisions of Regula-<br>tion (EEC) No 1408/71.</p>
<p>Article 3</p>
<p>Part of the unemployment contributions paid by seasonal workers shall be<br>reimbursed by Switzerland and Liechtenstein, respectively, to the States of<br>residence of these workers according to the following procedure:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;For each State, the total amount of contributions shall be established<br>according to the number of seasonal workers who are nationals of<br>this State and present in Switzerland and Liechtenstein, respecti-<br>vely, at the end of August, to the average length of the season, to<br>the wages and to the rates of contribution to Swiss and Liechtenstein<br>unemployment insurance, respectively (shares of the employer and<br>of the worker).</p>
<p>(b) The amount reimbursed to each State shall correspond to fifty per<br>cent of the total amount of the contributions, calculated according<br>to subparagraph (a).</p>
<p>(c) The reimbursement shall be made only when the total number of<br>seasonal workers residing in the State concerned exceeds, during the<br>accounting period, five hundred as regards Switzerland or fifty as<br>regards Liechtenstein.</p>
<p>Article 4</p>
<p>The provisions on the reimbursement of unemployment contributions con-<br>tained in the conventions on unemployment insurance concluded by Switzer-</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 16</p>
<p>227</p>
<p>land with France (Convcntion of 14 December 1978), Italy (Convention of</p>
<p>12 December 1978)', the Federal Republic of Germany (Convention of 17<br>November 1982), Austria (Convention of 14 December 1978) and the Princi-<br>pality of Liechtenstein (Convention of 15 January 1979), shall continue to<br>apply during the transitional periods.</p>
<p>Article 5</p>
<p>The validity of this Protocol shall be limited to the length of the transitional<br>periods as defined in Protocol 15.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 16</p>
<p><sup>1</sup> To be examined in the light of current bilateral discussions between Italy and Switzer-<br>land.</p>
<p>228</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 17</h1>
<h2>CONCERNING ARTICLE 34</h2>
<p>1. Article 34 of the Agreement shall not prejudge the adoption of legislation<br>or the application of any measures by the Contracting Parties concerning<br>third country access to their markets.</p>
<p>Any legislation in a field which is governed by the Agreement shall be<br>dealt with according to the procedures laid down in the Agreement and the<br>Contracting Parties shall endeavour to elaborate corresponding EEA rules.</p>
<p>In all other cases the Contracting Parties shall inform the EEA Joint Com-<br>mittee of the measures and, whenever necessary, endeavour to adopt provi-<br>sions to ensure that the measures are not circumvented through the territory<br>of the other Contracting Parties.</p>
<p>If no agreement can be reached on such rules or provisions, the Contrac-<br>ting Party concerned may take measures necessary to prevent circumven-<br>tion.</p>
<p>2. For the definition of the beneficiaries of the rights derived from Article<br>34 , Title I of the General Programme for the abolition of restrictions on<br>freedom of establishment (OJ 2, 15.1.1962, p.36/62) shall apply with the<br>same legal effect as within the Community.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 17</p>
<p>229</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 18</h1>
<h2>ON INTERNAL PROCEDURES</h2>
<h2>FOR THE IMPLEMENTATION OF ARTICLE 43</h2>
<p>For the Community, the procedures to be followed for the implementation<br>of Article 43 of the Agreement are set out in the Treaty establishing the<br>European Economic Community.</p>
<p>For the EFTA States, the procedures are set out in the Agreement on a<br>Standing Committee of the EFTA States and will cover the following ele-<br>ments:</p>
<p>An EFTA State which intends to take measures in accordance with Article<br>43 of the Agreement shall in good time give notice thereof to the standing<br>committee of the EFTA States.</p>
<p>However, in case of secrecy or urgency, notice shall be given to the other<br>EFTA States and to the standing committee of the EFTA States at the latest<br>by the date of entry into force of the measures.</p>
<p>The standing committee of the EFTA States shall examine the situation<br>and deliver an opinion regarding the introduction of the measures. It shall<br>keep the situation under review, and may at any time make, by majority<br>vote, recommendations regarding the possible amendment, suspension or<br>abolition of the measures introduced or regarding any other measures to as-<br>sist the EFTA State concerned to overcome its difficulties.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 18</p>
<p>230</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 19</h1>
<h2>ON MARITIME TRANSPORT</h2>
<p>The Contracting Parties shall not apply between themselves the measures<br>referred to in Council Regulations (EEC)/4057/86 (OJ No L 378, 31.12.1986,<br>p.14) and (EEC)4058/86 (OJ No L 378, 31.12.1986, p.21) and Council Deci-<br>sion 83/573/EEC (OJ No L 332, 28.11.1983, p.37) or any other similar mea-<br>sures, provided that the acquis on maritime transport included in the Agree-<br>ment is fully implemented.</p>
<p>The Contracting Parties will coordinate their actions and measures to-<br>wards third countries and third country companies in the area of maritime<br>transport according to the following provisions:</p>
<p>1. If a Contracting Party decides to monitor the activities of certain third<br>countries in the field of cargo shipping it shall inform the EEA Joint Com-<br>mittee and may propose to other Contracting Parties that they participate in<br>this action.</p>
<p>2. If a Contracting Party decides to make diplomatic representations to a<br>third country in response to a restriction or a threat to restrict free access to<br>cargoes in ocean trades, it shall inform the EEA Joint Committee. The other<br>Contracting Parties may decide to join in such diplomatic representations.</p>
<p>3. If any of the Contracting Parties intends to take measures or action<br>against a third country and/or third country shipowners in order to respond<br>inter alia to unfair pricing practices by certain third country shipowners enga-<br>ged in international cargo liner shipping or to restrictions or threats to re-<br>strict free access to cargoes in ocean trades, it shall inform the EEA Joint<br>Committee. Whenever appropriate, the Contracting Party initiating the pro-<br>cedures may request the other Contracting Parties to cooperate in these pro-<br>cedures.</p>
<p>The other Contracting Parties may decide to take the same measures or<br>actions for their own jurisdictions. Where measures or actions taken by a<br>Contracting Party are evaded through the territory of other Contracting Par-<br>ties which have not adopted such measures or actions, the Contracting Party<br>whose measures or actions are evaded may take appropriate measures to re-<br>medy the situation.</p>
<p>4. If any of the Contracting Parties intends to negotiate cargo-sharing arran-<br>gements as described in Articles 5(1) and 6 of Council Regulation No<br>(EEC)4055/86 (OJ No L 378, 31.12.1986, p.l) or to extend the provisions of<br>this Regulation to nationals of a third country as foreseen in Article 7 the-<br>reof, it shall inform the EEA Joint Committee.</p>
<p>If one or more of the other Contracting Parties object to the intended ac-<br>tion, a satisfactory solution will be sought within the EEA Joint Committee.<br>If the Contracting Parties do not reach agreement, appropriate measures<br>may be taken . If no other means are available, such measures may include<br>the revocation between Contracting Parties of the principle of freedom to<br>provide maritime transport services, established in Article 1 of the Regula-<br>tion.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 19</p>
<p>231</p>
<p>5. Whenever possible, the information referred to in paragraphs 1 to 4 shall<br>be given in good time to allow the Contracting Parties to coordinate their<br>actions.</p>
<p>6. At the request of a Contracting Party, consultations shall take place bet-<br>ween Contracting Parties on questions concerning shipping matters and<br>dealt with in international organizations and on the various aspects of devel-<br>opment which have taken place in relations between Contracting Parties and<br>third countries in shipping matters, and on the functioning of bilateral or<br>multilateral agreements concluded in this sphere.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 19</p>
<p>232</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 20</h1>
<h2>ON ACCESS TO INLAND WATERWAYS</h2>
<p>1. Mutual right of access shall be granted by each of the Contracting Parties<br>to each other’s inland waterways. In the case of the Rhine and the Danube,<br>the Contracting Parties will take all necessary steps to reach simultaneously<br>the objective of equal access and freedom of establishment in the area of<br>inland waterways.</p>
<p>2. Arrangements to ensure reciprocal equal access to inland waterways wit-<br>hin the territory of the Contracting Parties for all Contracting Parties shall<br>be elaborated within the international organizations concerned by 1 January<br>1996, taking into account the obligations under relevant multilateral Agree-<br>ments.</p>
<p>3. All relevant “acquis” in inland waterways shall apply as of the entry into<br>force of the Agreement to those EFTA States which have, at that time, ac-<br>cess to Community inland waterways, and to the other EFTA States as soon<br>as they obtain the right of equal access.</p>
<p>However, Article 8 of Regulation (EEC) No 1101/89 of 27 April 1989 (OJ<br>No L 116, 28.4.1989, p.25), as adapted for the purposes of the Agreement,<br>shall become applicable to such inland waterway vessels from the latter<br>EFTA States which are brought into service after 1 January 1993 as soon as<br>these States obtain access to the inland waterways of the Community.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 20</p>
<p>233</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 21</h1>
<h2>ON THE IMPLEMENTATION OF COMPETITION<br>RULES APPLICABLE TO UNDERTAKINGS</h2>
<p>Article 1</p>
<p>The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall, in an agreement between the EFTA<br>States, be entrusted with equivalent powers and similar functions to those of<br>the EC Commission, at the time of the signature of the Agreement, for the<br>application of the competition rules of the Treaty establishing the European<br>Economic Community and the Treaty establishing the European Coal and<br>Steel Community, enabling the EFTA Surveillance Authority to give effect<br>to the principles laid down in Articles 1 (2) (e) and 53 to 60 of the Agree-<br>ment, and in Protocol 25.</p>
<p>The Community shall, where necessary, adopt the provisions giving effect<br>to the principles laid down in Articles 1 (2) (e) and 53 to 60 of the Agree-<br>ment, and in Protocol 25, in order to ensure that the EC Commission has<br>equivalent powers and similar functions under this Agreement to those<br>which it has, at the time of the signature of the Agreement, for the applica-<br>tion of the competition rules of the Treaty establishing the European Econo-<br>mic Community and the Treaty establishing the European Coal and Steel<br>Community.</p>
<p>Article 2</p>
<p>If, following the procedures set out in Part VII of the Agreement, new acts<br>for the implementation of Articles 1 (2) (e) and 53 to 60 and of Protocol 25,<br>or on amendments of the acts listed in Article 3 of this Protocol are adopted,<br>corresponding amendments shall be made in the agreement setting up the<br>EFTA Surveillance Authority so as to ensure that the EFTA Surveillance<br>Authority will be entrusted simultaneously with equivalent powers and simi-<br>lar functions to those of the EC Commission.</p>
<p>Article 3</p>
<p>1. In addition to the acts listed in Annex XIV, the following acts reflect the<br>powers and functions of the EC Commission for the application of the com-<br>petition rules of the Treaty establishing the European Economic Commu-<br>nity:</p>
<p>Control of concentrations</p>
<p>1. 389 R 4064: Articles 6 to 25 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 4064/89 of<br>21 December 1989 on the control of concentrations between undertakings<br>(OJ No L 395, 30.12.1989, p.l), as corrected by OJ No L 257, 21.9.1990,<br>p.13</p>
<p>2. 390 R 2367: Commission Regulation (EEC) No 2367/90 of 25 July 1990<br>on the notifications, time limits and hearings provided for in Council Regula-<br></p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 21</p>
<p>234</p>
<p>tion (EEC) No 4064/89 on the control of concentrations between underta-<br>kings (OJ No L 219, 14.8.1990, p.5)</p>
<p>General procedural rules</p>
<p>3. 362 R 0017: Council Regulation No 17/62 of 6 February 1962. First Regu-<br>lation implementing Articles 85 and 86 of the Treaty (OJ No 13, 21.2.1962,<br>p.204/62), as amended by:</p>

<p>179 H: Act concerning the conditions of Accession and Adjustments<br>to the Treaties - Accession to the European Communities of the<br>Hellenic Republic (OJ No L 291, 19.11.1979, p.93)</p>
<p>1 851: Act concerning the conditions of Accession and Adjustments<br>to the Treaties - Accession to the European Communities of the<br>Kingdom of Spain and the Portuguese Republic (OJ No L 302,</p>

<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;368 R 1133: Regulation (EEC) No 1133/68 of 26 July 1968 (OJ No L<br>189, 1.8.1968, p.l)</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;375 R 1699: Regulation (EEC) No 1699/75 of 2 July 1975 (OJ No L<br>172, 3.7.1975, p.l 1)</p>
<p>179 H: Act concerning the conditions of Accession and Adj ustments<br>to the Treaties - Accession to the European Communities of the<br>Hellenic Republic (OJ No L 291, 19.11.1979, p.94)</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;385 R 2526: Regulation (EEC) No 2526/85 of 5 August 1985 (OJ No<br>L240, 7.9.1985, p.l)</p>

<p>Transport</p>
<p>6. 362 R 0141: Council Regulation No 141/62 of 26 November 1962 exemp-<br>ting transport from the application of Council Regulation No 17 amended<br>by Regulations Nos 165/65/EEC and 1002/67/EEC (OJ No 124, 28.11.1962,<br>p.2751/62)</p>
<p>7. 368 R 1017: Article 6 and Articles 10 to 31 of Council Regulation (EEC)<br>No 1017/68 of 19 July 1968 applying rules of competition to transport by rail,<br>road and inland waterway (OJ No L 175, 23.7.1968, p.l)</p>
<p>8. 369 R 1629: Commission Regulation (EEC) No 1629/69 of 8 August 1969<br>on the form, content and other details of complaints pursuant to Article 10,<br>applications pursuant to Article 12 and notifications pursuant to Article 14<br>(1) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1017/68 of 19 July 1968 (OJ No L 209,<br>21.8.1969, p.l)</p>

<p>31.12.1986, p.4)</p>
<p>12. 388 R 4260: Commission Regulation (EEC) No 4260/88 of 16 December<br>1988 on the Communications, complaints and applications and the hearings<br>provided for in Council Regulation (EEC) No 4056/86 laying down detailed<br>rules for the application of Articles 85 and 86 of the Treaty to maritime trans-<br>port (OJ No L 376, 31.12.1988, p.l)</p>
<p>13. 387 R 3975: Council Regulation (EEC) No 3975/87 of 14 December 1987<br>laying down the procedure for the application of the rules on competition to<br>undertakings in the air transport sector (OJ No L 374, 31.12.1987, p.l), as<br>amended by:</p>
