<p>14. 388 R 4261: Commission Regulation (EEC) No 4261/88 of 16 December<br>1988 on the form, content and other details of complaints and of applica-<br>tions, and the hearings provided for in Council Regulation (EEC) No<br>3975/87 laying down the procedure for the application of the rules of compe-<br>tition to undertakings in the air transport sector (OJ No L 376, 31.12.1988,<br>p.10)</p>
<p>2. In addition to the acts listed in Annex XIV, the following acts reflect<br>the powers and functions of the EC Commission for the application of the</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 21</p>
<p>236</p>
<p>competition rules of the Treaty establishing the European Coal and Steel<br>Community (ECSC):</p>
<p>1. Article (ECSC) 65 (2), subparagraphs 3 to 5, (3), (4), subparagraph 2,<br>and (5)</p>
<p>2. Article (ECSC) 66 (2), subparagraphs 2 to 4, and (4) to (6)</p>
<p>3. 354 D 7026: High Authority Decision No 26/54 of 6 May 1954 laying down<br>in implementation of Article 66 (4) of the Treaty a regulation concerning in-<br>formation to be furnished (OJ of the European Coal and Steel Community<br>No 9, 11.5.1954, p.350/54)</p>
<p>4. 378 S 0715: Commission Decision No 715/78/ECSC of 6 April 1978 con-<br>cerning limitation periods in proceedings and the enforcement of sanctions<br>under the Treaty establishing the European Coal and Steel Community (OJ<br>No L 94, 8.4.1978, p.22)</p>
<p>5. 384 S 0379: Commission Decision No 379/84/ECSC of 15 February 1984<br>defining the powers of officials and agents of the Commission instructed to<br>carry out the checks provided for in the ECSC Treaty and decisions taken<br>in application thereof (OJ No L 46, 16.2.1984, p.23)</p>
<p>Article 4</p>
<p>1. Agreements, decisions and concerted practices of the kind described in<br>Article 53 (1) which come into existence after the entry into force of the Ag-<br>reement and in respect of which the parties seek application of Article 53 (3)<br>shall be notified to the competent surveillance authority pursuant to Article<br>56, Protocol 23 and the rules referred to in Articles 1 to 3 of this Protocol.<br>Until they have been notified, no decision in application of Article 53 (3)<br>may be taken.</p>
<p>2. Paragraph 1 shall not apply to agreements, decisions and concerted<br>practices where:</p>
<p>(a) the only parties thereto are undertakings from one EC Member<br>State or from one EFTA State and the agreements, decisions or<br>concerted practices do not reläte either to imports or to exports bet-<br>ween Contracting Parties;</p>
<p>(b) not more than two undertakings are party thereto, and the agree-<br>ments only:</p>
<p>(i) restrict the freedom of one party to the contract in determining<br>the prices or conditions of business upon which the goods which<br>he has obtained from the other party to the contract may be<br>resold; or</p>
<p>(ii) impose restrictions on the exercise of the rights of the assignee<br>or user of industrial property rights - in particular patents, ut-<br>ility models, designs or trademarks - or of the person entitled<br>under a contract to the assignment, or grant, of the right to use<br>a method of manufacture or knowledge relating to the use and<br>to the application of industrial processes;</p>
<p>(c) they have as their sole object:</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 21</p>
<p>237</p>
<p>(i) the development or uniform application of standards or types;<br>or</p>
<p>(ii) joint research or development; or</p>
<p>(iii) specialization in the manufacture of products including agree-<br>ments necessary for achieving this:</p>
<p>-where the products which are the subject of specialization do<br>not, in a substantial part of the territory covered by the Agree-<br>ment, represent more than 15 per cent of the volume of busi-<br>ness done in identical products or those considered by consu-<br>mers to be similar by reason of their characteristics, price and<br>use; and</p>
<p>- where the total annual turnover of the participating underta-<br>kings does not exceed ECU 200 million.</p>
<p>These agreements, decisions and concerted practices may be notified to the<br>competent surveillance authority pursuant to Article 56, Protocol 23 and the<br>rules referred to in Articles 1 to 3 of this Protocol.</p>
<p>Article 5</p>
<p>1. Agreements, decisions and concerted practices of the kind described in<br>Article 53 (1) which are in existence at the date of entry into force of the<br>Agreement and in respect of which the parties seek application of Article 53<br>(3) shall be notified to the competent surveillance authority pursuant to the<br>provisions in Article 56, Protocol 23 and the rules referred to in Articles 1 to<br>3 of this Protocol within six months of the date of entry into force of the<br>Agreement.</p>
<p>2. Paragraph 1 shall not apply to agreements, decisions or concerted practi-<br>ces of the kind described in Article 53 (1) of the Agreement and falling under<br>Article 4 (2) of this Protocol; these may be notified to the competent surveil-<br>lance authority pursuant to Article 56, Protocol 23 and the rules referred to<br>in Articles 1 to 3 of this Protocol.</p>
<p>Article 6</p>
<p>The competent surveillance authority shall specify in its decisions pursuant<br>to Article 53 (3) the date from which the decisions shall take effect. That<br>date may be earlier than the date of notification as regards agreements, deci-<br>sions of associations of undertakings or concerted practices falling under Ar-<br>ticles 4 (2) and 5 (2) of this Protocol, or those falling under Article 5 (1) of<br>this Protocol which have been notified within the time limit specified in Ar-<br>ticle 5 (1).</p>
<p>Article 7</p>
<p>1. Where agreements, decisions or concerted practices of the kind described<br>in Article 53 (1) which are in existence at the date of entry into force of the<br>Agreement and notified within the time limits specified in Article 5 (1) of</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 21</p>
<p>238</p>
<p>this Protocol do not satisfy the requirements of Article 53 (3) and the under-<br>takings or associations of undertakings concerned cease to give effect to<br>them or modify them in such a manner that they no longer fall under the<br>prohibition contained in Article 53 (1) or that they satisfy the requirements<br>of Article 53 (3), the prohibition contained in Article 53 (1) shall apply only<br>for a period fixed by the competent surveillance authority. A decision by the<br>competent surveillance authority pursuant to the foregoing sentence shall<br>not apply as against undertakings and associations of undertakings which did<br>not expressly consent to the notification.</p>
<p>2. Paragraph 1 shall apply to agreements, decisions or concerted practices<br>falling under Article 4 (2) of this Protocol which are in existence at the date<br>of entry into force of the Agreement if they are notified within six months<br>after that date.</p>
<p>Article 8</p>
<p>Applications and notifications submitted to the EC Commission prior to the<br>date of entry into force of the Agreement shall be deemed to comply with<br>the provisions on application and notification under the Agreement.</p>
<p>The competent surveillance authority pursuant to Article 56 of the Agree-<br>ment and Article 10 of Protocol 23 may require a duly completed form as<br>prescribed for the implementation of the Agreement to be submitted to it<br>within such time as it shall appoint. In that event, applications and notifica-<br>tions shall be treated as properly made only if the forms are submitted within<br>the prescribed period and in accordance with the provisions of the Agree-<br>ment.</p>
<p>Article 9</p>
<p>Fines for infringement of Article 53 (1) shall not be imposed in respect of<br>any act prior to notification of the agreements, decisions and concerted prac-<br>tices to which Articles 5 and 6 of this Protocol apply and which have been<br>notified within the period specified therein.</p>
<p>Article 10</p>
<p>The Contracting Parties shall ensure that the measures affording the neces-<br>sary assistance to officials of the EFTA Surveillance Authority and the EC<br>Commission, in order to enable them to make their investigations as fore-<br>seen under the Agreement, are taken within six months of the entry into<br>force of the Agreement.</p>
<p>Article 11</p>
<p>As regards agreements, decisions and concerted practices already in exis-<br>tence at the date of entry into force of the Agreement which fall under Ar-<br>ticle 53 (1), the prohibition in Article 53 (1) shall not apply where the agree-<br>ments, decisions or practices are modified within six months from the date<br></p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 21</p>
<p>239</p>
<p>of entry into force of the Agreement so as to fulfil the conditions contained<br>in the block exemptions provided for in Annex XIV.</p>
<p>Article 12</p>
<p>As regards agreements, decisions of associations of undertakings and con-<br>certed practices already in existence at the date of entry into force of the<br>Agreement which fall under Article 53 (1), the prohibition in Article 53 (1)<br>shall not apply, from the date of entry into force of the Agreement, where<br>the agreements, decisions or practices are modified within six months from<br>the date of entry into force of the Agreement so as not to fall under the prohi-<br>bition of Article 53 (1) any more.</p>
<p>Article 13</p>
<p>Agreements, decisions of associations of undertakings and concerted practi-<br>ces which benefit from an individual exemption granted under Article 85 (3)<br>of the Treaty establishing the European Economic Community before the<br>entry into force of the Agreement shall continue to be exempted as regards<br>the provisions of the Agreement, until their date of expiry as provided for in<br>the decisions granting these exemptions or until the EC Commission other-<br>wise decides, whichever date is the earlier.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 21</p>
<p>240</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 22</h1>
<h2>CONCERNING THE DEFINITION OF</h2>
<h2>’UNDERTAKING’</h2>
<h2>AND TURNOVER’ (ARTICLE 56)</h2>
<p>Article 1</p>
<p>For the purposes of the attribution of individual cases pursuant to Article 56<br>of the Agreement, an 'undertaking’ shall be any entity carrying out activities<br>of a commercial or economic nature.</p>
<p>Article 2</p>
<p>Turnover’ within the meaning of Article 56 of the Agreement shall comprise<br>the amounts derived by the undertakings concerned, in the territory covered<br>by the Agreement, in the preceding financial year from the sale of products<br>and the provision of services falling within the undertaking’s ordinary scope<br>of activities after deduction of sales rebates and of value added tax and other<br>taxes directly related to turnover.</p>
<p>Article 3</p>
<p>In place of turnover, the following shall be used:</p>
<p>(a) for credit institutions and other financial institutions, their total as-<br>sets multiplied by the ratio between loans and advances to credit<br>institutions and customers in transactions with residents in the terri-<br>tory covered by the Agreement and the total sum of those loans and<br>advances;</p>
<p>(b) for insurance undertakings, the value of gross premiums received<br>from residents in the territory covered by the Agreement, which<br>shall comprise all amounts received and receivable in respect of in-<br>surance contracts issued by or on behalf of the insurance underta-<br>kings, including also outgoing reinsurance premiums, and after de-<br>duction of taxes and parafiscal contributions or levies charged by<br>reference to the amounts of individual premiums or the total value<br>of premiums.</p>
<p>Article 4</p>
<p>1. In derogation from the definition of the turnover relevant for the applica-<br>tion of Article 56 of the Agreement, as contained in Article 2 of this Proto-<br>col, the relevant turnover shall be constituted:</p>
<p>(a) as regards agreements, decisions of associations of undertakings<br>and concerted practices related to distribution and supply arrange-<br>ments between non-competing undertakings, of the amounts deri-<br>ved from the sale of goods or the provision of services which are the<br>subject matter of the agreements, decisions or concerted practices,<br>and from the other goods or services which are considered by users</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 22</p>
<p>241</p>
<p>16 Riksdagen 1991/92. 1 saml. Nr 170. Bil. 15<br></p>
<p>to be equivalent in view of their characteristics, price and intended<br>use;</p>
<p>(b) as regards agreements, decisions of associations of undertakings<br>and concerted practices related to arrangements on transfer of tech-<br>nology between non-competing undertakings, of the amounts deri-<br>ved from the sale of goods or the provision of services which result<br>from the technology which is the subject matter of the agreements,<br>decisions or concerted practices, and of the amounts derived from<br>the sale of those goods or the provision of those services which that<br>technology is designed to improve or replace.</p>
<p>2. However, where at the time of the coming into existence of arrangements<br>as described in paragraph 1 (a) and (b) turnover as regards the sale of goods<br>or the provision of services is not in evidence, the general provision as contai-<br>ned in Article 2 shall apply.</p>
<p>Article 5</p>
<p>1. Where individual cases concern products falling within the scope of appli-<br>cation of Protocol 25, the relevant turnover for the attribution of those cases<br>shall be the turnover achieved in these products.</p>
<p>2. Where individual cases concern products falling within the scope of appli-<br>cation of Protocol 25 as well as products or services falling within the scope<br>of application of Articles 53 and 54 of the Agreement, the relevant turnover<br>is determined by taking into account all the products and services as provided<br>for in Article 2 .</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 22</p>
<p>242</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 23</h1>
<h2>CONCERNING THE COOPERATION BETWEEN<br>THE SURVEILLANCE AUTHORITIES (ARTICLE 58)<br>GENERAL PRINCIPLES</h2>
<p>Article 1</p>
<p>The EFTA Surveillance Authority and the EC Commission shall exchange<br>information and consult each other on general policy issues at the request of<br>either of the surveillance authorities.</p>
<p>The EFTA Surveillance Authority and the EC Commission, in accordance<br>with their internal rules, respecting Article 56 of the Agreement and Proto-<br>col 22 and the autonomy of both sides in their decisions, shall cooperate in<br>the handling of individual cases falling under Article 56 (1) (b) and (c), (2),<br>second sentence and (3), as provided for in the provisions below.</p>
<p>For the purposes of this Protocol, the term Territory of a surveillance aut-<br>hority’ shall mean for the EC Commission the territory of the EC Member<br>States to which the Treaty establishing the European Economic Community<br>or the Treaty establishing the European Coal and Steel Community, as the<br>case may be, applies, upon the terms laid down in those Treaties, and for the<br>EFTA Surveillance Authority the territories of the EFTA States to which the<br>Agreement applies.</p>
<p>THE INITIAL PHASE OF THE PROCEEDINGS</p>
<p>Article 2</p>
<p>In cases falling under Article 56 (1) (b) and (c), (2), second sentence and (3)<br>of the Agreement, the EFTA Surveillance Authority and the EC Commis-<br>sion shall without undue delay forward to each other notifications and com-<br>plaints to the extent that it is not apparent that these have been addressed to<br>both surveillance authorities. They shall also inform each other when ope-<br>ning ex officio procedures.</p>
<p>The surveillance authority which has received information as provided for<br>in the first subparagraph may present its comments thereon within 40 wor-<br>king days of its receipt.</p>
<p>Article 3</p>
<p>The competent surveillance authority shall, in cases falling under Article 56<br>(1) (b) and (c), (2), second sentence and (3) of the Agreement, consult the<br>other surveillance authority when:</p>
<p>- &nbsp;publishing its intention to give a negative clearance;</p>
<p>- &nbsp;publishing its intention to take a decision in application of Article 53 (3);<br>or</p>
<p>- &nbsp;addressing to the undertakings or associations of undertakings concerned<br>its statement of objections.</p>
<p>The other surveillance authority may deliver its comments within the time<br>limits set out in the abovementioned publication or statement of objections.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 23</p>
<p>243</p>
<p>Observations received from the undertakings concerned or third parties<br>shall be transmitted to the other surveillance authority.</p>
<p>Article 4</p>
<p>In cases falling under Article 56 (1) (b) and (c), (2), second sentence and (3)<br>of the Agreement, the competent surveillance authority shall transmit to the<br>other surveillance authority the administrative letters by which a file is closed<br>or a complaint rejected.</p>
<p>Article 5</p>
<p>In cases falling under Article 56 (1) (b) and (c), (2), second sentence and (3)<br>of the Agreement, the competent surveillance authority shall invite the other<br>surveillance authority to be represented at hearings of the undertakings con-<br>cerned. The invitation shall also extend to the States falling within the com-<br>petence of the other surveillance authority.</p>
<p>ADVISORY COMMITTEES</p>
<p>Article 6</p>
<p>In cases falling under Article 56 (1) (b) and (c), (2), second sentence and (3)<br>of the Agreement, the competent surveillance authority shall, in due time,<br>inform the other surveillance authority of the date of the meeting of the Ad-<br>visory Committee and transmit the relevant documentation.</p>
<p>All documents forwarded for that purpose from the other surveillance aut-<br>hority shall be presented to the Advisory Committee of the surveillance aut-<br>hority which is competent to decide on a case in accordance with Article 56<br>together with the material sent out by that surveillance authority.</p>
<p>Each surveillance authority and the States falling within its competence<br>shall be entitled to be present in the Advisory Committees of the other sur-<br>veillance authority and to express their views therein; they shall not have,<br>however, the right to vote.</p>
<p>REQUEST FOR DOCUMENTS AND THE RIGHT TO MAKE<br>OBSERVATIONS</p>
<p>Article 7</p>
<p>In cases falling under Article 56 (1) (b) and (c), (2), second sentence and (3)<br>of the Agreement, the surveillance authority which is not competent to de-<br>cide on a case in accordance with Article 56 may request at all stages of the<br>proceedings copies of the most important documents lodged with the compe-<br>tent surveillance authority for the purpose of establishing the existence of<br>infringements of Articles 53 and 54 or of obtaining a negative clearance or<br>exemption, and may furthermore, before a final decision is taken, make any<br>observations it considers appropriate.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 23</p>
<p>244</p>
<p>ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANCE</p>
<p>Article 8</p>
<p>1. When sending a request for information to an undertaking or association<br>of undertakings located within the territory of the other surveillance autho-<br>rity, the competent surveillance authority, as defined in Article 56 of the Ag-<br>reement, shall at the same time forward a copy of the request to the other<br>surveillance authority.</p>
<p>2. Where an undertaking or association of undertakings does not supply the<br>information requested within the time limit fixed by the competent surveil-<br>lance authority, or supplies incomplete information, the competent surveil-<br>lance authority shall by decision require the information to be supplied. In<br>the case of undertakings or associations of undertakings located within the<br>territory of the other surveillance authority, the competent surveillance aut-<br>hority shall forward a copy of that decision to the other surveillance autho-<br>rity.</p>
<p>3. At the request of the competent surveillance authority, as defined in Ar-<br>ticle 56 of the Agreement, the other surveillance authority shall, in accor-<br>dance with its internal rules, undertake investigations within its territory in<br>cases where the competent surveillance authority so requesting considers it<br>to be necessary.</p>
<p>4. The competent surveillance authority is entitled to be represented and<br>take an active part in investigations carried out by the other surveillance aut-<br>hority in respect of paragraph 3.</p>
<p>5. All information obtained during such investigations on request shall be<br>transmitted to the surveillance authority which requested the investigations<br>immediately after their finalization.</p>
<p>6. Where the competent surveillance authority, in cases falling under Ar-<br>ticle 56 (1) (b) and (c), (2), second sentence and (3) of the Agreement, car-<br>ries out investigations within its territory, it shall inform the other surveil-<br>lance authority of the fact that such investigations have taken place and, on<br>request, transmit to that authority the relevant results of the investigations.</p>
<p>Article 9</p>
<p>1. Information acquired as a result of the application of this Protocol shall<br>be used only for the purpose of procedures under Articles 53 and 54 of the<br>Agreement.</p>
<p>2. The EC Commission, the EFTA Surveillance Authority, the competent<br>authorities of the EC Member States and the EFTA States, and their officials<br>and other servants shall not disclose information acquired by them as a result<br>of the application of this Protocol and of the kind covered by the obligation<br>of professional secrecy.</p>
<p>3. Rules on professional secrecy and restricted use of information provided<br>for in the Agreement or in the legislation of the Contracting Parties shall not<br>prevent exchange of information as set out in this Protocol.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 23</p>
<p>245</p>
<p>Article 10</p>
<p>1. Undertakings shall, in cases of notifications of agreements, address the<br>notification to the competent surveillance authority in accordance with Ar-<br>ticle 56 of the Agreement. Complaints may be addressed to either surveil-<br>lance authority.</p>
<p>2. Notifications or complaints addressed to the surveillance authority which,<br>pursuant to Article 56, is not competent to decide on a given case shall be<br>transferred without delay to the competent surveillance authority.</p>
<p>3. If, in the preparation or initiation of ex officio proceedings, it becomes<br>apparent that the other surveillance authority is competent to decide on a<br>case in accordance with Article 56 of the Agreement, this case shall be trans-<br>ferred to the competent surveillance authority.</p>
<p>4. Once a case is transmitted to the other surveillance authority as provided<br>for in paragraphs 2 and 3, a retransmission of the case may not take place.<br>A transmission of a case may not take place after the publishing of the inten-<br>tion to give a negative clearance, the publishing of the intention to take a<br>decision in application of Article 53 (3) of the Agreement, the addressing to<br>undertakings or associations of undertakings concerned of the statement of<br>objections or the sending of a letter informing the applicant that there are<br>insufficient grounds for pursuing the complaint.</p>
<p>Article 11</p>
<p>The date of submission of an application or notification shall be the date on<br>which it is received by the EC Commission or the EFTA Surveillance Autho-<br>rity, regardless of which of these is competent to decide on the case under<br>Article 56 of the Agreement. Where, however, the application or notifica-<br>tion is sent by registered post, it shall be deemed to have been received on<br>the date shown on the postmark of the place of posting.</p>
<p>LANGUAGES</p>
<p>Article 12</p>
<p>Undertakings shall be entitled to address and be addressed by the EFTA Sur-<br>veillance Authority and the EC Commission in an official language of an<br>EFTA State or the European Community which they choose as regards noti-<br>fications, applications and complaints. This shall also cover all instances of a<br>proceeding, whether it be opened on notification, application or complaint<br>or ex officio by the competent surveillance authority.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 23</p>
<p>246</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 24</h1>
<h2>ON COOPERATION IN THE FIELD OF CONTROL OF<br>CONCENTRATIONS</h2>
<p>GENERAL PRINCIPLES</p>
<p>Article 1</p>
<p>1. The EFTA Surveillance Authority and the EC Commission shall ex-<br>change information and consult each other on general policy issues at the<br>request of either of the surveillance authorities.</p>
<p>2. In cases falling under Article 57 (2) (a), the EC Commission and the<br>EFTA Surveillance Authority shall cooperate in the handling of concentra-<br>tions as provided for in the provisions set out below.</p>
<p>3. For the purposes of this Protocol, the term “territory of a surveillance<br>authority” shall mean for the EC Commission the territory of the EC Mem-<br>ber States to which the Treaty establishing the European Economic Commu-<br>nity or the Treaty establishing the European Coal and Steel Community, as<br>the case may be, applies, upon the terms laid down in those Treaties, and for<br>the EFTA Surveillance Authority the territories of the EFTA States to which<br>the Agreement applies.</p>
<p>Article 2</p>
<p>1. Cooperation shall take place, in accordance with the provisions set out in<br>this Protocol, where:</p>
<p>(a) the combined turnover of the undertakings concerned in the terri-<br>tory of the EFTA States equals 25 per cent or more of their total<br>turnover within the territory covered by the Agreement; or</p>
<p>(b) each of at least two of the undertakings concerned has a turnover<br>exceeding ECU 250million in the territory of the EFTA States; or</p>
<p>(c) the concentration is liable to create or strengthen a dominant posi-<br>tion as a result of which effective competition would be significantly<br>impeded in the territories of the EFTA States or a substantial part<br>thereof.</p>
<p>2. Cooperation shall also take place where:</p>
<p>(a) the concentration threatens to create or strengthen a dominant po-<br>sition as a result of which effective competition would be signifi-<br>cantly impeded on a market within an EFTA State which presents<br>all the characteristics of a distinct market, be it a substantial part of<br>the territory covered by this Agreement or not; or</p>
<p>(b) an EFTA State wishes to adopt measures to protect legitimate inte-<br>rests as set out in Article 7.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 24</p>
<p>247</p>
<p>INITIAL PHASE OF THE PROCEEDINGS</p>
<p>Article 3</p>
<p>1. The EC Commission shall transmit to the EFTA Surveillance Authority<br>copies of notifications of the cases referred to in Article 2 (1) and (2) (a)<br>within three working days and, as soon as possible, copies of the most impor-<br>tant documents lodged with or issued by the EC Commission.</p>
<p>2. The EC Commission shall carry out the procedures set out for the imple-<br>mentation of Article 57 of the Agreement in close and constant liaison with<br>the EFTA Surveillance Authority. The EFTA Surveillance Authority and<br>EFTA States may express their views upon those procedures. For the purpo-<br>ses of Article 6 of this Protocol, the EC Commission shall obtain information<br>from the competent authority of the EFTA State concerned and give it the<br>opportunity to make known its views at every stage of the procedures up<br>to the adoption of a decision pursuant to that Article. To that end, the EC<br>Commission shall give it access to the file.</p>
<p>HEARINGS</p>
<p>Article 4</p>
<p>In cases referred to in Article 2 (1) and (2) (a), the EC Commission shall<br>invite the EFTA Surveillance Authority to be represented at the hearings of<br>the undertakings concerned. The EFTA States may likewise be represented<br>at those hearings.</p>
<p>THE EC ADVISORY COMMITTEE ON CONCENTRATIONS</p>
<p>Article 5</p>
<p>1. In cases referred to in Article 2 (1) and (2) (a), the EC Commission shall<br>in due time inform the EFTA Surveillance Authority of the date of the mee-<br>ting of the EC Advisory Committee on Concentrations and transmit the rele-<br>vant documentation.</p>
<p>2. All documents forwarded for that purpose from the EFTA Surveillance<br>Authority, including documents emanating from EFTA States, shall be pre-<br>sented to the EC Advisory Committee on Concentrations together with the<br>other relevant documentation sent out by the EC Commission.</p>
<p>3. The EFTA Surveillance Authority and the EFTA States shall be entitled<br>to be present in the EC Advisory Committee on Concentrations and to ex-<br>press their views therein; they shall not have, however, the right to vote.</p>
<p>RIGHTS OF INDIVIDUAL STATES</p>
<p>Article 6</p>
<p>1. The EC Commission may, by means of a decision notified without delay<br>to the undertakings concerned, to the competent authorities of the EC Mem-<br>ber States and to the EFTA Surveillance Authority, refer a notified concent-</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 24</p>
<p>248</p>
<p>ration to an EFTA State where a concentration threatens to create or<br>strengthen a dominant position as a result of which effective competition<br>would be significantly impeded on a market within that State, which presents<br>all the characteristics of a distinct market, be it a substantial part of the terri-<br>tory covered by the Agreement or not.</p>
<p>2. In cases referred to in paragraph 1, any EFTA State may appeal to the<br>European Court of Justice, on the same grounds and conditions as an EC<br>Member State under Article 173 of the Treaty establishing the European<br>Economic Community, and in particular request the application of interim<br>measures, for the purpose of applying its national competition law.</p>
<p>Article 7</p>
<p>1. Notwithstanding the sole competence of the EC Commission to deal with<br>concentrations of a Community dimension as set out in Council Regulation<br>(EEC) No 4064/89 of 21 December 1989 on the control of concentrations<br>between undertakings (OJ No L 395, 30.12.1989, p.l, as corrected by OJ<br>No L 257, 21.9.1990, p.13), EFTA States may take appropriate measures to<br>protect legitimate interests other than those taken into consideration accor-<br>ding to the above Regulation and compatible with the general principles and<br>other provisions as provided for, directly or indirectly, under the Agree-<br>ment.</p>
<p>2. Public security, plurality of media and prudential rules shall be regarded<br>as legitimate interests within the meaning of paragraph 1.</p>
<p>3. Any other public interest must be communicated to the EC Commission<br>and shall be recognized by the EC Commission after an assessment of its<br>compatibility with the general principles and other provisions as provided<br>for, directly or indirectly, under the Agreement before the measures referred<br>to above may be taken. The EC Commission shall inform the EFTA Surveil-<br>lance Authority and the EFTA State concerned of its decision within one<br>month of that communication.</p>
<p>ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANCE</p>
<p>Article 8</p>
<p>1. In carrying out the duties assigned to it for the implementation of Article<br>57, the EC Commission may obtain all necessary information from the<br>EFTA Surveillance Authority and EFTA States.</p>
<p>2. When sending a request for information to a person, an undertaking or<br>an association of undertakings located within the territory of the EFTA Sur-<br>veillance Authority, the EC Commission shall at the same time forward a<br>copy of the request to the EFTA Surveillance Authority.</p>
<p>3. Where such persons, undertakings or associations of undertakings do not<br>provide the information requested within the period fixed by the EC Com-<br>mission, or provide incomplete information, the EC Commission shall by</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 24</p>
<p>249</p>
<p>decision require the information to be provided and forward a copy of that<br>decision to the EFTA Surveillance Authority.</p>
<p>4. At the request of the EC Commission, the EFTA Surveillance Authority<br>shall undertake investigations within its territory.</p>
<p>5. The EC Commission is entitled to be represented and take an active part<br>in investigations carried out pursuant to paragraph 4.</p>
<p>6. All information obtained during such investigations on request shall be<br>transmitted to the EC Commission immediately after their finalization.</p>
<p>7. Where the EC Commission carries out investigations within the territory<br>of the Community, it shall, as regards cases falling under Article 2 (1) and<br>(2) (a), inform the EFTA Surveillance Authority of the fact that such investi-<br>gations have taken place and on request transmit in an appropriate way the<br>relevant results of the investigations.</p>
<p>PROFESSIONAL SECRECY</p>
<p>Article 9</p>
<p>1. Information acquired as a result of the application of this Protocol shall be<br>used only for the purpose of procedures under Article 57 of the Agreement.</p>
<p>2. The EC Commission, the EFTA Surveillance Authority, the competent<br>authorities of the EC Member States and of the EFTA States, and their offi-<br>cials and other servants shall not disclose information acquired by them as a<br>result of the application of this Protocol and of the kind covered by the obli-<br>gation of professional secrecy.</p>
<p>3. Rules on professional secrecy and restricted use of information provided<br>for in the Agreement or the legislation of the Contracting Parties shall not<br>prevent the exchange and use of information as set out in this Protocol.</p>
<p>NOTIFICATIONS</p>
<p>Article 10</p>
<p>1. Undertakings shall address their notifications to the competent surveil-<br>lance authority in accordance with Article 57 (2) of the Agreement.</p>
<p>2. Notifications or complaints addressed to the authority which, pursuant to<br>Article 57, is not competent to take decisions on a given case shall be trans-<br>ferred without delay to the competent surveillance authority.</p>
<p>Article 11</p>
<p>The date of submission of a notification shall be the date on which it is recei-<br>ved by the competent surveillance authority.</p>
<p>The date of submission of a notification shall be the date on which it is<br>received by the EC Commission or the EFTA Surveillance Authority, if the<br>case is notified in accordance with the implementing rules under Article 57<br>of the Agreement, but falls under Article 53.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 24</p>
<p>250</p>
<p>LANGUAGES</p>
<p>Article 12</p>
<p>1. Undertakings shall be entitled to address and be addressed by the EFTA<br>Surveillance Authority and the EC Commission in an official language of an<br>EFTA State or the Community which they choose as regards notifications.<br>This shall also cover all instances of a proceeding.</p>
<p>2. If undertakings choose to address a surveillance authority in a language<br>which is not one of the official languages of the States falling within the com-<br>petence of that authority, or a working language of that authority, they shall<br>simultaneously supplement all documentation with a translation into an offi-<br>cial language of that authority.</p>
<p>3. As far as undertakings are concerned which are not parties to the notifica-<br>tion, they shall likewise be entitled to be addressed by the EFTA Surveil-<br>lance Authority and the EC Commission in an appropriate official language<br>of an EFTA State or of the Community or in a working language of one of<br>those authorities. If they choose to address a surveillance authority in a lang-<br>uage which is not one of the official languages of the States falling within<br>the competence of that authority, or a working language of that authority,<br>paragraph 2 shall apply.</p>
<p>4. The language which is chosen for the translation shall determine the lang-<br>uage in which the undertakings may be addressed by the competent autho-<br>rity.</p>
<p>TIME LIMITS AND OTHER PROCEDURAL QUESTIONS</p>
<p>Article 13</p>
<p>As regards time limits and other procedural provisions, the rules implemen-<br>ting Article 57 shall apply also for the purpose of the cooperation between<br>the EC Commission and the EFTA Surveillance Authority and EFTA States,<br>unless otherwise provided for in this Protocol.</p>
<p>TRANSITION RULE</p>
<p>Article 14</p>
<p>Article 57 shall not apply to any concentration which was the subject of an<br>agreement or announcement or where control was acquired before the date<br>of entry into force of the Agreement. It shall not in any circumstances apply<br>to a concentration in respect of which proceedings were initiated before that<br>date by a national authority with responsibility for competition.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 24</p>
<p>251</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 25</h1>
<h2>ON COMPETITION REGARDING COAL AND STEEL</h2>
<p>Article 1</p>
<p>1. All agreements between undertakings, decisions by associations of un-<br>dertakings and concerted practices in respect of particular products referred<br>to in Protocol 14 which may affect trade between Contracting Parties tending<br>directly or indirectly to prevent, restrict or distort normal competition within<br>the territory covered by this Agreement shall be prohibited, and in particular<br>those tending:</p>
<p>(a) to fix or determine prices;</p>
<p>(b) to restrict or control production, technical development or invest-<br>ment;</p>
<p>(c) to share markets, products, customers or sources of supply.</p>
<p>2. However, the competent surveillance authority, as provided for in Article<br>56 of the Agreement, shall authorize specialization agreements or joint-<br>buying or joint-selling agreements in respect of the products referred to in<br>paragraph 1, if it finds that:</p>
<p>(a) such specialization or such joint-buying or joint-selling will make<br>for a substantial improvement in the production or distribution of<br>those products;</p>
<p>(b) the agreement in question is essential in order to achieve these re-<br>sults and is not more restrictive than is necessary for that purpose;<br>and</p>
<p>(c) the agreement is not liable to give the undertakings concerned the<br>power to determine the prices, or to control or restrict the produc-<br>tion or marketing, of a substantial part of the products in question<br>within the territory covered by the Agreement, or to shield them<br>against effective competition from other undertakings within the<br>territory covered by the Agreement.</p>
<p>If the competent surveillance authority finds that certain agreements are<br>strictly analogous in nature and effect to those referred to above, having par-<br>ticular regard to the fact that this paragraph applies to distributive underta-<br>kings, it shall authorize them also when satisfied that they meet the same<br>requirements.</p>
<p>3. Any agreement or decision prohibited by paragraph 1 shall be automati-<br>cally void and may not be relied upon before any court or tribunal in the EC<br>Member States or the EFTA States.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 25</p>
<p>Article 2</p>
<p>1. Any transaction shall require the prior authorization of the competent<br>surveillance authority, as provided for in Article 56 of the Agreement, sub-<br>ject to the provisions of paragraph 3 of this Article, if it has in itself the direct<br>or indirect effect of bringing about within the territory covered by the Agree-</p>
<p>252</p>
<p>ment, as a result of action by any person or undertaking or group of persons<br>or undertakings, a concentration between undertakings at least one of which<br>is covered by Article 3, which may affect trade between Contracting Parties,<br>whether the transaction concerns a single product or a number of different<br>products, and whether it is effected by merger, acquisition of shares or parts<br>of the undertaking or assets, loan, contract or any other means of control.</p>
<p>2. The competent surveillance authority, as provided for in Article 56 of the<br>Agreement, shall grant the authorization referred to in paragraph 1 if it finds<br>that the proposed transaction will not give to the persons or undertakings<br>concerned the power, in respect of the product or products within its jurisdic-<br>tion:</p>
<p>- &nbsp;to determine prices, to control or restrict production or distribution or to<br>hinder effective competition in a substantial part of the market for those<br>products; or</p>
<p>- &nbsp;to evade the rules of competition instituted under this Agreement, in par-<br>ticular by establishing an artificially privileged position involving a sub-<br>stantial advantage in access to supplies or markets.</p>
<p>3. Classes of transactions may, in view of the size of the assets or underta-<br>kings concerned, taken in conjunction with the kind of concentration to be<br>effected, be exempted from the requirement of prior authorization.</p>
<p>4. If the competent surveillance authority, as provided for in Article 56 of<br>the Agreement, finds that public or private undertakings which, in law or in<br>fact, hold or acquire in the market for one of the products within its jurisdic-<br>tion a dominant position shielding them against effective competition in a<br>substantial part of the territory covered by this Agreement are using that<br>position for purposes contrary to the objectives of this Agreement and if such<br>abuse may affect trade between Contracting Parties, it shall make to them<br>such recommendations as may be appropriate to prevent the position from<br>being so used.</p>
<p>Article 3</p>
<p>For the purposes of Articles 1 and 2 as well as for the purposes of information<br>required for their application and proceedings in connection with them, 'un-<br>dertaking’ means any undertaking engaged in production in the coal or the<br>Steel industry within the territory covered by the Agreement, and any under-<br>taking or agency regularly engaged in distribution other than sale to domes-<br>tic consumers or small craft industries.</p>
<p>Article 4</p>
<p>Annex XIV to the Agreement contains specific provisions giving effect to<br>the principles set out in Articles 1 and 2.</p>
<p>Article 5</p>
<p>The EFTA Surveillance Authority and the EC Commission shall ensure the<br>application of the principles laid down in Articles 1 and 2 of this Protocol in</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 25</p>
<p>253</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 26</h1>
<h2>ON THE POWERS AND FUNCTIONS OF THE EFTA<br>SURVEILLANCE AUTHORITY IN THE FIELD OF<br>STATE AID</h2>
<p>The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall, in an agreement between the EFTA<br>States, be entrusted with equivalent powers and similar functions to those of<br>the EC Commission, at the time of the signature of the Agreement, for the<br>application of the competition rules applicable to State aid of the Treaty es-<br>tablishing the European Economic Community, enabling the EFTA Surveil-<br>lance Authority to give effect to the principles expressed in Articles 1 (2) (e),<br>49 and 61 to 63 of the Agreement. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall<br>also have such powers to give effect to the competition rules applicable to<br>State aid relating to products falling under the Treaty establishing the Euro-<br>pean Coal and Steel Community as referred to in Protocol 14.<br></p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 26</p>
<p>255</p>
<p>accordance with the provisions giving effect to Articles 1 and 2 as contained<br>in Protocol 21 and Annex XIV to the Agreement.</p>
<p>Article 6</p>
<p>Individual cases referred to in Articles 1 and 2 of this Protocol shall be deci-<br>ded upon by the EC Commission or the EFTA Surveillance Authority in ac-<br>cordance with Article 56 of the Agreement.</p>
<p>Article 7</p>
<p>With a view to developing and maintaining a uniform surveillance throug-<br>hout the European Economic Area in the field of competition and of promo-<br>ting a homogeneous implementation, application and interpretation of the<br>provisions of the Agreement to this end, the competent authorities shall coo-<br>perate in accordance with the provisions set out in Protocol 23.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 25</p>
<p>254</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 27</h1>
<h2>ON COOPERATION IN THE FIELD OF STATE AID</h2>
<p>In order to ensure a uniform implementation, application and interpretation<br>of the rules on State aid throughout the territory of the Contracting Parties<br>as well as to guarantee their harmonious development, the EC Commission<br>and the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall observe the following rules:</p>
<p>(a) Exchange of information and views on general policy issues such as<br>the implementation, application and interpretation of the rules on<br>State aid set out in the Agreement shall be held periodically or at<br>the request of either surveillance authority.</p>
<p>(b) The EC Commission and the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall<br>periodically prepare surveys on State aid in their respective States.<br>These surveys shall be made available to the other surveillance aut-<br>hority.</p>
<p>(c) If the procedure referred to in the first and second subparagraphs<br>of Article 93 (2) of the Treaty establishing the European Economic<br>Community or the corresponding procedure set out in an agree-<br>ment between the EFTA States establishing the EFTA Surveillance<br>Authority is opened for State aid programmes and cases, the EC<br>Commission or the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall give notice<br>to the other surveillance authority as well as to the parties concer-<br>ned to submit their comments.</p>
<p>(d) The surveillance authorities shall inform each other of all decisions<br>as soon as they are taken.</p>
<p>(e) The opening of the procedure referred to in paragraph (c) and the<br>decisions referred to in paragraph (d) shall be published by the com-<br>petent surveillance authorities.</p>
<p>(f) Notwithstanding the provisions of this Protocol, the EC Commis-<br>sion and the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall, at the request of<br>the other surveillance authority, provide on a case-by-case basis in-<br>formation and exchange views on individual State aid programmes<br>and cases.</p>
<p>(g) Information obtained in accordance with paragraph (f) shall be<br>treated as confidential.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 27</p>
<p>256</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 28</h1>
<h2>ON INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY</h2>
<p>Article 1</p>
<p>Substance of protection</p>
<p>1. For the purposes of this Protocol, the term ’intellectual property’ shall<br>include the protection of industrial and commercial property as covered by<br>Article 13 of the Agreement.</p>
<p>2. Without prejudice to the provisions of this Protocol and of Annex XVII,<br>the Contracting Parties shall upon the entry into force of the Agreement ad-<br>just their legislation on intellectual property so as to make it compatible with<br>the principles of free circulation of goods and services and with the level of<br>protection of intellectual property attained in Community law, including the<br>level of enforcement of those rights.</p>
<p>3. Subject to the procedural provisions of the Agreement and without preju-<br>dice to the provisions of this Protocol and of Annex XVII, the EFTA States<br>will adjust, upon request and after consultation between the Contracting<br>Parties, their legislation on intellectual property in order to reach at least the<br>level of protection of intellectual property prevailing in the Community upon<br>signature of the Agreement.</p>
<p>Article 2</p>
<p>Exhaustion of rights</p>
<p>1. To the extent that exhaustion is dealt with in Community measures or ju-<br>risprudence, the Contracting Parties shall provide for such exhaustion of in-<br>tellectual property rights as laid down in Community law. Without prejudice<br>to future developments of case law, this provision shall be interpreted in ac-<br>cordance with the meaning established in the relevant rulings of the Court<br>of Justice of the European Communities given prior to the signature of the<br>Agreement.</p>
<p>2. As regards patent rights, this provision shall take effect at the latest one<br>year after the entry into force of the Agreement.</p>
<p>Article 3</p>
<p>Community Patents</p>
<p>1. The Contracting Parties undertake to use their best endeavours to conc-<br>lude within a period of three years after the entry into force of the Agree-<br>ment relating to Community Patents (89/695/EEC) negotiations with a view<br>to the participation of the EFTA States in that Agreement. However, for<br>Iceland, this date will not be earlier than 1 January 1998.</p>
<p>2. The specific conditions for the participation of the EFTA States in the<br>Agreement relating to Community Patents (89/695/EEC) shall be subject to<br>future negotiations.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 28</p>
<p>257</p>
<p>17 Riksdagen 1991192. 1 saml. Nr 170. Bil. 15</p>
<p>3. The Community undertakes, after the entry into force of the Agreement<br>relating to Community Patents, to invite those EFTA States who so request<br>to enter into negotiations, in accordance with Article 8 of the Agreement<br>relating to Community Patents, provided they will have in addition respected<br>the provisions of paragraphs 4 and 5.</p>
<p>4. The EFTA States shall comply in their law with the substantive provisions<br>of the European Patent Convention of 5 October 1973,</p>
<p>5. As regards patentability of pharmaceutical and foodstuff products, Fin-<br>land shall comply with the provisions of paragraph 4 by 1 January 1995. As<br>regards patentability of pharmaceutical products, Iceland shall comply with<br>the provisions of paragraph 4 by 1 January 1997. The Community shall howe-<br>ver not address an invitation as mentioned in paragraph 3 to Finland and<br>Iceland before these dates, respectively.</p>
<p>6. Notwithstanding Article 2, the holder, or his beneficiary, of a patent for<br>a product mentioned in paragraph 5 filed in a Contracting Party at a time<br>when a product patent could not be obtained in Finland or Iceland for that<br>product may rely upon the rights granted by that patent in order to prevent<br>the import and marketing of that product in the Contracting Parties where<br>that product enjoys patent protection even if that product was put on the<br>market in Finland or Iceland for the first time by him or with his consent.</p>
<p>This right may be invoked for the products referred to in paragraph 5 until<br>the end of the second year after Finland or Iceland, respectively, has made<br>these products patentable.</p>
<p>Article 4</p>
<p>Semiconductor products</p>
<p>1. The Contracting Parties shall have the right to take decisions on the exten-<br>sion of the legal protection of topographies of semiconductor products to<br>persons from any third country or territory, which is not a Contracting Party<br>to this Agreement, who do not benefit from the right to protection according<br>to the provisions of this Agreement. They may also conclude agreements to<br>this effect.</p>
<p>2. The Contracting Party concerned shall endeavour, where the right to pro-<br>tection for topographies of semiconductor products is extended to a non-<br>Contracting Party, to ensure that the non-Contracting Party concerned will<br>grant the right to protection to the other Contracting Parties to this Agree-<br>ment under equivalent conditions to those granted to the Contracting Party<br>concerned.</p>
<p>3. The extension of rights conferred by parallel or equivalent agreements or<br>understandings or equivalent decisions between any of the Contracting Par-<br>ties and third countries shall be recognized and respected by all of the Cont-<br>racting Parties.</p>
<p>4. In respect of paragraphs 1 to 3, the general information, consultation and<br>dispute settlement procedures contained in this Agreement shall apply.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 28</p>
<p>258</p>
<p>5. In any case of different relations arising between any of the Contracting<br>Parties and any third country, consultations shall take place without delay as<br>set out in paragraph 4 concerning the implications of such a divergence for<br>the continuation of the free circulation of goods under this Agreement. Whe-<br>never such an agreement, understanding or decision is adopted, despite con-<br>tinuing disagreement between the Community and any other Contracting<br>Party concerned, Part VII of this Agreement shall apply.</p>
<p>Article 5</p>
<p>International conventions</p>
<p>1. The Contracting Parties shall undertake to obtain their adherence before<br>1 January 1995 to the following multilateral conventions on industrial, intel-<br>lectual and commercial property:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;Paris Convention for the Protection of Industrial Property (Stock-<br>holm Act, 1967);</p>
<p>(b) Berne Convention for the Protection of Literary and Artistic Works<br>(Paris Act, 1971);</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;International Convention for the Protection of Performers, Produ-<br>cers of Phonograms and Broadcasting Organizations (Rome, 1961);</p>
<p>(d) Protocol relating to the Madrid Agreement concerning the interna-<br>tional Registration of Marks (Madrid 1989);</p>
<p>(e) &nbsp;Nice Agreement concerning the International Classification of<br>Goods and Services for the purpose of the Registration of Marks<br>(Geneva 1977, amended 1979);</p>
<p>(f) &nbsp;Budapest Treaty on the International Recognition of the Deposit of<br>Microorganisms for the purposes of Patent Procedure (1980);</p>
<p>(g) &nbsp;Patent Cooperation Treaty (1984).</p>
<p>2. For the adherence of Finland, Ireland and Norway to the Protocol rela-<br>ting to the Madrid Agreement the date mentioned in paragraph 1 shall be<br>replaced by 1 January 1996 and, for Iceland, 1 January 1997, respectively.</p>
<p>3. Upon entry into force of this Protocol, the Contracting Parties shall com-<br>ply in their internal legislation with the substantive provisions of the Conven-<br>tions listed in paragraph 1 (a) to (c). However, Ireland shall comply in its<br>internal legislation with the substantive provisions of the Berne Convention<br>by 1 January 1995.</p>
<p>Article 6</p>
<p>Negotiations concerning the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade</p>
<p>The Contracting Parties agree, without prejudice to the competence of the<br>Community and its Member States in matters of intellectual property, to im-<br>prove the regime established by the Agreement as regards intellectual pro-<br>perty in light of the results of the Uruguay Round negotiations.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 28</p>
<p>259</p>
<table border="1">
<tr><td>
<p>Article 7</p></td><td>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>Mutual information and consultation</p></td><td>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 28</p></td></tr>
</table>
<p>The Contracting Parties undertake to keep each other informed in the con-<br>text of work within the framework of international organizations and within<br>the context of agreements dealing with intellectual property.</p>
<p>The Contracting Parties also undertake, in areas covered by a measure adop-<br>ted in Community law, to engage upon request in prior consultation in the<br>above-mentioned framework and contexts.</p>
<p>Article 8</p>
<p>Transitional provisions</p>
<p>The Contracting Parties agree to enter into negotiations in order to enable<br>full participation of interested EFTA States in future measures concerning<br>intellectual property which might be adopted in Community law.</p>
<p>Should such measures have been adopted before the entry into force of the<br>Agreement, negotiations to participate in such measures shall begin at the<br>earliest opportunity.</p>
<p>Article 9</p>
<p>Competence</p>
<p>The provisions of this Protocol shall be without prejudice to the competence<br>of the Community and of its Member States in matters of intellectual pro-<br>perty.</p>
<p>260</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 29</h1>
<h2>ON VOCATIONAL TRAINING</h2>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 29</p>
<p>In order to promote the movement of young people within the EEA, the<br>Contracting Parties agree to strengthen their cooperation in the field of voca-<br>tional training and to endeavour to improve conditions for students wishing<br>to study in an EEA State other than their own. In this context they agree<br>that the provisions of the Agreement concerning the right of residence for<br>students do not alter the possibilities of individual Contracting Parties, exis-<br>ting before the entry into force of the Agreement, as to the tuition fees char-<br>ged to foreign students.</p>
<p>261</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 30</h1>
<h2>ON SPECIFIC PROVISIONS ON THE<br>ORGANIZATION OF COOPERATION IN THE FIELD<br>OF STATISTICS</h2>
<p>1. A conference of representatives of national statistical organizations of the<br>Contracting Parties, the Statistical Office of the European Communities<br>(Eurostat) and the Office of the Statistical Adviser of the EFTA States (OSA<br>EFTA) shall be created. The conference shall guide statistical cooperation,<br>develop programmes and procedures for statistical cooperation in close<br>coordination with those of the Community and monitor their implementa-<br>tion.</p>
<p>2. The EFTA States shall, from the entry into force of the Agreement, parti-<br>cipate within the framework of plans for priority actions in the field of statis-<br>tical information.<sup>1</sup></p>
<p>The EFTA States shall contribute financially to such actions in accordance<br>with Article 82<sup>1</sup> (a) of the Agreement and the Financial Regulations thereto.</p>
<p>The EFTA States shall participate fully in the EC committees which assist<br>the EC Commission in the management or development of such actions in<br>so far the subjects dealt with are covered by the Agreement.<sup>1</sup></p>
<p>Statistical information from EFTA States relating to matters covered by<br>the Agreement shall be coordinated by the OSA EFTA and transmitted<br>through it to Eurostat. Storage and processing of data shall take place within<br>Eurostat.</p>
<p>4. Eurostat and the OSA EFTA shall ensure that EEA statistics are dissemi-<br>nated to the various users and to the public.</p>
<p>5. The EFTA States shall defray the additional costs incurred by Eurostat<br>for storing, processing and disseminating data from their countries according<br>to the provisions of the Agreement. The amounts involved shall be fixed pe-<br>riodically by the EEA Joint Committee.</p>
<p>6. Confidential statistical data may be used only for statistical purposes.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 30</p>
<p><sup>1</sup>1.e. future plans of the kind established by 389 Y 0628 (01) Council Resolution of<br>19 June 1989 on the implementation of a plan for priority actions in the field of statisti-<br>cal information: Statistical programme of the European Communities 1989 to 1992<br>(OJ No C 161, 28.6.1989, p.l)</p>
<p>262</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 31</h1>
<h2>ON COOPERATION IN SPECIFIC FIELDS OUTSIDE<br>THE FOUR FREEDOMS</h2>
<p>Article 1</p>
<p>Research and technological development</p>
<p>1. (a) The EFTA States shall, from the entry into force of the Agreement,</p>
<p>participate in the implementation of the Framework Programme of<br>Community activities in the field of research and technological de-<br>velopment (1990 to 1994)<sup>1</sup> through participation in its specific pro-<br>grammes.</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;The EFTA States shall contribute financially to the activities refer-<br>red to in subparagraph (a) in accordance with Article 82 (1) (a) of<br>the Agreement.</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;The EFTA States shall, in consequence of subparagraph (b), partici-<br>pate fully in all the EC committees which assist the EC Commission<br>in the management or development of the said Framework Pro-<br>gramme and its specific programmes.</p>
<p>(d) &nbsp;Given the particular nature of the cooperation foreseen in the field<br>of research and technological development, representatives of the<br>EFTA States shall in addition be associated with the work of the<br>Scientific and Technical Research Committee (CREST) and other<br>EC committees which the EC Commission consults in this field, to<br>the extent necessary for the good functioning of that cooperation.</p>
<p>2. In the case of Iceland, however, the provisions of paragraph 1 shall apply<br>from 1 January 1994.</p>
<p>3. Evaluation and major redirection of activities in the Framework Pro-<br>gramme for Community activities in the field of research and technological<br>devlopment (1990 to 1994), after the entry into force of the Agreement, shall<br>be governed by the procedure referred to in Article 79 (3) of the Agreement.</p>
<p>4. The Agreement shall be without prejudice, on the one hand, to the bilate-<br>ral cooperation taking place under the Framework Programme for Commu-<br>nity activities in the field of research and technological development (1987<br>to 1991)<sup>2</sup> and, on the other hand, in so far as they concern cooperation which<br>is not covered by the Agreement, to the bilateral framework agreements for<br>scientific and technical cooperation between the Community and the EFTA<br>States.</p>
<p>Article 2</p>
<p>Information services</p>
<p>The EEA Joint Committee shall, from the entry into force of the Agree-<br>ment, decide the terms and conditions for the participation of the EFTA Sta-</p>
<p><sup>1</sup> 390 D 0221: Council Decision 90/221/Euratom/EEC of 23 April 1990 (1990 to 1994)<br>(OJ No L 117, 8.5.1990, p. 28).</p>
<p>* 387 D 0516: Council Decision 87/516/Euratom/EEC of 28 September 1987 (OJNoL<br>302, 24.10.1987, p. 1)</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 31</p>
<p>263</p>
<p>tes in the programmes established under the EC Council decisions mentio-<br>ned below, or deriving therefrom, in the field of information services:</p>
<p>- 388 D 0524: Council Decision 88/524/EEC of 26 July 1988 concerning the<br>establishment of a plan of action for setting up an information services<br>market( OJ No L 288, 21.10.1988, p. 39)</p>
<p>- 389 D 0286: Council Decision 89/286/EEC of 17 April 1989 on the imple-<br>mentation at Community level of the main phase of strategic programme<br>for innovation and technology transfer (1989 to 1993) (Sprint pro-<br>gramme) ( OJ No L 112, 25.4.1989, p. 12).</p>
<p>Article 3</p>
<p>Environment</p>
<p>1. Cooperation in the field of environment shall be strengthened in the fra-<br>mework of the activities of the Community, in particular in the following<br>areas:</p>
<p>- policy and action programmes on the environment;</p>
<p>- &nbsp;integration of environmental protection requirements into other policies;</p>
<p>- &nbsp;economic and fiscal instruments;</p>
<p>- environmental questions which have transboundary implications;</p>
<p>- &nbsp;major regional and global topics under discussion within international or-<br>ganizations.</p>
<p>The cooperation shall include, inter alia, regular meetings.</p>
<p>2. The necessary decisions shall be taken as soon as possible after the entry<br>into force of the Agreement, to ensure the participation of the EFTA States<br>in the European Environment Agency, once this Agency has been establis-<br>hed by the Community, to the extent that this matter has not been settled<br>prior to that date.</p>
<p>3. Where it has been decided by the EEA Joint Committee that cooperation<br>shall take the form of parallel legislation of identical or similar content by<br>the Contracting Parties, the procedures referred to in Article 79 (3) of the<br>Agreement shall thereafter apply to the preparation of such legislation in the<br>field in question.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 31</p>
<p>Article 4</p>
<p>Education, training and youth</p>
<p>1. The EFTA States shall, from the entry into force of the Agreement, parti-<br>cipate in the Community programme Youth for Europé in accordance with<br>Part VI.</p>
<p>2. The EFTA States shall, as from 1 January 1995, participate subject to the<br>provisions of Part VI, in all programmes of the Community in the field of<br>education, training and youth then in force or adopted. The planning and<br>development of programmes of the Community in this field shall, as from<br>the entry into force of the Agreement, be subject to the procedures referred<br>to in Part VI, in particular Article 79 (3).</p>
<p>264</p>
<p>3. The EFTA States shall contribute financially in accordance with Article<br>82 (1) (a) to the programmes referred to in paragraphs 1 and 2 .</p>
<p>4. The EFTA States shall, as from the start of cooperation in programmes<br>to which they contribute financially in accordance with Article 82 (1) (a),<br>participate fully in all the EC committees which assist the EC Commission<br>in the management or development of these programmes.</p>
<p>5. The EFTA States shall, from the entry into force of the Agreement, parti-<br>cipate in the various activities of the Community involving the exchange of<br>information including, where appropriate, contacts and meetings of experts,<br>seminars and conferences. The Contracting Parties shall, furthermore,<br>through the EEA Joint Committee or otherwise, take any other initiatives<br>which may appear appropriate in this regard.</p>
<p>6. The Contracting Parties shall encourage appropriate cooperation bet-<br>ween the competent organizations, institutions and other bodies in their re-<br>spective territories where this would contribute to the strengthening and<br>broadening of cooperation. This shall apply in particular to matters covered<br>by the activities of the European Centre for Development of Vocational<br>Training (CEDEFOP)<sup>3</sup></p>
<p>Article 5</p>
<p>Social policy</p>
<p>1. In the field of social policy, the dialogue referred to in Article 79 (1) of<br>the Agreement shall comprise, inter alia, the holding of meetings, including<br>contacts between experts, the examination of questions of mutual interest in<br>specific fields, the exchange of information on activities of the Contracting<br>Parties, stocktaking of the State of cooperation and the carrying out, in com-<br>mon, of activities such as seminars and conferences.</p>
<p>2. The Contracting Parties shall seek in particular to strengthen cooperation<br>in the framework of Community activities which may result from the follo-<br>wing Community acts:</p>
<p>- 388 Y 0203: Council Resolution of 21 December 1987 on safety, hygiene<br>and health at work ( OJ No C 28, 3.2.1988, p. 3)</p>
<p>- 391 Y 0531: Council Resolution of 21 May 1991 on the third medium-<br>term Community action programme on equal opportunities for women<br>and men (1991-1995) (OJNoC142, 31.5.1991, p. 1)</p>
<p>- &nbsp;390 Y 627(06): Council Resolution of 29 May 1990 on action to assist the<br>long-term unemployed (OJ No C 157, 27.6.1990, p. 4)</p>
<p>- 386 X 0379: Council Recommendation 86/379/EEC of 24 July 1986 on the</p>
<p><sup>3</sup> 375 R 0337: Council Regulation (EEC) No 337/75 of 10 February 1975 establishing a<br>European Centre for the Development of Vocational Training (OJ No L 39,<br>13.2.1975, p.l), as amended by:</p>
<p>- 1 79 H: Act concerning the Conditions of Accession and Adjustments to the Trea-<br>ties - Accession of the Hellenic Republic (OJ No L 291, 19.11.1979, p.99)</p>
<p>- 1 85 I: Act concerning the Conditions of Accession and Adjustment to the Treaties<br>Accession of the Kingdom of Spain and the Portuguese Republic (OJ No L 302,<br>15.11.85, p.170)</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 31</p>
<p>265</p>
<p>employment of disabled people in the Community (OJ No L 225,<br>12.8.1986, p. 43)</p>
<p>- 389 D 0457: Council Decision 89/457/EEC of 18 July 1989 establishing a<br>medium-term Community action programme concerning the economic<br>and social integration of the economically and socially less privileged<br>groups in the society (OJ No L 224, 2.8.1989 p. 10)</p>
<p>3. The EFTA States shall, from the entry into force of the Agreement, parti-<br>cipate within the framework of the Community actions for the elderly<sup>4</sup>.</p>
<p>The EFTA States shall contribute financially in accordance with Article 82<br>(1) (b) of the Agreement.</p>
<p>The EFTA States shall participate fully in the EC committees which assist<br>the EC Commission in the management or development of the programme<br>except for matters relating to the distribution of EC financial resources bet-<br>ween Member States of the Community.</p>

<p>5. The Contracting Parties shall encourage appropriate cooperation bet-<br>ween the competent organizations, institutions and other bodies in their re-<br>spective territories where this would contribute to the strengthening and<br>broadening of cooperation. This shall apply in particular to matters covered<br>by the activities of the European Foundation for the Improvement of Wor-<br>king and Living Conditions.<sup>5</sup></p>
<p>Article 6</p>
<p>Consumer protection</p>
<p>1. In the field of consumer protection the Contracting Parties shall strengt-<br>hen the dialogue between them by all appropriate means, with a view to<br>identifying areas and activities where closer cooperation could contribute to<br>the attainment of their objectives.</p>
<p>2. The Contracting Parties shall seek to strengthen cooperation in the fra-<br>mework of Community activities, which may result from the following Com-<br>munity acts, in particular in ensuring consumer influence and participation:</p>
<p>389 Y 1122(01): Council Resolution of 9 November 1989 on future priorities<br>for relaunching consumer protection policy (OJ C 294, 22.11.1989, p. 1);</p>
<p>590 DC 0098: Three Year Action Plan of Consumer Policy in the EEC (1990-</p>
<p><sup>4</sup> 391 D 0049: Council Decision 91/49/EEC of 26 November (OJ No L 28,2.2.1991, p.<br>29</p>
<p><sup>5</sup> 375 R 1365: Regulation (EEC) No 1365/75 of the Council of 26 May 1975 on the<br>creation of a European Foundation for the Improvement of Living and Working Con-<br>ditions (OJ No L 139, 30.5.1975, p.l), as amended by:</p>
<p>- 1 79 H: Act concerning the Conditions of Accession and Adjustments to the Trea-<br>ties - Accession of the Hellenic Republic (OJ No L 291, 19.11.1979, p.l 11)</p>
<p>- 1 851: Act concerning the Conditions of Accession and Adjustments to the Treaties -<br>Accession of the Kingdom of Spain and the Portuguese Republic (OJ No L 302,<br>15.11.85, p.170)</p>

<p>266</p>
