<p>1)</p>
<p>Article 7</p>
<p>Small and medium-sized enterprises</p>
<p>1. The cooperation in the field of small and medium-sized enterprises shall<br>in particular be promoted within the framework of actions of the Commu-<br>nity:</p>
<p>- &nbsp;to remove undue administrative, financial and legal constraints on busi-<br>ness;</p>
<p>- &nbsp;to inform and assist enterprises, and in particular small and medium-sized<br>enterprises, on policies and programmes which might be of relevance to<br>them;</p>
<p>- &nbsp;to encourage cooperation and partnership between enterprises, and in<br>particular small and medium-sized enterprises, from different regions of<br>the European Economic Area.</p>
<p>2. The Contracting Parties shall seek in particular to strengthen cooperation<br>in the framework of Community activities which may result from the follo-<br>wing Community acts:</p>
<p>- 388 Y 0727(02): Council Resolution on the improvement of the business<br>environment and action to promote the development of enterprises,<br>especially small and medium-sized enterprises, in the Community (OJ C<br>197, 27.7.1988, p. 6)</p>
<p>- 389 D 0490: Council Decision 89/490/EEC of 28 July 1989 on the impro-<br>vement of the business environment and the promotion of the develop-<br>ment of enterprises, in particular small and medium-sized enterprises, in<br>the Community (OJNoL239, 16.8.1989, p. 33)</p>
<p>- 389 Y 1007(01): Council Resolution of 26 September 1989 in the develop-<br>ment of subcontracting in the Community (OJ C 254, 7.10.1989, p. 1)</p>
<p>- 390 X 0246: Council Recommendation of 28 May 1990 relating to the im-<br>plementation of a policy of administrative simplification in favour of<br>SMEs in the Member States (OJ No L 141, 2.6.1990, p. 55)</p>
<p>- 391 Y 0605: Council Resolution of 27 May 1991 on the action programme<br>for small and medium-sized enterprises including craft industry enterpri-<br>ses (OJ No C146, 5.6.1991, p. 3)</p>
<p>- 391 D 0319: Council Decision 91/319/EEC of 18 June 1991 revising the<br>programme on the improvement of the business environment and the<br>promotion of the development of enterprises, in particular small and<br>medium-sized enterprises in the Community (OJ L 175, 4.7.1991, p. 32)</p>
<p>3. The EEA Joint Committee shall, from the entry into force of the Agree-<br>ment, take the appropriate decisions concerning the modalities, including<br>those concerning any financial contributions by EFTA States, which shall ap-<br>ply in respect of the cooperation in the framework of the Community’s activi-</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 31</p>
<p>267</p>
<p>ties in implementing the Council Decision on the improvement of the busi-<br>ness environment and the promotion of development of enterprises, in parti-<br>cular small and medium-sized enterprises in the Community<sup>6</sup> and activities<br>following therefrom.</p>
<p>Article 8</p>
<p>Tourism</p>
<p>In the field of tourism, the dialogue referred to in Article 79 (1) of the Agree-<br>ment shall aim at identifying areas and actions where closer cooperation<br>could contribute to the promotion of tourism and to the improvement of the<br>general conditions of the tourist industry in the territories of the Contracting<br>Parties.</p>
<p>Article 9</p>
<p>Audiovisual sector</p>
<p>The necessary decisions shall be taken as soon as possible after the entry into<br>force of the Agreement, to ensure the participation by the EFTA States in<br>the programmes established under 390 D 0685 Council Decision 90/685/EEC<br>of 21 December 1990 concerning the implementation of an action pro-<br>gramme to promote the development of the European audiovisual industry<br>(MEDIA) (1991 to 1995) (OJ No L 380, 31.12.1990, p. 37) to the extent this<br>matter has not been settled prior to that date.</p>
<p>Article 10</p>
<p>Civil protection</p>
<p>1. The Contracting Parties shall seek to strengthen cooperation in the fra-<br>mework of Community activities which may result from (489 Y 0223) Reso-<br>lution of the Council and the Representatives of the Member States, meeting<br>within the Council, of 13 February 1989 on the new developments in Com-<br>munity cooperation on civil protection (OJ No C 44, 23.2.1989, p. 3)</p>
<p>2. The EFTA States shall ensure that the number 112 is introduced within<br>their territories as the single European emergency call number in accordance<br>with the provisions of (391 D 0396) Council Decision of 29 July 1991 on the<br>introduction of a single European emergency call number (OJ No L 217,<br>6.8.1991, p. 31)</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 31</p>
<p><sup>6</sup>389 D 0490: Council Decision 89/490/EEC of 28 July 1989 (OJ C 239, 16.8.1989, p.<br>33)</p>
<p>268</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 32</h1>
<h2>ON FINANCIAL MODALITIES FOR<br>IMPLEMENTATION OF ARTICLE 82</h2>
<p>Article 1</p>
<p>Procedure for the determination of the financial participation of the EFTA<br>States</p>
<p>1. The procedure for the calculation of the financial participation of the<br>EFTA States in Community activities shall be that set out in the following<br>paragraphs.</p>
<p>2. The EC Commission shall communicate to the EEA Joint Committee to-<br>gether with relevant background material at the latest on 30 May of each<br>financial year:</p>
<p>(a) the amounts entered “for information”, in commitment appropria-<br>tions and payment appropriations, in the statement of expenditure<br>of the preliminaiy draft general budget of the European Communi-<br>ties, corresponding to the activities in which the EFTA States take<br>part and calculated in accordance with the provisions of Article 82;</p>
<p>(b) the estimated amount of the contributions, entered for information<br>in the statement of revenue of the preliminary draft budget, corre-<br>sponding to the participation of the EFTA States in these activities.</p>
<p>3. The EEA Joint Committee shall, before 1 July each year, confirm that the<br>amounts referred to in paragraph 2 are in accordance with the provisions of<br>Article 82 of the Agreement.</p>
<p>4. The amounts “for information” corresponding to the participation of the<br>EFTA States, both in commitment appropriations and in payment appro-<br>priations, as well as the amount of the contributions, shall be adjusted when<br>the budget is adopted by the budgetary authority, in order to respect the pro-<br>visions of Article 82.</p>
<p>5. As soon as the general budget has been finally adopted by the budgetary<br>authority the EC Commission shall communicate to the EEA Joint Commit-<br>tee the amounts which are entered therein “for information” both in the sta-<br>tement of revenue and of expenditure corresponding to the participation of<br>the EFTA States.</p>
<p>The EEA Joint Committee shall, within a period of 15 days following that<br>communication, confirm that these amounts are in accordance with the pro-<br>visions of Article 82.</p>
<p>6. By 1 January at the latest of each financial year, the Standing Committee<br>of the EFTA States shall inform the EC Commission of the final breakdown<br>of the contribution for each EFTA State.</p>
<p>This breakdown shall be of a binding character for each EFTA State.</p>
<p>Should this information not be provided by 1 January, the breakdown of<br>the previous year shall apply on a provisional basis.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 32</p>
<p>269</p>
<p>Article 2</p>
<p>Making available the contributions of the EFTA States</p>
<p>1. On the basis of the information transmitted by the Standing Committee<br>of the EFTA States pursuant to the provisions of Article 1(6) above, the EC<br>Commission shall establish:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;pursuant to Article 28.1 of the Financial Regulation<sup>1</sup> a proposal for a<br>claim, corresponding to the amount of the participation of the EFTA<br>States, calculated on the basis of the commitment appropriations.<br>The drawing up of the proposal for a claim shall give rise to the for-<br>mal opening by the EC Commission of the commitment appropria-<br>tions on the budgetary lines concerned within the framework of the<br>budgetary structure created to this end.</p>
<p>If the budget has not been adopted by the opening of the financial<br>year, the provisions of Article 9 of the Financial Regulation shall ap-<br>ply.</p>
<p>(b) pursuant to Article 28(2) of the Financial Regulation, a call for funds<br>corresponding to the amount of the contributions of the EFTA Sta-<br>tes, calculated on the basis of the payment appropriations.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 32</p>
<p>2. This order shall provide for the payment, by each EFTA State, of its cont-<br>ribution in two stages:</p>
<p>- &nbsp;six twelfths of its contribution not later than 20 January</p>
<p>- &nbsp;six twelfths of its contribution not later than 15 July.</p>
<p>However, the six twelfths to be paid at the latest on 20 January are calculated<br>on the basis of the amount, “for information” set out in the statement of re-<br>venue of the preliminary draft budget: the regularization of the amounts thus<br>paid shall occur with the payment of the twelfths falling due on 15 July.</p>
<p>If the budget is not adopted before 30 March, the second payment shall<br>also take place on the basis of the amount foreseen “for information” in the<br>preliminary draft budget. The regularization shall take place three months<br>after the completion of the procedures provided for in Article 1(5).</p>
<p>The collections corresponding to the payment by the EFTA States of their<br>contributions shall give rise to the formal opening of payment appropriations<br>on the budgetary lines concerned within the framework of the budgetary<br>structure created to this end without prejudice to the application of the pro-<br>visions of Article 9 of the Financial Regulation.</p>
<p>3. Contributions shall be expressed and paid in ecu.</p>
<p>4. To this end, each EFTA State shall open with its Treasury or the body<br>it shall designate for this purpose an account in ecus on behalf of the EC<br>Commission.</p>
<p><sup>1</sup> Financial Regulation of 21 December 1977 applicable to the general budget of the<br>European Communities (OJ L No L 355, 31.12.1977, p. 1), as modified by Council<br>Regulation (Euratom,ECSC,EEC) No 610/90 of 13 March 1990 (OJ No L 70,<br>16.3.1990, p. 1), hereinafter referred to as the Financial Regulation.</p>
<p>270</p>
<p>5. Any delay in the entries in the account referred to in paragraph 4 in rela-<br>tion to the deadlines set out in paragraph 2 shall give rise to the payment, by<br>the EFTA State concerned, of interest at a rate equal to the rate applied by<br>the European Monetary Co-operation Fund to its operations in ecus, plus<br>1,5 of a percentage point, for the month of the expiration date and published<br>each month in the Official Journal of the European Communities, series C.</p>
<p>Article 3</p>
<p>Adjustments in the light of implementation</p>
<p>1. The amounts of the participation of the EFTA States, determined for<br>each budgetary line concerned, in accordance with the provisions of Article<br>82 of the Agreement shall normally remain unchanged during the financial<br>year in question.</p>
<p>2. The EC Commission, at the time of the closure of the accounts relating<br>to each financial year (n), within the framework of the establishment of the<br>revenue and expenditure account, shall proceed to the regularization of the<br>accounts with respect to the participation of the EFTA States, taking into<br>consideration:</p>
<p>- &nbsp;modifications which have taken place, either by transfer or by supple-<br>mentary budget during the financial year;</p>
<p>- &nbsp;the final implementation of the appropriations for the financial year, ta-<br>king into account possible cancellations and carry-overs;</p>
<p>- any sums covering Community related expenditure which the EFTA Sta-<br>tes cover individually or payments made by EFTA States in kind, e.g.<br>administrative support.</p>
<p>This regularization shall occur in the framework of the establishment of<br>the budget for the following year (n + 2).</p>
<p>3. However, in exceptional circumstances duly justified, and in so far as the<br>proportionality factor has to be safeguarded, the EC Commission may re-<br>quest, from the EFTA States, after approval by the EEA Joint Committee,<br>an additional contribution during the same financial year as that during<br>which the variation has occurred. Such additional contributions shall be re-<br>gistered on the accounts referred to in Article 2(4) on a date to be fixed by<br>the EEA Joint Committee and which shall as far as possible coincide with<br>the regularization foreseen in Article 2(2). In the event of delay in these regi-<br>strations, the provisions of Article 2(5) shall apply.</p>
<p>4. Complementary rules for the implementation of paragraphs 1 to 3 shall be<br>adopted as necessary by the EEA Joint Committee.</p>
<p>This shall apply in particular as regards the manner in which account shall<br>be taken of any sums covering Community related expenditure which the<br>EFTA States cover individually or payments made by EFTA States in kind.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 32</p>
<p>271</p>
<p>Article 4</p>
<p>Review</p>
<p>The provisions of:</p>
<p>- &nbsp;Article 2(1) ;</p>
<p>- &nbsp;Article 2(2);</p>
<p>- Article 3(2); and</p>
<p>- &nbsp;Article 3(3);</p>
<p>shall be reviewed before 1 January 1994 by the EEA Joint Committee and<br>amended as appropriate in the light of experience of their implementation<br>and in the light of Community decisions affecting the Financial Regulation<br>and/or the presentation of the general budget.</p>
<p>Article 5</p>
<p>Conditions for implementation</p>
<p>1. The utilization of the appropriations arising from the participation of the<br>EFTA States shall take place in accordance with the provisions of the Finan-<br>cial Regulation.</p>
<p>2 However, with regard to the rules relating to tendering procedures, calls<br>for tender shall be open to all EC Member States as well as to all EFTA<br>States in so far as they involve financing on budgetary lines in respect of<br>which the EFTA States are participating.</p>
<p>Article 6</p>
<p>Information</p>
<p>1. The EC Commission shall provide the Standing Committee of the EFTA<br>States, at the end of each quarter, with an extract from its accounts showing,<br>with regard both to receipts and expediture, the situation as regards the im-<br>plementation of the programmes and other actions in which the EFTA States<br>participate financially.</p>
<p>2. After the closure of the financial year, the EC Commission shall communi-<br>cate to the Standing Committee of the EFTA States the data concerning the<br>programmes and other actions in which the EFTA States participate finan-<br>cially, which appear in the revenue and expenditure account and the balance<br>sheet drawn up in accordance with the provisions of Articles 78 and 81 of the<br>Financial Regulation.</p>
<p>3. The Community shall provide the Standing Committee of the EFTA Sta-<br>tes with such other financial information as the latter may reasonably request<br>as regards the programmes and others actions in which they participate fi-<br>nancially.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 32</p>
<p>272</p>
<p>Article 7</p>
<p>Control</p>
<p>1. The control of the determination and of the availability of all income as<br>well as the control of the commitment and of the scheduling of all expendi-<br>ture corresponding to the participation of the EFTA States, shall take place<br>in accordance with the provisions of the Treaty establishing the European<br>Economic Community, of the Financial Regulation and of the applicable re-<br>gulations in the fields referred to in Article 76 and 78 of the Agreement.</p>
<p>2. Appropriate arrangements shall be established between the auditing aut-<br>horities in the Community and in the EFTA States with a view to facilitating<br>the control of income and expenditure corresponding to the participation of<br>EFTA States in Community activities in accordance with paragraph 1.</p>
<p>Article 8</p>
<p>GDP figure to be taken into consideration to calculate the proportionality<br>factor</p>
<p>1. The GDP data at market prices referred to in Article 82 of the Agreement<br>shall be those published as a result of the implementation of Article 76 of the<br>Agreement.</p>
<p>2. Exceptionally, for the financial years 1993 and 1994, the data concerning<br>GDP shall be those established by the OECD. If necessary, the EEA Joint<br>Committee may decide to extend this provision for one or more subsequent<br>years.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 32</p>
<p>273</p>
<p>18 Riksdagen 1991192. 1 saml. Nr 170. Bil. 15</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 33</h1>
<h2>ON ARBITRATION PROCEDURES</h2>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Protcol 33</p>
<p>1. If a dispute has been referred to arbitration there shall be three arbitra-<br>tors, unless the parties to the dispute decide otherwise.</p>
<p>2. The two sides to the dispute shall each, within thirty days, appoint one<br>arbitrator.</p>
<p>3. The arbitrators so designated shall nominate by consensus one umpire,<br>who shall be a national of one of the Contracting Parties other than those of<br>the arbitrators designated. If they cannot agree within two months of their<br>appointment, the umpire shall be chosen by them from seven persons on a<br>list established by the EEA Joint Committee. The Joint Committee shall es-<br>tablish and keep under review this list in accordance with the rules of proce-<br>dure for the Committee.</p>
<p>4. Unless the Contracting Parties decide otherwise, the arbitration tribunal<br>shall adopt its rules of procedure. It takes its decisions by majority.</p>
<p>274</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 34</h1>
<p>ON THE POSSIBILITY FOR COURTS AND<br>TRIBUNALS OF EFTA STATES TO REQUEST THE<br>COURT OF JUSTICE OF THE EUROPEAN<br>COMMUNITIES TO DECIDE ON THE<br>INTERPRETATION OF EEA RULES<br>CORRESPONDING TO EC RULES</p>
<p>Article 1</p>
<p>When a question of interpretation of provisions of the Agreement, which<br>are identical in substance to the provisions of the Treaties establishing the<br>European Communities, as amended or supplemented, or of acts adopted in<br>pursuance thereof, arises in a case pending before a court or tribunal of an<br>EFTA State, the court or tribunal may, if it considers this necessary, ask the<br>Court of Justice of the European Communities to decide on such a question.</p>
<p>Article 2</p>
<p>An EFTA State which intends to make use of this Protocol shall notify the<br>Depositary and the Court of Justice of the European Communities to what<br>extent and according to what modalities the Protocol will apply to its courts<br>and tribunals.</p>
<p>Article 3</p>
<p>The Depositary shall notify the Contracting Parties of any notification under<br>Article 2.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 34</p>
<p>275</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 35</h1>
<h2>ON THE IMPLEMENTATION OF EEA RULES</h2>
<p>Whereas this Agreement aims at achieving a homogeneous European Eco-<br>nomic Area, based on common rules, without requiring any Contracting<br>Party to transfer legislative powers to any institution of the European Econo-<br>mic Area; and</p>
<p>Whereas this consequently will have to be achieved through national pro-<br>cedures;</p>
<p>Sole Article</p>
<p>For cases of possible conflicts between implemented EEA rules and other<br>statutory provisions, the EFTA States undertake to introduce, if necessary,<br>a statutory provision to the effect that EEA rules prevail in these cases.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 35</p>
<p>276</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 36</h1>
<h2>ON THE STATUTE OF THE EEA JOINT<br>PARLIAMENTARY COMMITTEE</h2>
<p>Article 1</p>
<p>The EEA Joint Parliamentary Committee established by Article 95 of the<br>Agreement shall be constituted and function in accordance with the provi-<br>sions of the Agreement and this Statute.</p>
<p>Article 2</p>
<p>The EEA Joint Parliamentary Committee shall consist of sixty-six members.<br>An equal number of members of the EEA Joint Parliamentary Committee<br>shall be appointed by the European Parliament and by the Parliaments of<br>the EFTA States, respectively.</p>
<p>Article 3</p>
<p>The EEA Joint Parliamentary Committee shall elect its President and Vice-<br>President from among its members. The office of President of the Commit-<br>tee shall be held alternately, for a period of one year, by a member appointed<br>by the European Parliament and by a member appointed by a Parliament of<br>an EFTAState.</p>
<p>The Committee shall appoint its bureau.</p>
<p>Article 4</p>
<p>The EEA Joint Parliamentary Committee shall hold a general session twice<br>ayear, alternately in the Community and in anEFTAState. The Committee<br>shall decide at each session where the next general session shall be held. Ex-<br>traordinary sessions may be held when the Committee or its bureau so deci-<br>des in accordance with the rules of procedure of the Committee.</p>
<p>Article 5</p>
<p>The EEA Joint Parliamentary Committee shall adopt its rules of procedure<br>with a two-third majority of the members of the Committee.</p>
<p>Article 6</p>
<p>The costs for participartion in the EEA Joint Parliamentary Committee shall<br>be borne by the Parliament that appointed a member.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 36</p>
<p>277</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 37</h1>
<h2>CONTAINING THE LIST PROVIDED FOR IN<br>ARTICLE 101</h2>
<p>1. Scientific Committee for Food (Commission Decision 74/234/EEC).</p>
<p>2. Pharmaceutical Committee (Council Decision 75/320/EEC).</p>
<p>3. Scientific Veterinary Committee (Commission Decision 81/651/EEC).</p>
<p>4. Committee on Transport Infrastructure (Council Decision 78/174/EEC).</p>
<p>5. Administrative Commission on Social Security for Migrant Workers<br>(Council Regulation (EEC) 1408/71).</p>
<p>6. Contact Committee on Money Laundering (Council Directive<br>91/308/EEC).</p>
<p>7. Advisory Committee on Restrictive Practices and Dominant Positions<br>(Council Regulation (EEC) 17/62).</p>
<p>8. Advisory Committee on Concentrations (Council Regulation (EEC)<br>4064/89).</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 37</p>
<p>278</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 38</h1>
<h2>ON THE FINANCIAL MECHANIS</h2>
<p>Article 1</p>
<p>1. The Financial Mechanism shall provide financial assistance to the devcl-<br>opment and structural adjustment of the regions referred to in Article 4, on<br>the one hand, in the form of interest rebates on loans and, on the other hand,<br>in the form of direct grants.</p>
<p>2. The Financial Mechanism shall be financed by the EFTA States. The lat-<br>ter shall extend a mandate to the European Investment Bank, which shall<br>execute this mandate according to the following Articles. The EFTA States<br>shall establish a Financial Mechanism Committee which shall take the deci-<br>sions required by Articles 2 and 3 as far as interest rebates and grants are<br>concerned.</p>
<p>Article 2</p>
<p>1. The interest rebates provided for in Article 1 shall be availble in connec-<br>tion with loans granted by the European Investment Bank and denominated,<br>as far as possible, in ecus.</p>
<p>2. The interest rebate on such loans shall be fixed at three precentage points,<br>per annum, by reference to European Investment Bank interest rates and<br>shall be available for ten years in respect of any one loan.</p>
<p>3. There shall be a period of grace of two years before repayment, in equal<br>tranches, of Capital commences.</p>
<p>4. The interest rebates shall be subject to approval by the EFTA Financial<br>Mechanism Committee and to the opinion of the EC Commission.</p>
<p>5. The total volume of loans, which shall be eligible, over the period 1993 to<br>1997 inclusive, for the interest rebates provided for in Article 1 and to be<br>committed in equal tranches, shall be ECU 1500 million.</p>
<p>Article 3</p>
<p>1. The total amount of the grants provided for in Article 1 shall be ECU 500<br>million, to be committed in equal tranches over the period 1993 to 1997, in-<br>clusive.</p>
<p>2. These grants shall be disbursed by the European Investment Bank on the<br>basis of the proposals from the beneficiary EC Member States and after see-<br>king the opinion of the EC Commission and having the approval of the<br>EFTA Financial Mechanism Committee, which shall be informed throug-<br>hout the process.</p>
<p>Article 4</p>
<p>1. The financial assistance provided for in Article 1 shall be limited to pro-<br>jects carried out by public authorities and public or private undertakings in</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 38</p>
<p>279</p>
<p>Greece, the island of Ireland, Portugal and in those regions of Spain listed<br>in the Appendix. The share of each region in the overall level of financial<br>assistance shall be determined by the Community, which shall inform the<br>EFTA States.</p>
<p>2. Priority shall be given to projects which place particular emphasis on the<br>en vironment (including urban development), on transport (including trans-<br>port infrastructure) or on education and training. Among projects submitted<br>by private undertakings, special consideration shall be given to small and<br>medium - sized enterprises.</p>
<p>3. The maximum grant element for any project supported by the Financial<br>Mechanism shall be fixed at a level which is not inconsistent with EC policies<br>in this regard.</p>
<p>Article 5</p>
<p>The EFTA States shall make such arrangements with the European Invest-<br>ment Bank and the EC Commission as may be mutually deemed appropriate<br>to ensure the good functioning of the Financial Mechanism. The costs rela-<br>ted to the administration of the Financial Mechanism shall be decided in this<br>context.</p>
<p>Article 6</p>
<p>The European Investment Bank shall be entitled to attend, as an observer,<br>meetings of the EEA Joint Committee when matters in relation to the Finan-<br>cial Mechanism which concern the European Investment Bank are on the<br>agenda.</p>
<p>Article 7</p>
<p>Further provisions for the implementation of the Financial Mechanism may<br>be decided upon by the EEA Joint Committee as necessary.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 38</p>
<p>280</p>
<p>APPENDIX TO PROTOCOL 38</p>
<p>List of eligible Spanish regions</p>
<p>Andalucia</p>
<p>Asturias</p>
<p>Castilla y Leon</p>
<p>Castilla-La Mancha<br>Ceuta-Melilla</p>
<p>Valencia</p>
<p>Extremadura</p>
<p>Galicia</p>
<p>Islas Canarias</p>
<p>Murcia</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 38</p>
<p>281</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 39</h1>
<h2>ON THE ECU</h2>
<p>For the purposes of this Agreement, “ECU” means the ECU as defined by<br>the competent Community authorities. In all acts referred to in the Annexes<br>to the Agreement, “European unit of account” shall be replaced by “ECU”.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 39</p>
<p>282</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 40</h1>
<h2>ON SVALBARD</h2>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 40</p>
<p>1. When ratifying the EEA Agreement, the Kingdom of Norway shall have<br>the right to exempt the territory of Svalbard from the application of the Ag-<br>reement.</p>
<p>2. If the Kingdom of Norway avails itself of this right, existing agreements<br>applicable to Svalbard, i.a. the Convention establishing the European Free<br>Trade Association, the Free Trade Agreement between the European Eco-<br>nomic Community and the Kingdom of Norway and the Free Trade Agree-<br>ment between the Member States of the European Coal and Steel Commu-<br>nity and the European Coal and Steel Community of the one part, and the<br>Kingdom of Norway of the other part, shall continue to apply to the territory<br>of Svalbard.</p>
<p>283</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 41</h1>
<h2>ON EXISTING AGREEMENTS</h2>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 41</p>
<p>In accordance with the provisions of Article 120 of the EEA Agreement,<br>the Contracting Parties have agreed that the following existing bilateral or<br>multilateral Agreements binding the European Economic Community, on<br>the one hand, and one or more EFTA States, on the other, shall continue to<br>apply after the entry into force of the EEA Agreement:</p>
<table border="1">

<p>3.12.1976</p></td><td>
<p>Protection of the Rhine against Chemical Pollution.<br>Mixed agreement between the Swiss Confederation and<br>the European Economic Community, the Federal Repu-<br>blic of Germany, France, Luxembourg and the Nether-<br>lands.</p></td></tr>

<p>284</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 42</h1>
<h2>ON BILATERAL ARRANGEMENTS CONCERNING<br>SPECIFIC AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS</h2>
<p>The Contracting Parties take note that at the same time as the Agreement,<br>bilateral agreements on trade in agricultural products have been signed.<br>These agreements, which develop further or supplement agreements made<br>earlier by the Contracting Parties, and moreover reflect, inter alia, their ag-<br>reed common objective to contribute to the reduction of social and economic<br>disparities between their regions, shall enter into force, at the latest, at the<br>time of entry into force of the present Agreement.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 42</p>
<p>285</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 43</h1>
<h2>ON THE AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE EC AND THE<br>REPUBLIC OF AUSTRIA ON THE TRANSIT OF<br>GOODS BY ROAD AND RAIL</h2>
<p>The Contracting Parties note that simultaneously with the present Agree-<br>ment, a bilateral Agreement was signed between the European Communi-<br>ties and Austria on the transit of goods by road and rail.</p>
<p>Provisions of the bilateral Agreement shall prevail over provisions of the<br>present Agreement to the extent that they cover the same subject matter and<br>as specified in the present Agreement.</p>
<p>Six months before the expiration of the Agreement between the European<br>Community and the Republic of Austria on the transit of goods by road and<br>rail, the situation in road transport will be jointly reviewed.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 43</p>
<p>286</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 44</h1>
<p>ON THE AGREEMENTBETWEEN THE ECAND THE<br>SWISS CONFEDERATION ON THE CARRIAGE OF<br>GOODS BY ROAD AND RAIL</p>
<p>The Contracting Parties note that simultaneously with the present Agree-<br>ment, a bilateral Agreement was signed between the European Communi-<br>ties and the Swiss Confederation on the carriage of goods by road and rail.</p>
<p>Provisions of the bilateral Agreement shall prevail over provisions of the<br>present Agreement to the extent that they cover the same subject matter and<br>as specified in the present Agreement.</p>
<p>Six months before the expiration of the Agreement between the European<br>Community and the Swiss Confederation on the carriage of goods by road<br>and rail, the situation in road transport will be jointly reviewed.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 44</p>
<p>287</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 45</h1>
<h2>ON TRANSITIONAL PERIODS CONCERNING SPAIN<br>AND PORTUGAL</h2>
<p>The Contracting Parties consider that the Agreement does not affect the<br>transitional periods accorded to Spain and Portugal by the Act of their acces-<br>sion to the European Communities, which could remain after the entry into<br>force of the Agreement, independently of the transitional periods provided<br>for in the Agreement itself.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 45</p>
<p>288</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 46</h1>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 46</p>
<h2>ON THE DEVELOPMENT OF COOPERATION IN</h2>
<h2>THE FISHERIES SECTOR</h2>
<p>In the light of the results of two-yearly reviews of the State of their coopera-<br>tion in the fisheries sector, the Contracting Parties will seek to develop this<br>cooperation on a harmonious, mutually beneficial basis and within the fra-<br>mework of their respective fisheries policies. The first review will take place<br>before the end of 1993.</p>
<p>289</p>
<p>19 Riksdagen 1991/92. 1 saml. Nr 170. Bil. 15</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 47</h1>
<h2>ON THE ABOLITION OF TECHNICAL BARRIERS</h2>
<h2>TO TRADE IN WINE</h2>
<p>The Contracting Parties shall authorize imports and marketing of wine pro-<br>ducts, originating in their territories, which are in conformity with the EC<br>legislation, as adapted for the purposes of the Agreement, as set out in the<br>Appendix to this Protocol related to product definition, oenological practi-<br>ces, composition of products and modalities for circulation and marketing.</p>
<p>For the purpose of this Protocol “originating wine products” shall be un-<br>derstood as “wine products in which all the grapes or any materials derived<br>from grapes used therein must be wholly obtained”.</p>
<p>For all purposes other than trade between the EFTA States and the Com-<br>munity, the EFTA States may continue to apply their national legislation.</p>
<p>The provisions of Protocol 1 on horizontal adaptations shall apply to the<br>acts referred to in the Appendix to this Protocol. The Standing Committee<br>of the EFTA States shall fulfil the functions mentioned in points 4(d) and 5<br>of Protocol 1.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 47</p>
<p>290</p>
<h1>APPENDIX</h1>
<p>1. 373 R 2805: Commission Regulation (EEC) No 2805/73 of<br>12 October 1973 determining a list of white quality wines, produced in speci-<br>fied regions and of imported white quality wines containing a certain percen-<br>tage of sulphur dioxide and laying down certain transitional provisions rela-<br>ting to the percentage of sulphur dioxide in wines produced before 1<br>October 1973 (OJ No L 289, 16.10.1973, p. 21), as amended by:</p>
<p>373 R 3548: Commission Regulation (EEC) No 3548/73 of 21<br>December 1973 (OJ No L 361, 29.12.1973, p. 35)</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;375 R 2160:Commission Regulation (EEC) No 2160/75 of<br>19 August 1975 (OJ No L 220, 20.8.1975, p. 7)</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;377 R 0966: Commission Regulation (EEC) No 966/77 of 4<br>May 1977 (OJ No L115, 6.5.1977, p. 77)</p>
<p>The provisions of the Regulation shall, for the purposes of the Agreement,<br>be read with the following adaptation:</p>
<p>Wines originating in EFTA States for which the provisions of this Regula-<br>tion are relevant, shall continue to be covered by section B of Article 1.</p>

<p>- regulated by Austrian rules.“</p>

<p>4December 1990 (OJNoL353, 17.12.1990, p. 23)</p>
<p>The provisions of the Regulation shall, for the purposes of the Agreement,<br>be read with the following adaptations:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;Article 1(1), l(4)(c), l(4)(e), l(4)(g) and the second subparagraph<br>of 1(4) shall not apply.</p>
<p>(b) By way of derogation from Article 1(6), for Switzerland the wine<br>marketing year starts at 1 July of each year and ends at 30 June of<br>the following year.</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;Titles I, with the exception of Article 13, III and IV shall not apply.</p>
<p>(d) Austria, Switzerland and Liechtenstein shall establish a classifica-<br>tion scheme of vine varieties drawn up in accordance with the prin-<br>ciples laid down in Article 13.</p>
<p>(e) In Article 16(7) “coupage of wine originating in a third country”</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 47</p>
<p>294</p>
<p>shall read “coupage of wine originating in a third country or an<br>EFTA State”.</p>
<p>(f) &nbsp;For products produced on their respective territories, Austria, Swit-<br>zerland and Liechtenstein may apply their national legislation regar-<br>ding practices as referred to in Articles 18, 19,21,22,23 and 24.</p>
<p>(g) &nbsp;Article 20 shall not apply.</p>
<p>(h) By way of derogation from Article 66(1), the following quality wines<br>produced in Austria according to particular methods may exceed 18<br>but not 22milliequivalents of volatile acid per litre: “Ausbruch”,<br>“Beerenauslese”, “Trockenbeerenauslese”, “Eiswein” and “Stroh-<br>wein”.</p>
<p>(i) &nbsp;Articles 70, 75, 76, 80 and 85 shall not apply.</p>
<p>(j) &nbsp;Article 78 shall be covered by point 3 of Protocol 1.</p>
<p>(k) Annex I shall be supplemented as follows:</p>
<p>(a) “Strohwein”: the product originating in Austria and produced<br>according to provisions laid down in Article 17(3)(1) of the<br>Austrian wine law Österreichisches Weingesetz, 1985)</p>
<p>(b) The grape must in fermentation produced in accordance with<br>provisions of point 3 of Annex I may be designated as</p>
<p>- “Sturm” if it originates in Austria; Ö “Federweiss” or<br>“Federweisser” if it originates in Switzerland or Liechtenstein.<br>However, for technical reasons the actual alcoholic strength by<br>volume may exceptionally exceed three-fifths of the total alcoho-<br>lic strength by volume.</p>
<p>(c) The term “Tafelwein” and its equivalents as referred to in<br>point 13 shall not be used for wines originating in Austria.</p>
<p>(l) &nbsp;Annex III, V and VII shall not apply.</p>
<p>(m) For the purposes of Annex IV, Austria, Liechtenstein and Switzer-<br>land shall be considered as belonging to wine-growing zone B.</p>
<p>(n) By way of derogation from Annex VI</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;Austria may maintain the general prohibition for sorbic acid</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;Norway and Sweden may maintain the general prohibition of meta-<br>tartaric acid</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;wines originating in Austria, Liechtenstein and Switzerland may be<br>treated with silver chloride according to their respective wine laws.</p>
<p>16. 387 R 0823: Council Regulation No 823/87/EEC of 16 March 1987 laying<br>down special provisions relating to quality wines produced in specified re-<br>gions (OJ No L 084, 27.3.1987, p. 59), as amended by</p>
<p>389R2043: Council Regulation (EEC) No2043/89 of 19Junel989<br>(OJ No L 202, 14.7.1989, p. 1)</p>
<p>390 R 3577: &nbsp;&nbsp;Council Regulation (EEC) No 3577/90 of</p>
<p>4 December 1990 (OJ No L 353, 17.12.1990, p. 23)</p>
<p>The provisions of the Regulation shall, for the purposes of the present Ag-<br>reement, be read with the following adaptations:</p>
<p>Wine products originating in EFTA States shall be considered as equiva-<br>lent to quality wines produced in specified regions (“quality wines p.s.r.”),</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 47</p>
<p>295</p>
<p>provided that they comply with national legislation which, for the purposes<br>of this Protocol, shall be in accordance with the principles of Article 2 of the<br>Agreement.</p>
<p>However, the description quality wines p.s.r., as well as the other descrip-<br>tions referred to in the second subparagraph of Article 1(2) of the Regula-<br>tion, may not be used for these wines.</p>
<p>The lists of quality wines established by wine-producing EFTA States<br>shall be published in the Official Journal of the European Communities.</p>

<p>7 November 1990 laying down conditions for the use of certain oenological<br>practices provided for in Council Regulation (EEC) No 822/87<br>(OJNo308/22, 8.11.1990, p.22)</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 47</p>
<p>298</p>
<p>28. 390 R3825:&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Commission Regulation No 3825/90/EEC of</p>
<p>19 December 1990 on the transitional measures applicable in Portugal from<br>1 Januaryto ISeptember 1991 in the wine sector (OJNoL366, 29.12.1990,<br>p.56)</p>

<p>Protocol 47</p>
<p>299</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 48</h1>
<h2>CONCERNING ARTICLES 105 AND 111</h2>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 48</p>
<p>Decisions taken by the EEA Joint Committee under Articles 105 and 111<br>may not affect the case law of the Court of Justice of the European Commu-<br>nities.</p>
<p>300</p>
<h1>PROTOCOL 49</h1>
<h2>ON CEUTA AND MELILLA</h2>
<p>Products covered by the Agreement and originating in the EEA, when im-<br>ported into Ceuta or Melilla, shall enjoy in all respects the same customs<br>regime as that which is applied to products originating in the customs terri-<br>tory of the Community under Protocol No 2 of the Act of Accession of the<br>Kingdom of Spain and the Portuguese Republic to the European Communi-<br>ties.</p>
<p>The EFTA States shall grant to imports of products covered by the Agree-<br>ment and originating in Ceuta and Melilla the same customs regime as that<br>which is granted to products imported from and originating in the EEA.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Protocol 49</p>
<p>301</p>
<h1>ANNEX I</h1>
<h1>VETERINARY AND PHYTOSANITARY<br>MATTERS</h1>
<h2>List provided for in Article 17</h2>
<p>INTRODUCTION</p>
<p>When the acts referred to in this Annex contain notions or refer to procedu-<br>res which are specific to the Community legal order, such as</p>
<p>preambles;</p>
<p>the addressees of the Community acts;</p>
<p>references to territories or languages of the EC;</p>
<p>references to rights and obligations of EC Member States, their pu-<br>blic entities, undertakings or individuals in relation to each other;<br>and</p>
<p>references to information and notification procedure;</p>
<p>Protocol 1 on horizontal adaptations shall apply, unless otherwise provided<br>for in this Annex.</p>
<p>SECTORAL ADAPTATION</p>
<p>Switzerland and Liechtenstein shall with regard to acts referred to in this An-<br>nex be regarded as one entity.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Annex I</p>
<p>302</p>
<h1>I VETERINÄRY ISSUES</h1>
<p>1. (a) The provisions relating to third country relations in the acts referred<br>to in this Chapter are not applicable. However, the following general prin-<br>ciples are applicable:</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;The Contracting Parties shall not apply more favourable rules on im-<br>ports from third countries than those resultingfrom the Agreement.<br>Nevertheless, regarding substances having a hormonal or thyrostatic<br>action the EFTA States may maintain their national legislation on<br>imports from third countries.</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;In trade between EFTA States or between an EFTA State and the<br>Community, animals and products coming from third countries, or<br>partially or totally derived therefrom, must comply with the rules of<br>the importing Contracting Party as concerns third countries.</p>
<p>The exporting Contracting Party shall ensure that the competent<br>authority, in each case, takes the necessary measures to secure that<br>the provisions of this paragraph are complied with.</p>
<p>(b) The Contracting Parties shall review the matter during 1995.</p>
<p>2. The provisions relating to border Controls, animal welfare and financial<br>arrangements in the acts referred to in this Chapter are not applicable. The<br>Contracting Parties shall review the matter during 1995.</p>
<p>3. In order to enable the EFTA Surveillance Authority to take the necessary<br>measures, the provisions of the acts referred to in this Chapter will be ap-<br>plied, for the purposes of this Agreement, as from nine months after the<br>entry into force of the Agreement and at the latest from 1 January 1994.</p>
<p>4. The acts referred to in this Chapter, except Directives 91/67/EEC,<br>91/492/EEC and 91/493/EEC, do not apply to Iceland. The other Contrac-<br>ting Parties may maintain their third country regime in trade with Iceland for<br>areas not covered by the acts mentioned. The Contracting Parties shall re-<br>view the matter during 1995.</p>
<p>5. Notwithstanding the integration into this Agreement of the Community<br>legislation concerning BSE and awaiting the outcome of ongoing discussions<br>aimed at arriving, as soon as possible, at an overall agreement related to the<br>application by the EFTA States of this legislation, the EFTA States may ap-<br>ply their national rules. However, they undertake to apply transparent natio-<br>nal rules based on objective criteria in a non-discriminatory and foreseeable<br>manner. Such national rules shall be communicated to the Community in ac-<br>cordance with the rules laid down in Protocol 1 paragraph 4 by the entry into<br>force of the Agreement. The Community reserves the right to apply similar<br>rules in trade with the EFTA State concerned. The Contracting Parties shall<br>review the situation during 1995.</p>
<p>6. Notwithstanding the integration into this Agreement of the Community<br>legislation concerning new pig disease and awaiting the outcome of ongoing<br>discussions aimed at arriving, as soon as possible, at an overall agreement<br>related to the application by Norway of this legislation, Norway may apply</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Annex I</p>
<p>303</p>
<p>its own protective rules, based on a definition of non-affected regions, for<br>live pigs, fresh meat, meat products and porcine semen. The other Contrac-<br>ting Parties reserve the right to apply similar rules in trade with Norway. The<br>Contracting Parties shall review the situation during 1995.</p>
<p>7. Notwithstanding the integration into this Agreement of Council Directive<br>91/68/EEC on animal health conditions governing intra-Community trade in<br>ovine and caprine animals and awaiting the outcome of ongoing discussions<br>aimed at arriving, as soon as possible, at an overall agreement related to the<br>application by Austria, Finland and Norway of this legislation, these Cont-<br>racting Parties may apply their national legislation. The other Contracting<br>Parties may maintain their third country regime towards these countries in<br>this field. The Contracting Parties shall review the situation during 1995.</p>
<p>8. Notwithstanding the integration into this Agreement of Council Directive<br>91/67/EEC concerning the animal health conditions governing the placing on<br>the market of aquaculture animals and products and awaiting the outcome<br>of ongoing discussions aimed at arriving, as soon as possible, at an overall<br>agreement related to the application by Finland, Iceland and Norway of this<br>legislation, these Contracting Parties may apply their national legislation<br>concerning live fish and crustaceans as well as eggs and gametes of fish and<br>crustaceans for farming or restocking. The other Contracting Parties may<br>maintain their third country regime towards these Contracting Parties in the<br>fields mentioned above. The Contracting Parties shall review the situation<br>during 1995.</p>
<p>9. Safeguard clause</p>
<p>(1) (a) The Community and an EFTA State may, on serious public or<br>animal health grounds, take interim protective measures according<br>to their own procedures with regard to the introduction into their<br>territory of animals or animal products.</p>
<p>These measures shall be notified without delay to each Contracting<br>Party and to both the EC Commission and the EFTA Surveillance<br>Authority.</p>
<p>(b) Consultations regarding the situation shall be held within 10 days<br>from the date of notification.</p>
<p>The EC Commission and/or the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall,<br>within their competences, take the necessary measures taking due<br>account of the results of such consultations.</p>
<p>(2) The EC Commission and the EFTA Surveillance Authority may<br>hold consultations regarding any aspect of the animal or public<br>health situation. The provisions of subparagraph (l)(b) are appli-<br>cable.</p>
<p>(3) (a) The EC Commission shall transmit to the EFTA Surveillance<br>Authority any safeguard decision relating to intra-Community<br>trade. If the EFTA Surveillance Authority considers the decision to<br>be inadequate, the provisions of subparagraph (2) are applicable.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Annex I</p>
<p>304</p>
<p>(b) The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall transmit to the EC Com-<br>mission any safeguard decision relating to trade between EFTA Sta-<br>tes. If the Commission considers the decision to be inadequate, the<br>provisions of subparagraph (2) are applicable.</p>
<p>10. On-the-spot inspections</p>
<p>(1) &nbsp;For application of the provisions regarding spot-checks, inspections<br>or disputes requiring the participation of experts referred to in this<br>Chapter, the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall be responsible with<br>regard to the EFTA States.</p>
<p>(2) &nbsp;The following principles shall apply:</p>
<p>(a) Inspections shall be carried out in accordance with programs<br>equivalent to those of the Community.</p>
<p>(b) The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall have a structure, equiva-<br>lent to that in the Community, for inspections in the EFTA States.</p>
<p>(c) The same criteria shall apply for inspections.</p>
<p>(d) The inspector shall be independent for the purposes of inspec-<br>tions.</p>
<p>(e) The inspectors shall have comparable levels of training and expe-<br>rience.</p>
<p>(f) Information concerning inspections shall be exchanged between<br>the EC Commission and the EFTA Surveillance Authority.</p>
<p>(g) The follow-up of the inspections shall be coordinated between<br>the EC Commission and the EFTA Surveillance Authority.</p>
<p>(3) &nbsp;Necessary rules for implementation of the provisions regarding spot-<br>checks, inspections or disputes requiring the participation of experts<br>will be determined in close cooperation between the EC Commis-<br>sion and the EFTA Surveillance Authority.</p>
<p>(4) &nbsp;The rules on spot-checks, inspections or disputes requiring the parti-<br>cipation of experts referred to in this Chapter, are only valid in re-<br>spect of the acts or the parts thereof applied by the EFTA States.</p>
<p>11. Designation of common reference laboratories</p>
<p>Without prejudice to financial implications, the Community reference labo-<br>ratories shall act as reference laboratories for all Parties to this Agreement.</p>
<p>Consultations shall take place between the Contracting Parties in order to<br>define the working conditions.</p>
<p>12. The Scientific Veterinary Committee</p>
<p>The EC Commission nominates from highly qualified scientific persons from<br>EFTA States, in addition to the number laid down in Article 3 of Commis-<br>sion Decision 81/651/EEC, two persons for each section as referred to in Ar-<br>ticles 2<sup>(1</sup>&gt; and 3 of the Decision, who will participate fully in the work of the<br>&lt;&gt;&gt; OJ No L 233, 19.8.1981, p.32<br></p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Annex I</p>
<p>305</p>
<p>20 Riksdagen 1991/92. 1 saml. Nr 170. Bil. 15</p>
<p>Scientific Veterinary Committee. They will not participate in the voting and<br>their position will be recorded separately.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Annex I</p>
<p>306</p>

<p>Ovinelcaprine</p>
<p>2. 391 L 0068: Council Directive 91/68/EEC of 28 January 1991 on animal<br>health conditions governing intra-Community trade in ovine and caprine ani-<br>mals (OJ No L 46, 19.2.1991, p. 19)</p>
<p>The provisions of the Directive shall, for the purposes of the present Ag-<br>reement, be read with the following adaptations:</p>
<p>(a) Article 2 (3) shall be replaced by:</p>
<p>“Holding shall mean an agricultural establishment or premises of a<br>dealer, as defined by the national rules in force, situated in the terri-<br>tory of an EC Member State or EFTA State and in which bovine and</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Annex I</p>
<p>309</p>
<p>porcine animals, sheep and goats, live poultry and domestic rabbits<br>are held or regularly kept, and the holding as defined in Article 2 (a)<br>of Council Directive 90/426/EEC of 26 June 1990 on animal health<br>conditions governing the movement and import from third countries<br>of live equidae.”</p>
<p>(b) Article 2 (9) shall be replaced by:</p>
<p>“Approved market or assembly centre means any place, other than<br>the holding, where ovine or caprine animals are sold, bought and/or<br>assembled or loaded, and which complies with Article 3(7) of Coun-<br>cil Directive 64/432/EEC and which has been approved.”</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;Article 4 (1) (a) shall be replaced by:</p>
<p>“must be identified and registered in such a way that the original or<br>transit holding, centre or organization can be traced. For the identi-<br>fication, the EFTA States undertake to coordinate their system bet-<br>ween them and the EC.</p>
<p>Before 1 September 1993, the EFTA States must take appropriate<br>measures to guarantee that the identification and registration sy-<br>stems applicable to intra-EEA trade are extended to the movement<br>of animals within their territory. National identification or registra-<br>tion systems must be notified to the EFTA Surveillance Authority<br>before 1 July 1993.“</p>
<p>(d) Article 4 (2) first indent shall be replaced by:</p>
<p>Ovine and caprine animals which might have to be slaughtered un-<br>der a national programme for the eradication of diseases which are<br>not referred to in the following list or in Chapter I of Annex B to<br>this Directive:</p>
<p>- Foot and mouth disease (FMD)</p>
<p>- Classical swine fever (CSF)</p>
<p>- African swine fever (ASF)</p>
<p>- Swine vesicular disease (SVD)</p>
<p>- Newcastle disease (ND)</p>
<p>- Rinderpest</p>
<p>- Peste des petits ruminants (PPR)</p>
<p>- Vesicular stomatitis (VS)</p>
<p>- Blue tongue</p>
<p>- African horse sickness (AHS)</p>
<p>- Viral equine encephalomyelitis</p>
<p>- Teschen disease</p>
<p>- Avian influenza</p>
<p>- Sheep and goat pox</p>
<p>- Lumpy skin disease</p>
<p>- Rift valley fever</p>
<p>- Contagious bovine pleuropneumonia.&quot;</p>
<p>(e) &nbsp;Article 4 (2) second indent shall be replaced by:</p>
<p>- ovine and caprine animals which cannot be marketed on their own<br>territory for health or animal health reasons.</p>
<p>* OJ No L 224, 18.8.1990, p.42</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Annex I</p>
<p>310</p>
<p>(f) &nbsp;Article 6 (b) (i) first indent shall be replaced by:</p>
<p>- the holding is subject to regular official veterinary checks in accor-<br>dance with the following requirements:</p>
<p>Without prejudice to the monitoring duties assigned to the official<br>veterinarian under this Agreement, the competent authority shall<br>carry out checks on holdings, approved markets and assembly cent-<br>res, centres or organizations in order to satisfy itself that animals and<br>products intended for trade comply with the requirements of this Di-<br>rective and in particular fulfil the conditions laid down in Article 4<br>paragraph l(a) concerning identification and registration, and must<br>be accompanied to their destination(s) by health certificates as pro-<br>vided for in this Directive/</p>
<p>(g) &nbsp;In Article 8 (2), the dates 1 January 1992 and 1 July 1992 referred to<br>in the last sentence of the paragraph are, with regard to the EFTA<br>States, replaced by 1 January 1993 and 1 July 1993 respectively.</p>
<p>(h) Article 10 shall not apply.</p>
<p>(i) &nbsp;In Annex A Chapter 2 (D) (2), the first phrase shall be replaced by:<br>“until 1 September 1993 ovine or caprine animals from holdings ot-<br>her than those referred to in point 1, provided that they meet the<br>following conditions:”</p>
<p>(j) &nbsp;Annex C shall be replaced by:</p>
<p>Brucellosis (B. melitensis) tests</p>
<p>For a holding to qualify for brucellosis-free status, testing for brucel-<br>losis (B. melitensis) is performed by means of the Rose Bengal met-<br>hod or by the complement-fixation method described in points 1 and<br>2 or by any other method recognized in accordance with the proce-<br>dure laid down in Article 15 of this Directive. The complement-fixa-<br>tion method is used for tests on individual animals.</p>
<p>1. Rose Bengal Test</p>
<p>The Rose Bengal test may be used for screening ovine or caprine<br>holdings in order to establish the status of holdings as officially bru-<br>cellosis-free or brucellosis-free.</p>
<p>2. Complement-fixation Test</p>
<p>(a) The complement-fixation test must be used for all individual animal<br>tests.</p>
<p>(b) The complement-fixation test may be used for ovine or caprine hol-<br>dings in order to establish the status of holdings as officially brucello-<br>sis-free or brucellosis-free.</p>
<p>When carrying out the Rose Bengal test, if more than 5% of the ani-<br>mals on a holding show a positive reaction, a further test is carried<br>out on every animal on the holding by means of the complement-<br>fixation method.</p>
<p>Serum containing 20 or more ICFT units/ml must be regarded as po-<br>sitive in the complement-fixation test.</p>
<p>The antigens used must be approved by the national laboratory and<br>must be standardized against the second international standard anti-<br>brucella abortus serum.&quot;</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Annex I</p>
<p>311</p>
<p>(k) Annex E</p>
<p>Model I (III) (b) and (V) (e) third indent,</p>
<p>Model II (III) (b) and (V) (f) third indent and</p>
<p>Model III (III) (b) and (V) (i) third indent shall not apply.</p>

<h2>1.2 PUBLIC HEALTH</h2>
<p>Fresh meat</p>

<p>(a) &nbsp;In Article 4 (A), the dates 1 January 1993 and 31 December 1991<br>referred to in the first sentence of the paragraph are, with regard to<br>the EFTA States, replaced by 1 September 1993 and 31 December<br>1992 respectively.</p>
<p>(b) Article 5 (1) (a) (i) shall be replaced by:</p>
<p>“in which, without prejudice to diseases specified in the following<br>list:</p>
<p>- Foot and mouth disease (FMD)</p>
<p>- Classical swine fever (CSF)</p>
<p>- African swine fever (ASF)</p>
<p>- Swine vesicular disease (SVD)</p>
<p>- Newcastle disease (ND)</p>
<p>- Rinderpest</p>
<p>- Peste des petits ruminants (PPR)</p>
<p>- Vesicular stomatitis (VS)</p>
<p>- Blue tongue</p>
<p>- African horse sickness (AHS)</p>

<p>- Sheep and goat pox</p>
<p>- Lumpy skin disease</p>
<p>- Rift valley fever</p>

<p>one of the following diseases has been diagnosed:</p>
<p>- generalized actinobacillosis or actinomycosis</p>

<p>- generalized tuberculosis</p>
<p>- generalized lymphadenitis</p>
<p>- glanders</p>
<p>- rabies</p>
<p>- tetanus</p>

<p>- acute brucellosis</p>
<p>- swine erysipelas</p>

<p>- speticaemia, pyaemia, toxaemia or viraemia;“</p>

<p>Egg products</p>
<p>23. 389 L 0437: Council Directive 89/437/EEC of 20 June 1989 on hygiene<br>and health problems affecting the production and the placing on the market<br>of egg products (OJ No L 212, 22.7.1989, p. 87), as amended by:</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;389 L 0662: Council Directive 89/662/EEC of 11 December 1989 (OJ<br>No L 395, 30.12.1989, p. 13)</p>
<p>The provisions of this Directive shall, for the purposes of the present Ag-<br>reement, be read with the following adaptations:</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Annex I</p>
<p>322</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;In Article 2, the first phrase shall be replaced by:</p>
<p>“For the purposes of this Directive:</p>
<p>eggs mean hen eggs in shell, suitable for direct human consumption<br>or for use in the food industries, except for incubated eggs which do<br>not meet the following requirements:</p>
<p>a) &nbsp;&nbsp;they shall be marked before insertion in the incubator,</p>
<p>b) &nbsp;they shall not be fertile and shall be absolutely clear when candled,</p>
<p>c) &nbsp;the air space shall not exceed a height of 9 mm,</p>
<p>d) &nbsp;they shall not have remained more than six days in an incubator,</p>
<p>e) &nbsp;&nbsp;they shall not be treated with antibiotics,</p>
<p>f) &nbsp;&nbsp;they shall be intended for use in a processing plant manufacturing<br>pasteurized egg products.</p>
<p>Industrial eggs means hen eggs in shell other than those referred<br>to in the preceding indent.</p>
<p>The following definitions shall also apply:“</p>
<p>(b) Article 2 (11) shall be replaced by the following:</p>
<p>“11) placing on the market: the marketing of egg products defined<br>as holding or displaying for sale, offering for sale, selling, delivering<br>or any other form of marketing.”</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;In Article 6 (1) second subparagraph, the beginning of the last sen-<br>tence shall read “The other Member States, the EFTA Surveillance<br>Authority and the EC Commission shall be informed”.</p>
<p>(d) Article 17 shall not apply.</p>
<p>(e) &nbsp;In the Annex, Chapter IV (1) shall be replaced by:</p>
<p>“1) Eggs used for the manufacture of egg products must be put in<br>packaging which comply with the following provisions:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;(i) Packs, including inner packing material, must be shock-resistant,<br>dry, clean and in good repair, and made of materials which protect<br>the eggs from extraneous odour and the risk of quality deterioration.</p>
<p>(ii) Large packs, used for transporting and dispatching eggs, inclu-<br>ding inner packing material, shall not be re-used unless they are as<br>new and meet the technical requirements of paragraph 1. Re-used<br>large packs must not bear any previous marking likely to lead to con-<br>fusion.</p>
<p>(iii) Small packs may not be re-used.</p>
<p>(b) (i) Eggs must be stored in clean, dry premises, free of extraneous<br>odour.</p>
<p>(ii) Eggs in transport and during storage must be kept clean, dry and<br>free of extraneous odour and effectively protected from shocks,<br>weather and the effect of light.</p>
<p>(iii) Eggs in store and in transport must be protected from extremes<br>of temperature.&quot;</p>
<p>(f) &nbsp;In the Annex, Chapter XI (1) (i) first indent, the following shall be<br>added:</p>
<p>“/AT/FI/NO/SE/CH/FL”</p>
<p>(g) &nbsp;In the Annex, Chapter XI (1) (i) second indent and (ii) third indent,</p>

<p>125. 389 X 0214: Commission Recommendation 89/214/EEC of 24 February<br>1989 on the rules to be followed for inspections carried out in fresh meat<br>establishments approved for the purposes of intra-Community trade (OJ No<br>L87, 31.3.1989, p. 1)</p>

<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Annex I</p>
<p>337</p>
<p>22 Riksdagen 1991/92. 1 saml. Nr 170. Bil. 15</p>
<h1>II FEEDINGSTUFFS</h1>
<p>1. Notwithstanding the provisions of the acts referred to in this Chapter,<br>Switzerland and Liechtenstein shall introduce national legislation concer-<br>ning pet food in accordance with these acts by the latest 1 January 1995.<br>From 1 January 1993 Switzerland and Liechtenstein shall not prohibit the<br>placing on the market of products which comply with the provisions of the<br>acts.</p>
<p>2. Products of animal origin obtained from feedingstuffs in conformity with<br>the provisions of the acts mentioned in this Annex shall not be submitted to<br>any trade restrictions as a consequence of the arrangements laid down in this<br>Chapter.</p>
<p>ACTS REFERRED TO</p>
<p>Additives</p>
<p>1. 370 L 0524: Council Directive 70/524/EEC of 23 November 1970 concer-<br>ning additives in feeding-stuffs (OJ No L 270, 14.12.1970, p. 1), as amended<br>by:</p>
<p>373 L 0103: Council Directive 73/103/EEC of 28 April 1973 (OJ No<br>L 124, 10.5.1973, p. 17)</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;384 L 0587: Council Directive 84/587/EEC of 30 June 1984 (OJ No<br>L319, 8.12.1984, p. 13)</p>
<p>387 L 0153: Council Directive 87/153/EEC of 16 February 1987 (OJ<br>No L64, 7.3.1987, p. 19)</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;391 L 0248: Commission Directive 91/248/EEC of 12 April 1991 (OJ<br>No L 124, 18.5.1991, p. 1)</p>
<p>391 L 0249: Commission Directive 91/249/EEC of 19 April 1991 (OJ<br>No L 124, 18.5.1991, p. 43)</p>
<p>391 L 0336: Commission Directive 91/336/EEC of 10 June 1991 (OJ<br>No L 185, 11.7.1991, p. 31)</p>
<p>The EFTA States will take over the provisions of the Directive as from 1<br>January 1993 subject to the following conditions:</p>
<p>the EFTA States may, with regard to Growth promoters, maintain<br>their national legislation. The Contracting Parties shall review the<br>matter during 1995;</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;the EFTA States may apply their national legislation related to other<br>additives covered by Annex I until 31 December 1994.</p>
<p>Nevertheless,</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;Finland may, with regard to Antibiotics, maintain its national<br>legislation. The Contracting Parties shall review the matter du-<br>ring 1995;</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;Iceland may,</p>
<p>with regard to Antibiotics, maintain its national legisla-</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Annex I</p>
<p>338</p>
<p>tion. The Contracting Parties shall review the matter du-<br>ring 1995;</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;with regard to Antioxidants, Aromatic and appetizing<br>substances as well as Couloring matters including pig-<br>ments, apply its national legislation until 31 December<br>1995;</p>
<p>Norway may,</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;with regard to Antibiotics, Coccidiostates and other med-<br>icinal substances, the Preservatives sulphuric acid and<br>chlorhydric acid as well as the Trace element copper as<br>growth promoter, maintain its national legislation. The<br>Contracting Parties shall review the matter during 1995;<br>with regard to Vitamins, provitamins and chemically well<br>defined substances having a similar effect, apply its natio-<br>nal legislation for a period expiring 31 December 1994.<br>The Contracting Parties may agree to prolong this period;</p>
<p>Sweden may, with regard to Antibiotics, Coccidiostates and ot-<br>her medicinal substances as well as the Preservative formic<br>acid, maintain its national legislation. The Contracting Parties<br>shall review the matter during 1995.</p>
<p>The provisions of the Directive shall, for the purposes of the<br>present Agreement, be read with the following adaptations:<br>For the application of Articles 4 and 5,</p>
<p>by 1 January 1993, the EFTA States shall forward dossiers con-<br>cerning additives authorized by EFTA States but not in the<br>Community, established according to the guidelines provided<br>for by Directive 87/153/EEC.</p>
<p>Dossiers and monographs, where appropriate, shall be for-<br>warded at least in the English language. Furthermore, a short<br>summary intended for publication, giving the basic information<br>contained in dossiers and monographs, shall be forwarded in<br>the English, French and German languages.</p>
<p>before 1 January 1995, the national authorizations granted by<br>EFTA States shall be decided on in accordance with the proce-<br>dure laid down in Article 23. Until a decision has been adopted<br>by the European Economic Community, the EFTA States may,<br>for products marketed in their territory, maintain their national<br>authorizations.</p>
<p>2. 387 L 0153: Council Directive 87/153/EEC of 16 February 1987 fixing gui-<br>delines for the assessment of additives in animal nutrition (OJ No L 64,<br>7.3.1987, p. 19)</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Annex I</p>
<p>Straight and compound feedingstuffs</p>
<p>3. 377 L 0101: Council Directive 77/101/EEC of 23 November 1976 on the<br>marketing of straight feedingstuffs (OJ No L 32, 3.2.1977, p. 1), as amended<br>by:</p>
<p>339</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;379 L 0372: Council Directive 79/372/EEC of 2 April 1979 (OJ No L<br>86, 6.4.1979, p. 29)</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;379 L 0797: First Commission Directive 79/797/EEC of<br>10 August 1979 (OJ No L 239, 22.9.1979, p. 53)</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;380 L 0510: Second Commission Directive 80/510/EEC of 2 May<br>1980 (OJ No L 126, 21.5.1980, p. 12)</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;382 L 0937: Third Commission Directive 82/937/EEC of<br>21 December 1982 (OJ No L 383, 31.12.1982, p. 11)</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;386 L 0354: Council Directive 86/354/EEC of 21 July 1986 (OJ No L<br>212, 2.8.1986, p. 27)</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;387 L 0234: Commission Directive 87/234/EEC of 31 March 1987<br>(OJ No L 102, 14.4.1987, p. 31)</p>

<h1>III PHYTOSANITARY MATTERS</h1>
<p>The provisions relating to third country relations and border Controls in the<br>acts referred to in this Chapter are not applicable.</p>

<p>Notwithstanding the provisions of the Directive:</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;The Contracting Parties shall from the entry into force of the Agree-<br>ment jointly elaborate a common catalogue of varieties comprising<br>also EFTA States’ varieties fulfilling the requirements of the Act.<br>They shall aim at completing such a common catalogue by 31 De-<br>cember 1995;</p>
<p>until the entry into force of the jointly elaborated catalogue the<br>EFTA States shall continue to apply national catalogues of varieties.</p>

<p>Annex I</p>
<p>359</p>
<h1>ANNEX II</h1>
<h1>TECHNICAL REGULATIONS, STANDARDS,</h1>
<h1>TESTING AND CERTIFICATION</h1>
<h2>List provided for in Article 23</h2>
<p>INTRODUCTION</p>
<p>When the acts referred to in this Annex contain notions or refer to procedu-<br>res which are specific to the Community legal order, such as</p>
<p>- preambles;</p>
<p>- the addressees of the Community acts;</p>
<p>- references to territories or languages of the EC;</p>
<p>- references to rights and obligations of EC Member States, their public<br>entities, undertakings or individuals in relation to each other; and</p>
<p>- references to information and notification procedures;</p>
<p>Protocol 1 on horizontal adaptations shall apply, unless otherwise provi-<br>ded for in this Annex.</p>
<p>SECTORAL ADAPTATIONS</p>
<p>References to Articles 30 and 36 or 30 to 36 of the Treaty establishing the<br>European Economic Community shall be replaced with references to Artic-<br>les 11 and 13 or 11 to 13 and, where applicable, 18 of the Agreement.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Annex II</p>
<p>360</p>
<h1>I. MOTOR VEHICLES</h1>
<p>The EFTA States may, until 1 January 1995, apply their national legislation,<br>including the possibility of refusing the registration, sale, entry into service<br>or use, on grounds relating to their emissions of gaseous pollutants for all<br>engines, particulates of diesel engines and noise, of motor vehicles falling<br>within the scope of the Directives in question which respect the requirements<br>of Directives 70/157/EEC, 70/220/EEC, 72/306/EEC and 88/77/EEC, as last<br>amended, and which are type-approved according to the requirements of Di-<br>rective 70/156/EEC. From 1 January 1995, the EFTA States may continue to<br>apply their national legislation, but they shall allow free circulation accor-<br>ding to the “Community acquis”. All proposals to amend, up-date, extend<br>or otherwise develop the “Community acquis” in relation to the matters co-<br>vered by these Directives shall be subject to the general decision-making<br>provisions of this Agreement.</p>
<p>The EFTA States shall not be entitled to grant EEC type-approval for<br>whole vehicles, or separate directives certificates for systems, components<br>or separate technical units according to the Directives within the scope of the<br>first paragraph, until 1 January 1995.</p>
<p>ACTS REFERRED TO</p>

<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Annex II</p>
<p>372</p>
<p>The Contracting Parties may refuse, within the period expiring on 1 July<br>1997, the placing on the market of vehicles of category Ml, M2 and M3 the<br>safety belts or restraint systems of which do not satisfy the requirements of<br>Directive 77/541/EEC as last amended by Directive 90/628/EEC, but shall<br>not refuse the placing on the market of vehicles which do respect these requi-<br>rements. The EFTA States shall only be entitled to grant EEC type-approval<br>according to these Directives from the date on which they apply in full the<br>Directives in question.</p>
<p>The provisions of the Directive shall, for the purposes of the present Ag-<br>reement, be read with the following adaptation:</p>
<p>In Annex III, the following shall be added to point 1.1.1.:</p>
<p>“12 for Austria</p>
<p>17 for Finland</p>
<p>15 for Iceland</p>
<p>FL for Liechtenstein</p>
<p>16 for Norway</p>
<p>5 for Sweden</p>
<p>14 for Switzerland&quot;.</p>

<p>40. 378 L1015: Council Directive 78/1015/EEC of 23 November 1978 on the<br>approximation of the laws of the Member States on the permissible sound<br>level and exhaust system of motorcycles (OJ No L 349,13.12.1978, p.21), as<br>corrected by OJ No L 10, 16.1.1979, p.15, as amended by:</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;1 79 H: Act concerning the Conditions of Accession and the Adjust-<br>ments to the Treaties - Accession to the European Communities of<br>the Hellenic Republic (OJ No L 291, 19.11.1979, p. 110)</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;1851: Act concerning the Conditions of Accession and Adjustments<br>to the Treaties - Accession to the European Communities of the<br>Kingdom of Spain and the Portuguese Republic (OJ No L 302,</p>
<p>15.11.1985, p.214)</p>
<p>387 L 0056: Council Directive 87/56/EEC of 18 December 1986 (OJ<br>No L 24, 27.1.1987, p.42)</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;389 L 0235: Council Directive 89/235/EEC of 13 March 1989 (OJ No<br>L98, 11.4.1989, p.l)</p>
<p>The EFTA States may, until 1 January 1995, apply their national legisla-<br>tion, including the possibility of refusing the registration, sale, entry into ser-<br>vice or use, on grounds of their sound level and exhaust system, of motorcyc-<br>les falling within the scope of the Directive in question which respect the re-<br>quirements of Directive 78/1015/EEC, as last amended. From 1 January<br>1995, the EFTA States may continue to apply their national legislation, but<br>they shall allow free circulation according to the “Community acquis”. All<br>proposals to amend, up-date, extend or otherwise develop the “Community<br>acquis” in relation to the matters covered by the Directive shall be subject<br>to the general decision-making provisions of this Agreement.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Annex II</p>
<p>374</p>
<p>The EFTA States shall not be entitled to grant certificates according to the<br>Directive until 1 January 1995.</p>
<p>The provisions of the Directive shall, for the purposes of the present Ag-<br>reement, be read with the following adaptations:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;In Article 2, the following indents shall be added:</p>
<p>- ”Typengenehmigung&quot; in Austrian law,</p>
<p>- “tyyppihyväksyntä”/ “typgodkännande” in Finnish law,</p>
<p>- “geröarviöurkenning” in Icelandic law,</p>
<p>- “Typengenehmigung” in Liechtensteiner law,</p>
<p>- “typegodkjenning” in Norwegian law,</p>
<p>- “typgodkännande” in Swedish law,</p>
<p>- “Typengenehmigung/”approbation du type“/”approvazione del<br>tipo“ in Swiss law”.</p>
<p>(b) In Annex II, the following shall be added to point 3.1.3:</p>

<p>17 for Finland</p>

<p>The provisions of the Directive shall, for the purposes of the present Ag-<br>reement, be read with the following adaptations:</p>
<p>(a) The products listed in Annex III(l)(a), when contained in retur-<br>nable packages may, until 31 December 1996, be marketed in the<br>following volumes:</p>
<p>in Switzerland and Liechtenstein: 0,7 liters;</p>
<p>in Sweden: 0,7 liters;</p>
<p>in Norway: 0,35 - 0,7 liters;</p>
<p>in Austria: 0,7 liters.</p>
<p>The products listed in Annex III(3)(a), when contained in retur-<br>nable packages may, in Norway, until 31 December 1996, be marke-<br>ted in the volumes 0,35 - 0,7 liters.</p>
<p>The products listed in Annex 111(4), when contained in returnable<br>packages may, in Sweden, until 31 December 1996, be marketed in<br>the volumes 0,375 - 0,75 liters.</p>
<p>The products listed in Annex III(8)(a) and (b), when contained in<br>returnable packages may, in Norway, until 31 December 1996, be<br>marketed in the volumes 0,35 liters.</p>
<p>From 1 January 1993 the EFTA States shall ensure free circulation<br>of products marketed according to the requirements of Directive<br>75/106, as last amended.</p>

<h1>X. ELECTRICAL MATERIAL</h1>
<p>ACTS REFERRED TO</p>
<p>1. 373 L 0023: Council Directive 73/23/EEC of 19 February 1973 on the har-<br>monization of the laws of the Member States relating to electrical equipment<br>designed for use within certain voltage limits (OJ No L 77, 26.3.1973, p.29)</p>
<p>Finland, Iceland and Sweden shall comply with the provisions of the Di-<br>rective by 1 January 1994.</p>
<p>2. 376 L 0117: Council Directive 76/117/EEC of 18 December 1975 on the<br>approximation of the laws of the Member States concerning electrical equip-<br>ment for use in potentially explosive atmospheres (OJ No L 24, 30.1.1976,<br>p.45)</p>
<p>3. 379 L 0196: Council Directive 79/196/EEC of 6 February 1979 on the ap-<br>proximation of the laws of the Member States concerning electrical equip-<br>ment for use in potentially explosive atmospheres employing certain types of<br>protection (OJ No L 43, 20.2.1979, p.20), as amended by:</p>
<p>384 L 0047: Commission Directive 84/47/EEC of 16 January 1984<br>(OJ No L 31, 2.2.1984, p.19)</p>
<p>388 L 0571: Commission Directive 88/571/EEC of 10 November<br>1988 (OJ No L 311, 17.11.1988, p.46)</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;388 L 0665: Council Directive 88/665/EEC of 21 December 1988 (OJ<br>No L 382, 31.12.1988, p.42)</p>

<h1>XII. FOODSTUFFS</h1>
<p>The EC Commission nominates from highly qualified scientific persons from<br>EFTA States at least one person who will be present in the Scientific Com-<br>mittee for Food and who will be entitled to express his views therein. His<br>position will be recorded separately.</p>
<p>The EC Commission shall, in due time, inform him of the date of the mee-<br>ting of the Committee and transmit the relevant information.</p>

<p>Annex II</p>
<p>422</p>
<h1>XIII. MEDICIN AL PRODUCTS</h1>
<p>The EFTA Surveillance Authority may designate, according to its working<br>procedures, two observers entitled to participate in the tasks of the Commit-<br>tee which are described in Article 2, first indent of the Council Decision<br>75/320/EEC of 20 May 1975 setting up a pharmaceutical committee.</p>
<p>Notwithstanding Article 101 of the Agreement, the EC Commission shall<br>invite experts from the EFTA States according to Article 99 of the Agree-<br>ment, to participate in the tasks which are described in Article 2, second in-<br>dent of the Council Decision 75/320/EEC.</p>
<p>The EC Commission shall, in due time, inform the EFTA Surveillance<br>Authority about the date of the meeting of the Committee and transmit the<br>relevant documentation.</p>
<p>ACTS REFERRED TO</p>
