<p>18. 376 L 0207: Council Directive 76/207/EEC of 9 February 1976 on the<br>implementation of the principle of equal treatment for men and women as<br>regards access to employment, vocational training and promotion, and wor-<br>king conditions (OJNo L 39, 14.2.1976, p.40).</p>
<p>The provisions of the Directive shall, for the purposes of the present Ag-<br>reement, be read with the following adaptation:</p>
<p>Switzerland and Liechtenstein shall put into effect the measures necessary<br>for them to comply with the provisions of this Directive as from 1 January<br>1995.</p>
<p>19. 379 L 0007: Council Directive 79/7/EEC of 19 December 1978 on the<br>progressive implementation of the principle of equal treatment for men and<br>women in matters of social security (OJ No L 6, 10.1.1979, p.24)</p>
<p>The provisions of the Directive shall, for the purposes of the present Ag-<br>reement, be read with the following adaptation:</p>
<p>Austria shall put into effect the measures necessary for it to comply with<br>the provisions of this Directive as from 1 January 1994.</p>
<p>20. 386 L 0378: Council Directive 86/378/EEC of 24 July 1986 on the imple-<br>mentation of the principle of equal treatment for men and women in occupa-<br>tional social security schemes (OJ No L 225, 12.8.1986, p.40)</p>

<p>Labour law</p>
<p>22. 375 L 0129: Council Directive 75/129/EEC of 17 February 1975 on the<br>approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to collective redun-<br>dancies (OJ No L 48, 22.2.1975, p.29).</p>
<p>23. 377 L 0187: Council Directive 77/187/EEC of 14 February 1977 on the<br>approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to the safeguarding</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Annex XVIII</p>
<p>664</p>
<p>of employees’ rights in the event of transfers of undertakings, businesses or<br>parts of businesses (OJ No L 61, 5.3.1977, p.26).</p>
<p>The provisions of the Directive shall, for the purposes of the present Ag-<br>reement, be read with the following adaptation:</p>
<p>In Article 1 (2), “the territorial scope of the Treaty” shall be read “the<br>territorial scope of the EEA Agreement”.</p>
<p>24. 380 L 0987: Council Directive 80/987/EEC of 20 October 1980 on the<br>approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to the protection of<br>employees in the event of the insolvency of their employer (OJ No L 283,<br>28.10.1980, p. 23), as amended by:</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;387 L 0164: Council Directive 87/164/EEC of 2 March 1987 (OJ No</p>
<p>L66, 11.3.1987, p.ll)</p>
<p>The provisions of the Directive shall, for the purposes of the present Ag-<br>reement, be read with the following adaptations:</p>
<p>(a) The following shall be added to section I of the Annex:</p>
<p>“E AUSTRIA</p>
<p>1. Members of the authority of a body corporate, which is respon-<br>sible for the statutory representation of that body.</p>
<p>2. Associates entitled to exercise dominant influence in the associa-<br>tion, even if this influence is based on fiduciary disposition.</p>
<p>G. LIECHTENSTEIN</p>
<p>Partners or shareholders entitled to exercise dominant influence in<br>a partnership or a company.</p>
<p>H. ICELAND</p>
<p>I. Those members of the Board of Directors of a bankrupt company<br>after the company’s financial situation became considerably ad-<br>verse.</p>
<p>2. Those having held 5 % or thereover of the Capital of a bankrupt<br>limited company.</p>
<p>3. The general manager of a liquidated company or those others<br>who, on account of their work with the company, had had a sur-<br>vey of the company’s finances in such manner that it could not<br>be concealed from them that a company’s liquidation had been<br>impending at the time the wages were being earned.</p>
<p>4. The spouse of a person in a situation specified in clauses 1 to 3 as<br>well as his/her direct relative and direct relative’s spouse.</p>
<p>I. SWEDEN</p>
<p>An employee, or the survivors of an employee, who on his own or<br>together with his close relatives was the owner of an essential part<br>of the employer’s undertaking or business and had a considerable<br>influence on its activities. This shall apply also when the employer<br>is a legal person without an undertaking or business.&quot;</p>
<p>(b) The following shall be added to section II of the Annex:</p>
<p>“E. LIECHTENSTEIN</p>
<p>Insured persons receiving benefits from the old age insurance.</p>
<p>E SWITZERLAND</p>
<p>Insured persons receiving benefits from the old age insurance.&quot;</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Annex XVIII</p>
<p>665</p>
<h1>ANNEX XIX</h1>
<h1>CONSUMER PROTECTION</h1>
<h2>List provided for in Article 72</h2>
<p>INTRODUCTION</p>
<p>When the acts referred to in this Annex contain notions or refer to procedu-<br>res which are specific to the Community legal order, such as</p>
<p>- preambles;</p>
<p>- the addressees of the Community acts;</p>
<p>- &nbsp;references to territories or languages of the EC;</p>
<p>- references to rights and obligations of EC Member States, their public<br>entities, undertakings or individuals in relation to each other; and</p>
<p>- references to information and notification procedures;</p>
<p>Protocol 1 on horizontal adaptations shall apply, unless otherwise provided<br>for in this Annex.</p>
<p>SECTORAL ADAPTATIONS</p>
<p>For the purposes of this Annex and notwithstanding the provisions of Proto-<br>col 1, the term “Member State(s)” contained in the acts referred to shall be<br>understood to include, in addition to its meaning in the relevant EC acts,<br>Austria, Finland, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway, Sweden and Switzerland.</p>

<h1>ANNEX XX</h1>

<h2>List provided for in Article 74</h2>
<p>INTRODUCTION</p>
<p>When the acts referred to in this Annex contain notions or refer to procedu-<br>res which are specific to the Community legal order, such as</p>
<p>- preambles;</p>
<p>- the addressees of the Community acts;</p>
<p>- &nbsp;references to territories or languages of the EC;</p>
<p>- &nbsp;references to rights and obligations of EC Member States, their public<br>entities, undertakings or individuals in relation to each other; and</p>
<p>- references to information and notification procedures;</p>
<p>Protocol 1 on horizontal adaptations shall apply, unless otherwise provided<br>for in this Annex.</p>
<p>SECTORAL ADAPTATION</p>
<p>For the purposes of this Annex and notwithstanding the provisions of Proto-<br>col 1, the term “Member State(s)” contained in the acts referred to shall be<br>understood to include, in addition to its meaning in the relevant EC acts,<br>Austria, Finland, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway, Sweden and Switzerland.</p>

<p>IV. CHEMICALS, INDUSTRIAL RISK AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<p>22. 376 L 0403: Council Directive 76/403/EEC of 6 April 1976 on the dispo-<br>sal of polychlorinated biphenyls and polychlorinated terphenyls (OJ No L<br>108, 26.4.1976, p.41)</p>

<p>672</p>
<p>23. 382 L 0501: Council Directive 82/501/EEC of 24 June 1982 on the major-<br>accident hazards of certain industrial activities (OJ No L230, 5.8.1982, p.l),<br>as amended by:</p>
<p>1 85 I: Act concerning the Conditions of Accession and Adjustments<br>to the Treaties - Accession to the European Communities of the<br>Kingdom of Spain and the Portuguese Republic<br>(OJNoL302,15.11.1985,p.219)</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;387 L 0216: Council Directive 87/216/EEC of 19 March 1987 (OJ No<br>L 085, 28.3.1987, p.36)</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;388 L 0610: Council Directive 88/610/EEC of 24 November 1988 (OJ<br>No L 336, 7.12.1988, p.14)</p>

<p>The provisions of the Directive shall, for the purposes of the Agreement,<br>be read with the following adaptation:</p>
<p>Austria, Finland, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway and Sweden shall put<br>into effect the measures necessary for them to comply with the provisions of<br>this Directive as from 1 January 1995.</p>
<p>25. 390 L 0220: Council Directive 90/220/EEC of 23 April 1990 on the deli-<br>berate release into the environment of genetically modified organisms (OJ<br>No L 117, 8.5.1990, p.15)</p>
<p>The provisions of the Directive shall, for the purposes of the present Ag-<br>reement, be read with the following adaptations:</p>
<p>(a) Austria, Finland, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway and Sweden shall</p>
<p>put into effect &nbsp;the measures necessary for them to comply with the</p>
<p>provisions of this Directive as from 1 January 1995.</p>
<p>(b) Article 16 shall be replaced by the following:</p>
<p>“1. Where a Contracting Party has justifiable reasons to consider that a<br>product which has been properly notified and has received written<br>consent under this Directive constitutes a risk to human health or<br>the environment, it may restrict or prohibit the use and/or sale of<br>that product on its territory. It shall immediately inform the other<br>Contracting Parties through the EEA Joint Committee of such ac-<br>tion and give reasons for its decision.</p>
<p>2. If a Contracting Party so requires, consultations on the appropriate-<br>ness of the measures taken shall take place in the EEA Joint Com-<br>mittee. Part VII of the Agreement shall apply.&quot;</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;The Contracting Parties agree that the Directive only covers aspects<br>relating to the potential risks to humans, plants, animals and the en-<br>vironment.</p>
<p>The EFTA States therefore reserve the right to apply their natio-<br>nal legislation in this area in relation to other concerns than health<br>and environment, in so far as it is compatible with this Agreement.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Annex XX</p>
<p>673</p>
<p>43 Riksdagen 1991192. 1 saml. Nr 170. Bil. 15</p>
<p>V. WASTE</p>
<p>26. 375 L 0439: Council Directive 75/439/EEC of 16 June 1975 on the dispo-<br>sal of waste oils (OJ No L 194, 25.7.1975, p.23), as amended by:</p>

<h1>ANNEX XXI</h1>
<h1>STATISTICS</h1>
<h2>List provided for in Article 76</h2>
<p>INTRODUCTION</p>
<p>When the acts referred to in this Annex contain notions or refer to procedu-<br>res which are specific to the Community legal order, such as</p>
<p>- preambles;</p>
<p>- the addressees of the Community acts;</p>
<p>- &nbsp;references to territories or languages of the EC;</p>
<p>- &nbsp;references to rights and obligations of EC Member States, their public<br>entities, undertakings or individuals in relation to each other; and</p>
<p>- &nbsp;references to information and notification procedures;</p>
<p>Protocol 1 on horizontal adaptations shall apply, unless otherwise provided<br>for in this Annex.</p>
<p>SECTORAL ADAPTATIONS</p>
<p>1. For the purposes of this Annex and notwithstanding the provisions of Pro-<br>tocol 1, the term “Member State(s)” contained in the acts referred to shall<br>be understood to include, in addition to its meaning in the relevant EC acts,<br>Austria, Finland, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway, Sweden and Switzerland.</p>
<p>2. References to the “Nomenclature of Industries in the European Commu-<br>nities (NICE)”, and to “Nomenclature of Economic Activities in the Euro-<br>pean Communities (NACE)” shall, except where otherwise provided, be<br>read as references to “Nomenclature of Economic Activities in the European<br>Communities (NACE Rev.l)”, as defined by the Council Regulation (EEC)<br>No 3037/90 of 9 October 1990 on the statistical classification of economic<br>activities in the European Communities, and as adapted for this Agreement.<br>The referred code numbers shall be read as the corresponding converted<br>code numbers in NACE Rev.l.</p>
<p>3. Provisions laying down by whom the costs for carrying out surveys and<br>the like shall be borne are not relevant for the purposes of this Agreement.</p>
<p>ACTS REFERRED TO</p>
<p>INDUSTRIAL STATISTICS</p>
<p>1. 364 L 0475: Council Directive 64/475/EEC of 30 July 1964 concerning co-<br>ordinated annual surveys of investment in industry (OJ No 131, 13.8.1964,<br>p.2193/64), as amended by:</p>
<p>1 72 B: Act concerning the Conditions of Accession and Adjust-<br>ments to the Treaties - Accession of the Kingdom of Denmark, Ire-<br>land and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Annex XXI</p>
<p>677</p>
<p>(OJ No L 73, 27.3.1972, p. 121,159)</p>
<p>1 79 H: Act concerning the Conditions of Accession and Adjust-<br>ments to the Treaties - Accession of the Hellenic Republic (OJ No<br>L291, 19.11.1979, p.112)</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;1851: Act concerning the Conditions of Accession and Adjustments<br>to the Treaties - Accession of the Kingdom of Spain and the Portu-<br>guese Republic (OJ No L 302, 15.11.1985, p.231)</p>
<p>The provisions of the Directive shall, for the purposes of the present Ag-<br>reement, be read with the following adaptations:</p>
<p>(a) The Annex is not relevant.</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;For Liechtenstein, the data required by this Directive shall be inclu-<br>ded in the data for Switzerland.</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;The EFTA States shall, respectively, carry out their first survey re-<br>quired by this Directive not later than in 1995.</p>
<p>(d) Finland, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway, Sweden and Switzerland<br>shall provide the data required by this Directive at least down to the<br>3-digit level and, if possible, down to the 4-digit level of NACE<br>Rev.l.</p>
<p>(e) Austria, Finland, Iceland, Norway, Sweden and Switzerland shall,<br>for the undertakings being classified by Council Regulation (EEC)<br>No 3037/90 of 9 October 1990 on the statistical classification of eco-<br>nomic activities in the European Communities under the code num-<br>ber 27.10 and taking due consideration of statistical confidentiality<br>as defined by Council Regulation (Euratom/EEC) No 1588/90 of 11<br>June 1990 on the transmission of data subject to statistical confiden-<br>tiality to the Statistical Office of the European Communities, as<br>adapted for this Agreement, provide through the competent natio-<br>nal statistical authorities the information equivalent to that reques-<br>ted in questionnaires 2.60 and 2.61 in the Annex to the Commission<br>Decision 3302/81/ECSC of 18 November 1981 on the information to<br>be furnished by Steel undertakings about their investment (OJ No L<br>333, 20.11.1981, p.35).</p>
<p>2. 372 L 0211: Council Directive 72/211/EEC of 30 May 1972 concerning co-<br>ordinated statistics on the business cycle in industry and small craft industries<br>(OJ No L 128, 3.6.1972, p.28), as amended by:</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;1 79 H: Act concerning the Conditions of Accession and Adjust-<br>ments to the Treaties - Accession of the Hellenic Republic (OJ No<br>L291, 19.11.1979, p.112)</p>
<p>1851: Act concerning the Conditions of Accession and Adjustments<br>to the Treaties - Accession of the Kingdom of Spain and the Portu-<br>guese Republic (OJ No L 302, 15.11.1985, p.231)</p>
<p>The provisions of the Directive shall, for the purposes of the present Ag-<br>reement, be read with the following adaptations:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;In Article 3, first paragraph, point 5, the text “specifying the number<br>of manual workers” shall be deleted.</p>
<p>(b) Iceland and Liechtenstein are exempted from collecting the data re-</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Annex XXI</p>
<p>678</p>
<p>quired by this Directive.</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;Switzerland shall collect the data required by this Directive from, at<br>the latest, 1997 onwards. However, the data shall already be provi-<br>ded on a quarterly basis from 1995 onwards.</p>
<p>(d) &nbsp;Finland shall collect the data required by this Directive from, at the<br>latest, 1997 onwards. However, monthly data on the industrial pro-<br>duction index shall be provided from, at the latest, 1995 onwards.</p>
<p>(e) Austria, Norway and Sweden shall collect the data required by this<br>Directive from, at the latest, 1995 onwards.</p>
<p>3. 372 L 0221: Council Directive 72/221/EEC of 6 June 1972 concerning co-<br>ordinated annual inquiry into industrial activity (OJ No L 133, 10.6.1972,<br>p.57), as amended by:</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;1 79 H: Act concerning the Conditions of Accession and Adjust-<br>ments to the Treaties - Accession of the Hellenic Republic (OJ No<br>L291, 19.11.1979, p.112)</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;1851: Act concerning the Conditions of Accession and Adjustments<br>to the Treaties - Accession of the Kingdom of Spain and the Portu-<br>guese Republic (OJ No L 302, 15.11.1985, p.231)</p>
<p>The provisions of the Directive shall, for the purposes of the present Ag-<br>reement, be read with the following adaptations:</p>
<p>(a) In Article 3, the reference to “NACE” shall be read as “NACE, 1970<br>edition”.</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;For Liechtenstein, the data required by this Directive shall be inclu-<br>ded in the data for Switzerland.</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;The EFTA States shall collect the data required by this Directive<br>from, at the latest, 1995 onwards.</p>
<p>(d) Finland, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway, Sweden and Switzerland<br>shall collect and provide the data required in Articles 2 and 5 of this<br>Directive at least down to the 3-digit level of NACE Rev.l.</p>
<p>(e) Switzerland and Liechtenstein are exempted from providing the<br>data on the economic activity unit and the local unit for all variables<br>except those on turnover and employment.</p>
<p>(f) &nbsp;The EFTA States are exempted from providing data on the variables<br>corresponding to the code numbers 1.21, 1.21.1, 1.22 and 1.22.1 of<br>the Annex.</p>
<p>4. 378 L 0166: Council Directive 78/166/EEC of 13 February 1978 concer-<br>ning co-ordinated statistics on the business cycle in building and civil eng-<br>ineering (OJ No L 52, 23.1.1978, p.17, as amended by:</p>

<p>(b) &nbsp;In Article 3(a), the data is to be provided at least quarterly.</p>

<p>Suomi/Finland</p>
<p>Norway</p>
<p>Norge/Noreg</p>
<p>Sweden</p>
<p>Sverige</p>
<p>Switzerland</p>
<p>Schweiz/Suisse/Svizzera&quot;</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;Annex III is amended as follows:</p>
<p>The following is inserted between the heading “LIST OF ...” and<br>part I of the table:</p>
<p>“A. EEA States”Part II is replaced by the following:</p>
<p>“II. EFTA States</p>
<p>13. Austria</p>
<p>14. Finland</p>
<p>15. Norway</p>
<p>16. Sweden</p>
<p>17. Switzerland</p>

<p>27. Other countries&quot;</p>
<p>(d) The EFTA States shall collect the data required by this Directive<br>from, at the latest, 1995 onwards.</p>

<p>Annex XXI</p>
<p>FOREIGN AND COMMUNITY-INTERNAL TRADE STATISTICS</p>
<p>8. 375 R1736: Regulation (EEC) No 1736/75 of the Council of 24 June 1975<br>on the external trade statistics of the Community and statistics of trade bet-<br>ween Member States (OJ No L 183, 14.7.1975, p.3), as amended by:</p>
<p>377 R 2845: Council Regulation (EEC) No 2845/77 of 19 December<br>1977 (OJNo L 329, 22.12.1977, p.3)</p>
<p>384 R 3396: Commission Regulation (EEC) No 3396/84 of 3 Decem-<br>ber 1984 (OJNo L 314, 4.12.1984, p.10)</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;387 R 3367: Council Regulation (EEC) No 3367/87 of 9 November</p>
<p>1987 on the application of the Combined Nomenclature to the statis-<br>tics of trade between Member States and amending Regulation<br>(EEC) No 1736/75 on the external trade statistics of the Community<br>and statistics of trade between its Member States (OJNo L 321,</p>
<p>684</p>
<p>11.11.1987, p.3)</p>
<p>387 R 3678: Commission Regulation (EEC) No 3678/87 of 9 Decem-<br>ber 1987 on statistical procedures in respect of the Community’s ex-<br>ternal trade (OJ No L 346, 10.12.1987, p.12)</p>
<p>388 R 0455: Commission Regulation (EEC) No 455/88 of 18 Fe-<br>bruary 1988 on the statistical threshold in the external trade statistics<br>of the Community and statistics of trade between Member States<br>(OJ No L 46, 19.2.1988, p.19)</p>
<p>388 R 1629: Council Regulation (EEC) No 1629/88 of 27 May 1988<br>(OJ No L147, 14.6.1988, p.l)</p>
<p>391 R 0091: Commission Regulation (EEC) No 91/91 of 15 January<br>1991 (OJNo L 11, 16.1.1991, p.5)</p>
<p>The provisions of the Regulation shall, for the purposes of the present Ag-<br>reement, be read with the following adaptations:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;Article 2 (2) (a) and (b) shall read:</p>
<p>“(a) goods entering or leaving the customs warehouses with the ex-<br>ception of the customs warehouses listed in Annex A;</p>
<p>(b) goods entering or leaving the free zones listed in Annex A.“</p>
<p>(b) Article 3 is replaced by the following:</p>
<p>1. The statistical territory of the EEA shall, in principle, comprise<br>the customs territories of the Contracting Parties. The Contrac-<br>ting Parties shall define their statistical territories accordingly.</p>
<p>2. The statistical territory of the Community shall comprise the cus-<br>toms territory of the Community as defined in Council Regula-<br>tion (EEC) No 2151/84 of 23 July 1984 on the definition of the<br>customs territory of the Community as last amended by Regula-<br>tion (EEC) No 4151/88.</p>
<p>3. For the EFTA States the statistical territory shall comprise the<br>customs territory. However, for Norway, the Svalbard Archipe-<br>lago and the Jan Mayen Island shall be included in the statistical<br>territory. Switzerland and Liechtenstein together form one single<br>statistical territory.</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;The classification referred to in Article 5 (1) and (3) shall be made<br>at least down to the first 6 digits.</p>
<p>(d) In Article 7(1), the introductory phrase is replaced by the following:</p>
<p>“Without prejudice to Article 5(1) and (2) of Regulation (EEC)<br>No 2658/87, the following should be indicated in the statistical<br>information medium of each CN subheading, at least down to the<br>first 6 digits.”</p>
<p>(e) The following new paragraph is added to Article 9:</p>
<p>“3. For the EFTA States, ”country of origin&quot; shall be taken to mean<br>the country in which the goods originated within the meaning of<br>the respective national rules of origin.”</p>
<p>(f) &nbsp;Article 17(1): The reference to “Council Regulation (EEC) No<br>803/68 of... as last amended by Regulation (EEC) No 1028/75” shall<br>read “Council Regulation (EEC) No 1224/80 of 28 May 1980 concer-<br>ning the valuation of goods for customs purposes (OJ No L 134,</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Annex XXI</p>
<p>685</p>
<p>31.5.1980, p.l)”.</p>
<p>(g) &nbsp;Article 34 is replaced by the following:</p>
<p>“The data referred to in Article 22 (1) shall be compiled for each<br>CN subheading according to the current version of the first 6 di-<br>gits of the Combined Nomenclature.”</p>
<p>(h) Annex C is amended as follows:</p>
<p>The following line is inserted between “EUROPE” and “Commu-<br>nity”:</p>
<p>“European Economic Area”</p>

<p>STATISTICAL CONFIDENTIALITY</p>
<p>17. 390 R 1588: Council Regulation (EEC) No 1588/90 of 11 June 1990 on<br>the transmission of data subject to statistical confidentiality to the Statistical<br>Office of the European Communities (OJ No L 151, 15.6.1990, p.l)</p>
<p>The provisions of the Regulation shall, for the purposes of the present Ag-<br>reement, be read with the following adaptations:</p>
<p>(a) The following new paragraph is added to Article 2:</p>
<p>“11. staff of the Office of the EFTA Statistical Adviser: staff of the<br>EFTA Secretariat working on the premises of the SOEC.”</p>
<p>(b) In the second sentence of Article 5 (1), the term “SOEC” is replaced<br>by “SOEC and of the Office of the EFTA Statistical Adviser”.</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;The following new subparagraph is added to Article 5 (2):</p>
<p>Confidential statistical data transmitted to the SOEC through the<br>Office of the EFTA Statistical Adviser shall be accessible also to the<br>staff of this Office.</p>
<p>(d) In Article 6, the term “SOEC” shall, for these purposes, be read as<br>to include the Office of the EFTA Statistical Adviser.</p>
<p>688</p>
<p>DEMOGRAPHICAL AND SOCIAL STATISTICS</p>
<p>18. 376 R 0311: Council Regulation (EEC) No 311/76 of 9 February 1976 on<br>the compilation of statistics on foreign workers (OJ No L 39, 14.2.1976, p.l)</p>
<p>The provisions of the Regulation shall, for the purposes of the present Ag-<br>reement, be read with the following adaptations:</p>
<p>(a) Finland, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway, Sweden and Switzerland<br>shall not be bound by the regional breakdown of the data required<br>in Article 1.</p>
<p>(b) The EFTA States shall collect the data required by this Regulation<br>from, at the latest, 1995 onwards.</p>
<p>NATIONAL ACCOUNTS - GDP</p>
<p>19. 389 L 0130: Council Directive 89/130/EEC,Euratom of 13 February 1989<br>on the harmonization of gross national product at market prices (OJ No L<br>49, 21.2.1989, p.26)</p>
<p>The provisions of the Directive shall, for the purposes of the present Ag-<br>reement, be read with the following adaptations:</p>
<p>(a) Liechtenstein is exempted from providing the data required by this<br>Directive.</p>
<p>(b) Austria, Finland, Iceland, Norway, Sweden and Switzerland shall<br>provide the data required by this Directive from, at the latest, 1995<br>onwards.</p>
<p>NOMENCLATURES</p>
<p>20. 390 R 3037: Council Regulation (EEC) No 3037/90 of 9 October 1990 on<br>the statistical classification of economic activities in the European Com-<br>munities (OJ No L 293, 24.10.1990, p.l)</p>
<p>The provisions of the Regulation shall, for the purposes of the present Ag-<br>reement, be read with the following adaptation:</p>
<p>Austria, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway, Sweden and Switzerland shall<br>use “NACE Rev.l” or a national classification derived therefrom pursuant<br>to Article 3 from, at the latest, 1995 onwards. Finland shall comply with this<br>Regulation from, at the latest, 1997 onwards.</p>

<p>23. 388 R 0571: Council Regulation (EEC) No 571/88 of 29 February 1988<br>on the organization of Community surveys on the structure of agricultural<br>holdings between 1988 and 1997 (OJ No L56, 2.3.1988, p.l), as amended<br>by:</p>

<p>(a) &nbsp;In Article 4, the text beginning with “and insofar as they are impor-<br>tant locally ...” until the end of the Article is not applicable.</p>
<p>(b) In Article 6(2), the text “standard gross margin (SGM), within the<br>meaning of Decision 85/377/EEC” is replaced by:</p>
<p>“standard gross margin (SGM), within the meaning of Decision<br>85/377/EEC, or to the value of the total agricultural production”.</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;In Article 8(2), the reference to “Decision 83/461/EEC, as amended<br>by Decisions 85/622/EEC and 85/643/EEC” is replaced by a refe-<br>rence to “Decision 89/651/EEC”. A new footnote is added at the<br>bottom of the page: OJ No L 391, 30.12.1989, p.l.</p>

<p>Annex XXI</p>
<p>(f) &nbsp;For Liechtenstein, the data required by this Regulation shall be in-<br>cluded in the data for Switzerland.</p>
<p>(g) &nbsp;Finland, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway, Sweden and Switzerland<br>shall not be bound by the geographical breakdown of the data requi-<br>red in Articles 4, 8 and Annex I of this Regulation. However, these<br>States shall assure that sample sizes are such that the breakdown of<br>the data other than regional is obtained on a representative basis.</p>
<p>(h) Finland, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway, Sweden and Switzerland<br>shall not be bound by the typology referred to in Articles 6, 7, 8, 9<br>and Annex I of this Regulation. However, these States shall transmit<br>the necessary additional information allowing the reclassification ac-<br>cording to this typology.</p>
<p>(i) &nbsp;The EFTA States are exempted from the obligation to carry out the<br>survey referred to in Article 3 (c).</p>
<p>(j) &nbsp;The EFTA States shall collect the data required by this Regulation<br>from, at the latest, 1995 onwards.</p>
<p>24. 390 R 0837: Council Regulation (EEC) No 837/90 of 26 March 1990 con-<br>cerning statistical information to be supplied by the Member States on ce-<br>reals production (OJNo L 88, 3.4.1990, p.l)</p>
<p>The provisions of the Regulation shall, for the purposes of the present Ag-<br>reement, be read with the following adaptations:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;In Article 8(4), the text “twice a year” is deleted.</p>
<p>(b) In Annex III, the following is added after the entry for United King-<br>dom:</p>
<p>Austria &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Bundesländer</p>
<p>Finland &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;-</p>
<p>Iceland &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;-</p>
<p>Norway</p>
<p>Sweden &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;-</p>
<p>Switzerland &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;-<br></p>
<p>692</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;Liechtenstein is exempted from supplying the data required by this<br>Regulation.</p>
<p>(d) Austria, Finland, Iceland, Norway, Sweden and Switzerland shall<br>provide the data required by this Regulation from, at the latest, 1995<br>onwards.</p>
<p>FISHERY STATISTICS</p>
<p>25. 391 R 1382: Council Regulation (EEC) No 1382/91 of 21 May 1991 on<br>the submission of data on the landings of fishery products in Member States<br>(OJNoL 133, 28.5.1991, p.l)</p>
<p>The provisions of the Regulation shall, for the purposes of the present Ag-<br>reement, be read with the following adaptations:</p>
<p>(a) In Annex 3, the layout of the table is changed according to the follo-<br>wing:</p>
<p>EC &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;EFTA&lt;’&gt;</p>
<p>Quantity Price Quantity Price</p>
<p>FOR HUMAN CONSUMPTION:</p>
<p>Cods (CDZ)</p>
<p>Fresh whole</p>
<p>Column to be completed by EFTA States, and by those EC<br>Member States which register EFTA vessels.</p>
<p>(b) The EFTA States shall provide the data required by this Regula-<br>tion from, at the latest, 1995 onwards. The report referred to in<br>Article 5(1) and, in case of the need, the request for exclusions<br>of small ports referred to in Article 5(6), first subparagraph,<br>shall be made in the course of the year 1995.</p>
<p>ENERGY STATISTICS</p>
<p>26. 390 L 0377: Council Directive 90/377/EEC of 29 June 1990 concerning a<br>Community procedure to improve the transparency of gas and electricity pri-<br>ces charged to industrial end-users (OJ No L 185, 17.7.1990, p.16)</p>
<p>The provisions of the Directive shall, for the purposes of the present Ag-<br>reement, be read with the following adaptations:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;The following is added to Article 2 (1) and (3):</p>
<p>“For Austria, Finland, Norway, Sweden and Switzerland the data<br>shall be sent to the SOEC through the countries’ competent national<br>authorities.”</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;Irrespective of the provisions of Articles 4 and 5, the handling of<br>confidential data from Austria, Finland, Norway, Sweden and Swit-<br>zerland is governed exclusively by the Council Regulation (Eurato-<br>m/EEC) No 1588/90 of 11 June 1990 on the transmission of data sub-<br>ject to statistical confidentiality to the Statistical Office of the Euro-<br></p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Annex XXI</p>
<p>693</p>
<p>pean Communities, as adapted for this Agreement.</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;Iceland and Liechtenstein shall be exempted from supplying the in-<br>formation requested by this Directive.</p>
<p>(d) Austria, Finland, Norway, Sweden and Switzerland shall provide<br>the information required by this Directive from, at the latest, 1995<br>onwards. These countries shall inform the SOEC by 1 January 1993<br>about the places and regions for which prices will be recorded accor-<br>ding to item 11 of Annex I and items 2 and 13 of Annex II.</p>

<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Annex XXI</p>
<p>694</p>
<h1>ANNEX XXII</h1>
<h1>COMPANY LAW</h1>
<h2>List provided for in Article 77</h2>
<p>INTRODUCTION</p>
<p>When the acts referred to in this Annex contain notions or refer to procedu-<br>res which are specific to the Community legal order, such as</p>
<p>- preambles;</p>
<p>- the addressees of the Community acts;</p>
<p>- &nbsp;references to territories or languages of the EC;</p>
<p>- &nbsp;references to rights and obligations of EC Member States, their public<br>entities, undertakings or individuals in relation to each other; and</p>
<p>- &nbsp;references to information and notification procedures;</p>
<p>Protocol 1 on horizontal adaptations shall apply, unless otherwise provi-<br>ded for in this Annex.</p>
<p>SECTORAL ADAPTATIONS</p>
<p>Integration of company forms not existing at the time of the initialling of the<br>EEA Agreement:</p>
<p>Where reference is made in the directives mentioned below exclusively or<br>primarily to one type of company, this reference may be changed upon the<br>introduetion of specific legislation for private companies. The introduetion<br>of such legislation and the denomination of the companies involved will be<br>notified to the EEA Joint Committee at the latest at the time of implementa-<br>tion of the relevant directives.</p>
<p>TRANSITION PERIODS</p>
<p>The EFTA States shall implement in full the provisions laid down in this An-<br>nex not later than three years, as regards Switzerland and Liechtenstein, and<br>two years as regards Austria, Finland, Iceland, Norway and Sweden, after<br>the entry into force of the EEA Agreement.</p>

<h1>FINAL ACT</h1>
<p>The plenipotentiaries of:</p>
<p>THE EUROPEAN ECONOMIC COMMUNITY,</p>
<p>THE EUROPEAN COAL AND STEEL COMMUNITY,</p>
<p>hereinafter referred to as “the Community”, and of:</p>
<p>THE KINGDOM OF BELGIUM,</p>
<p>THE KINGDOM OF DENMARK,</p>
<p>THE FEDERAL REPUBLIC OF GERMANY,</p>
<p>THE HELLENIC REPUBLIC,</p>
<p>THE KINGDOM OF SPAIN,</p>
<p>THE FRENCH REPUBLIC,</p>
<p>IRELAND,</p>
<p>THE ITALIAN REPUBLIC,</p>
<p>THE GRAND DUCHY OF LUXEMBOURG,</p>
<p>THE KINGDOM OF THE NETHERLANDS,</p>
<p>THE PORTUGUESE REPUBLIC,</p>
<p>THE UNITED KINGDOM OF GREAT BRITAIN AND NORT-<br>HERN IRELAND,</p>
<p>Contracting Parties to the Treaty establishing the EUROPEAN ECONO-<br>MIC COMMUNITY and the Treaty establishing the EUROPEAN COAL<br>AND STEEL COMMUNITY,</p>
<p>hereinafter referred to as “the EC Member States”,</p>
<p>and</p>
<p>the plenipotentiaries of:</p>
<p>THE REPUBLIC OF AUSTRIA,</p>
<p>THE REPUBLIC OF FINLAND,</p>
<p>THE REPUBLIC OF ICELAND,</p>
<p>THE PRINCIPALITY OF LIECHTENSTEIN,</p>
<p>THE KINGDOM OF NORWAY,</p>
<p>THE KINGDOM OF SWEDEN,</p>
<p>THE SWISS CONFEDERATION,</p>
<p>hereinafter referred to as “the EFTA States”,</p>
<p>meeting at Oporto, this second day of May in the year one thousand nine<br>hundred and ninety-two for the signature of the Agreement on the European<br>Economic Area, hereinafter referred to as the EEA Agreement, have adop-<br>ted the following texts:</p>
<p>I. &nbsp;the Agreement on the European Economic Area;</p>
<p>II. &nbsp;the texts listed below which are annexed to the Agreement on the Euro-<br>pean Economic Area:</p>
<p>A. Protocol 1 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;on horizontal adaptations</p>

<p>The plenipotentiaries of the EC Member States and of the Community and<br>the plenipotentiaries of the EFTA States have adopted the joint declarations<br>listed below and annexed to this Final Act:</p>
<p>1. Joint Declaration concerning the preparation of joint reports under<br>paragraph 5 of Protocol 1 on horizontal adaptations;</p>
<p>2. Joint Declaration on mutual recognition and protection agreements for<br>the designations of wine and spirituous beverages;</p>
<p>3. Joint Declaration on a transitional period concerning the issuing or ma-<br>king out of documents relating to the proof of origin;</p>
<p>4. Joint Declaration concerning Articles 10 and 14(1) of Protocol 11 to the<br>Agreement;</p>
<p>5. Joint Declaration on electro-medical equipment;</p>
<p>6. Joint Declaration concerning nationals of the Republic of Iceland who<br>hold a diploma in specialized medicine, specialized dentistry, veterinary<br>medicine, pharmacy, general medical practice or architecture conferred in a<br>third country;</p>
<p>7. Joint Declaration concerning nationals of the Republic of Iceland who<br>hold higher-education diplomas awarded on completion of professional edu-<br>cation and training of at least three years’ duration conferred in a third<br>country;</p>
<p>8. Joint Declaration on transport of goods by road;</p>
<p>9. Joint Declaration concerning rules on competition;</p>
<p>10. Joint Declaration on Article 61(3)(b) of the Agreement;</p>
<p>11. Joint Declaration on Article61(3)(c) of the Agreement;</p>
<p>12. Joint Declaration on aid granted through the EC Structural Funds or ot-<br>her financial instruments;</p>
<p>13. Joint Declaration on paragraph (c) of Protocol 27 to the Agreement;</p>
<p>14. Joint Declaration on shipbuilding;</p>
<p>15. Joint Declaration on applicable procedures in cases where, by virtue of<br>Article 76 and Part VI of the Agreement and corresponding Protocols,<br>EFTA States participate fully in EC committees;</p>
<p>45 Riksdagen 1991/92. 1 saml. Nr 170. Bil. 15</p>
<p>16. Joint Declaration on cooperation in cultural affairs;</p>
<p>17. Joint Declaration on cooperation against illegal traffic in cultural goods;</p>
<p>18. Joint Declaration on the association of Community experts with the work<br>of committees among the EFTA States or set up by the EFTA Surveillance<br>Authority;</p>
<p>19. Joint Declaration on Article 103 of the EEA Agreement;</p>
<p>20. Joint Declaration on Protocol 35 to the Agreement;</p>
<p>21. Joint Declaration concerning the Financial Mechanism;</p>
<p>22. Joint Declaration on the relation between the EEA Agreement and exis-<br>ting agreements;</p>
<p>23. Joint Declaration on the agreed interpretation of Article 4(1) and (2) of<br>Protocol 9 on trade in fish and other marine products;</p>
<p>24. Joint Declaration concerning the application of tariff concessions for cer-<br>tain agricultural products;</p>
<p>25. Joint Declaration on plant health issues;</p>
<p>26. Joint Declaration on mutual assistance between control authorities in the<br>area of spirit drinks;</p>
<p>27. Joint Declaration on Protocol 47 on the abolition of technical barriers to<br>trade in wine;</p>
<p>28. Joint Declaration on modification of tariff concessions and on special<br>treatment of Spain and Portugal;</p>
<p>29. Joint Declaration on animal welfare;</p>
<p>30. Joint Declaration on the Harmonized System.</p>
<p>The plenipotentiaries of the EC Member States and the plenipotentiaries of<br>the EFTA States have adopted the declarations listed below and annexed to<br>this Final Act:</p>
<p>1. Declaration by the Governments of the Member States of the EC and the<br>EFTA States on the facilitation of border Controls;</p>
<p>2. Declaration by the Governments of the Member States of the EC and the<br>EFTA States on political dialogue.</p>
<p>The plenipotentiaries of the EC Member States and of the Community and<br>the plenipotentiaries of the EFTA States have also taken note of the arrange-<br>ment regarding the functioning of a High-Level Interim Group during the<br>period preceding the entry into force of the EEA Agreement which is an-<br>nexed to this Final Act. They have further agreed that the High-Level Inte-<br>rim Group shall, at the latest by the entry into force of the EEAAgreement,<br>decide on the authentication of texts of the EC acts referred to in the An-<br>nexes to the EEA Agreement which have been drawn up in the Finnish, Ice-<br>landic, Norwegian and Swedish languages.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Final act</p>
<p>706</p>
<p>The plenipotentiaries of the EC Member States and of the Community<br>and the plenipotentiaries of the EFTA States have further taken note of the<br>arrangement regarding the publication of EEA relevant information which<br>is annexed to this Final Act.</p>
<p>Further, the plenipotentiaries of the EC Member States and of the Com-<br>munity and the plenipotentiaries of the EFTA States have taken note of the<br>arrangement regarding the publication of EFTA notices on procurement<br>which is annexed to this Final Act.</p>
<p>Furthermore, the plenipotentiaries of the EC Member States and of the<br>Community and the plenipotentiaries of the EFTA States have adopted the<br>Agreed Minutes from the negotiations which are annexed to this Final Act.<br>The Agreed Minutes shall have a binding character.</p>

<p>709</p>
<p>JOINT DECLARATIONS BY</p>
<p>THE CONTRACTING PARTIES</p>
<p>TO THE AGREEMENT ON</p>
<p>THE EUROPEAN ECONOMIC AREA</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Final act</p>
<p>710</p>
<p>JOINT DECLARATION</p>
<p>CONCERNING THE PREPARATION OF JOINT<br>REPORTS UNDER PARAGRAPH 5 OF PROTOCOL 1<br>ON HORIZONTAL ADAPTATIONS</p>
<p>As regards the review and reporting procedures under paragraph 5 of Proto-<br>col 1 on Horizontal Adaptations, it is understood that the EEA Joint Com-<br>mittee may, whenever it considers this useful, request the preparation of a<br>joint report.</p>
<p>JOINT DECLARATION ON MUTUAL<br>RECOGNITION AND PROTECTION AGREEMENTS<br>FOR THE DESIGNATIONS OF WINE AND<br>SPIRITUOUS BEVERAGES</p>
<p>The Contracting Parties agree to negotiate with a view to concluding before<br>1 July 1993 separate mutual recognition and protection agreements for the<br>designations of wine and spiritious beverages, taking into account the exis-<br>ting bilateral agreements.</p>
<p>JOINT DECLARATION</p>
<p>ON A TRANSITIONAL PERIOD CONCERNING THE<br>ISSUING OR MAKING OUT OF DOCUMENTS<br>RELATING TO THE PROOF OF ORIGIN</p>
<p>(a) For two years after the entry into force of the EEA Agreement, the com-<br>petent customs authorities of the Community and those of Austria, Finland,<br>Iceland, Norway, Sweden and Switzerland shall accept as valid proof of ori-<br>gin within the meaning of Protocol 4 to the EEA Agreement the following<br>documents referred to in Article 13 of Protocol No. 3 to the Free Trade Ag-<br>reements between the EEC and the individual EFTA States mentioned<br>above:</p>
<p>(i) &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;EUR.l certificates, including Long-Term certificates, endor-<br>sed beforehand with the stamp of the competent customs Of-<br>fice of the exporting State;</p>
<p>(ii) &nbsp;&nbsp;EUR.l certificates, including Long-Term certificates, endor-<br>sed by an approved exporter with a special stamp which has<br>been approved by the customs authorities of the exporting<br>State; and</p>
<p>(iii) &nbsp;&nbsp;invoices referring to Long-Term certificates.</p>
<p>(b) For six months after the entry into force of the EEA Agreement, the<br>competent customs authorities of the Community and those of Austria, Fin-<br>land, Iceland, Norway, Sweden and Switzerland shall accept as valid proof of<br>origin within the meaning of Protocol 4 to the EEA Agreement the following<br>documents referred to in Article 8 of Protocol No.3 to the Free Trade Agree-<br>ments between the EEC and the individual EFTA States mentioned above:</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Final act</p>
<p>711</p>
<p>(i) &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;invoices bearing the exporter’s declaration as given in Annex</p>
<p>V to Protocol No.3 made out in accordance with Article 13 of<br>that Protocol; and</p>
<p>(ii) &nbsp;&nbsp;invoices bearing the exporter’s declaration as given in Annex</p>
<p>V to Protocol No.3, made out by any exporter.</p>
<p>(c) Requests for subsequent verification of documents referred to in para-<br>graphs (a) and (b) shall be accepted by the competent customs authorities of<br>the Community and those of Austria, Finland, Iceland, Norway, Sweden<br>and Switzerland for a period of two years after issuing and making out of the<br>proof of origin concerned. These verifications shall be carried out in accor-<br>dance with Title VI of Protocol 4 to the EEA Agreement.</p>
<p>JOINT DECLARATION CONCERNING ARTICLES 10<br>AND 14 (1) OF PROTOCOL 11 TO THE AGREEMENT</p>
<p>The Contracting Parties stress the importance they attach to the protection<br>of nominative data. They undertake to consider this matter further with a<br>view to ensuring appropriate protection of such data under Protocol 11, at<br>least at a level comparable to the one provided for by the Council of Europé<br>Convention of 28 January 1981.</p>
<p>JOINT DECLARATION</p>
<p>ON ELECTRO-MEDICAL EQUIPMENT</p>
<p>The Contracting Parties take note that the Commission has presented to the<br>Council a proposal for a Council directive on electro-medical equipment fal-<br>ling so far within the scope of Directive 84/539/EEC (OJ No L 300,<br>19.11.1984, p. 179) (AnnexII).</p>
<p>The Commission proposal strengthens the protection of patients, users<br>and third persons by referring to harmonized standards which are to be adop-<br>ted by CEN-CENELEC in accordance with the legal requirements and by<br>subjecting these products to appropriate conformity assessment procedures<br>including a third party intervention for certain devices.</p>
<p>JOINT DECLARATION</p>
<p>CONCERNING NATIONALS OF THE REPUBLIC OF<br>ICELAND WHO HOLD A DIPLOMA IN SPECIALIZED<br>MEDICINE, SPECIALIZED DENTISTRY,<br>VETERINARY MEDICINE, PHARMACY, GENERAL<br>MEDICAL PRACTICE OR ARCHITECTURE<br>CONFERRED IN A THIRD COUNTRY</p>
<p>Noting that Council Directives 75/362/EEC, 78/686/EEC, 78/1026/EEC,<br>85/384/EEC, 85/433/EEC and 86/457/EEC, as adapted for EEA purposes,<br>refer only to diplomas, certificates and other evidence of formal qualifica-<br>tions conferred in the Contracting Parties;</p>
<p>anxious, however, to take account of the special position of nationals of</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Final act</p>
<p>712</p>
<p>the Republic of Iceland who, since there is no complete university training<br>in specialized medicine, specialized dentistry, veterinary medicine and archi-<br>tecture in Iceland itself, since there are limited possibilities of training in spe-<br>cialized dentistry and of specific training in general medical practice and ot-<br>her specialization in medicine, and since there is only recently a complete<br>university training in pharmacy offered in Iceland, have studied in a third<br>country;</p>
<p>the Contracting Parties hereby recommend that the Governments concer-<br>ned should allow nationals of the Republic of Iceland who hold a diploma in<br>specialized dentistry, in veterinary medicine, in architecture, in pharmacy,<br>on completion of specific training in general medical practice or of specializa-<br>tions in medicine, awarded in a third country and recognized by the compe-<br>tent Icelandic authorities, to take up and pursue activities as specialists in<br>dentistry, veterinary surgeons, architects, pharmacists, general medical<br>practitioners or specialists in medicine within the European Economic Area,<br>by recognizing these diplomas in their territories.</p>
<p>JOINT DECLARATION<br>CONCERNING NATIONALS OF THE REPUBLIC OF<br>ICELAND WHO HOLD HIGHER-EDUCATION<br>DIPLOMAS AWARDED ON COMPLETION OF<br>PROFESSIONAL EDUCATION AND TRAINING OF AT<br>LEAST THREE YEARS’ DURATION CONFERRED<br>IN A THIRD COUNTRY</p>
<p>Noting that Council Directive 89/48/EEC of 21 December 1988 on a general<br>system for the recognition of higher-education diplomas awarded on comple-<br>tion of professional education and training of at least three years’ duration<br>(OJ No L 19, 24.1.1989, p. 16), as adapted for EEA purposes, refers to dip-<br>lomas, certificates and other evidence of formal qualifications conferred<br>mainly in the Contracting Parties;</p>
<p>anxious, however, to take account of the special position of nationals of<br>the Republic of Iceland who, since there are limited possibilities of post-se-<br>condary education and a long tradition of students receiving this education<br>abroad, have studied in a third country;</p>
<p>the Contracting Parties hereby recommend that the Governments concer-<br>ned should allow nationals of the Republic of Iceland who hold a diploma of<br>studies covered by the general system, awarded in a third country and recog-<br>nized by the competent Icelandic authorities, to take up and pursue within<br>the European Economic Area the activities of the professions concerned, by<br>recognizing these diplomas in their territories.</p>
<p>JOINT DECLARATION</p>
<p>ON TRANSPORT OF GOODS BY ROAD</p>
<p>If the European Community elaborates new legislation to amend, replace or<br>prolong the application of rules on access to the market in transport of goods</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Final act</p>
<p>713</p>
<p>by road (First Council Directive of 23 July 1962 on the establishment of cer-<br>tain common rules for international transport, OJ No 070, 6.8.62, p.2005;<br>Council Directive 65/269/EEC, OJ No 88, 24.5.1965, p. 1469; Council Regu-<br>lation (EEC) 3164/76, OJ No L 357, 29.12.1976, p.l; Council Decision<br>80/48/EEC, OJ No L 18, 24.1.1980, p.21; Council Regulation (EEC)<br>4059/89, OJ No L390, 30.12.1989, p. 3) the Contracting Parties shall, in ac-<br>cordance with the jointly agreed procedures, take a decision concerning an<br>amendment of the relevant Annex, allowing carriers of the Contracting Par-<br>ties reciprocal and mutual access to the market in transport of goods by road<br>on equal terms.</p>
<p>For the duration of the Agreement between the European Communities<br>and Austria on transport of goods by road and rail, future amendments of<br>the present Agreement, shall not affect the existing mutual rights for market<br>access referred to in Article 16 of the Agreement between the European<br>Communities and Austria on transport of goods by road and rail, and as set<br>out in the bilateral Agreements between Austria on the one hand and Fin-<br>land, Norway, Sweden and Switzerland on the other hand, unless otherwise<br>agreed by the Parties concerned.</p>
<h2>JOINT DECLARATION</h2>
<h2>CONCERNING RULES ON COMPETITION</h2>
<p>The Contracting Parties declare that the implementation of the EEA compe-<br>tition rules, in cases falling within the responsibility of the EC Commission,<br>is based on the existing Community competences, supplemented by the pro-<br>visions contained in the Agreement. In cases falling within the responsibility<br>of the EFTA Surveillance Authority, the implementation of the EEA com-<br>petition rules is based on the agreement establishing that authority as well as<br>on the provisions contained in the EEA Agreement.</p>
<h2>JOINT DECLARATION</h2>
<h2>ON ARTICLE 61 (3)(b) 0F THE AGREEMENT</h2>
<p>The Contracting Parties declare that in establishing whether a derogation<br>can be granted under Article 61 (3) (b) the EC Commission shall take the<br>interest of the EFTA States into account and the EFTA Surveillance Autho-<br>rity shall take the interest of the Community into account.</p>
<h2>JOINT DECLARATION</h2>
<h2>ON ARTICLE 61 (3)(c) OF THE AGREEMENT</h2>
<p>The Contracting Parties take note that even if eligibility of the regions has to<br>be denied in the context of Article 61 (3)(a) and according to the criteria of<br>the first stage of analysis under subparagraph (c) (see Commission Commu-<br>nication on the method for the application of Article 92 (3)(a) and (c) to<br>regional aid, OJ No C 212, 12.8.1988, p.2) examination according to other<br>criteria, e.g. very low population density, is possible.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Final act</p>
<p>714</p>
<p>JOINT DECLARATION</p>
<p>ON AID GRANTED THROUGH THE EC<br>STRUCTURAL FUNDS OR OTHER FINANCIAL<br>INSTRUMENTS</p>
<p>The Contracting Parties declare that financial support to undertakings finan-<br>ced by the EC Structural Funds or receiving assistance from the European<br>Investment Bank or from any other similar financial instrument or fund shall<br>be in keeping with the provisions of this Agreement on State aid. They dec-<br>lare that exchange of information and views on these forms of aid shall take<br>place at the request of either surveillance authority.</p>
<p>JOINT DECLARATION</p>
<p>ON PARAGRAPH (c) OF PROTOCOL 27 TO THE<br>AGREEMENT</p>
<p>The notice referred to in paragraph (c) of Protocol 27 shall contain a descrip-<br>tion of the State aid programme or case concerned, including all elements<br>which are necessary for a proper evaluation of the programme or case (de-<br>pending on the State aid elements concerned, such as type of State aid, bud-<br>get, beneficiary, duration). Moreover, the reasons for the opening of the<br>procedure referred to in Article 93 (2) of the Treaty establishing the Euro-<br>pean Economic Community or of the corresponding procedure set out in an<br>agreement between the EFTA States establishing the EFTA Surveillance<br>Authority shall be communicated to the other surveillance authority. Ex-<br>change of information between the two surveillance authorities shall take<br>place on a reciprocal basis.</p>
<p>JOINT DECLARATION ON SHIPBUILDING</p>
<p>The Contracting Parties agree that, until the expiry of the 7th Shipbuilding<br>Directive (i.e. at the end of 1993), they will refrain from the application of<br>the general rules on State aid laid down in Article 61 of the Agreement to<br>the sector of shipbuilding.</p>
<p>Article 62(2) of the Agreement as well as the Protocols referring to State<br>aid are applicable to the sector of shipbuilding.</p>
<p>JOINT DECLARATION</p>
<p>ON APPLICABLE PROCEDURES IN CASES WHERE,<br>BY VIRTUE OF ARTICLE 76 AND PART VI OF THE<br>AGREEMENT AND CORRESPONDING<br>PROTOCOLS, EFTA STATES PARTICIPATE FULLY IN<br>EC COMMITTEES</p>
<p>The EFTA States shall have the same rights and obligations as EC Member<br>States within EC committees in which they participate fully, by virtue of Ar-<br>ticle 76 and Part VI of the Agreement and the corresponding Protocols, ex-<br>cept in respect of voting procedures, if any. In reaching its decision, the EC</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Final act</p>
<p>715</p>
<p>Commission shall take due account of the views expressed by the EFTA Sta-<br>tes in the same manner as of the views expressed by the EC Member States<br>before voting.</p>
<p>In cases where the EC Member States have the possibility of appealing to<br>the EC Council against the decision of the EC Commission, the EFTA States<br>may raise the issue in the EEA Joint Committee in conformity with Article<br>5 of the Agreement.</p>
<p>JOINT DECLARATION</p>
<p>ON COOPERATION IN CULTURAL AFFAIRS</p>
<p>The Contracting Parties, having regard to their cooperation within the Coun-<br>cil of Europé, recalling the Declaration of 9 April 1984 from the Ministerial<br>meeting in Luxembourg between the European Community and its Member<br>States and the States of the European Free Trade Association, mindful that<br>the establishment of the free movement of goods, services, Capital and per-<br>sons within the EEA will have a significant impact in the field of culture,<br>declare their intention to strengthen and broaden cooperation in the area of<br>cultural affairs, in order to contribute to a better understanding between the<br>peoples of a multi-cultural Europé and to safeguard and further develop the<br>national and regional heritage that enriches the European culture by its di-<br>versity.</p>
<p>JOINT DECLARATION</p>
<p>ON COOPERATION AGAINST ILLEGAL TRAFFIC</p>
<p>IN CULTURAL GOODS</p>
<p>The Contracting Parties declare their willingness to establish cooperation ar-<br>rangements and procedures against illegal traffic in cultural goods as well as<br>arrangements concerning the management of the regime for regular traffic<br>in cultural goods.</p>
<p>Without prejudice to the provisions of the EEA Agreement and other in-<br>ternational obligations, these arrangements and procedures shall take into<br>account the legislation which the Community is developing in this field.</p>
<p>JOINT DECLARATION</p>
<p>ON THE ASSOCIATION OF COMMUNITY EXPERTS<br>WITH THE WORK OF COMMITTEES AMONG THE<br>EFTA STATES OR SET UP BY THE EFTA<br>SURVEILLANCE AUTHORITY</p>
<p>Having regard to the association of experts of the EFTA States with the work<br>of the EC committees listed in Protocol 37 to the Agreement, Community<br>experts shall on the same basis be associated, at Commmunity request, with<br>the work of any corresponding bodies among the EFTA States or set up by<br>the EFTA Surveillance Authority relating to the same subject matter as co-<br>vered by the EC committees listed in Protocol 37.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Final act</p>
<p>716</p>
<h2>JOINT DECLARATION</h2>
<h2>ON ARTICLE 103 OF THE EEA AGREEMENT</h2>
<p>It is the understanding of the Contracting Parties that the reference to the<br>fulfilment of constitutional requirements contained in Article 103 (1) of the<br>EEA Agreement and the reference to provisional application contained in<br>Article 103 (2) have no practical implications for internal Community proce-<br>dures.</p>
<h2>JOINT DECLARATION</h2>
<h2>ON PROTOCOL 35 TO THE AGREEMENT</h2>
<p>It is the understanding of the Contracting Parties that Protocol 35 does not<br>restrict the effects of those existing internal rules which provide for direct<br>effect and primacy of international agreements.</p>
<h2>JOINT DECLARATION</h2>
<h2>CONCERNING THE FINANCIAL MECHANISM</h2>
<p>In the event that an EFTA Contracting Party should withdraw from EFTA<br>and accede to the Community, appropriate arrangements should be made to<br>ensure that no additional financial obligations are, as a result, incurred by<br>the remaining EFTA States. The Contracting Parties note in this regard the<br>decision by the EFTA States to calculate their respective contributions to the<br>Financial Mechanism based on the GNP at market price data for the three<br>most recent years. As regards any acceding EFTA State, appropriate and<br>equitable Solutions should be found in the context of the accession negotia-<br>tions.</p>
<h2>JOINT DECLARATION</h2>
<h2>ON THE RELATION BETWEEN THE EEA<br>AGREEMENT AND EXISTING AGREEMENTS</h2>
<p>The EEA Agreement shall not affect rights assured through existing agree-<br>ments binding one or more EC Member States, on the one hand, and one or<br>more EFTA States, on the other, or two or more EFTA States, such as<br>among others agreements concerning individuals, economic operators, re-<br>gional cooperation and administrative arrangements, until at least equiva-<br>lent rights have been achieved under the Agreement.</p>
<h2>JOINT DECLARATION</h2>
<h2>ON THE AGREED INTERPRETATION OF ARTICLE<br>4 (1) AND (2) OF PROTOCOL 9 ON TRADE IN FISH<br>AND OTHER MARINE PRODUCTS</h2>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Final act</p>
<p>1. While the EFTA States will not take over the “acquis communautaire”<br>concerning the fishery policy it is understood that, where reference is made<br>to aid granted through State resources, any distortion of competition is to be</p>
<p>717</p>
<p>assessed by the Contracting Parties in the context of Articles 92 and 93 of the<br>EEC Treaty and in relation to relevant provisions of the “acquis communau-<br>taire” concerning the fishery policy and the content of the Joint Declaration<br>regarding Article 61(3)(c) of the Agreement.</p>
<p>2. While the EFTA States will not take over the “acquis communautaire”<br>concerning the fishery policy it is understood that, where reference is made<br>to legislation relating to the organization of the market, any distortion of<br>competition caused by such legislation is to be assessed in relation to the<br>principles of the “acquis communautaire” concerning the common organiza-<br>tion of the market.</p>
<p>Whenever an EFTA State maintains or introduces national provisions on<br>market organization in the fisheries sector, such provisions shall be conside-<br>red a priori to be compatible with the principles, referred to in the preceding<br>subparagraph, if they contain at least the following elements:</p>
<p>(a) the legislation on producers’ organizations reflects the principles of the<br>“acquis communautaire” regarding:</p>
<p>establishment on the producers’ initiative;</p>
<p>- freedom to become and cease to be a member;</p>
<p>absence of a dominant position, unless necessary in pur-<br>suance of objectives corresponding to those specified in Ar-<br>ticle 39 of the EEC Treaty;</p>
<p>(b) whenever the rules of producers’ organizations are extended to non-<br>members of producers’ organizations, the provisions to be applied corre-<br>spond to those laid down in Article 7 of Regulation (EEC) No. 3687/91;</p>
<p>(c) whenever provisions in respect of interventions to support prices exist or<br>are established, they correspond to those specified in Title III of Regulation<br>(EEC) No. 3687/91.</p>
<h2>JOINT DECLARATION</h2>
<h2>CONCERNING THE APPLICATION OF TARIFF<br>CONCESSIONS FOR CERTAIN AGRICULTURAL<br>PRODUCTS</h2>
<p>The Contracting Parties declare that in case of tariff concessions granted for<br>the same product, both under Protocol 3 to the Agreement and under a bila-<br>teral agreement on trade in agricultural products as referred to in Protocol 42<br>to the above-mentioned Agreement, the most advantageous tariff treatment<br>shall be granted upon submission of the relevant documentation.</p>
<p>This is without prejudice to the obligations resulting from Article 16 of the<br>Agreement.</p>
<h2>JOINT DECLARATION</h2>
<h2>ON PLANT HEALTH ISSUES</h2>
<p>The Contracting Parties State that the existing Community acts in this area<br>are under review. Therefore, this legislation will not be taken over by the<br></p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Final act</p>
<p>718</p>
<p>EFTA States. New rules will be dealt with according to Articles 99 and 102<br>of the Agreement.</p>
<h2>JOINT DECLARATION</h2>
<h2>ON MUTUAL ASSISTANCE BETWEEN CONTROL<br>AUTHORITIES IN THE AREA OF SPIRIT DRINKS</h2>
<p>The Contracting Parties agree that any future EC legislation on mutual assis-<br>tance in the area of spirit drinks between the competent authorities of EC<br>Member States, relevant for this Agreement, shall be dealt with according<br>to the general provisions on decision making of the Agreement.</p>
<h2>JOINT DECLARATION</h2>
<h2>ON PROTOCOL 47 ON THE ABOLITION OF<br>TECHNICAL BARRIERS TO TRADE IN WINE</h2>
<p>The adaptation concerning the use of the terms 'Federweiss’ and 'Federweis-<br>ser’ as provided for in the Appendix to Protocol 47, shall be without preju-<br>dice to any future modifications of the relevant Community legislation where<br>provisions may be introduced regulating the use of the same terms and their<br>equivalents for wine produced in the Community.</p>
<p>The classification of EFTA States’ wine producing regions in wine-gro-<br>wing zone B for the purposes of this Agreement, shall not prejudge any fu-<br>ture modifications of the Community’s classification scheme which may have<br>a subsequent impact on the classification within the framework of the Agree-<br>ment. Any such modifications shall be dealt with in accordance with the ge-<br>neral provisions of the Agreement.</p>
<h2>JOINT DECLARATION</h2>
<h2>ON MODIFICATION OF TARIFF CONCESSIONS<br>AND ON SPECIAL TREATMENT OF SPAIN AND<br>PORTUGAL</h2>
<p>A full implementation of the system outlined in Protocol 3 depends in some<br>Contracting Parties on amendments to the national price compensation sy-<br>stem. These amendments are not possible without the modification of tariff<br>concessions. Such modifications would not imply the need for compensation<br>between the Contracting Parties of the EEA Agreement.</p>
<p>The system outlined in Protocol 3 does not preclude the application of the<br>relevant transitional provisions of the Act of Accession of Spain and Portugal<br>and shall not result in the Community, in its composition as of 31 December<br>1985, granting Contracting Parties to the EEA Agreement a more favou-<br>rable treatment than the one applied to the new EC Member States. In parti-<br>cular, the application of this system does not preclude the application of the<br>accession price compensatory amounts established in application of the Act<br>of Accession of Spain and Portugal.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Final act</p>
<p>719</p>
<h2>JOINT DECLARATION ON ANIMAL WELFARE</h2>
<p>Notwithstanding the provisions of point 2, Chapter I (veterinary issues) of<br>Annex I to the Agreement, the Contracting Parties note the new develop-<br>ment of the Community legislation in this area and agree to consult each ot-<br>her in case differences in their legislations concerning animal welfare consti-<br>tute barriers to the free movement of goods. The Contracting Parties agree<br>to monitor the situation in this area.</p>
<p>Commission of the European Communities</p>
<p>Brussels,</p>
<p>Directorate-General</p>
<p>External Relations</p>
<p>The director general</p>
<p>H.E. Mr H. Hafstein</p>
<p>Ambassadör</p>
<p>Permanent Representative</p>
<p>of Iceland to the European Communities</p>
<p>Rue Archiméde 5</p>
<p>1040-Brussels</p>
<h2>JOINT DECLARATION</h2>
<h2>ON THE HARMONIZED SYSTEM</h2>
<p>The Contracting Parties agree to harmonize as soon as possible, and by 31<br>December 1992 at the latest, the German text of the description of goods in<br>the Harmonized System, contained in the relevant protocols and annexes to<br>the EEA Agreement.</p>
<h2>DECLARATION</h2>
<h2>BY THE GOVERNMENTS OF THE MEMBER STATES<br>OF THE EC AND THE EFTA STATES ON THE<br>FACILITATION OF BORDER CONTROLS</h2>
<p>In order to promote the free movements of persons the Member States of<br>the EC and the EFTA States shall, subject to the practical modalities to be<br>defined in appropriate fora, cooperate with a view to the facilitation of Cont-<br>rols for each others’ citizens and the members of their families at borders<br>between their territories.</p>
<h2>DECLARATION ON POLITICAL DIALOGUE</h2>
<p>The European Community and its Member States and the Member States of<br>the European Free Trade Association expressed their wish to strengthen<br>their political dialogue on foreign policy with the view to developing closer<br>relations in spheres of mutual interest.</p>
<p>They agreed to that end:</p>
<p>- to hold informal exchanges of view at ministerial level at meetings of the<br></p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Final act</p>
<p>720</p>
<p>EEA Council. As appropriate these exchanges of view could be prepared<br>by meetings at political directors’ level;</p>
<p>- &nbsp;to make full use of existing diplomatic channels, in particular the diplo-<br>matic representations in the Capital of the country holding the EC Presi-<br>dency, in Brussels and in the capitais of the EFTA Countries;</p>
<p>- &nbsp;to consult informally at conferences and in international organizations;</p>
<p>- &nbsp;that this will in no way affect or replace existing bilateral contacts in this<br>field.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Final act</p>
<p>721</p>
<p>46 Riksdagen 1991/92. 1 saml. Nr 170. Bil. 15</p>
<p>INTERIM ARRANGEMENT</p>
<p>TO PREPARE FOR THE ORDERLY ENTRY</p>
<p>INTO FORCE OF THE AGREEMENT</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Final act</p>
<p>722</p>
<h2>COMMISSIONOF THE EUROPEAN COMMUNITIES</h2>
<p>Brussels</p>
<p>Directorate-generale external relations</p>
<p>The director general</p>
<p>Mr H. Hafstein, Ambassadör,<br>Head of the EFTA Delegation,<br>EFTA Secretariat,<br>Rue Arlon 118,<br>1040-Brussels.</p>
<p>Dear Mr Hafstein,</p>
<p>I refer to our discussions concerning the EEA interim phase and understand<br>that we agree to set up an interim arrangement to prepare for the orderly<br>entry into force of the Agreement.</p>
<p>Under this arrangement, the structures and procedures established during<br>the EEANegotiations will be maintained. A High Level Interim Group as-<br>sisted by Expert Interim Groups, analogous to the previous High Level Ne-<br>gotiating Group and the Negotiating Groups, composed by representatives<br>of the Community and of the EFTA States, will i.a. examine in the EEA<br>context Community acquis issued between 1 August 1991 and the entry into<br>force of the Agreement. Consensus will be recorded and finalized either in<br>Additional Protocols to be attached to the EEA Agreement, or in appro-<br>priate decisions by the EEA Joint Committee after the entry into force of the<br>Agreement. Any substantial negotiating problems arising under the interim<br>arrangement will be dealt with by the EEA Joint Committee after the entry<br>into force of the Agreement.</p>
<p>It being understood that the information and consultation procedures of<br>the EEA Agreement can only be applied after the latter’s entry into force,<br>the Community will inform the EFTA States during the interim phase on<br>proposals for new Community acquis after they have been submitted to the<br>EC Council of Ministers.</p>
<p>I would be grateful for confirmation of your agreement on this interim ar-<br>rangement.</p>
<p>Yours sincerely,</p>
<p>Horst G. Krenzler</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Final act</p>
<p>723</p>
<h2>ICELANDIC MISSION</h2>
<h2>TO THE EUROPEAN COMMUNITIES</h2>
<p>Rue Archiméde 5</p>
<p>1040 Bruxelles</p>
<p>Brussels,</p>
<p>Dear Mr Krenzler,</p>
<p>I hereby acknowledge receipt today of your letter which reads as follows:</p>
<p>”1 refer to our discussions concerning the EEA interim phase and under-<br>stand that we agree to set up an interim arrangement to prepare for the or-<br>derly entry into force of the Agreement.</p>
<p>Under this arrangement, the structures and procedures established during<br>the EEA Negotiations will be maintained. A High Level Interim Group, as-<br>sisted by Expert Interim Groups, analogous to the previous High Level Ne-<br>gotiating Group and the Negotiating Groups, composed by representatives<br>of the Community and of the EFTA States, will i.a. examine in the EEA con-<br>text Community acquis issued between 1 August 1991 and the entry into<br>force of the Agreement. Consensus will be recorded and finalized either in<br>Additional Protocols to be attached to the draft EEA Agreement, or in ap-<br>propriate decisions by the EEA Joint Committee after the entry into force<br>of the Agreement. Any substantial negotiating problems arising under the<br>interim arrangement will be dealt with by the EEA Joint Committee after<br>the entry into force of the Agreement.</p>
<p>It being understood that the information and consultation procedures of<br>the EEAAgreement can only be applied after the latter’s entry into force,<br>the Community will inform the EFTA States during the interim phase on<br>proposals for new Community acquis after they have been submitted to the<br>EC Council of Ministers.</p>
<p>I would be grateful for confirmation of your agreement on this interim ar-<br>rangement.”</p>
<p>I have the honour to confirm my agreement on this interim arrangement.</p>
<p>Yours sincerely,</p>
<p>Hannes Hafstein, Ambassadör,<br>Head of the Icelandic Mission<br>to the European Communities<br>Mr Horst Krenzler<br>Director-General</p>

<p>ARRANGEMENT REGARDING</p>
<p>PUBLICATION OF EEA RELEVANT</p>
<p>INFORMATION</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Final act</p>
<p>725</p>
<h2>ICELANDIC MISSION TO THE EUROPEAN<br>COMMUNITIES</h2>
<p>Rue Archiméde 5</p>
<p>1040 Bruxelles</p>
<p>Brussels,</p>
<p>Subject: Publication of EEA relevant information</p>
<p>Sir,</p>
<p>With regard to publication of EEA relevant information to be published af-<br>ter the entry into force of the EEA Agreement, I have the honour to summa-<br>rize the agreement we have reached as follows.</p>
<p>There will be a co-ordinated system consisting of the Official Journal of<br>the EC and a special EEA supplement thereto. Where information to be<br>published both for the EC and the EFTA States is identical, publication by<br>the EC in the Official Journal of the EC will serve at the same time as publi-<br>cation in the three common EC/EFTA languages, while the information in<br>the remaining four EFTA languages (Finnish, Icelandic, Norwegian and<br>Swedish) will be published in the EEA supplement to the Official Journal of<br>the EC. The EFTA States undertake to provide an appropriate infrastruc-<br>ture in order to ensure the timely availability of the necessary translations<br>into the four non-EC EFTA languages. The EFTA States will be responsible<br>for producing the material for the production of the EEA supplement.</p>
<p>The publication system would contain the following elements:</p>
<p>(a) Decisions of the EEA Joint Committee relating to the acquis and other<br>decisions, acts, notices, etc., by the EEHA organs</p>
<p>The decisions of the EEA Joint Committee relating to the acquis shall be<br>published in the nine official languages in a special EEA section of the Offi-<br>cial Journal of the EC. That publication will serve as publication in relation<br>to the three common languages. These decisions will also be published in the<br>EEA supplement in the official languages of the Nordic EFTA States and,<br>under the responsibility of the EFTA States, possibly, for information, in the<br>EFTA working language.</p>
<p>The same applies to other decisions, acts, notices, etc., by the EEA or-<br>gans, in particular the EEA Council and the EEA Joint Committee.</p>
<p>As concerns decisions by the EEA Joint Committee relating to the acquis,<br>the table of contents of the EEA section will contain references to where the<br>relevant internal EC texts can be found.</p>
<p>(b) EFTA data with EC relevance</p>
<p>Information emanating from the EFTA States, the EFTA Surveillance Aut-<br>hority, the Standing Committee of the EFTA States and the EFTA Court<br>regarding, for example, competition, State aid, public procurement and tech-<br>nical standards will be published in the nine official languages of the EC<br>in a special EEA section of the Official Journal of the EC. That publication</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Final act</p>
<p>726</p>
<p>will also serve as publication for the EFTA States for the three common lang-<br>uages whereas the other four EFTA languages will be produced in the EEA<br>supplement. Where relevant, the table of contents of the EEA section and<br>the EEA supplement, respectively, will contain references to where the cor-<br>responding information emanating from the EC and its Member States can<br>be found.</p>
<p>(c) EC data with EFTA relevance</p>
<p>Information emanating from the EC and its Member States regarding, for<br>example, competition, State aid, public procurement and technical standards<br>will be published in the nine official languages of the EC in the Official Jour-<br>nal of the EC. That publication will also serve as publication for the EFTA<br>States for the three common languages whereas the other four EFTA langua-<br>ges will be produced in the EEAsupplement. Where relevant, reference will<br>be made to where the corresponding information emanating from the EFTA<br>States, the EFTA Surveillance Authority, the Standing Committee of the<br>EFTA States and the EFTA Court can be found.</p>
<p>The financial aspects of the publication system will be the subject of a se-<br>parate arrangement.</p>
<p>I should be obliged if you would confirm that you are in agreement with<br>the above.</p>
<p>Please accept, Sir, the assurances of my highest consideration.</p>
<p>Hannes Hafstein, Ambassadör</p>
<p>Head of the Icelandic Mission to the European Communities</p>
<p>Mr Horst Krenzler</p>
<p>Director-General</p>
<p>Commission of the European Communities</p>
<p>Directorate-General I</p>
<p>Avenue Auderghem 35</p>
<p>Brussels</p>
<h2>COMMISSION OF THE EUROPEAN COMMUNITIES</h2>
<p>Directorate-General</p>
<p>External Relations</p>
<p>The Director-General</p>
<p>Mr H. Hafstein, Ambassadör</p>
<p>Head of the EFTA Delegation</p>
<p>EFTA Secretariat</p>
<p>rue Arlon 1181040 Brussels</p>
<p>Sir,</p>
<p>I hereby acknowledge receipt today of your letter which reads as follows:</p>
<p>”With regard to publication of EEA relevant information to be published<br>after the entry into force of the EEA Agreement, I have the honour to sum-<br>marize the agreement we have reached as follows.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Final act</p>
<p>727</p>
<p>There will be a co-ordinated system consisting of the Official Journal of<br>the EC and a special EEA supplement thereto. Where information to be<br>published both for the EC and the EFTA States is identical, publication by<br>the EC in the Official Journal of the EC will serve at the same time as publi-<br>cation in the three common EC/EFTAlanguages, while the information in<br>the remaining four EFTA languages (Finnish, Icelandic, Norwegian and<br>Swedish) will be published in the EEA supplement to the Official Journal of<br>the EC. The EFTA States undertake to provide an appropriate infrastruc-<br>ture in order to ensure the timely availability of the necessary translations<br>into the four non-EC EFTA languages. The EFTA States will be responsible<br>for producing the material for the production of the EEA supplement.</p>
<p>The publication system would contain the following elements:</p>
<p>(a) Decisions of the EEA Joint Committee relating to the acquis and other<br>decisions, acts, notices, etc., by the EEA organs</p>
<p>The decisions of the EEA Joint Committee relating to the acquis shall be<br>published in the nine official languages in a special EEA section of the Offi-<br>cial Journal of the EC. That publication will serve as publication in relation<br>to the three common languages. These decisions will also be published in the<br>EEAsupplement in the official languages of the Nordic EFTA States and,<br>under the responsibility of the EFTA States, possibly, for information, in the<br>EFTAworking language.</p>
<p>The same applies to other decisions, acts, notices, etc., by the EEA or-<br>gans, in particular the EEA Council and the EEA Joint Committee.</p>
<p>As concerns decisions by the EEA Joint Committee relating to the acquis,<br>the table of contents of the EEA section will contain references to where the<br>relevant internal EC texts can be found.</p>
<p>(b) EFTA data with EC relevance</p>
<p>Information emanating from the EFTA States, the EFTA Surveillance Aut-<br>hority, the Standing Committee of the EFTA States and the EFTA Court<br>regarding, for example, competition, State aid, public procurement and tech-<br>nical standards will be published in the nine official languages of the EC in a<br>special EEA section of the Official Journal of the EC. That publication will<br>also serve as publication for the EFTA States for the three common langua-<br>ges whereas the other four EFTA languages will be produced in the EEA<br>supplement. Where relevant, the table of contents of the EEA section and<br>the EEA supplement, respectively, will contain references to where the cor-<br>responding information emanating from the EC and its Member States can<br>be found.</p>
<p>(c) EC data with EFTA relevance</p>
<p>Information emanating from the EC and its Member States regarding, for<br>example, competition, State aid, public procurement and technical standards<br>will be published in the nine official languages of the EC in the Official Jour-<br></p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>Final act</p>
<p>728</p>
<p>nal of the EC. That publication will also serve as publication for the EFTA<br>States for the three common languages whereas the other four EFTA langua-<br>ges will be produced in the EEA supplement.
