Without prejudice to the provisions of Articles 19 and 21, the EFTA Sur-<br>veillance Authority and the competent authorities of the EFTA States, their<br>officials and other servants shall not disclose information acquired by them<br>as a result of the application of this Protocol or Article 58 of the EEA Agree-<br>ment and Protocol 23 thereto and of the kind covered by the obligation of<br>professional secrecy. This obligation shall also apply to the representatives<br>of the EC Commission and of the EC Member States who participate in the<br>Advisory Committee pursuant to Article 10(4) and in the hearing pursuant<br>to Article 8(2) of Chapter IV.</p>
<p>3. The provisions of paragraphs 1 and 2 shall not prevent publication of gen-<br>eral information or surveys which do not contain information relating to par-<br>ticular undertakings or associations of undertakings.</p>
<p>Article 21</p>
<p>Publication of decisions</p>
<p>1. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall publish the decisions which it<br>takes pursuant to Articles 2, 3, 6 and 8 of this Chapter and to Article 3 of<br>Chapter XVI.</p>
<p>2. The publication shall State the names of the parties and the main content<br>of the decision; it shall have regard to the legitimate interest of undertakings<br>in the protection of their business secrets.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>202</p>
<p>Article 22</p>
<p>Special provisions</p>
<p>The EFTA Surveillance Authority may submit to the attention of the EFTA<br>States, for consultation within the Standing Committee in accordance with<br>Article 2 of the Agreement on a Standing Committee of the EFTA States,<br>proposals for exempting, in accordance with Article 53(3) of the EEA<br>Agreement, certain categories of agreement, decision and concerted prac-<br>tice from the prohibition set out in Article 53(1) of that Agreement.</p>
<h2>CHAPTER III FORM, CONTENT AND OTHER<br>DETAILS CONCERNING APPLICATIONS AND<br>NOTIFICATIONS</h2>
<p>Article 1</p>
<p>Persons entitled to submit applications and notifications</p>
<p>1. Any undertaking which is party to agreements, decisions or practices of<br>the kind described in Articles 53 and 54 of the EEA Agreement may submit<br>an application under Article 2 of Chapter II or a notification under Article 4<br>of Chapter II and Article 1 of Chapter XVI. Where the application or noti-<br>fication is submitted by some, but not all, of the undertakings concerned,<br>they shall give notice to the others.</p>
<p>2. Where applications and notifications under Articles 2, 3(1), 3(2)(b) and<br>4 of Chapter II and Article 1 of Chapter XVI are signed by representatives<br>of undertakings, or associations of undertakings, or natural or legal persons<br>such representatives shall produce written proof that they are authorized to<br>act.</p>
<p>3. Where a joint application or notification is submitted a joint<br>representative should be appointed.</p>
<p>Article 2</p>
<p>Submission of applications and notifications</p>
<p>1. Nine copies of each application and notification shall be submitted to the<br>EFTA Surveillance Authority.</p>
<p>2. The supporting documents shall be either original or copies; copies must<br>be certified as true copies of the original.</p>
<p>3. Applications and notifications shall be in an official language of an EFTA<br>State or the European Community. Supporting documents shall be sub-<br>mitted in their original language. Where the original language is not an offi-<br>cial language of an EFTA State or the European Community, a translation<br>in one of these languages shall be attached.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>203</p>
<p>Article 3</p>
<p>Effective date of submission of applications and registrations</p>
<p>The date of submission of an application or notification shall, without preju-<br>dice to Article 11 of Protocol 23 to the EEA Agreement, be the date on<br>which it is received by the EFTA Surveillance Authority. Where, however,<br>the application or notification is sent by registered post, it shall be deemcd<br>to have been received on the date shown on the postmark of the place of<br>posting.</p>
<p>Article 4</p>
<p>Content of applications and notifications</p>
<p>1. Applications under Article 2 of Chapter II relating to the applicability of<br>Article 53(1) of the EEA Agreement and notifications under Article 4 of<br>Chapter II or Article 1(2) of Chapter XVI shall be submitted on forms issued<br>for that purpose by the Governments of the EFTA States, by common ac-<br>cord, as shown in Appendix 1, or by the EC Commission.</p>
<p>2. Applications and notifications shall contain the information asked for in<br>these forms.</p>
<p>3. Several participating undertakings may submit an application or notifica-<br>tion on a single form.</p>
<p>4. Applications under Article 2 of Chapter II relating to the applicability of<br>Article 54 of the EEA Agreement shall contain a full statement of the facts,<br>specifying, in particular, the practice concerned and the position of the un-<br>dertaking or undertakings within the territory covered by the EEA Agree-<br>ment or a substantial part thereof in regard to products or services to which<br>the practice relätes. The forms issued for that purpose by the Governments<br>of the EFTA States, by common accord, as shown in Appendix 1, or by the<br>EC Commission may be used.</p>
<p>Article 5</p>
<p>Special provisions</p>
<p>The EFTA Surveillance Authority may submit to the Governments of the<br>EFTA States, in accordance with the provisions of Article 49 of this Agree-<br>ment, proposals for forms and complementary notes.</p>
<h2>CHAPTER IV HEARINGS PROVIDED FOR IN<br>ARTICLE 19(1) AND (2) OF CHAPTER II</h2>
<p>Article 1</p>
<p>Before Consulting the Advisory Committee on Competition, the EFTA Sur-<br>veillance Authority shall hold a hearing pursuant to Article 19(1) of<br>Chapter II.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol 4</p>
<p>204</p>
<p>Article 2</p>
<p>1. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall inform undertakings and associ-<br>ations of undertakings in writing of the objections raised against them. The<br>communication shall be addressed to each of them or to a joint agent ap-<br>pointed by them.</p>
<p>2. The EFTA Surveillance Authority may inform the parties by giving notice<br>in the EEA Section of the Official Journal of the European Communities, if<br>from the circumstances of the case this appears appropriate, in particular<br>where notice is to be given to a number of undertakings but no joint agent<br>has been appointed. The notice shall have regard to the legitimate interest<br>of the undertakings in the protection of their business secrets.</p>
<p>3. A fine or a periodic penalty payment may be imposed on an undertaking<br>or association of undertakings only if the objections were notified in the<br>manner provided for in paragraph 1.</p>
<p>4. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall, when giving notice of objec-<br>tions, fix a time-limit up to which the undertakings and associations of under-<br>takings may inform the EFTA Surveillance Authority of their views.</p>
<p>Article 3</p>
<p>1. Undertakings and associations of undertakings shall, within the ap-<br>pointed time-limit, make known in writing their views concerning the objec-<br>tions raised against them.</p>
<p>2. They may in their written comments set out all matters relevant to their<br>defence.</p>
<p>3. They may attach any relevant documents in proof of the facts set out.<br>They may also propose that the EFTA Surveillance Authority hear persons<br>who may corroborate those facts.</p>
<p>Article 4</p>
<p>The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall in its decisions deal only with those<br>objections raised against undertakings and associations of undertakings in<br>respect of which they have been afforded the opportunity of making known<br>their views.</p>
<p>Article 5</p>
<p>If natural or legal persons showing a sufficient interest apply to be heard pur-<br>suant to Article 19(2) of Chapter II, the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall<br>afford them the opportunity of making known their views in writing within<br>such time-limit as it shall fix.</p>
<p>Article 6</p>
<p>Where the EFTA Surveillance Authority, having received an application<br>pursuant to Article 3(2) of Chapter II, considers that on the basis of the in-</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>205</p>
<p>formation in its possession there are insufficient grounds for granting the ap-<br>plication, it shall inform the applicants of its reasons and fix a time-limit for<br>them to submit any further comments in writing.</p>
<p>Article 7</p>
<p>1. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall afford to persons who have so<br>requested in their written comments the opportunity to put forward their ar-<br>guments orally, if those persons show a sufficient interest or if the EFTA<br>Surveillance Authority proposes to impose on them a fine or periodic pen-<br>alty payment.</p>
<p>2. The EFTA Surveillance Authority may likewise afford to any other per-<br>son the opportunity of orally expressing his views.</p>
<p>Article 8</p>
<p>1. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall summon the persons to be heard<br>to attend on such date as it shall appoint.</p>
<p>2. It shall forthwith transmit a copy of the summons to the competent auth-<br>orities of the EFTA States, who may appoint an official to take part in the<br>hearing. Likewise, the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall invite the EC<br>Commission to be represented at the hearing. The invitation shall also ex-<br>tend to the EC Member States.</p>
<p>Article 9</p>
<p>1. Hearings shall be conducted by the persons appointed by the EFTA Sur-<br>veillance Authority for that purpose.</p>
<p>2. Persons summoned to attend shall appear either in person or be<br>represented by legal representatives or by representatives authorized by<br>their constitution. Undertakings and associations of undertakings may more-<br>over be represented by a duly authorized agent appointed from among their<br>permanent staff.</p>
<p>Persons heard by the EFTA Surveillance Authority may be assisted by<br>lawyers or advisers who are entitled to plead before the EFTA Court, or by<br>other qualified persons.</p>
<p>3. Hearings shall not be public. Persons shall be heard separately or in the<br>presence of other persons summoned to attend. In the latter case, regard<br>shall be had to the legitimate interest of the undertakings in the protection<br>of their business secrets.</p>
<p>4. The essential content of the statements made by each person heard shall<br>be recorded in minutes which shall be read and approved by him.</p>
<p>Article 10</p>
<p>Without prejudice to Article 2(2), information and summonses from the<br>EFTA Surveillance Authority shall be sent to the addressees by registered</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>206</p>
<p>letter with acknowledgement of receipt, or shall be delivered by hand against<br>receipt.</p>
<p>Article 11</p>
<p>1. In fixing the time-limits provided for in Articles 2, 5 and 6, the EFTA Sur-<br>veillance Authority shall have regard both to the time required for prep-<br>aration of comments and to the urgency of the case. The time-limit shall be<br>not less than two weeks; it may be extended.</p>
<p>2. Time-limits shall run from the day following receipt of a communication<br>or delivery thereof by hand.</p>
<p>3. Written comments must reach the EFTA Surveillance Authority or be<br>dispatched by registered letter before expiry of the time-limit. Where the<br>time-limit would expire on a Sunday or public holiday, it shall be extended<br>up to the end of the next following working day. For the purpose of calculat-<br>ing this extension, public holidays shall, in cases where the relevant date is<br>the date of receipt of written comments, be those set out in Appendix 2 to<br>this Protocol, and in cases where the relevant date is the date of dispatch,<br>those appointed by law in the country of dispatch.</p>
<p>CHAPTER V LIMITATION PERIODS IN<br>PROCEEDINGS AND THE ENFORCEMENT OF<br>SANCTIONS UNDER THE RULES RELATING TO<br>TRANSPORT AND COMPETITION AS CONTAINED IN<br>CHAPTERS II TO IV AND VI TO XIV</p>
<p>Article 1</p>
<p>Limitation periods in proceedingsz</p>
<p>1. The power of the EFTA Surveillance Authority to impose fines or penal-<br>ties for infringements of the rules of the EEA Agreement relating to trans-<br>port or competition shall be subject to the following limitation periods:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;three years in the case of infringements of provisions concerning ap-<br>plications or notifications of undertakings or associations of under-<br>takings, requests for information, or the carrying out of investi-<br>gations;</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;five years in the case of all other infringements.</p>
<p>2. Time shall begin to run upon the day on which the infringement is com-<br>mitted. However, in the case of continuing or repeated infringements, time<br>shall begin to run upon the day on which the infringement ceases.</p>
<p>Article 2</p>
<p>Interruption of the limitation period in proceedings</p>
<p>1. Any action taken by the EFTA Surveillance Authority, by the EC Com-<br>mission at the request of the EFTA Surveillance Authority pursuant to<br></p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>207</p>
<p>Article 8 of Protocol 23 to the EEA Agreement, or by any EFTA State, act-<br>ing at the request of the EFTA Surveillance Authority, for the purpose of<br>the preliminary investigation or proceedings in respect of an infringement<br>shall interrupt the limitation period in proceedings. The limitation period<br>shall be interrupted with effect from the date on which the action is notified<br>to at least one undertaking or association of undertakings which have parti-<br>cipated in the infringement.</p>
<p>Actions which interrupt the running of the period shall include in particu-<br>lar the following:</p>
<p>(a) written requests for information by the EFTA Surveillance Auth-<br>ority, or by the competent authority of an EFTA State acting at the<br>request of the EFTA Surveillance Authority; or a decision by the<br>EFTA Surveillance Authority requiring the requested information;</p>
<p>(b) written authorizations to carry out investigations issued to their offi-<br>cials by the EFTA Surveillance Authority or by the competent auth-<br>ority of any EFTA State at the request of the EFTA Surveillance<br>Authority; or a decision by the EFTA Surveillance Authority order-<br>ing an investigation;</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;the commencement of proceedings by the EFTA Surveillance Auth-<br>ority;</p>
<p>(d) notification of the EFTA Surveillance Authority’s statement of ob-<br>jections.</p>
<p>2. The interruption of the limitation period shall apply for all the undertak-<br>ings or associations of undertakings which have participated in the infringe-<br>ment.</p>
<p>3. Each interruption shall start time running afresh. However, the limitation<br>period shall expire at the latest on the day on which a period equal to twice<br>the limitation period has elapsed without the EFTA Surveillance Authority<br>having imposed a fine or a penalty; that period shall be extended by the time<br>during which limitation is suspended pursuant to Article 3.</p>
<p>Article 3</p>
<p>Suspension of the limitation period in proceedings</p>
<p>The limitation period in proceedings shall be suspended for as long as the<br>decision of the EFTA Surveillance Authority is the subject of proceedings<br>pending before the EFTA Court in accordance with Article 108(2) of the<br>EEA Agreement and with the relevant provisions of this Agreement.</p>
<p>Article 4</p>
<p>Limitation period for the enforcement of sanctions</p>
<p>1. The power of the EFTA Surveillance Authority to enforce decisions im-<br>posing fines, penalties, or periodic payments for infringements of the rules<br></p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>208</p>
<p>of the EEA Agreement relating to transport or competition shall be subject<br>to a limitation period of five years.</p>
<p>2. Time shall begin to run upon the day on which the decision becomes final.</p>
<p>Article 5</p>
<p>Interruption of the limitation period for the enforcement of sanctions</p>
<p>1. The limitation period for the enforcement of sanctions shall be inter-<br>rupted:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;by notification of a decision varying the original amount of the fine,<br>penalty or periodic penalty payments or refusing an application for<br>variation;</p>
<p>(b) by any action of the EFTA Surveillance Authority or of an EFTA<br>State at the request of the EFTA Surveillance Authority, for the pur-<br>pose of enforcing payments, of a fine, penalty or periodic penalty<br>payment.</p>
<p>2. Each interruption shall start time running afresh.</p>
<p>Article 6</p>
<p>Suspension of the limitation period for the enforcement of sanctions</p>
<p>The limitation period for the enforcement of sanctions shall be suspended<br>for so long as:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;time to pay is allowed; or</p>
<p>(b) enforcement of payment is suspended pursuant to a decision of the<br>EFTA Court in accordance with Article 108(2) of the EEA Agree-<br>ment and with the relevant provisions of this Agreement.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>209</p>
<p>14 Riksdagen 1991/92. 1 saml. Nr 170. Bil. 16</p>
<h1>PART II TRANSPORT</h1>
<h2>CHAPTER VI APPLICATION OF RULES OF<br>COMPETITION TO TRANSPORT BY RAIL, ROAD<br>AND INLAND WATERWAY</h2>
<p>Due to the division of the text of Regulation (EEC) No 1017/68 between An-<br>nex XIV to the EEA Agreement (substantive rules) and the present Chapter<br>(procedural rules), the text, as adapted, of Articles 1 to 5 and Articles 7 to 9 is<br>to be found in the act referred to in point 10 of Annex XIV to the EEA Agree-<br>ment (Regulation (EEC) No 1017/68). The EFTA Surveillance Authority<br>shall decide on these cases in accordance with the provisions of Article 56 of<br>the EEA Agreement, in particular paragraph (l)(a) and (b) and paragraph<br>(3).</p>
<p>Articles 1 to 5</p>
<p>(No text)</p>
<p>Article 6</p>
<p>Agreements intended to reduce disturbances resulting from the structure<br>of the transport market</p>
<p>1. Until such time as appropriate measures to ensure a stable transport mar-<br>ket are introduced, the prohibition laid down in Article 2 of the act referred<br>to in point 10 of Annex XIV to the EEA Agreement (Regulation (EEC)<br>No 1017/68) may be declared inapplicable to any agreement, decision or<br>concerted practice which tends to reduce disturbances on the market in ques-<br>tion.</p>
<p>2. A decision not to apply the prohibition laid down in Article 2 of the said<br>act, made in accordance with the procedure laid down in Article 14, may not<br>be taken until the Standing Committee has found on the basis of a report by<br>the EFTA Surveillance Authority, that a State of crisis exists in all or part of<br>a transport market.</p>
<p>3. Without prejudice to the provisions of paragraph 2, the prohibition in<br>Article 2 of the said act may be declared inapplicable only where:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;the agreement, decision or concerted practice in question does not<br>impose upon the undertakings concerned any restriction not indis-<br>pensable to the reduction of disturbances; and</p>
<p>(b) does not make it possible for such undertakings to eliminate com-<br>petition in respect of a substantial part of the transport market con-<br>cerned.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>210</p>
<p>Articles 7 to 9</p>
<p>(No text)</p>
<p>Article 10</p>
<p>Procedures on complaint or on the EFTA Surveillance Authority’s own<br>initiative</p>
<p>Acting on receipt of a complaint or on its own initiative, the EFTA Surveil-<br>lance Authority shall initiate procedures to terminate any infringement of<br>the provisions of Article 2 or Article 8 of the act referred to in point 10 of<br>Annex XIV to the EEA Agreement (Regulation (EEC) No 1017/68) or to<br>enforce Article 4(2) of that act.</p>
<p>Complaints may be submitted by:</p>
<p>(a) EFTA States;</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;natural or legal persons who claim a legitimate interest.</p>
<p>Article 11</p>
<p>Result of procedures on complaint or on the EFTA Surveillance Authority’s<br>own initiative</p>
<p>1. Where the EFTA Surveillance Authority finds that there has been an in-<br>fringement of Article 2 or Article 8 of the act referred to in point 10 of Annex<br>XIV to the EEA Agreement (Regulation (EEC) No 1017/68), it may by de-<br>cision require the undertakings or associations of undertakings concerned to<br>bring such infringement to an end.</p>
<p>Without prejudice to the other provisions of this Chapter and the said act,<br>the EFTA Surveillance Authority may, before taking a decision under the<br>preceding subparagraph, address to the undertakings or associations of un-<br>dertakings concerned recommendations for termination of the infringement.</p>
<p>2. Paragraph 1 shall apply also to cases falling within Article 4(2) of the said<br>act.</p>
<p>3. If the EFTA Surveillance Authority, acting on a complaint received, con-<br>cludes that on the evidence before it there are no grounds for intervention<br>under Article 2, Article 4(2) or Article 8 of the said act in respect of any<br>agreement, decision or concerted practice, it shall issue a decision rejecting<br>the complaint as unfounded.</p>
<p>4. If the EFTA Surveillance Authority, whether acting on a complaint re-<br>ceived or on its own initiative, concludes that an agreement, decision or<br>concerted practice satisfies the provisions both of Article 2 and of Article 5<br>of the said act, it shall issue a decision applying Article 5. Such decision shall<br>indicate the date from which it is to take effect. This date may be prior to<br>that of the decision.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>211</p>
<p>Article 12</p>
<p>Application of Article 5 of the act referred to in point 10 of Annex XIV<br>to the EEA Agreement (Regulation (EEC) No 1017/68) - objections</p>
<p>1. Undertakings and associations of undertakings which seek application of<br>Article 5 of the act referred to in point 10 of Annex XIV to the EEA Agree-<br>ment (Regulation (EEC) No 1017/68) in respect of agreements, decisions<br>and concerted practices falling within the provisions of Article 2 of the said<br>act to which they are parties may submit applications to the EFTA Surveil-<br>lance Authority.</p>
<p>2. If the EFTA Surveillance Authority judges an application admissible and<br>is in possession of all the available evidence, and no action under Article 10<br>has been taken against the agreement, decision or concerted practice in<br>question, then it shall publish as soon as possible in the EEA Section of the<br>Official Journal of the European Communities a summary of the application<br>and invite all interested third parties to submit their comments to the EFTA<br>Surveillance Authority within 30 days. Such publication shall have regard<br>to the legitimate interest of undertakings in the protection of their business<br>secrets.</p>
<p>3. Unless the EFTA Surveillance Authority notifies applicants, within<br>90 days from the date of such publication in the EEA Section of the Official<br>Journal of the European Communities, that there are serious doubts as to<br>the applicability of Article 5 of the said act, the agreement, decision or<br>concerted practice shall be deemed exempt, in so far as it conforms with the<br>description given in the application, from the prohibition for the time al-<br>ready elapsed and for a maximum of three years from the date of publication<br>in the EEA Section of the Official Journal of the European Communities.</p>
<p>If the EFTA Surveillance Authority finds, after expiry of the 90-day time-<br>limit, but before expiry of the three-year period, that the conditions for ap-<br>plying Article 5 of the said act are not satisfied, it shall issue a decision declar-<br>ing that the prohibition in Article 2 of the said act is applicable. Such decision<br>may be retroactive where the parties concerned have given inaccurate in-<br>formation or where they abuse the exemption from the provisions of<br>Article 2 of the said act.</p>
<p>4. If, within the 90-day time-limit, the EFTA Surveillance Authority notifies<br>applicants as referred to in the first subparagraph of paragraph 3, it shall ex-<br>amine whether the provisions of Article 2 and of Article 5 of the said act are<br>satisfied.</p>
<p>If it finds that the provisions of Article 2 and of Article 5 of the said act are<br>satisfied it shall issue a decision applying Article 5. The decision shall indic-<br>ate the date from which it is to take effect. This date may be prior to that of<br>the application.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol 4</p>
<p>212</p>
<p>Article 13</p>
<p>Duration and revocation of decisions applying Article 5 of the act<br>referred to in point 10 of Annex XIV to the EEA Agreement (Regulation<br>(EEC) No 1017/68)</p>
<p>1. Any decision applying Article 5 of the said act taken under Article 11(4)<br>or under the second subparagraph of Article 12(4) shall indicate the period<br>for which it is to be valid; normally such period shall not be less than six<br>years. Conditions and obligations may be attached to the decision.</p>
<p>2. The decision may be renewed if the conditions for applying Article 5 of<br>the said act continue to be satisfied.</p>
<p>3. The EFTA Surveillance Authority may revoke or amend its decision or<br>prohibit specified acts by the parties:</p>
<p>(a) where there has been a change in any of the facts which were basic<br>to the making of the decision;</p>
<p>(b) where the parties commit a breach of any obligation attached to the<br>decision;</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;where the decision is based on incorrect information or was induced<br>by deceit;</p>
<p>(d) where the parties abuse the exemption from the provisions of<br>Article 2 of the said act granted to them by the decision.</p>
<p>In cases falling within (b), (c) or (d), the decision may be revoked with retro-<br>active effect.</p>
<p>Article 14</p>
<p>Decisions applying Article 6</p>
<p>1. Any agreement, decision or concerted practice covered by Article 2 of the<br>act referred to in point 10 of Annex XIV to the EEA Agreement (Regulation<br>(EEC) No 1017/68) in respect of which the parties seek application of<br>Article 6 shall be notified to the EFTA Surveillance Authority.</p>
<p>2. Any decision by the EFTA Surveillance Authority to apply Article 6 of<br>the said act shall have effect only from the date of its adoption. It shall State<br>the period for which it is to be valid. Such period shall not exceed three years<br>from the finding of a State of crisis by the Standing Committee provided for<br>in Article 6(2).</p>
<p>3. Such decision may be renewed by the EFTA Surveillance Authority if the<br>Standing Committee again finds, acting under the procedure provided for in<br>Article 6(2), that there is a State of crisis and if the other conditions laid down<br>in Article6 continue to be satisfied.</p>
<p>4. Conditions and obligations may be attached to the decision.</p>
<p>5. The decision of the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall cease to have ef-<br>fect not later than six months from the coming into operation of the measures<br>referred to in Article 6(1).</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>213</p>
<p>6. The provisions of Article 13(3) shall apply.</p>
<p>Article 15</p>
<p>Powers</p>
<p>Subject to review of its decision by the EFTA Court in accordance with Art-<br>icle 108(2) of the EEA Agreement and with the relevant provisions of this<br>Agreement, the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall have sole power, on the<br>conditions set out in Article 56 of the EEA Agreement:</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;to impose obligations pursuant to Article 4(2) of the act referred to<br>in point 10 of Annex XIV to the EEA Agreement (Regulation<br>(EEC) No 1017/68);</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;to issue decisions pursuant to Article 5 of the said act and Article 6<br>of this Chapter.</p>
<p>The authorities of the EFTA States shall retain the power to decide whether<br>any case falls within the provisions of Article 2 or Article 8 of the said act,<br>until such time as the EFTA Surveillance Authority has initiated a procedure<br>with a view to formulating a decision in the case in question or has sent noti-<br>fication as provided for in the first subparagraph of Article 12(3).</p>
<p>Article 16</p>
<p>Liaison with authorities of the EFTA States</p>
<p>1. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall carry out the procedures pro-<br>vided for in this Chapter in close and constant liaison with the competent<br>authorities of the EFTA States; these authorities shall have the right to ex-<br>press their views on such procedures.</p>
<p>2. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall immediately forward to the com-<br>petent authorities of the EFTA States copies of the complaints and applica-<br>tions, and of the most important documents sent to it or which it sends out<br>in the course of such procedures.</p>
<p>The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall forthwith transmit to the compet-<br>ent authorities of the EFTA States a copy of notifications, complaints and<br>information on opening of ex officio procedures received from the EC Com-<br>mission pursuant to Articles 2 and 10 of Protocol 23 to the EEA Agreement.</p>
<p>The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall forthwith transmit to the compet-<br>ent authorities of the EFTA States a copy of documents received from the<br>EC Commission pursuant to Article 7 of Protocol 23 to the EEA Agreement.</p>
<p>3. An Advisory Committee on Competition in the Transport Industry shall<br>be consulted prior to the taking of any decision following upon a procedure<br>under Article 10 or of any decision under the second subparagraph of Article<br>12(3), or under the second subparagraph of paragraph 4 of the same Article,<br>or under paragraph 2 or paragraph 3 of Article 14. The Advisory Committee<br>shall also be consulted prior to a proposal referred to in Article 29.</p>
<p>4. The Advisory Committee shall be composed of officials competent in the<br>matter of restrictive practices and monopolies in transport. Each EFTA<br>State shall appoint two officials to represent it, each of whom, if prevented<br>from attending, may be replaced by some other official.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol 4</p>
<p>214</p>
<p>The EC Commission and the EC Member States shall be entitled to be<br>present in the Advisory Committee and to express their views therein. How-<br>ever, their representatives shall not have the right to vote.</p>
<p>5. Consultation shall take place at a joint meeting convcned by the EFTA<br>Surveillance Authority; such meeting shall be held not earlier than 14 days<br>after dispatch of the notice convening it. This notice shall, in respect of each<br>case to be examined, be accompanied by a summary of the case together<br>with an indication of the most important documents, and a preliminary draft<br>decision.</p>
<p>In view of the participation provided for in the second subparagraph of<br>paragraph 4, the EC Commission shall receive an invitation to the meeting<br>and the relevant information as provided for in Article 6 of Protocol 23 to the<br>EEA Agreement.</p>
<p>6. The Advisory Committee may deliver an opinion notwithstanding that<br>some of its members or their alternates are not present. A report of the out-<br>come of the consultative proceedings shall be annexed to the draft decision.<br>It shall not be made public.</p>
<p>Article 17</p>
<p>Consideration by the Standing Committee of questions of principle concern-<br>ing the provisions on transport as contained in the EEA Agreement raised<br>in connection with specific cases.</p>
<p>1. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall not give a decision in respect of<br>which consultation as laid down in Article 16 is compulsory until after the<br>expiry of 20 days from the date on which the Advisory Committee has de-<br>livered its opinion.</p>
<p>2. Before the expiry of the period specified in paragraph 1, any EFTA State<br>may request that the Standing Committee be convened to examine with the<br>EFTA Surveillance Authority any question of principle concerning the pro-<br>visions on transport as contained in the EEA Agreement which such EFTA<br>State considers to be involved in the particular case for decision.</p>
<p>The Standing Committee shall meet within 30 days from the request by<br>the EFTA State concerned for the sole purpose of considering such questions<br>of principle.</p>
<p>The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall not give its decision until after the<br>meeting of the Standing Committee.</p>
<p>3. Further, the Standing Committee may at any time, at the request of an<br>EFTA State or of the EFTA Surveillance Authority, consider general ques-<br>tions raised by the implementation of the competition policy in the transport<br>sector.</p>
<p>4. In all cases where the Standing Committee is asked to meet to consider<br>under paragraph 2 questions of principle or under paragraph 3 general ques-<br>tions, the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall, for the purposes of this Chap-<br>ter, take into account the policy guidelines which emerge from the meeting.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol 4</p>
<p>215</p>
<p>Article 18</p>
<p>Inquiries into transport sectors</p>
<p>1. If trends in transport, fluctuations in or inflexibility of transport rates, or<br>other circumstances, suggest that competition in transport is being restricted<br>or distorted within the territory covered by the EEA Agreement in a specific<br>geographical area, or over one or more transport links, or in respect of the<br>carriage of passengers or goods belonging to one or more specific categories,<br>the EFTA Surveillance Authority may decide, in accordance with the provi-<br>sions of Protocol 23 to the EEA Agreement, to conduct a general inquiry<br>into the sector concerned, in the course of which it may request transport<br>undertakings in that sector to supply the information and documentation<br>necessary for giving effect to the principles formulated in Articles 2 to 5, 7<br>and 8 of the act referred to in point 10 of Annex XIV to the EEA Agreement<br>(Regulation (EEC) No 1017/68) and to Article 6 of this Chapter.</p>
<p>2. When making inquiries pursuant to paragraph 1, the EFTA Surveillance<br>Authority shall also request undertakings or groups of undertakings whose<br>size suggests that they occupy a dominant position within the territory cov-<br>ered by the EEA Agreement or a substantial part thereof to supply such par-<br>ticulars of the structure of the undertakings and of their behaviour as are<br>requisite to an appraisal of their position in the light of the provisions of<br>Article 8 of the said act.</p>
<p>3. Article 16(2) to (6) and Articles 17, 19, 20 and 21 shall apply.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol 4</p>
<p>Article 19</p>
<p>Requests for information</p>
<p>1. In carrying out the duties assigned to it by Articles 55 and 58 of the EEA<br>Agreement, by provisions set out in Protocol 23 and in Annex XIV to the<br>EEA Agreement or by provisions of this Chapter, the EFTA Surveillance<br>Authority may obtain all necessary information from the governments and<br>competent authorities of the EFTA States and from undertakings and associ-<br>ations of undertakings.</p>
<p>2. When sending a request for information to an undertaking or association<br>of undertakings, the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall at the same time for-<br>ward a copy of the request to the competent authority of the EFTA State in<br>whose territory the seat of the undertakings is situated.</p>
<p>3. In its request, the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall State the legal basis<br>and the purpose of the request, and also the penalties provided for in<br>Article 22(l)(b) for supplying incorrect information.</p>
<p>4. The owners of the undertakings or their representatives and, in the case<br>of legal persons, companies or firms, or of associations having no legal per-<br>sonality, the person authorized to represent them by law or by their constitu-<br>tion, shall be bound to supply the information requested.</p>
<p>5. Where an undertaking or association of undertakings does not supply the</p>
<p>216</p>
<p>information requested within the time-limit fixed by the EFTA Surveillance<br>Authority, or supplies incomplete information, the EFTA Surveillance<br>Authority shall by decision require the information to be supplied. The de-<br>cision shall specify what information is required, fix an appropriate time-<br>limit within which it is to be supplied and indicate the penalties provided for<br>in Article 22(l)(b) and Article 23(l)(c), and the right to have the decision<br>reviewed by the EFTA Court in accordance with Article 108(2) of the EEA<br>Agreement and with the relevant provisions of this Agreement, in particular<br>Article 35.</p>
<p>6. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall at the same time forward a copy<br>of its decision to the competent authority of the EFTA State in whose terri-<br>tory the seat of the undertaking or association of undertakings is situated.</p>
<p>Article 20</p>
<p>Investigations by the authorities of the EFTA States</p>
<p>1. At the request of the EFTA Surveillance Authority, the competent auth-<br>orities of the EFTA States shall undertake the investigations which the<br>EFTA Surveillance Authority considers to be necessary under Article 21(1),<br>or which it has ordered by decision pursuant to Article 21(3). The officials of<br>the competent authorities of the EFTA States responsible for conducting<br>these investigations shall exercise their powers upon production of an au-<br>thorization in writing issued by the competent authority of the EFTA State<br>in whose territory the investigation is to be made. Such authorization shall<br>specify the subject matter and purpose of the investigation.</p>
<p>2. If so requested by the EFTA Surveillance Authority or by the competent<br>authority of the EFTA State in whose territory the investigation is to be<br>made, the officials of the EFTA Surveillance Authority may assist the offi-<br>cials of such authority in carrying out their duties.</p>
<p>Article 21</p>
<p>Investigating powers of the EFTA Surveillance Authority</p>
<p>1. In carrying out the duties assigned to it by Articles 55 and 58 of the EEA<br>Agreement, by provisions set out in Protocol 23 and in Annex XIV to the<br>EEA Agreement or by provisions of this Chapter, the EFTA Surveillance<br>Authority may undertake all necessary investigations into undertakings and<br>associations of undertakings in the territory of an EFTA State. To this end<br>the officials authorized by the EFTA Surveillance Authority are em-<br>powered:</p>
<p>(a) to examine the books and other business records;</p>
<p>(b) to take copies of or extracts from the books and business records;</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;to ask for oral explanations on the spot;</p>
<p>(d) to enter any premises, land and vehicles of undertakings.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol 4</p>
<p>2. The officials of the EFTA Surveillance Authority authorized for the pur-</p>
<p>217</p>
<p>pose of these investigations shall exercise their powers upon production of<br>an authorization in writing specifying the subject matter and purpose of the<br>investigation and the penalties provided for in Article 22(l)(c) in cases where<br>production of the required books or other business records is incomplete.</p>
<p>In good time before the investigation, the EFTA Surveillance Authority<br>shall inform the competent authority of the EFTA State in whose territory<br>the same is to be made of the investigation and of the identity of the author-<br>ized officials. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall also provide such an<br>authorization to representatives of the EC Commission who shall take part<br>in the investigation in accordance with Article 8(4) of Protocol 23 to the EEA<br>Agreement.</p>
<p>3. Undertakings and associations of undertakings shall submit to investi-<br>gations ordered by decision of the EFTA Surveillance Authority. The de-<br>cision shall specify the subject matter and purpose of the investigation, ap-<br>point the date on which it is to begin and indicate the penalties provided for<br>in Article 22(l)(c) and Article 23( 1 )(d) and the right to have the decision re-<br>viewed by the EFTA Court.</p>
<p>4. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall take decisions referred to in para-<br>graph 3 after consultation with the competent authority of the EFTA State<br>in whose territory the investigation is to be made.</p>
<p>5. Officials of the competent authority of the EFTA State in whose territory<br>the investigation is to be made, may at the request of such authority or of the<br>EFTA Surveillance Authority, assist the officials of the EFTA Surveillance<br>Authority in carrying out their duties.</p>
<p>6. Where an undertaking opposes an investigation ordered pursuant to this<br>Article, the EFTA State concerned shall afford the necessary assistance to<br>the officials authorized by the EFTA Surveillance Authority to enable them<br>to make their investigation. EFTA States shall, after consultation with the<br>EFTA Surveillance Authority, take the necessary measures to this end<br>within six months of the entry into force of the EEA Agreement.</p>
<p>Article 22</p>
<p>Fines</p>
<p>1. The EFTA Surveillance Authority may by decision impose on undertak-<br>ings or associations of undertakings fines of from 100 to 5 000 ECU where,<br>intentionally or negligently:</p>
<p>(a) they supply incorrect or misleading information in an application<br>pursuant to Article 12 or in a notification pursuant to Article 14; or</p>
<p>(b) they supply incorrect information in response to a request made pur-<br>suant to Article 18 or to Article 19(3) or (5), or do not supply in-<br>formation within the time-limit fixed by a decision taken under Art-<br>icle 19(5); or</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;they produce the required books or other business records in incom-<br>plete form during investigations under Article 20 or Article 21, or re-</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>218</p>
<p>fuse to submit to an investigation ordered by decision issued in im-<br>plementation of Article 21(3).</p>
<p>2. The EFTA Surveillance Authority may by decision impose on undertak-<br>ings or associations of undertakings fines of from 1 000 to 1 000 000 ECU, or<br>a sum in excess thereof but not exceeding 10% of the turnover in the preced-<br>ing business year of each of the undertakings participating in the infringe-<br>ment, where either intentionally or negligently:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;they infringe Article 2 or Article 8 of the act referred to in point 10<br>of Annex XIV to the EEA Agreement (Regulation (EEC)<br>No 1017/68); or</p>
<p>(b) they commit a breach of any obligation imposed pursuant to<br>Article 13(1) or Article 14(4).</p>
<p>In fixing the amount of the fine, regard shall be had both to the gravity and<br>to the duration of the infringement.</p>
<p>3. Article 16(3) to (6) and Article 17 shall apply.</p>
<p>4. Decisions taken pursuant to paragraphs 1 and 2 shall not be of a criminal<br>law nature.</p>
<p>Article 23</p>
<p>Periodic penalty payments</p>
<p>1. The EFTA Surveillance Authority may by decision impose on undertak-<br>ings or associations of undertakings periodic penalty payments of from 50 to<br>1 000 ECU per day, calculated from the date appointed by the decision, in<br>order to compel them:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;to put an end to an infringement of Article 2 or Article 8 of the act<br>referred to in point 10 of Annex XIV to the EEAAgreement (Regu-<br>lation (EEC) No 1017/68) of this Chapter, the termination of which<br>it has ordered pursuant to Article 11 or to comply with an obligation<br>imposed pursuant to Article 4(2) of the said act;</p>
<p>(b) to refrain from any act prohibited under Article 13(3);</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;to supply complete and correct information which it has requested<br>by decision taken pursuant to Article 19(5);</p>
<p>(d) to submit to an investigation which it has ordered by decision taken<br>pursuant to Article 21(3).</p>
<p>2. Where the undertakings or associations of undertakings have satisfied the<br>obligation which it was the purpose of the periodic penalty payment to en-<br>force, the EFTA Surveillance Authority may fix the total amount of the peri-<br>odic penalty payment at a lower figure than that which would arise under the<br>original decision.</p>
<p>3. Article 16(3) to (6) and Article 17 shall apply.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>219</p>
<table border="1">
<tr><td>
<p>Article 24</p></td><td>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>Review by the EFTA Court</p></td><td>
<p>Bilaga 16</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>The EFTA Court shall, in accordance with Article 108(2) of the EEA Agree-<br>ment and with the relevant provisions of this Agreement, have unlimited jur-<br>isdiction within the meaning of Article 35 of this Agreement to review de-<br>cisions whereby the EFTA Surveillance Authority has fixed a fine or periodic<br>penalty payment; it may cancel, reduce or increase the fine or periodic pen-<br>alty payment imposed.</p></td><td>
<p>ESA/Court<br>Agreement<br>Protocol4</p></td></tr>
</table>
<p>Article 25</p>
<p>ECU</p>
<p>For the purpose of applying Articles 22 to 24, ’ECU’ means the ECU as de-<br>fined by the competent authorities of the European Communities.</p>
<p>Article 26</p>
<p>Hearing of the parties and of third persons</p>
<p>1. Before taking decisions as provided for in Articles 11, 12(3), second sub-<br>paragraph, and 12(4), 13(3), 14(2) and (3), 22 and 23, the EFTA Surveillance<br>Authority shall give the undertakings or associations of undertakings con-<br>cerned the opportunity of being heard on the matters to which the EFTA<br>Surveillance Authority has taken objection.</p>
<p>2. If the EFTA Surveillance Authority or the competent authorities of the<br>EFTA States consider it necessary, they may also hear other natural or legal<br>persons. Applications to be heard on the part of such persons where they<br>show a sufficient interest shall be granted.</p>
<p>3. Where the EFTA Surveillance Authority intends to give negative clear-<br>ance pursuant to Article 5 of the act referred to in point 10 of Annex XIV<br>to the EEA Agreement (Regulation (EEC) No 1017/68) or Article 6 of this<br>Chapter, it shall publish a summary of the relevant agreement, decision or<br>concerted practice and invite all interested third parties to submit their ob-<br>servations within a time-limit which it shall fix being not less than one month.<br>Publication shall have regard to the legitimate interest of undertakings in the<br>protection of their business secrets.</p>
<p>Article 27</p>
<p>Professional secrecy</p>
<p>1. Without prejudice to Article 9 of Protocol 23 to the EEA Agreement, in-<br>formation acquired as a result of the application of Articles 18,19, 20 and 21<br>of this Chapter or Article 58 of the EEA Agreement and Protocol 23 thereto<br>shall be used only for the purpose of the relevant request or investigation.</p>
<p>2. Without prejudice to the provisions of Articles 26 and 28, the EFTA Sur-<br>veillance Authority and the competent authorities of the EFTA States, their<br></p>
<p>220</p>
<p>officials and other servants shall not disclose information acquired by them<br>as a result of the application of this Protocol or Article 58 of the EEA Agree-<br>ment and Protocol 23 thereto and of the kind covered by the obligation of<br>professional secrecy. This obligation shall also apply to the representatives<br>of the EC Commission and of the EC Member States who participate in the<br>Advisory Committee pursuant to Article 16(4) and in the hearing pursuant<br>to Article 8(2) of Chapter VIII.</p>
<p>3. The provisions of paragraphs 1 and 2 shall not prevent publication of gen-<br>eral information or surveys which do not contain information relating to par-<br>ticular undertakings or associations of undertakings.</p>
<p>Article 28</p>
<p>Publication of decisions</p>
<p>1. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall publish the decisions which it<br>takes pursuant to Articles 11, 12(3), second subparagraph, 12(4), 13(3) and<br>14(2) and (3).</p>
<p>2. The publication shall State the names of the parties and the main content<br>of the decision; it shall have regard to the legitimate interest of undertakings<br>in the protection of their business secrets.</p>
<p>Article 29</p>
<p>Special provisions</p>
<p>The EFTA Surveillance Authority may submit to the Governments of the<br>EFTA States, in accordance with the provisions of Article 49 of this Agree-<br>ment, proposals for forms to be used for complaints pursuant to Article 10,<br>applications pursuant to Article 12 and notifications pursuant to<br>Article 14(1), as well as proposals for complementary notes to the forms.</p>
<p>CHAPTER VII FORM, CONTENT AND OTHER<br>DETAILS OF COMPLAINTS PURSUANT TO ARTICLE<br>10, APPLICATIONS PURSUANT TO ARTICLE 12<br>AND NOTIFICATIONS PURSUANT TO ARTICLE 14(1)<br>OF CHAPTER VI</p>
<p>Article 1</p>
<p>Complaints</p>
<p>1. Complaints pursuant to Article 10 of Chapter VI shall be submitted in<br>writing in an official language of an EFTA State or the European Commun-<br>ity; they may be submitted on forms issued for this purpose by the Govern-<br>ments of the EFTA States, by common accord, as shown in Appendix 3, or<br>by the EC Commission.</p>
<p>2. When representatives of undertakings, of associations of undertakings,<br>or of natural or legal persons sign such complaints, they shall produce written<br>proof that they are authorized to act.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>221</p>
<p>Article 2</p>
<p>Persons entitled to submit applications and notifications</p>
<p>1. Any undertaking which is party to agreements, decisions or practices of<br>the kind described in Article 2 of the act referred to in point 10 of Annex<br>XIV to the EEA Agreement (Regulation (EEC) No 1017/68) may submit an<br>application under Article 12 or a notification under Article 14(1) of<br>Chapter VI. Where the application or notification is submitted by some, but<br>not all, of the undertakings concerned, they shall give notice to the others.</p>
<p>2. Where applications or notifications under Articles 12 and 14(1) of<br>Chapter VI are signed by representatives of undertakings, of associations of<br>undertakings, or of natural or legal persons, such representatives shall pro-<br>duce written proof that they are authorized to act.</p>
<p>3. Where a joint application or notification is submitted, a joint<br>representative shall be appointed.</p>
<p>Article 3</p>
<p>Submission of applications and notifications</p>
<p>1. Applications pursuant to Article 12 of Chapter VI shall be submitted on<br>forms issued for this purpose by the Governments of the EFTA States, by<br>common accord, as shown in Appendix 4, or by the EC Commission.</p>
<p>2. Notifications pursuant to Article 14(1) of Chapter VI shall be submitted<br>on forms issued for this purpose by the Governments of the EFTA States,<br>by common accord, as shown in Appendix 5, or by the EC Commission.</p>
<p>3. Several participating undertakings may submit an application or notifica-<br>tion on a single form.</p>
<p>4. Applications and notifications shall contain the information requested in<br>the forms.</p>
<p>5. Nine copies of each application or notification and of the supporting<br>documents shall be submitted to the EFTA Surveillance Authority.</p>
<p>6. The supporting documents shall be either originals or copies. Copies must<br>be certified as true copies of the original.</p>
<p>7. Applications and notifications shall be in an official language of an EFTA<br>State or the European Community. Supporting documents shall be sub-<br>mitted in their original language. Where the original language is not one of<br>the official languages, a translation in one of these languages shall be at-<br>tached.</p>
<p>Article 4</p>
<p>Special provisions</p>
<p>The EFTA Surveillance Authority may submit to the Governments of the<br>EFTA States, in accordance with the provisions of Article 49 of this Agree-<br>ment, proposals for forms and complementary notes.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol 4</p>
<p>222</p>
<h2>CHAPTER VIII HEARINGS PROVIDED FOR IN<br>ARTICLE 26(1) OF CHAPTER VI</h2>
<p>Article 1</p>
<p>Before Consulting the Advisory Committee on Competition in the Transport<br>Industry, the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall hold a hearing pursuant to<br>Article 26(1) of Chapter VI.</p>
<p>Article 2</p>
<p>1. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall inform undertakings and associ-<br>ations of undertakings in writing of the objections raised against them. The<br>Communications shall be addressed to each of them or to a joint agent ap-<br>pointed by them.</p>
<p>2. The EFTA Surveillance Authority may inform the parties by giving notice<br>in the EEA Section of the Official Journal of the European Communities, if<br>from the circumstances of the case this appears appropriate, in particular<br>where notice is to be given to a number of undertakings but no joint agent<br>has been appointed. The notice shall have regard to the legitimate interest<br>of the undertakings in the protection of their business secrets.</p>
<p>3. A fine or a periodic penalty payment may be imposed on an undertaking<br>or association of undertakings only if the obligations were notified in the<br>manner provided for in paragraph 1.</p>
<p>4. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall, when giving notice of objec-<br>tions, fix a time-limit up to which the undertakings and associations of under-<br>takings may inform the EFTA Surveillance Authority of their views.</p>
<p>Article 3</p>
<p>1. Undertakings and associations of undertakings shall, within the ap-<br>pointed time-limit, make known in writing their views concerning the objec-<br>tions raised against them.</p>
<p>2. They may in their written comments set out all matters relevant to their<br>defence.</p>
<p>3. They may attach any relevant documents in proof of the facts set out.<br>They may also propose that the EFTA Surveillance Authority hear persons<br>who may corroborate those facts.</p>
<p>Article 4</p>
<p>The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall in its decision deal only with those<br>objections raised against undertakings and associations of undertakings in<br>respect of which they have been afforded the opportunity of making known<br>their views.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>223</p>
<p>Article 5</p>
<p>If natural or legal persons showing a sufficient interest apply to be heard pur-<br>suant to Article 26(2) of Chapter VI, the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall<br>afford them the opportunity of making known their views in writing within<br>such time limits as it shall fix.</p>
<p>Article 6</p>
<p>Where the EFTA Surveillance Authority, having received an application<br>pursuant to Article 10(2) of Chapter VI, considers that on the basis of the<br>information in its possession there are insufficient grounds for granting the<br>application, it shall inform the applicants of its reasons and fix a time-limit<br>for them to submit any further comments in writing.</p>
<p>Article 7</p>
<p>1. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall afford to persons who have so<br>requested in their written comments the opportunity to put forward their ar-<br>guments orally, if those persons show a sufficient interest or if the EFTA<br>Surveillance Authority proposes to impose on them a fine or periodic pen-<br>alty payment.</p>
<p>2. The EFTA Surveillance Authority may likewise afford to any other per-<br>son the opportunity of orally expressing his views.</p>
<p>Article 8</p>
<p>1. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall summon the persons to be heard<br>to attend on such date as it shall appoint.</p>
<p>2. It shall forthwith transmit a copy of the summons to the competent auth-<br>orities of the EFTA States, who may appoint an official to take part in the<br>hearing. Likewise, the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall invite the EC<br>Commission to be represented at the hearing. The invitation shall also ex-<br>tend to the EC Member States.</p>
<p>Article 9</p>
<p>1. Hearings shall be conducted by the persons appointed by the EFTA Sur-<br>veillance Authority for that purpose.</p>
<p>2. Persons summoned to attend shall appear either in person or be<br>represented by legal representatives or by representatives authorized by<br>their constitution. Undertakings and associations of undertakings may more-<br>over be represented by a duly authorized agent appointed from among their<br>permanent staff.</p>
<p>Persons heard by the EFTA Surveillance Authority may be assisted by<br>lawyers or advisers who are entitled to plead before the EFTA Court, or by<br>other qualified persons.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>224</p>
<p>3. Hearings shall not be public. Persons shall be heard separately or in the<br>presence of other persons summoned to attend. In the latter case, regard<br>shall be had to the legitimate interest of the undertakings in the protection<br>of their business secrets.</p>
<p>4. The essential content of the statements made by each person heard shall<br>be recorded in minutes which shall be read and approved by him.</p>
<p>Article 10</p>
<p>Without prejudice to Article 2(2), information and summonses from the<br>EFTA Surveillance Authority shall be sent to the addressees by registered<br>letter with acknowledgement of receipt, or shall be delivered by hand against<br>receipt.</p>
<p>Article 11</p>
<p>1. In fixing the time limits provided for in Articles 2,5 and 6, the EFTA Sur-<br>veillance Authority shall have regard both to the time required for prep-<br>aration of comments and to the urgency of the case. The time-limit shall be<br>not less than two weeks; it may be extended.</p>
<p>2. Time limits shall run from the day following receipt of a communication<br>or delivery thereof by hand.</p>
<p>3. Written comments must reach the EFTA Surveillance Authority or be<br>dispatched by registered letter before expiry of the time-limit. Where the<br>time-limit would expire on a Sunday or public holiday, it shall be extended<br>up to the end of the next following working day. For the purpose of calculat-<br>ing the extension, public holidays shall, in cases where the relevant date is<br>the date of receipt of written comments, be those set out in Appendix 2 to<br>this Protocol, and in cases where the relevant date is the date of dispatch,<br>those appointed by law in the country of dispatch.</p>
<h2>CHAPTER IX RULES FOR THE APPLICATION OF<br>ARTICLES 53 AND 54 OF THE EEA AGREEMENT TO<br>MARITIME TRANSPORT</h2>
<p>Due to the division of the text of Regulation (EEC) No 4056/86 between Annex<br>XIV to the EEA Agreement (substantive rules) and the present Chapter<br>(procedural rules), the text, as adapted, of Section I, Articles 1 to 9, is to be<br>found in the act referred to in point 11 of Annex XIV to the EEA Agreement<br>(Regulation (EEC) No 4056/86). The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall de-<br>cide on these cases in accordance with the provisions of Article 56 of the EEA<br>Agreement, in particularparagraph (l)(a) and (b) andparagraph (3).</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>225</p>
<p>15 Riksdagen 1991/92. 1 saml. Nr 170. Bil. 16</p>
<h2>SECTION I</h2>
<p>Articles 1 to 9</p>
<p>(No text)</p>
<h2>SECTION II</h2>
<p>RULES OF PROCEDURE</p>
<p>Article 10</p>
<p>Procedures on complaint or on the EFTA Surveillance Authority’s own<br>initiative</p>
<p>Acting on receipt of a complaint or on its own initiative, the EFTA Surveil-<br>lance Authority shall initiate procedures to terminate any infringement of<br>the provisions of Articles 53(1) or 54 of the EEA Agreement or to enforce<br>Article 7 of the act referred to in point 11 of Annex XIV to the EEA Agree-<br>ment (Regulation (EEC) No4056/86).</p>
<p>Complaints may be submitted by:</p>
<p>(a) EFTA States;</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;natural or legal persons who claim a legitimate interest.</p>
<p>Article 11</p>
<p>Result of procedures on complaint or on the EFTA Surveillance Authority’s<br>own initiative</p>
<p>1. Where the EFTA Surveillance Authority finds that there has been an in-<br>fringement of Articles 53( 1) or 54 of the EEA Agreement, it may by decision<br>require the undertakings or associations of undertakings concerned to bring<br>such infringement to an end.</p>
<p>Without prejudice to the other provisions of this Chapter or to the provi-<br>sions of the act referred to in point 11 of Annex XIV to the EEA Agreement<br>(Regulation (EEC) No4056/86), the EFTA Surveillance Authority may, be-<br>fore taking a decision under the preceding subparagraph, address to the un-<br>dertakings or associations of undertakings concerned recommendations for<br>termination of the infringement.</p>
<p>2. Paragraph 1 shall apply also to cases falling within Article 7 of the said<br>act.</p>
<p>3. If the EFTA Surveillance Authority, acting on a complaint received, con-<br>cludes that on the evidence before it there are no grounds for intervention<br>under Articles 53(1) or 54 of the EEA Agreement or Article 7 of the said<br>act, in respect of any agreement, decision or practice, it shall issue a decision<br>rejecting the complaint as unfounded.</p>
<p>4. If the EFTA Surveillance Authority, whether acting on a complaint re-<br>ceived or on its own initiative, concludes that an agreement, decision or<br>concerted practice satisfies the provisions both of Article 53(1) and of<br>Article 53(3) of the EEA Agreement, it shall issue a decision applying<br></p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>226</p>
<p>Article 53(3). Such decision shall indicate the date from which it is to take<br>effect. This date may be prior to that of the decision.</p>
<p>Article 12</p>
<p>Application of Article 53(3) of the EEA Agreement - objections</p>
<p>1. Undertakings and associations of undertakings which seek application of<br>Article 53(3) of the EEA Agreement in respect of agreements, decisions and<br>concerted practices falling within the provisions of Article 53(1) to which<br>they are parties shall, without prejudice to Article 11 of Protocol 23 to the<br>EEA Agreement, submit applications to the EFTA Surveillance Authority.</p>
<p>2. If the EFTA Surveillance Authority judges an application admissible and<br>is in possession of all the available evidence, and no action under Article 10<br>has been taken against the agreement, decision or concerted practice in<br>question, then it shall publish as soon as possible in the EEA Section of the<br>Official Journal of the European Communities a summary of the application<br>and invite all interested third parties and the EFTA States to submit their<br>comments to the EFTA Surveillance Authority within 30 days. Such publica-<br>tions shall have regard to the legitimate interest of undertakings in the pro-<br>tection of their business secrets.</p>
<p>3. Unless the EFTA Surveillance Authority notifies applicants, within 90<br>days from the date of such publication in the EEA Section of the Official<br>Journal of the European Communities, that there are serious doubts as to<br>the applicability of Article 53(3), the agreement, decision or concerted prac-<br>tice shall be deemed exempt, in so far as it conforms with the description<br>given in the application, from the prohibition for the time already elapsed<br>and for a maximum of six years from the date of publication in the EEA<br>Section of the Official Journal of the European Communities.</p>
<p>If the EFTA Surveillance Authority finds, after expiry of the 90-day time-<br>limit, but before expiry of the six-year period, that the conditions for apply-<br>ing Article 53(3) are not satisfied, it shall issue a decision declaring that the<br>prohibition in Article 53(1) is applicable. Such decision may be retroactive<br>where the parties concerned have given inaccurate information or where<br>they abuse the exemption from the provisions of Article53(1).</p>
<p>4. The EFTA Surveillance Authority may notify applicants as referred to in<br>the first subparagraph of paragraph 3 and shall do so if requested by an<br>EFTA State within 45 days of the forwarding to the EFTA State of the ap-<br>plication in accordance with Article 15(2). This request must be justified on<br>the basis of considerations relating to the competition rules of the EEA<br>Agreement.</p>
<p>If it finds that the conditions of Article 53(1) and of Article 53(3) are satis-<br>fied, the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall issue a decision applying<br>Article 53(3). The decision shall indicate the date from which it is to take<br>effect. This date may be prior to that of the application.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>227</p>
<p>Article 13</p>
<p>Duration and revocation of decisions applying Article 53(3) of the EEA<br>Agreement</p>
<p>1. Any decision applying Article53(3) taken under Article 11(4) or under<br>the second subparagraph of Article 12(4) shall indicate the period for which<br>it is to be valid; normally such period shall not be less than six years. Condi-<br>tions and obligations may be attached to the decision.</p>
<p>2. The decision may be renewed if the conditions for applying Article 53(3)<br>continue to be satisfied.</p>
<p>3. The EFTA Surveillance Authority may revoke or amend its decision or<br>prohibit specified acts by the parties:</p>
<p>(a) where there has been a change in any of the facts which were basic<br>to the making of the decision;</p>
<p>(b) where the parties commit a breach of any obligation attached to the<br>decision;</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;where the decision is based on incorrect information or was induced<br>by deceit, or</p>
<p>(d) where the parties abuse the exemption from the provisions of<br>Article 53(1) granted to them by the decision.</p>
<p>In cases falling within (b), (c) or (d), the decision may be revoked with retro-<br>active effect.</p>
<p>Article 14</p>
<p>Powers</p>
<p>Subject to review of its decision by the EFTA Court in accordance with<br>Article 108(2) of the EEA Agreement and with the relevant provisions of<br>this Agreement, the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall have sole power, on<br>the conditions set out in Article 56 of the EEA Agreement:</p>
<p>to impose obligations pursuant to Article 7 of the act referred to in<br>point 11 of Annex XIV to the EEA Agreement (Regulation (EEC)<br>No 4056/86);</p>
<p>- to issue decisions pursuant to Article 53(3) of the EEA Agreement.<br>The authorities of the EFTA States shall retain the power to decide whether<br>any case falls within the provisions of Article 53(1) or Article 54, until such<br>time as the EFTA Surveillance Authority has initiated a procedure with a<br>view to formulating a decision in the case in question or has sent notification<br>as provided for in the first subparagraph of Article 12(3).</p>
<p>Article 15</p>
<p>Liaison with the authorities of the EFTA States</p>
<p>1. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall carry out the procedures pro-<br>vided for in this Chapter in close and constant liaison with the competent<br></p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>228</p>
<p>authorities of the EFTA States; these authorities shall have the right to ex-<br>press their views on such procedures.</p>
<p>2. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall immediately forward to the com-<br>petent authorities of the EFTA States copies of the complaints and applica-<br>tions, and of the most important documents sent to it or which it sends out<br>in the course of such procedures.</p>
<p>The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall forthwith transmit to the compet-<br>ent authorities of the EFTA States a copy of notifications, complaints and<br>information on opening of ex officio procedures received from the EC Com-<br>mission pursuant to Articles 2 and 10 of Protocol 23 to the EEA Agreement.</p>
<p>The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall forthwith transmit to the compet-<br>ent authorities of the EFTA States a copy of documents received from the<br>EC Commission pursuant to Article 7 of Protocol 23 to the EEA Agreement.</p>
<p>3. An Advisory Committee on Competition in Maritime Transport shall be<br>consulted prior to the taking of any decision following upon a procedure<br>under Article 10 or of any decision issued under the second subparagraph of<br>Article 12(3), or under the second subparagraph of paragraph 4 of the same<br>Article. The Advisory Committee shall also be consulted prior to a proposal<br>referred to in Article 26.</p>
<p>4. The Advisory Committee shall be composed of officials competent in the<br>sphere of maritime transport and agreements and dominant positions. Each<br>EFTA State shall nominate two officials to represent it, each of whom may<br>be replaced, in the event of his being prevented from attending, by another<br>official.</p>
<p>The EC Commission and the EC Member States shall be entitled to be<br>present in the Advisory Committee and to express their views therein. How-<br>ever, their representatives shall not have the right to vote.</p>
<p>5. Consultation shall take place at a joint meeting convened by the EFTA<br>Surveillance Authority; such meeting shall be held not earlier than fourteen<br>days after dispatch of the notice convening it. This notice shall, in respect of<br>each case to be examined, be accompanied by a summary of the case to-<br>gether with an indication of the most important documents, and a prelimin-<br>ary draft decision.</p>
<p>In view of the participation provided for in the second subparagraph of<br>paragraph 4, the EC Commission shall receive an invitation to the meeting<br>and the relevant information as provided for in Article 6 of Protocol 23 to the<br>EEA Agreement.</p>
<p>6. The Advisory Committee may deliver an opinion notwithstanding that<br>some of its members or their alternates are not present. A report of the out-<br>come of the consultative proceedings shall be annexed to the draft decision.<br>It shall not be made public.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>229</p>
<p>Article 16</p>
<p>Requests for information</p>
<p>1. In carrying out the duties assigned to it by Articles 55 and 58 of the EEA<br>Agreement, by provisions set out in Protocol 23 and in Annex XIV to the<br>EEA Agreement or by provisions of this Chapter, the EFTA Surveillance<br>Authority may obtain all necessary information from the Governments and<br>competent authorities of the EFTA States and from undertakings and associ-<br>ations of undertakings.</p>
<p>2. When sending a request for information to an undertaking or association<br>of undertakings, the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall at the same time for-<br>ward a copy of the request to the competent authority of the EFTA State in<br>whose territory the seat of the undertaking or association of undertakings is<br>situated.</p>
<p>3. In its request, the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall State the legal basis<br>and the purpose of the request, and also the penalties provided for in<br>Article 19(l)(b) for supplying incorrect information.</p>
<p>4. The owners of the undertakings or their representatives and, in the case<br>of legal persons, companies or firms, or of associations having no legal per-<br>sonality, the person authorized to represent them by law or by their constitu-<br>tion, shall be bound to supply the information requested.</p>
<p>5. Where an undertaking or association of undertakings does not supply the<br>information requested within the time-limit fixed by the EFTA Surveillance<br>Authority, or supplies incomplete information, the EFTA Surveillance<br>Authority shall by decision require the information to be supplied. The de-<br>cision shall specify what information is required, fix an appropriate time-<br>limit within which it is to be supplied and indicate the penalties provided for<br>in Article 19(l)(b) and Article 20(l)(c) and the right to have the decision<br>reviewed by the EFTA Court in accordance with Article 108(2) of the EEA<br>Agreement and with the relevant provisions of this Agreement, in particular<br>Article 35.</p>
<p>6. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall at the same time forward a copy<br>of its decision to the competent authority of the EFTA State in whose terri-<br>tory the seat of the undertaking or association of undertakings is situated.</p>
<p>Article 17</p>
<p>Investigations by the authorities of the EFTA States</p>
<p>1. At the request of the EFTA Surveillance Authority, the competent auth-<br>orities of the EFTA States shall undertake the investigations which the<br>EFTA Surveillance Authority considers to be necessaiy under Article 18(1),<br>or which it has ordered by decision pursuant to Article 18(3). The officials of<br>the competent authorities of the EFTA States responsible for conducting<br>these investigations shall exercise their powers upon production of an au-<br>thorization in writing issued by the competent authority of the EFTA State</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>230</p>
<p>in whose territory the investigation is to be made. Such authorization shall<br>specify the subject matter and purpose of the investigation.</p>
<p>2. If so requested by the EFTA Surveillance Authority or by the competent<br>authority of the EFTA State in whose territory the investigation is to be<br>made, EFTA Surveillance Authority officials may assist the officials of such<br>authority in carrying out their duties.</p>
<p>Article 18</p>
<p>Investigating powers of the EFTA Surveillance Authority</p>
<p>1. In carrying out the duties assigned to it by Articles55 and 58 of the EEA<br>Agreement, by provisions set out in Protocol 23 and in Annex XIV to the<br>EEA Agreement or by provisions of this Chapter, the EFTA Surveillance<br>Authority may undertake all necessary investigations into undertakings and<br>associations of undertakings in the territory of an EFTA State.</p>
<p>To this end the officials authorized by the EFTA Surveillance Authority<br>are empowered:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;to examine the books and other business records;</p>
<p>(b) to take copies of or extracts from the books and business records;</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;to ask for oral explanations on the spot;</p>
<p>(d) to enter any prcmises, land and vehicles of undertakings.</p>
<p>2. The officials of the EFTA Surveillance Authority authorized for the pur-<br>pose of these investigations shall exercise their powers upon production of<br>an authorization in writing specifying the subject matter and purpose of the<br>investigation and the penalties provided for in Article 19( 1)(c) in cases where<br>production of the required books or other business records is incomplete. In<br>good time before the investigation, the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall<br>inform the competent authority of the EFTA State in whose territory the<br>same is to be made of the investigation and of the identity of the authorized<br>officials. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall also provide such an au-<br>thorization to representatives of the EC Commission who shall take part in<br>the investigation in accordance with Article 8(4) of Protocol 23 to the EEA<br>Agreement.</p>
<p>3. Undertakings and associations of undertakings shall submit to investi-<br>gations ordered by decision of the EFTA Surveillance Authority. The de-<br>cision shall specify the subject matter and purpose of the investigation, ap-<br>point the date on which it is to begin and indicate the penalties provided for<br>in Article 19(l)(c) and Article20(l)(d) and the right to have the decision re-<br>viewed by the EFTA Court in accordance with Article 108(2) of the EEA<br>Agreement and with the relevant provisions of this Agreement, in particular<br>Article 35.</p>
<p>4. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall take decisions referred to in<br>paragraph 3 after consultation with the competent authority of the EFTA<br>State in whose territory the investigation is to be made.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>5. Officials of the competent authority of the EFTA State in whose territory</p>
<p>231</p>
<p>the investigation is to be made, may at the request of such authority or of the<br>EFTA Surveillance Authority, assist the officials of the EFTA Surveillance<br>Authority in carrying out their duties.</p>
<p>6. Where an undertaking opposes an investigation ordered pursuant to this<br>Article, the EFTA State concerned shall afford the necessary assistance to<br>the officials authorized by the EFTA Surveillance Authority to enable them<br>to make their investigation. To this end, EFTA States shall take the necess-<br>ary measures, after Consulting the EFTA Surveillance Authority, within six<br>months of the entry into force of the EEA Agreement.</p>
<p>Article 19</p>
<p>Fines</p>
<p>1. The EFTA Surveillance Authority may by decision impose on undertak-<br>ings or associations of undertakings fines of from 100 to 5 000 ECU where,<br>intentionally or negligently:</p>
<p>(a) they supply incorrect or misleading information, either in a<br>communication pursuant to Article 5(5) of the act referred to in po-<br>int 11 of Annex XIV to the EEA Agreement (Regulation (EEC)<br>No 4056/86) or in an application pursuant to Article 12 of this Chap-<br>ter; or</p>
<p>(b) they supply incorrect information in response to a request made pur-<br>suant to Article 16(3) or (5), or do not supply information within the<br>time-limit fixed by a decision taken under Article 16(5); or</p>
