<p>(c) &nbsp;they produce the required books or other business records in incom-<br>plete form during investigations under Article 17 or Article 18, or re-<br>fuse to submit to an investigation ordered by decision issued in im-<br>plcmentation of Article 18(3).</p>
<p>2. The EFTA Surveillance Authority may by decision impose on undertak-<br>ings or associations of undertakings fines of from 1000 to 1000 000 ECU, or<br>a sum in excess thereof but not exceeding 10% of the turnover in the preced-<br>ing business year of each of the undertakings participating in the infringe-<br>ment, where either intentionally or negligently:</p>
<p>(a) they infringe Article 53(1) or Article 54 of the EEA Agreement, or<br>do not comply with an obligation imposed under Article 7 of the said<br>act;</p>
<p>(b) they commit a breach of any obligation imposed pursuant to<br>Article 5 of the said act or to Article 13(1).</p>
<p>In fixing the amount of the fine, regard shall be had both to the gravity and<br>to the duration of the infringement.</p>
<p>3. Article 15(3) and (4) shall apply.</p>
<p>4. Decisions taken pursuant to paragraphs 1 and 2 shall not be of a criminal<br>law nature.</p>
<p>The fines provided for in paragraph 2(a) shall not be imposed in respect of<br></p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>232</p>
<p>acts taking place after notification to the EFTA Surveillance Authority and<br>before its decision in application of Article 53(3) of the EEA Agreement,<br>provided they fall within the limits of the activity described in the notifica-<br>tion.</p>
<p>However, this provision shall not have effect where the EFTA Surveil-<br>lance Authority has informed the undertakings concerned that after prelim-<br>inary examination it is of the opinion that Article 53(1) of the EEA Agree-<br>ment applies and that application of Article53(3) is not justified.</p>
<p>Article 20</p>
<p>Periodic penalty payments</p>
<p>1. The EFTA Surveillance Authority may by decision impose on undertak-<br>ings or associations of undertakings periodic penalty payments of from 50 to<br>1000 ECU per day, calculated from the date appointed by the decision, in<br>order to compel them:</p>
<p>(a) to put an end to an infringement of Article 53(1) or Article 54 of the<br>EEA Agreement the termination of which it has ordered pursuant<br>to Article 11, or to comply with an obligation imposed pursuant to<br>Article 7 of the act referred to in point 11 of Annex XIV to the EEA<br>Agreement (Regulation (EEC) No 4056/86);</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;to refrain from any act prohibited under Article 13(3);</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;to supply complete and correct information which it has requested<br>by decision taken pursuant to Article 16(5);</p>
<p>(d) to submit to an investigation which it has ordered by decision taken<br>pursuant to Article 18(3).</p>
<p>2. Where the undertakings or associations of undertakings have satisfied the<br>obligation which it was the purpose of the periodic penalty payment to en-<br>force, the EFTA Surveillance Authority may fix the total amount of the peri-<br>odic penalty payment at a lower figure than that which would arise under the<br>original decision.</p>
<p>3. Article 15(3) and (4) shall apply.</p>
<p>Article 21</p>
<p>Review by the EFTA Court</p>
<p>The EFTA Court, in accordance with Article 108(2) of the EEA Agreement<br>and with the relevant provisions of this Agreement, shall have unlimited jur-<br>isdiction within the meaning of Article 35 of this Agreement to review de-<br>cisions whereby the EFTA Surveillance Authority has fixed a fine or periodic<br>penalty payment; it may cancel, reduce or increase the fine or periodic pen-<br>alty payment imposed.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>233</p>
<p>Article 22</p>
<p>ECU</p>
<p>For the purpose of applying Articles 19 to 21, ’ECU’ means the ECU as de-<br>fined by the competent authorities of the European Communities.</p>
<p>Article 23</p>
<p>Hearing of the parties and of third persons</p>
<p>1. Before taking decisions as provided for in Articles 11,12(3), second sub-<br>paragraph, 12(4), 13(3), 19 and 20, the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall<br>give the undertakings or associations of undertakings concerned the oppor-<br>tunity of being heard on the matters to which the EFTA Surveillance Auth-<br>ority has taken objection.</p>
<p>2. If the EFTA Surveillance Authority or the competent authorities of the<br>EFTA States consider it necessary, they may also hear other natural or legal<br>persons. Applications to be heard on the part of such persons where they<br>show a sufficient interest shall be granted.</p>
<p>3. Where the EFTA Surveillance Authority intends to give negative clear-<br>ance pursuant to Article 53(3) of the EEA Agreement, it shall publish a sum-<br>mary of the relevant agreement, decision or concerted practice and invite all<br>interested third parties to submit their observations within a time-limit which<br>it shall fix being not less than one month. Publication shall have regard to the<br>legitimate interest of undertakings in the protection of their business secrets.</p>
<p>Article 24</p>
<p>Professional secrecy</p>
<p>1. Without prejudice to Article 9 of Protocol 23 to the EEA Agreement, in-<br>formation acquired as a result of the application of Articles 17 and 18 of this<br>Chapter or Article 58 of the EEA Agreement and Protocol 23 thereto shall<br>be used only for the purpose of the relevant request or investigation.</p>
<p>2. Without prejudice to the provisions of Articles 23 and 25, the EFTA Sur-<br>veillance Authority and the competent authorities of the EFTA States, their<br>officials and other servants shall not disclose information acquired by them<br>as a result of the application of this Protocol or Article 58 of the EEA Agree-<br>ment and Protocol 23 thereto and of the kind covered by the obligation of<br>professional secrecy. This obligation shall also apply to the representatives<br>of the EC Commission and of the EC Member States who participate in the<br>Advisory Committee pursuant to Article 15(4) and in the hearing pursuant<br>to Article 12(2) of Chapter X.</p>
<p>3. The provisions of paragraphs 1 and 2 shall not prevent publication of gen-<br>eral information or surveys which do not contain information relating to par-<br>ticular undertakings or associations of undertakings.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>234</p>
<p>Article 25</p>
<p>Publication of decisions</p>
<p>1. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall publish the decisions which it<br>takes pursuant to Articles 11, 12(3), second paragraph, 12(4) and 13(3).</p>
<p>2. The publication shall State the names of the parties and the main content<br>of the decision; it shall have regard to the legitimate interest of undertakings<br>in the protection of their business secrets.</p>
<p>Article 26</p>
<p>Special provisions</p>
<p>The EFTA Surveillance Authority may submit to the Governments of the<br>EFTA States, in accordance with the provisions of Article 49 of this Agree-<br>ment, proposals for forms to be used for complaints pursuant to Article 10<br>and applications pursuant to Article 12, as well as proposals for complement-<br>ary notes to the forms.</p>
<p>CHAPTER X THE OBLIGATION OF<br>COMMUNICATION, THE FORM, CONTENT AND<br>OTHER DETAILS OF COMPLAINTS AND OF<br>APPLICATIONS, AND THE HEARINGS PROVIDED<br>FOR IN CHAPTER IX</p>
<p>SECTION I</p>
<p>NOTIFICATIONS, COMPLAINTS AND APPLICATIONS</p>
<p>Article 1</p>
<p>Notifications</p>
<p>1. Awards at arbitration and recommendations by conciliators accepted by<br>the parties shall be notified to the EFTA Surveillance Authority when they<br>concern the settlement of disputes relating to the practices of conferences<br>referred to in Articles 4 and 5(2) and (3) of the act referred to in point 11 of<br>Annex XIV to the EEA Agreement (Regulation (EEC) No 4056/86).</p>
<p>2. The obligation of notification applies to any party to the dispute resolved<br>by the award or recommendation.</p>
<p>3. Notifications shall be submitted forthwith by registered letter with an ac-<br>knowledgement of receipt or shall be delivered by hand against receipt. They<br>shall be written in an official language of an EFTA State or the European<br>Community.</p>
<p>Supporting documents shall be either originals or copies. Copies must be<br>certified as true copies of the original. They shall be submitted in their ori-<br>ginal language. Where the original language is not an official language of<br>an EFTA State or the European Community, a translation in one of these<br>languages shall be attached.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>235</p>
<p>4. When representatives of undertakings, of associations of undertakings,<br>or of natural or legal persons sign such notifications, they shall produce writ-<br>ten proof that they are authorized to act.</p>
<p>Article 2</p>
<p>Complaints</p>
<p>1. Complaints pursuant to Article 10 of Chapter IX shall be submitted in<br>writing in an official language of an EFTA State or the European Commun-<br>ity, their form, content and other details being left to the discretion of com-<br>plainants.</p>
<p>2. Complaints may be submitted by:</p>
<p>(a) EFTA States;</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;natural or legal persons who claim a legitimate interest.</p>
<p>3. When representatives of undertakings, of associations of undertakings,<br>or of natural or legal persons sign such complaints, they shall produce written<br>proof that they are authorized to act.</p>
<p>Article 3</p>
<p>Persons entitled to submit applications</p>
<p>1. Any undertaking which is party to agreements, decisions or practices of<br>the kind described in Article 53(1) of the EEA Agreement may submit an<br>application under Article 12 of Chapter IX. Where the application is sub-<br>mitted by some but not all of the undertakings concerned, they shall give<br>notice to the others.</p>
<p>2. Where applications under Article 12 of Chapter IX are signed by<br>representatives of undertakings, of associations of undertakings, or of nat-<br>ural or legal persons, such representatives shall produce written proof that<br>they are authorized to act.</p>
<p>3. Where a joint application is submitted, a joint representative shall be ap-<br>pointed.</p>
<p>Article 4</p>
<p>Submission of applications</p>
<p>1. Applications pursuant to Article 12 of Chapter IX shall be submitted on<br>forms issued for this purpose by the Governments of the EFTA States, by<br>common accord, as shown in Appendix 6, or by the EC Commission.</p>
<p>2. Several participating undertakings may submit an application on a single<br>form.</p>
<p>3. Applications shall contain the information requested in the form.</p>
<p>4. Nine copies of each application and of the supporting documents shall be<br>submitted to the EFTA Surveillance Authority.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>236</p>
<p>5. The supporting documents shall be either originals or copies. Copies must<br>be certified as true copies of the original.</p>
<p>6. Applications shall be in an official language of an EFTA State or the Eur-<br>opean Community. Supporting documents shall be submitted in their ori-<br>ginal language. Where the original language is not an official language of<br>an EFTA State or the European Community, a translation in one of these<br>languages shall be attached.</p>
<p>7. The date of submission of an application shall be the date on which it is<br>received by the EFTA Surveillance Authority, without prejudice to<br>Article 11 of Protocol 23 to the EEA Agreement. Where, however, the ap-<br>plication is sent by registered post, it shall be deemed to have been received<br>on the date shown on the postmark of the place of posting.</p>
<p>8. Where an application submitted pursuant to Article 12 of Chapter IX falls<br>outside the scope of that Chapter, the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall<br>without delay inform the applicant that it intends to examine the application<br>under the provisions of such other act referred to in Article 3 of Protocol 21<br>and Annex XIV to the EEA Agreement as is applicable to the case; how-<br>ever, the date of submission of the application shall be the date resulting<br>from paragraph 7. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall inform the applic-<br>ant of its reasons and fix a period for him to submit any comments in writing<br>before it conducts its appraisal pursuant to the provisions of that other act.</p>
<h2>SECTION II</h2>
<p>HEARINGS</p>
<p>Article 5</p>
<p>Before Consulting the Advisory Committee on Competition in Maritime<br>Transport, the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall hold a hearing pursuant<br>to Article 23(1) of Chapter IX.</p>
<p>Article 6</p>
<p>1. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall inform undertakings and associ-<br>ations of undertakings in writing of the objections raised against them. The<br>communication shall be addressed to each of them or to a joint agent ap-<br>pointed by them.</p>
<p>2. The EFTA Surveillance Authority may inform the parties by giving notice<br>in the EEA Section of the Official Journal of the European Communities, if<br>from the circumstances of the case this appears appropriate, in particular<br>where notice is to be given to a number of undertakings but no joint agent<br>has been appointed. The notice shall have regard to the legitimate interest<br>of the undertakings in the protection of their business secrets.</p>
<p>3. A fine or a periodic penalty payment may be imposed on an undertaking<br>or association of undertakings only if the objections were notified in the<br>manner provided for in paragraph 1.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>237</p>
<p>4. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall, when giving notice of objec-<br>tions, fix a period within which the undertakings and associations of under-<br>takings may inform the EFTA Surveillance Authority of their views.</p>
<p>Article 7</p>
<p>1. Undertakings and associations of undertakings shall, within the ap-<br>pointed period, make known in writing their views concerning the objections<br>raised against them.</p>
<p>2. They may in their written comments set out all matters relevant to their<br>defence.</p>
<p>3. They may attach any relevant documents in proof of the facts set out.<br>They may also propose that the EFTA Surveillance Authority hear persons<br>who may corroborate those facts.</p>
<p>Article 8</p>
<p>The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall in its decision deal only with those<br>objections raised against undertakings and associations of undertakings in<br>respect of which they have been afforded the opportunity of making known<br>their views.</p>
<p>Article 9</p>
<p>If natural or legal persons showing a sufficient interest apply to be heard pur-<br>suant to Article 23(2) of Chapter IX the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall<br>afford them the opportunity of making known their views in writing within<br>such period as it shall fix.</p>
<p>Article 10</p>
<p>Where the EFTA Surveillance Authority, having received a complaint pur-<br>suant to Article 10 of Chapter IX, considers that on the basis of the informa-<br>tion in its possession there are insufficient grounds for acting on the com-<br>plaint, it shall inform the persons who submitted the complaint of its reasons<br>and fix a period for them to submit any further comments in writing.</p>
<p>Article 11</p>
<p>1. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall afford to persons who have so<br>requested in their written comments the opportunity to put forward their ar-<br>guments orally, if those persons show a sufficient interest or if the EFTA<br>Surveillance Authority proposes to impose on them a fine or periodic pen-<br>alty payment.</p>
<p>2. The EFTA Surveillance Authority may likewise afford to any other per-<br>son the opportunity of orally expressing his views.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>238</p>
<p>Article 12</p>
<p>1. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall summon the persons to be heard<br>to attend on such date as it shall appoint.</p>
<p>2. It shall forthwith transmit a copy of the summons to the competent auth-<br>orities of the EFTA States, who may appoint an official to take part in the<br>hearing. Likewise, the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall invite the EC<br>Commission to be represented at the hearing. The invitation shall also ex-<br>tend to the EC Member States.</p>
<p>Article 13</p>
<p>1. Hearings shall be conducted by the persons appointed by the EFTA Sur-<br>veillance Authority for that purpose.</p>
<p>2. Persons summoned to attend shall either appear in person or be<br>represented by legal representatives or by representatives authorized by<br>their constitution. Undertakings and associations of undertakings may more-<br>over be represented by a duly authorized agent appointed from among their<br>permanent staff.</p>
<p>Persons heard by the EFTA Surveillance Authority may be assisted by<br>lawyers or advisers who are entitled to plead before the EFTA Court, or by<br>other qualified persons.</p>
<p>3. Hearings shall not be public. Persons shall be heard separately or in the<br>presence of other persons summoned to attend. In the latter case, regard<br>shall be had to the legitimate interest of the undertakings in the protection<br>of their business secrets.</p>
<p>4. The essential content of the statements made by each person heard shall<br>be recorded in minutes which shall be read and approved by him.</p>
<p>Article 14</p>
<p>Without prejudice to Article 6(2), information and summonses from the<br>EFTA Surveillance Authority shall be sent to the addressees by registered<br>letter with acknowledgement of receipt, or shall be delivered by and against<br>receipt.</p>
<p>Article 15</p>
<p>1. In fixing the periods provided for in Articles 4(8), 6, 9 and 10, the EFTA<br>Surveillance Authority shall have regard both to the time required for prep-<br>aration of comments and to the urgency of the case. A period shall be not<br>less than two weeks; it may be extended.</p>
<p>2. Periods shall run from the day following receipt of a communication or<br>delivery thereof by hand.</p>
<p>3. Written comments must reach the EFTA Surveillance Authority or be<br>dispatched by registered letter before expiry of the period. Where the period</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>239</p>
<p>would expire on a Sunday or a public holiday, it shall be extended up to the<br>end of the next following working day. For the purpose of calculating the<br>extension, public holidays shall, in cases where the relevant date is the date<br>of receipt of written comments, be those set out in Appendix 2 to this Proto-<br>col, and in cases where the relevant date is the date of dispatch, those ap-<br>pointed by law in the country of dispatch.</p>
<p>Article 16</p>
<p>Special provisions</p>
<p>The EFTA Surveillance Authority may submit to the Governments of the<br>EFTA States, in accordance with the provisions of Article 49 of this Agree-<br>ment, proposals for forms and complementary notes.</p>
<h2>CHAPTER XI PROCEDURE FOR THE<br>APPLICATION OF THE RULES ON COMPETITION TO<br>UNDERTAKINGS IN THE AIR TRANSPORT</h2>
<h2>SECTOR</h2>
<p>Article 1</p>
<p>Scope</p>
<p>1. This Chapter lays down detailed rules for the application of Articles 53<br>and 54 of the EEA Agreement to air transport services.</p>
<p>2. This Chapter shall apply only to international air transport between air-<br>ports within the territory covered by the EEA Agreement.</p>
<p>Article 2</p>
<p>Exceptions for certain technical agreements</p>
<p>1. The prohibition laid down in Article 53(1) of the EEA Agreement shall<br>not apply to the agreements, decisions and concerted practices listed in Ap-<br>pendix 7 to this Protocol, in so far as their sole object and effect is to achieve<br>technical improvements or cooperation. This list is not exhaustive.</p>
<p>2. If necessary, the EFTA Surveillance Authority may submit to the Gov-<br>ernments of the EFTA States, in accordance with the provisions of Article 49<br>of this Agreement, proposals for the amendment of the list in Appendix 7.</p>
<p>Article 3</p>
<p>Procedures on complaint or on the EFTA Surveillance Authority’s own<br>initiative</p>
<p>1. Acting on receipt of a complaint or on its own initiative, the EFTA Sur-<br>veillance Authority shall initiate procedures to terminate any infringement<br>of the provisions of Articles 53(1) or 54 of the EEA Agreement.</p>
<p>Complaints may be submitted by:</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol 4</p>
<p>240</p>
<p>(a) EFTA States;</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;natural or legal persons who claim a legitimate interest.</p>
<p>2. Upon application by the undertakings or associations of undertakings<br>concerned, the EFTA Surveillance Authority may certify that, on the basis<br>of the facts in its possession, there are no grounds under Article 53(1) or<br>Article 54 of the EEA Agreement for action on its part in respect of an agree-<br>ment, decision or concerted practice.</p>
<p>Article 4</p>
<p>Result of procedures on complaint or on the EFTA Surveillance<br>Authority’s own initiative</p>
<p>1. Where the EFTA Surveillance Authority finds that there has been an in-<br>fringement of Articles 53(1) or 54 of the EEA Agreement, it may by decision<br>require the undertakings or associations of undertakings concerned to bring<br>such an infringement to an end.</p>
<p>Without prejudice to the other provisions of this Chapter, the EFTA Sur-<br>veillance Authority may address recommendations for termination of the in-<br>fringement to the undertakings or associations of undertakings concerned<br>before taking a decision under the preceding subparagraph.</p>
<p>2. If the EFTA Surveillance Authority, acting on a complaint received, con-<br>cludes that, on the evidence before it, there are no grounds for intervention<br>under Articles 53(1) or 54 of the EEA Agreement in respect of any agree-<br>ment, decision or concerted practice, it shall take a decision rejecting the<br>complaint as unfounded.</p>
<p>3. If the EFTA Surveillance Authority, whether acting on a complaint re-<br>ceived or on its own initiative concludes that an agreement, decision or<br>concerted practice satisfies the provisions of both Article 53(1) and 53(3) of<br>the EEA Agreement, it shall take a decision applying paragraph 3 of the said<br>Article. Such a decision shall indicate the date from which it is to take effect.<br>This date may be prior to that of the decision.</p>
<p>Article 4a</p>
<p>Interim measures against anti-competitive practices</p>
<p>1. Without prejudice to the application of Article 4(1), where the EFTA<br>Surveillance Authority has clear prima facie evidence that certain practices<br>are contrary to Article 53 or 54 of the EEA Agreement and have the object<br>or effect of directly jeopardizing the existence of an air service, and where<br>recourse to normal procedures may not be sufficient to protect the air service<br>or the airline company concerned, it may by decision take interim measures<br>to ensure that these practices are not implemented or cease to be imple-<br>mented and give such instructions as are necessary to prevent the occurrence<br>of these practices until a decision under Article 4(1) is taken.</p>
<p>2. A decision taken pursuant to paragraph 1 shall apply for a period not ex-<br>ceeding six months. Article 8(5) shall not apply.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol 4</p>
<p>241</p>
<p>16 Riksdagen 1991/92. 1 saml. Nr 170. Bil. 16</p>
<p>The EFTA Surveillance Authority may review the initial decision, with or<br>without modification, for a period not exceeding three months. In such case,<br>Article 8(5) shall apply.</p>
<p>Article 5</p>
<p>Application of Article 53(3) of the EEA Agreement - objections</p>
<p>1. Undertakings and associations of undertakings which wish to seek ap-<br>plication of Article 53(3) of the EEA Agreement in respect of agreements,<br>decisions and concerted practices falling within the provisions of paragraph<br>1 of the said Article to which they are parties shall submit applications to the<br>EFTA Surveillance Authority.</p>
<p>2. If the EFTA Surveillance Authority judges an application admissible and<br>is in possession of all the available evidence and no action under Article 3<br>has been taken against the agreement, decision or concerted practice in<br>question, then it shall publish as soon as possible in the EEA Section of the<br>Official Journal of the European Communities a summary of the application<br>and invite all interested third parties and the EFTA States to submit their<br>comments to the EFTA Surveillance Authority within 30 days. Such publica-<br>tions shall have regard to the legitimate interest of undertakings in the pro-<br>tection of their business secrets.</p>
<p>3. Unless the EFTA Surveillance Authority notifies applicants, within 90<br>days of the date of such publication in the EEA Section of the Official<br>Journal of the European Communities, that there are serious doubts as to<br>the applicability of Article 53(3) of the EEA Agreement, the agreement, de-<br>cision or concerted practice shall be deemed exempt, in so far as it conforms<br>with the description given in the application, from the prohibition for the<br>time already elapsed and for a maximum of six years from the date of pub-<br>lication in the EEA Section of the Official Journal of the European Commu-<br>nities.</p>
<p>If the EFTA Surveillance Authority finds, after expiry of the 90-day time-<br>limit, but before expiry of the six-year period, that the conditions for apply-<br>ing Article 53(3) of the EEA Agreement are not satisfied, it shall issue a de-<br>cision declaring that the prohibition in Article 53(1) applies. Such decision<br>may be retroactive where the parties concerned have given inaccurate in-<br>formation or where they abuse an exemption from the provisions of<br>Article 53(1) or have contravened Article 54.</p>
<p>4. The EFTA Surveillance Authority may notify applicants as referred to in<br>the first subparagraph of paragraph 3; it shall do so if requested by an EFTA<br>State within 45 days of the forwarding to the EFTA State of the application<br>in accordance with Article 8(2). This request must be justified on the basis<br>of considerations relating to the competition rules of the EEA Agreement.</p>
<p>If it finds that the conditions of Article 53(1) and (3) of the EEA Agree-<br>ment are satisfied, the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall issue a decision<br>applying Article 53(3). The decision shall indicate the date from which it is<br>to take effect. This date may be prior to that of the application.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>242</p>
<p>Article 6</p>
<p>Duration and revocation of decisions applying Article 53(3) of the EEA<br>Agreement</p>
<p>1. Any decision applying Article 53(3) of the EEA Agreement adopted<br>under Articles 4 or 5 of this Chapter shall indicate the period for which it is<br>to be valid; normally such period shall not be less than six years. Conditions<br>and obligations may be attached to the decision.</p>
<p>2. The decision may be renewed if the conditions for applying Article 53(3)<br>of the EEA Agreement continue to be satisfied.</p>
<p>3. The EFTA Surveillance Authority may revoke or amend its decision or<br>prohibit specific acts by the parties:</p>
<p>(a) where there has been a change in any of the facts which were basic<br>to the making of the decision; or</p>
<p>(b) where the parties commit a breach of any obligation attached to the<br>decision; or</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;where the decision is based on incorrect information or was induced<br>by deceit; or</p>
<p>(d) where the parties abuse the exemption from the provisions of<br>Article 53(1) of the EEA Agreement granted to them by the de-<br>cision.</p>
<p>In cases falling under subparagraphs (b), (c) or (d), the decision may be re-<br>voked with retroactive effect.</p>
<p>Article 7</p>
<p>Powers</p>
<p>Subject to review of its decision by the EFTA Court, in accordance with<br>Article 108(2) of the EEA Agreement and with the relevant provisions of<br>this Agreement, the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall have sole power to<br>issue decisions pursuant to Article 53(3) of the EEA Agreement, on the con-<br>ditions set out in Article 56 of the EEA Agreement.</p>
<p>The authorities of the EFTA States shall retain the power to decide<br>whether any case falls under the provisions of Articles 53(1) or 54 of the<br>EEA Agreement, until such time as the EFTA Surveillance Authority has<br>initiated a procedure with a view to formulating a decision on the case in<br>question or has sent notification as provided by the first subparagraph of<br>Article 5(3) of this Chapter.</p>
<p>Article 8</p>
<p>Liaison with the authorities of the EFTA States</p>
<p>1. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall carry out the procedures pro-<br>vided for in this Chapter in close and constant liaison with the competent<br>authorities of the EFTA States; these authorities shall have the right to ex-<br>press their views on such procedures.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol 4</p>
<p>243</p>
<p>2. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall immediately forward to the com-<br>petent authorities of the EFTA States copies of the complaints and applica-<br>tions and of the most important documents sent to it or which it sends out in<br>the course of such procedures.</p>
<p>The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall forthwith transmit to the compet-<br>ent authorities of the EFTA States a copy of notifications, complaints and<br>information on opening of ex officio procedures received from the EC Com-<br>mission pursuant to Articles 2 and 10 of Protocol 23 to the EEA Agreement.</p>
<p>The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall forthwith transmit to the compet-<br>ent authorities of the EFTA States a copy of documents received from the<br>EC Commission pursuant to Article 7 of Protocol 23 to the EEA Agreement.</p>
<p>3. An Advisory Committee on Competition in Air Transport shall be con-<br>sulted prior to the taking of any decision following upon a procedure under<br>Article 3 or of any decision under the second subparagraph of Article 5(3), or<br>under the second subparagraph of paragraph 4 of the same Article or under<br>Article 6. The Advisory Committee shall also be consulted prior to a pro-<br>posal referred to in Article 19.</p>
<p>4. The Advisory Committee shall be composed of officials competent in the<br>sphere of air transport and agreements and dominant positions. Each EFTA<br>State shall nominate two officials to represent it, each of whom may be<br>replaced, in the event of his being prevented from attending, by another offi-<br>cial.</p>
<p>The EC Commission and the EC Member States shall be entitled to be<br>present in the Advisory Committee and to express their views therein. How-<br>ever, their representatives shall not have the right to vote.</p>
<p>5. Consultation shall take place at a joint meeting convened by the EFTA<br>Surveillance Authority; such a meeting shall be held not earlier than 14 days<br>after dispatch of the notice convening it. In respect of each case to be exam-<br>ined, this notice shall be accompanied by a summary of the case, together<br>with an indication of the most important documents, and a preliminary draft<br>decision.</p>
<p>In view of the participation provided for in the second subparagraph of<br>paragraph 4, the EC Commission shall receive an invitation to the meeting<br>and the relevant information as provided for in Article 6 of Protocol 23 to the<br>EEA Agreement.</p>
<p>6. The Advisory Committee may deliver an opinion notwithstanding that<br>some of its members or their alternates are not present. A report of the out-<br>come of the consultative proceedings shall be annexed to the draft decision.<br>It shall not be made public.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>Article 9</p>
<p>Requests for information</p>
<p>1. In carrying out the duties assigned to it by Articles 55 and 58 of the EEA<br>Agreement, by provisions set out in Protocol 23 and in Annex XIV to the<br></p>
<p>244</p>
<p>EEA Agreement or by provisions of this Chapter, the EFTA Surveillance<br>Authority may obtain all necessary information from the governments and<br>competent authorities of the EFTA States and from undertakings and associ-<br>ations of undertakings.</p>
<p>2. When sending a request for information to an undertaking or association<br>of undertakings, the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall forward a copy of<br>the request at the same time to the competent authority of the EFTA State<br>in whose territory the head office of the undertaking or association of under-<br>takings is situated.</p>
<p>3. In its request, the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall State the legal basis<br>and purpose of the request and also the penalties for supplying incorrect in-<br>formation provided for in Article 12(l)(b).</p>
<p>4. The owners of the undertakings or their representatives and, in the case<br>of legal persons or of companies, firms or associations having no legal per-<br>sonality, the person authorized to represent them by law or by their rules<br>shall be bound to supply the information requested.</p>
<p>5. When an undertaking or association of undertakings does not supply the<br>information requested within the time-limit fixed by the EFTA Surveillance<br>Authority, or supplies incomplete information, the EFTA Surveillance<br>Authority shall by decision require the information to be supplied. The de-<br>cision shall specify what information is required, fix an appropriate time-<br>limit within which it is to be supplied and indicate the penalties provided for<br>in Article 12(l)(b) and Article 13(l)(c), as well as the right to have the de-<br>cision reviewed by the EFTA Court in accordance with Article 108(2) of the<br>EEA Agreement and with the relevant provisions of this Agreement, in par-<br>ticular Article 35.</p>
<p>6. At the same time the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall send a copy of<br>its decision to the competent authority of the EFTA State in whose territory<br>the head office of the undertaking or association of undertakings is situated.</p>
<p>Article 10</p>
<p>Investigations by the authorities of the EFTA States</p>
<p>1. At the request of the EFTA Surveillance Authority, the competent auth-<br>orities of the EFTA States shall undertake the investigations which the<br>EFTA Surveillance Authority considers to be necessary under Article 11(1)<br>or which it has ordered by decision adopted pursuant to Article 11(3). The<br>officials of the competent authorities of the EFTA States responsible for con-<br>ducting these investigations shall exercise their powers upon production of<br>an authorization in writing issued by the competent authority of the EFTA<br>State in whose territory the investigation is to be made. Such an authoriza-<br>tion shall specify the subject matter and purpose of the investigation.</p>
<p>2. If so requested by the EFTA Surveillance Authority or by the competent<br>authority of the EFTA State in whose territory the investigation is to be</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>245</p>
<p>made, EFTA Surveillance Authority officials may assist the officials of the<br>competent authority in carrying out their duties.</p>
<p>Article 11</p>
<p>Investigating powers of the EFTA Surveillance Authority</p>
<p>1. In carrying out the duties assigned to it by Articles 55 and 58 of the EEA<br>Agreement, by provisions set out in Protocol 23 and in Annex XIV to the<br>EEA Agreement or by provisions of this Chapter, the EFTA Surveillance<br>Authority may undertake all necessary investigations into undertakings and<br>associations of undertakings. To this end the officials authorized by the<br>EFTA Surveillance Authority shall be empowered:</p>
<p>(a) to examine the books and other business records;</p>
<p>(b) to take copies of, or extracts from, the books and business records;</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;to ask for oral explanations on the spot;</p>
<p>(d) to enter any premises, land and vehicles used by undertakings or as-<br>sociations of undertakings.</p>
<p>2. The authorized officials of the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall exer-<br>cise their powers upon production of an authorization in writing specifying<br>the subject matter and purpose of the investigation and the penalties pro-<br>vided for in Article 12(l)(c) in cases where production of the required books<br>or other business records is incomplete. In good time, before the investi-<br>gation, the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall inform the competent auth-<br>ority of the EFTA State, in whose territory the same is to be made, of the<br>investigation and the identity of the authorized officials. The EFTA Surveil-<br>lance Authority shall also provide such an authorization to representatives<br>of the EC Commission who shall take part in the investigation in accordance<br>with Article 8(4) of Protocol 23 to the EEA Agreement.</p>
<p>3. Undertakings and associations of undertakings shall submit to investi-<br>gations ordered by decision of the EFTA Surveillance Authority. The de-<br>cision shall specify the subject matter and purpose of the investigation, ap-<br>point the date on which it is to begin and indicate the penalties provided for<br>in Articles 12(l)(c) and 13(l)(d) and the right to have the decision reviewed<br>by the EFTA Court.</p>
<p>4. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall take the decisions mentioned in<br>paragraph 3 after consultation with the competent authority of the EFTA<br>State in whose territory the investigation is to be made.</p>
<p>5. Officials of the competent authority of the EFTA State in whose territory<br>the investigation is to be made may assist the EFTA Surveillance Authority<br>officials in carrying out their duties, at the request of such authority or of the<br>EFTA Surveillance Authority.</p>
<p>6. Where an undertaking opposes an investigation ordered pursuant to this<br>Article, the EFTA State concerned shall afford the necessary assistance to<br>the officials authorized by the EFTA Surveillance Authority to enable them<br>to make their investigation. To this end, EFTA States shall take the necess-<br></p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol 4</p>
<p>246</p>
<p>ary measures after consultation of the EFTA Surveillance Authority within<br>six months of the entry into force of the EEA Agreement.</p>
<p>Article 12</p>
<p>Fines</p>
<p>1. The EFTA Surveillance Authority may, by decision, impose fines on un-<br>dertakings or associations of undertakings of from 100 to 5 000 ECU where,<br>intentionally or negligently:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;they supply incorrect or misleading information in connection with<br>an application pursuant to Article 3(2) or Article 5; or</p>
<p>(b) they supply incorrect information in response to a request made pur-<br>suant to Article 9(3) or (5), or do not supply information within the<br>time-limit fixed by a decision adopted under Article 9(5); or</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;they produce the required books or other business records in incom-<br>plete form during investigations under Article 10 or Article 11, or re-<br>fuse to submit to an investigation ordered by decision taken pursu-<br>ant to Article 11(3).</p>
<p>2. The EFTA Surveillance Authority may, by decision, impose fines on un-<br>dertakings or associations of undertakings of from 1 000 to 1000 000 ECU,<br>or a sum in excess thereof, but not exceeding 10% of the turnover in the<br>preceding business year of the undertakings participating in the infringe-<br>ment, where either intentionally or negligently they:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;infringe Article 53(1) or Article 54 of the EEA Agreement; or</p>
<p>(b) commit a breach of any obligation imposed pursuant to Article 6(1)<br>of this Chapter.</p>
<p>In fixing the amount of the fine, regard shall be had both to the gravity and<br>to the duration of the infringement.</p>
<p>3. Article 8 shall apply.</p>
<p>4. Decisions taken pursuant to paragraphs 1 and 2 shall not be of a penal<br>nature.</p>
<p>5. The fines provided for in paragraph 2(a) shall not be imposed in respect<br>of acts taking place after notification to the EFTA Surveillance Authority<br>and before its decision in application of Article 53(3) of the EEA Agree-<br>ment, provided they fall within the limits of the activity described in the noti-<br>fication.</p>
<p>However, this provision shall not have effect where the EFTA Surveil-<br>lance Authority has informed the undertakings or associations of undertak-<br>ings concerned that, after preliminary examination, it is of the opinion that<br>Article 53(1) of the EEA Agreement applies and that application of<br>Article53(3) is not justified.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court<br>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>247</p>
<p>Article 13</p>
<p>Periodic penalty payments</p>
<p>1. By decision, the EFTA Surveillance Authority may impose periodic pen-<br>alty payments on undertakings or associations of undertakings of from 50 to<br>1 000 ECU per day, calculated from the date appointed by the decision, in<br>order to compel them:</p>
<p>(a) to put an end to an infringement of Article 53(1) or Article 54 of the<br>EEAAgreement, the termination ofwhich has been ordered pursu-<br>ant to Article 4 of this Chapter;</p>
<p>(b) to refrain from any act prohibited under Article 6(3);</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;to supply complete and correct information which has been re-<br>quested by decision, taken pursuant to Article 9(5);</p>
<p>(d) to submit to an investigation which has been ordered by decision<br>taken pursuant to Article 11(3);</p>
<p>(e) to comply with any measure imposed by decision taken under<br>Article 4a.</p>
<p>2. When the undertakings or associations of undertakings have satisfied the<br>obligation which it was the purpose of the periodic penalty payment to en-<br>force, the EFTA Surveillance Authority may fix the total amount of the peri-<br>odic penalty payment at a lower figure than that which would result from the<br>original decision.</p>
<p>3. Article 8 shall apply.</p>
<p>Article 14</p>
<p>Review by the EFTA Court</p>
<p>The EFTA Court, in accordance with Article 108(2) of the EEA Agreement<br>and with the relevant provisions of this Agreement, shall have unlimited jur-<br>isdiction within the meaning of Article 35 of this Agreement to review de-<br>cisions whereby the EFTA Surveillance Authority has fixed a fine or periodic<br>penalty payment; it may cancel, reduce or increase the fine or periodic pen-<br>alty payment imposed.</p>
<p>Article 15</p>
<p>ECU</p>
<p>For the purpose of applying Articles 12 to 14, ’ECU’ means the ECU as de-<br>fined by the competent authorities of the European Communities.</p>
<p>Article 16</p>
<p>Hearing of the parties and of third persons</p>
<p>1. Before refusing the certificate mentioned in Article 3(2), or taking de-<br>cisions as provided for in Articles 4, 4a, 5(3) second subparagraph and 5(4),<br>6(3), 12 and 13, the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall give the undertakings<br></p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>248</p>
<p>or associations of undertakings concerned the opportunity of being heard on<br>the matters to which the EFTA Surveillance Authority takes, or has taken,<br>objection.</p>
<p>2. If the EFTA Surveillance Authority or the competent authorities of the<br>EFTA States consider it necessary, they may also hear other natural or legal<br>persons. Applications by such persons to be heard shall be granted when<br>they show a sufficient interest.</p>
<p>3. When the EFTA Surveillance Authority intends to take a decision pursu-<br>ant to Article 53(3) of the EEA Agreement, it shall publish a summary of<br>the relevant agreement, decision or concerted practice in the EEA Section<br>of the Official Journal of the European Communities and invite all interested<br>third parties to submit their observations within a period, not being less than<br>one month, which it shall fix. Publication shall have regard to the legitimate<br>interest of undertakings in the protection of their business secrets.</p>
<p>Article 17</p>
<p>Professional secrecy</p>
<p>1. Without prejudice to Article 9 of Protocol 23 to the EEA Agreement, in-<br>formation acquired as a result of the application of Articles 9 to 11 of this<br>Chapter or Article 58 of the EEA Agreement and Protocol 23 thereto shall<br>be used only for the purpose of the relevant request or investigation.</p>
<p>2. Without prejudice to the provisions of Articles 16 and 18, the EFTA Sur-<br>veillance Authority and the competent authorities of the EFTA States, their<br>officials and other servants shall not disclose information of a kind covered<br>by the obligation of professional secrecy and which has been acquired by<br>them as a result of the application of this Protocol or Article 58 of the EEA<br>Agreement and Protocol 23 thereto. This obligation shall also apply to the<br>representatives of the EC Commission and of the EC Member States who<br>participate in the Advisory Committee pursuant to Article 8(4) and in the<br>hearing pursuant to Article 11(2) of Chapter XII.</p>
<p>3. The provisions of paragraphs 1 and 2 shall not prevent publication of gen-<br>eral information or of surveys which do not contain information relating to<br>particular undertakings or associations of undertakings.</p>
<p>Article 18</p>
<p>Publication of decisions</p>
<p>1. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall publish the decision which it ad-<br>opts pursuant to Articles3(2), 4, 5(3) second subparagraph, 5(4) and 6(3).</p>
<p>2. The publication shall State the names of the parties and the main contents<br>of the decision; it shall have regard to the legitimate interest of undertakings<br>in the protection of their business secrets.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>249</p>
<p>Article 19</p>
<p>Special provisions</p>
<p>The EFTA Surveillance Authority may submit to the Governments of the<br>EFTA States, in accordance with the provisions of Article 49 of this Agree-<br>ment, proposals for forms to be used for complaints pursuant to Article 3<br>and applications pursuant to Articles 3(2) and 5, as well as proposals for com-<br>plementary notes to the forms.</p>
<p>CHAPTER XII FORM, CONTENT AND OTHER<br>DETAILS OF COMPLAINTS AND OF APPLICATIONS,<br>AND THE HEARINGS PROVIDED FOR IN</p>
<p>CHAPTER XI LAYING DOWN THE PROCEDURE FOR<br>THE APPLICATION OF THE RULES OF<br>COMPETITION TO UNDERTAKINGS IN THE AIR<br>TRANSPORT SECTOR</p>
<p>SECTION I</p>
<p>COMPLAINTS AND APPLICATIONS</p>
<p>Article 1</p>
<p>Complaints</p>
<p>1. Complaints pursuant to Article3(l) of ChapterXI shall be submitted in<br>writing in an official language of an EFTA State or the European Commun-<br>ity, their form, content and other details being left to the discretion of com-<br>plainants.</p>
<p>2. Complaints may be submitted by:</p>
<p>(a) EFTA States;</p>
<p>(b) natural or legal persons who claim a legitimate interest.</p>
<p>3. When representatives of undertakings, of associations of undertakings,<br>or of natural or legal persons sign such complaints, they shall produce written<br>proof that they are authorized to act.</p>
<p>Article 2</p>
<p>Persons entitled to submit applications</p>
<p>1. Any undertaking which is party to agreements, decisions or practices of<br>the kind described in Articles53(1) and 54 of the EEAAgreement may sub-<br>mit an application under Articles 3(2) and 5 of Chapter XI. Where the ap-<br>plication is submitted by some but not all of the undertakings concerned,<br>they shall give notice to the others.</p>
<p>2. Where applications under Articles 3(2) and 5 of Chapter XI are signed by<br>representatives of undertakings, of associations of undertakings, or of nat-<br>ural or legal persons, such representatives shall produce written proof that<br>they are authorized to act.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>250</p>
<p>3. Where a joint application is submitted, a joint representative shall be ap-<br>pointed.</p>
<p>Article 3</p>
<p>Submission of applications</p>
<p>1. Applications pursuant to Articles3(2) and 5 of ChapterXI shall be sub-<br>mitted on forms issued for this purpose by the Governments of the EFTA<br>States, by common accord, as shown in Appendix 8, or by the EC Commis-<br>sion.</p>
<p>2. Several participating undertakings may submit an application on a single<br>form.</p>
<p>3. Applications shall contain the information requested in the form.</p>
<p>4. Nine copies of each application and of the supporting documents shall be<br>submitted to the EFTA Surveillance Authority.</p>
<p>5. The supporting documents shall be either originals or copies. Copies must<br>be certified as true copies of the original.</p>
<p>6. Applications shall be in one of the official languages of an EFTA State or<br>the European Community. Supporting documents shall be submitted in their<br>original language. Where the original language is not an official language of<br>an EFTA State or the European Community, a translation in one of these<br>languages shall be attached.</p>
<p>7. The date of submission of an application shall be the date on which it is<br>received by the EFTA Surveillance Authority, without prejudice to<br>Article 11 of Protocol 23 to the EEA Agreement. Where, however, the ap-<br>plication is sent by registered post, it shall be deemed to have been received<br>on the date shown on the postmark of the place of posting.</p>
<p>8. Where an application submitted pursuant to Articles 3(2) and 5 of<br>Chapter XI falls outside the scope of that Chapter, the EFTA Surveillance<br>Authority shall without delay inform the applicant that it intends to examine<br>the application under the provisions of such other acts referred to in Annex<br>XIV to the EEA Agreement as is applicable to the case; however, the date<br>of submission of the application shall be the date resulting from paragraph 7.<br>The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall inform the applicant of its reasons<br>and fix a period for him to submit any comments in writing before it conducts<br>its appraisal pursuant to the provisions of that other act.</p>
<h2>SECTION II</h2>
<p>HEARINGS</p>
<p>Article 4</p>
<p>Before Consulting the Advisory Committee on Competition in Air Trans-<br>port, the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall hold a hearing pursuant to<br>Article 16(1) of Chapter XI.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>251</p>
<p>Article 5</p>
<p>1. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall inform undertakings and associ-<br>ations of undertakings in writing of the objections raised against them. The<br>communication shall be addressed to each of them or to a joint agent ap-<br>pointed by them.</p>
<p>2. The EFTA Surveillance Authority may inform the parties by giving notice<br>in the EEA Section of the Official Journal of the European Communities, if<br>from the circumstances of the case this appears appropriate, in particular<br>where notice is to be given to a number of undertakings but no joint agent<br>has been appointed. The notice shall have regard to the legitimate interest<br>of the undertakings in the protection of their business secrets.</p>
<p>3. A fine or a periodic penalty payment may be imposed on an undertaking<br>or association of undertakings only if the objections were notified in the<br>manner provided for in paragraph 1.</p>
<p>4. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall, when giving notice of objec-<br>tions, fix a period within which the undertakings and associations of under-<br>takings may inform the EFTA Surveillance Authority of their view.</p>
<p>Article 6</p>
<p>1. Undertakings and associations of undertakings shall, within the ap-<br>pointed period, make known in writing their views concerning the objections<br>raised against them.</p>
<p>2. They may in their written comments set out all matters relevant to their<br>defence.</p>
<p>3. They may attach any relevant documents in proof of the facts set out.<br>They may also propose that the EFTA Surveillance Authority hear persons<br>who may corroborate those facts.</p>
<p>Article 7</p>
<p>The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall in its decision deal only with those<br>objections raised against undertakings and associations of undertakings in<br>respect of which they have been afforded the opportunity of making known<br>their views.</p>
<p>Article 8</p>
<p>If natural or legal persons showing a sufficient interest apply to be heard pur-<br>suant to Article 16(2) of Chapter XI the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall<br>afford them the opportunity of making known their views in writing within<br>such period as it shall fix.</p>
<p>Article 9</p>
<p>Where the EFTA Surveillance Authority, having received a complaint pur-<br>suant to Article 3(1) of Chapter XI considers that on the basis of the informa-</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol 4</p>
<p>252</p>
<p>tion in its possession there are insufficient grounds for acting on the com-<br>plaint, it shall inform the persons who submitted the complaint of its reasons<br>and fix a period for them to submit any further comments in writing.</p>
<p>Article 10</p>
<p>1. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall afford to persons who have so<br>requested in their written comments the opportunity to put forward their ar-<br>guments orally, if those persons show a sufficient interest or if the EFTA<br>Surveillance Authority proposes to impose on them a fine or periodic pen-<br>alty payment.</p>
<p>2. The EFTA Surveillance Authority may likewise afford to any other per-<br>son the opportunity of orally expressing his views.</p>
<p>Article 11</p>
<p>1. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall summon the persons to be heard<br>to attend on such date as it shall appoint.</p>
<p>2. It shall forthwith transmit a copy of the summons to the competent auth-<br>orities of the EFTA States, who may appoint an official to take part in the<br>hearing. Likewise, the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall invite the EC<br>Commission to be represented at the hearing. The invitation shall also ex-<br>tend to the EC Member States.</p>
<p>Article 12</p>
<p>1. Hearings shall be conducted by the persons appointed by the EFTA Sur-<br>veillance Authority for that purpose.</p>
<p>2. Persons summoned to attend shall either appear in person or be<br>represented by legal representatives or by representatives authorized by<br>their constitution. Undertakings and associations of undertakings may more-<br>over be represented by a duly authorized agent appointed from among their<br>permanent staff.</p>
<p>Persons heard by the EFTA Surveillance Authority may be assisted by<br>lawyers or advisers who are entitled to plead before the EFTA Court, or by<br>other qualified persons.</p>
<p>3. Hearings shall not be public. Persons shall be heard separately or in the<br>presence of other persons summoned to attend. In the latter case, regard<br>shall be had to the legitimate interest of the undertakings in the protection<br>of their business secrets.</p>
<p>4. The essential content of the statements made by each person heard shall<br>be recorded in minutes which shall be read and approved by him.</p>
<p>Article 13</p>
<p>Without prejudice to Article 5(2), information and summonses from the<br>EFTA Surveillance Authority shall be sent to the addressees by registered<br></p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>253</p>
<p>letter with acknowledgement of receipt, or shall be delivered by hand against<br>receipt.</p>
<p>Article 14</p>
<p>1. In fixing the periods provided for in Articles 3(8), 5, 8 and 9, the EFTA<br>Surveillance Authority shall have regard both to the time required for prep-<br>aration of comments and to the urgency of the case. A period shall be not<br>less than two weeks; it may be extended.</p>
<p>2. Periods shall run from the day following receipt of a communication or<br>delivery thereof by hand.</p>
<p>3. Written comments must reach the EFTA Surveillance Authority or be<br>dispatched by registered letter before expiry of the period. Where the period<br>would expire on a Sunday or a public holiday, it shall be extended up to the<br>end of the next following working day. For the purpose of calculating the<br>extension, public holidays shall, in cases where the relevant date is the date<br>of receipt of written comments, be those set out in Appendix 2 to this Proto-<br>col, and in cases where the relevant date is the date of dispatch, those ap-<br>pointed by law in the country of dispatch.</p>
<p>Article 15</p>
<p>Special provisions</p>
<p>The EFTA Surveillance Authority may submit to the Governments of the<br>EFTA States, in accordance with the provisions of Article 49 of this Agree-<br>ment, proposals for forms and complementary notes.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>254</p>
<h1>PART III CONTROL OF</h1>
<h1>CONCENTRATIONS</h1>
<h2>CHAPTER XIII RULES RELATING TO CONTROL<br>OF CONCENTRATIONS BETWEEN UNDERTAKINGS</h2>
<p>Due to the division of the text of Regulation (EEC) No 4064/89 between Annex<br>XIV to the EEA Agreement (substantive rules) and the present Chapter<br>(procedural rules), the text, as adapted, of Articles 1 to 5 is to be found in the<br>act referred to in point 1 of Annex XIV to the EEA Agreement (Regulation<br>(EEC) No 4064/89). The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall carry out the<br>control of concentration in accordance with the provisions of Article 57 of the<br>EEA Agreement, in particularparagraph 2(b).</p>
<p>Articles 1 to 5</p>
<p>(No text)</p>
<p>Article 6</p>
<p>Examination of the notification and initiation of proceedings</p>
<p>1. The EFTA Surveillance Authority, in accordance with the provisions of<br>Article 57(1) and (2)(b) of the EEAAgreement, shall examine the notifica-<br>tion as soon as it is received.</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;Where it concludes that the concentration notified does not fall<br>within the scope of the act referred to in point 1 of Annex XIV to<br>the EEAAgreement (Regulation (EEC) No 4064/89), it shall record<br>that finding by means of a decision.</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;Where it finds that the concentration notified, although falling<br>within the scope of the said act, does not raise serious doubts as to its<br>compatibility with the functioning of the EEA Agreement, it shall<br>decide not to oppose it and shall declare that it is compatible with<br>the functioning of the EEA Agreement.</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;If, on the other hand, it finds that the concentration notified falls<br>within the scope of the said act and raises serious doubts as to its<br>compatibility with the functioning of the EEA Agreement, it shall<br>decide to initiate proceedings.</p>
<p>2. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall notify its decision to the under-<br>takings concerned and the competent authorities of the EFTA States without<br>delay.</p>
<p>Article 7</p>
<p>Suspension of concentrations</p>
<p>1. For the purposes of paragraph 2 a concentration as defined in Article 1 of<br>the act referred to in point 1 of Annex XIV to the EEAAgreement (Regula-<br>tion (EEC) No 4064/89) shall not be put into effect either before its notifica-<br>tion or within the first three weeks following its notification.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol 4</p>
<p>255</p>
<p>2. Where the EFTA Surveillance Authority, following a preliminary exam-<br>ination of the notification within the period provided for in paragraph 1,<br>finds it necessary in order to ensure the full effectiveness of any decision<br>taken later pursuant to Article 8(3) and (4), it may decide on its own initiat-<br>ive to continue the suspension of a concentration in whole or in part until it<br>takes a final decision, or to take other interim measures to that effect.</p>
<p>3. Paragraphs 1 and 2 shall not impede the implementation of a public bid<br>which has been notified to the EFTA Surveillance Authority in accordance<br>with Article 4(1) of the said act, provided that the acquirer does not exercise<br>the voting rights attached to the securities in question or does so only to<br>maintain the full value of those investments and on the basis of a derogation<br>granted by the EFTA Surveillance Authority pursuant to paragraph 4.</p>
<p>4. The EFTA Surveillance Authority may, on request, grant a derogation<br>from the obligations imposed in paragraphs 1, 2 or 3 in order to prevent ser-<br>ious damage to one or more undertakings concerned by a concentration or<br>to a third party. That derogation may be made subject to conditions and ob-<br>ligations in order to ensure conditions of effective competition. A derogation<br>may be applied for and granted at any time, even before notification or after<br>the transaction.</p>
<p>5. The validity of any transaction carried out in contravention of paragraph<br>1 or 2 shall be dependent on a decision pursuant to Article 6( 1)(b) or 8(2) or<br>(3) or on a presumption pursuant to Article 10(6).</p>
<p>This Article shall, however, have no effect on the validity of transactions<br>in securities including those convertible into other securities admitted to<br>trading on a market which is regulated and supervised by authorities recog-<br>nized by public bodies, operates regularly and is accessible directly or<br>indirectly to the public, unless the buyer and seller knew or ought to have<br>known that the transaction was carried out in contravention of paragraph 1<br>or 2.</p>
<p>Article 8</p>
<p>Powers of decision of the EFTA Surveillance Authority</p>
<p>1. Without prejudice to Article 9, all proceedings initiated pursuant to<br>Article 6(l)(c) shall be closed by means of a decision as provided for in para-<br>graphs 2 to 5.</p>
<p>2. Where the EFTA Surveillance Authority finds that, following modifica-<br>tion by the undertakings concerned if necessary, a notified concentration ful-<br>fils the criterion laid down in Article 2(2) of the act referred to in point 1 of<br>Annex XIV to the EEAAgreement (Regulation (EEC) No 4064/89), it shall<br>issue a decision declaring the concentration compatible with the functioning<br>of the EEA Agreement.</p>
<p>It may attach to its decision conditions and obligations intended to ensure<br>that the undertakings concerned comply with the commitments they have<br>entered into vis-ä-vis the EFTA Surveillance Authority with a view to modi-</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>256</p>
<p>fying the original concentration plan. The decision declaring the concentra-<br>tion compatible shall also cover restrictions directly related and necessary to<br>the implementation of the concentration.</p>
<p>3. Where the EFTA Surveillance Authority finds that a concentration fulfils<br>the criterion laid down in Article 2(3) of the said act, it shall issue a decision<br>declaring that the concentration is incompatible with the functioning of the<br>EEA Agreement.</p>
<p>4. Where a concentration has already been implemented, the EFTA Sur-<br>veillance Authority may, in a decision pursuant to paragraph 3 or by separate<br>decision, require the undertakings or assets brought together to be separated<br>or the cessation of joint control or any other action that may be appropriate<br>in order to restore conditions of effective competition.</p>
<p>5. The EFTA Surveillance Authority may revoke the decision it has taken<br>pursuant to paragraph 2 where:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;the declaration of compatibility is based on incorrect information for<br>which one of the undertakings is responsible or where it has been<br>obtained by deceit; or</p>
<p>(b) the undertakings concerned commit a breach of an obligation at-<br>tached to the decision.</p>
<p>6. In the case referred to in paragraph 5, the EFTA Surveillance Authority<br>may take a decision under paragraph 3, without being bound by the deadline<br>referred to in Article 10(3).</p>
<p>Article 9</p>
<p>Referral to the competent authorities of the EFTA States</p>
<p>1. The EFTA Surveillance Authority may, by means of a decision notified<br>without delay to the undertakings concerned and the competent authorities<br>of the other EFTA States, refer a notified concentration to the competent<br>authorities of the EFTA State concerned in the following circumstances.</p>
<p>2. Within three weeks of the date of receipt of the copy of the notification<br>an EFTA State may inform the EFTA Surveillance Authority which shall<br>inform the undertakings concerned that a concentration threatens to create<br>or to strengthen a dominant position as a result of which effective competi-<br>tion would be significantly impeded on a market, within that State, which<br>presents all the characteristics of a distinct market, be it a substantial part of<br>the territory of the EFTA States or not.</p>
<p>3. If the EFTA Surveillance Authority considers that, having regard to the<br>market for the products or services in question and the geographical refer-<br>ence market within the meaning of paragraph 7, there is such a distinct mar-<br>ket and that such a threat exists, either:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;it shall itself deal with the case in order to maintain or restore effect-<br>ive competition on the market concerned; or</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;it shall refer the case to the competent authorities of the EFTA State</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>257</p>
<p>17 Riksdagen 199H92. 1 saml. Nr 170. Bil. 16<br></p>
<p>concerned with a view to the application of that Statc’s national<br>competition law.</p>
<p>If, however, the EFTA Surveillance Authority considers that such a distinct<br>market or threat does not exist it shall adopt a decision to that effect which<br>it shall address to the EFTA State concerned.</p>
<p>4. A decision to refer or not to refer pursuant to paragraph 3 shall be taken<br>where:</p>
<p>(a) as a general rule within the six-week period provided for in<br>Article 10(1), second paragraph, where the EFTA Surveillance<br>Authority, pursuant to Article 6(l)(b), has not initiated proceed-<br>ings; or</p>
<p>(b) within three months at most of the notification of the concentration<br>concerned where the EFTA Surveillance Authority has initiated<br>proceedings under Article 6(l)(c), without taking the preparatory<br>steps in order to adopt the necessary measures under Article 8(2),<br>second subparagraph, (3) or (4) to maintain or restore effective<br>competition on the market concerned.</p>
<p>5. If within the three months referred to in paragraph 4(b) the EFTA Sur-<br>veillance Authority, despite a reminder from the EFTA State concerned, has<br>not taken a decision on referral in accordance with paragraph 3 nor has taken<br>the preparatory steps referred to in paragraph 4(b), it shall be deemed to<br>have taken a decision to refer the case to the EFTA State concerned in ac-<br>cordance with paragraph 3(b).</p>
<p>6. The publication of any report or the announcement of the findings of the<br>examination of the concentration by the competent authority of the EFTA<br>State concerned shall be effected not more than four months after the EFTA<br>Surveillance Authority’s referral.</p>
<p>7. The geographical reference market shall consist of the area in which the<br>undertakings concerned are involved in the supply and demand of products<br>or services, in which the conditions of competition are sufficiently homogen-<br>eous and which can be distinguished from neighbouring areas because, in<br>particular, conditions of competition are appreciably different in those areas.<br>This assessment should take account in particular of the nature and charac-<br>teristics of the products or services concerned, of the existence of entry bar-<br>riers or of consumer preferences, of appreciable differences of the undertak-<br>ings’ market shares between the area concerned and neighbouring areas or<br>of substantial price differences.</p>
<p>8. In applying the provisions of this Article, the EFTA State concerned may<br>take only the measures strictly necessary to safeguard or restore effective<br>competition on the market concerned.</p>
<p>9. In accordance with the relevant provisions of the EEA Agreement, any<br>EFTA State may appeal to the EFTA Court in accordance with<br>Article 108(2) of the EEA Agreement and with the relevant provisions of</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>258</p>
<p>this Agreement, and in particular request the application of Article 41 of this<br>Agreement, for the purpose of applying its national competition law.</p>
<p>10. This Article will be reviewed before the end of the year 1993.</p>
<p>Article 10</p>
<p>Time limits for initiating proceedings and for decisions</p>
<p>1. The decisions referred to in Article 6(1) must be taken within one month<br>at most. That period shall begin on the day following that of the receipt of<br>a notification or, if the information to be supplied with the notification is<br>incomplete, on the day following that of the receipt of the complete informa-<br>tion. That period shall be increased to six weeks if the EFTA Surveillance<br>Authority receives a request from an EFTA State in accordance with Article<br>9(2).</p>
<p>2. Decisions taken pursuant to Article 8(2) concerning notified concentra-<br>tions must be taken as soon as it appears that the serious doubts referred to<br>in Article 6(l)(c) have been removed, particularly as a result of modifica-<br>tions made by the undertakings concerned, and at the latest by the deadline<br>laid down in paragraph 3.</p>
<p>3. Without prejudice to Article 8(6), decisions taken pursuant to<br>Article 8(3) concerning notified concentrations must be taken within not<br>more than four months of the date on which the proceeding is initiated.</p>
<p>4. The period set by paragraph 3 shall exceptionally be suspended where,<br>owing to circumstances for which one of the undertakings involved in the<br>concentration is responsible, the EFTA Surveillance Authority has had to<br>request information by decision pursuant to Article 11 or to order an investi-<br>gation by decision pursuant to Article 13.</p>
<p>5. Where the EFTA Court gives a judgment which annuls the whole or part<br>of an EFTA Surveillance Authority decision taken under this Chapter, the<br>periods laid down in this Chapter shall start again from the date of the judg-<br>ment.</p>
<p>6. Where the EFTA Surveillance Authority has not taken a decision in ac-<br>cordance with Article 6( 1)(b) or (c) or Article 8(2) or (3) within the deadlines<br>set in paragraphs 1 and 3 respectively, the concentration shall be deemed to<br>have been declared compatible with the functioning of the EEA Agreement,<br>without prejudice to Article 9.</p>
<p>Article 11</p>
<p>Requests for information</p>
<p>1. In carrying out the duties assigned to it by Articles 57 or 58 of the EEA<br>Agreement, by provisions set out in Protocol 24 and in Annex XIV to the<br>EEA Agreement and by the provisions of this Chapter, the EFTA Surveil-<br>lance Authority may obtain all necessary information from the Governments</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>259</p>
<p>and competent authorities of the EFTA States, from the persons referred to<br>in Article 3(l)(b) of the act referred to in point 1 of Annex XIV to the EEA<br>Agreement (Regulation (EEC) No 4064/89), and from undertakings and as-<br>sociations of undertakings.</p>
<p>2. When sending a request for information to a person, an undertaking or<br>an association of undertakings, the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall at the<br>same time send a copy of the request to the competent authority of the EFTA<br>State within the territory of which the residence of the person or the seat of<br>the undertaking or association of undertakings is situated.</p>
<p>3. In its request the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall State the legal basis<br>and the purpose of the request and also the penalties provided for in<br>Article 14(l)(c) for supplying incorrect information.</p>
<p>4. The information requested shall be provided, in the case of undertakings,<br>by their owners or their representatives and, in the case of legal persons,<br>companies or firms, or of associations having no legal personality, by the per-<br>sons authorized to represent them by law or by their statutes.</p>
<p>5. Where a person, an undertaking or an association of undertakings does<br>not provide the information requested within the period fixed by the EFTA<br>Surveillance Authority or provides incomplete information, the EFTA Sur-<br>veillance Authority shall by decision require the information to be provided.<br>The decision shall specify what information is required, fix an appropriate<br>period within which it is to be supplied and State the penalties provided for<br>in Articles 14(l)(c) and 15(l)(a) and the right to have the decision reviewed<br>by the EFTA Court in accordance with Article 108(2) of the EEA Agree-<br>ment and with the relevant provisions of this Agreement, in particular<br>Article 35.</p>
<p>6. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall at the same time send a copy of<br>its decision to the competent authority of the EFTA State within the territory<br>of which the residence of the person or the seat of the undertaking or associ-<br>ation of undertakings is situated.</p>
<p>Article 12</p>
<p>Investigations by the authorities of the EFTA States</p>
<p>1. At the request of the EFTA Surveillance Authority, the competent auth-<br>orities of the EFTA States shall undertake the investigations which the<br>EFTA Surveillance Authority considers to be necessary under Article 13(1),<br>or which it has ordered by decision pursuant to Article 13(3). The officials of<br>the competent authorities of the EFTA States responsible for conducting<br>those investigations shall exercise their powers upon production of an au-<br>thorization in writing issued by the competent authority of the EFTA State<br>within the territory of which the investigation is to be carried out. Such au-<br>thorization shall specify the subject matter and purpose of the investigation.</p>
<p>2. If so requested by the EFTA Surveillance Authority or by the competent<br>authority of the EFTA State within the territory of which the investigation is</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol4</p>
<p>260</p>
<p>to be carried out, officials of the EFTA Surveillance Authority may assist the<br>officials of that authority in carrying out their duties.</p>
<p>Article 13</p>
<p>Investigative powers of the EFTA Surveillance Authority</p>
<p>1. In carrying out the duties assigned to it by Articles 57 and 58 of the EEA<br>Agreement, by provisions set out in Protocol 24 and in Annex XIV to the<br>EEA Agreement and by the provisions of this Chapter, the EFTA Surveil-<br>lance Authority may undertake all necessary investigations into undertak-<br>ings and associations of undertakings.</p>
<p>To that end the officials authorized by the EFTA Surveillance Authority<br>shall be empowered:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;to examine the books and other business records;</p>
<p>(b) to take or demand copies of or extracts from the books and business<br>records;</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;to ask for oral explanations on the spot;</p>
<p>(d) to enter any premises, land and means of transport of undertakings.</p>
<p>2. The officials of the EFTA Surveillance Authority authorized to carry out<br>the investigations shall exercise their powers on production of an authoriza-<br>tion in writing specifying the subject matter and purpose of the investigation<br>and the penalties provided for in Article 14(l)(d) in cases where production<br>of the required books or other business records is incomplete. In good time<br>before the investigation, the EFTA Surveillance Authority shall inform, in<br>writing, the competent authority of the EFTA State within the territory of<br>which the investigation is to be carried out of the investigation and of the<br>identities of the authorized officials. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall<br>also provide such an authorization to representatives of the EC Commission<br>who shall take part in the investigation in accordance with Article 8(5) of<br>Protocol 24 to the EEA Agreement.</p>
<p>3. Undertakings and associations of undertakings shall submit to investi-<br>gations ordered by decision of the EFTA Surveillance Authority. The de-<br>cision shall specify the subject matter and purpose of the investigation, ap-<br>point the date on which it shall begin and State the penalties provided for in<br>Articles 14(l)(d) and 15(l)(b) and the right to have the decision reviewed by<br>the EFTA Court in accordance with Article 108(2) of the EEA Agreement<br>and with the relevant provisions of this Agreement, in particular Article 35.</p>
<p>4. The EFTA Surveillance Authority shall in good time and in writing in-<br>form the competent authority of the EFTA State within the territory of<br>which the investigation is to be carried out of its intention of taking a decision<br>pursuant to paragraph 3. It shall hear the competent authority before taking<br>its decision.</p>
<p>5. Officials of the competent authority of the EFTA State within the terri-<br>tory of which the investigation is to be carried out may, at the request of that<br>authority or of the EFTA Surveillance Authority, assist the officials of the<br>EFTA Surveillance Authority in carrying out their duties.</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:170</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>ESA/Court</p>
<p>Agreement</p>
<p>Protocol 4</p>
<p>261</p>
<p>6. Where an undertaking or association of undertakings opposes an investi-<br>gation ordered pursuant to this Article, the EFTA State concerned shall af-<br>ford the necessary assistance to the officials authorized by the EFTA Surveil-<br>lance Authority to enable them to carry out their investigation.
